Unlike most other sushi bars where the bar seating faces the raw seafood display case, you get a side angle view of the sushi chefs preparing sushi as well as the chefs preparing other dishes in the back. 

Kelp sushi joint has some great $3 appetizers deals including the crab rangoon, edamame, ginger salad gyoza, miso soup, and seaweed salad.  In addition, Kelp sushi joint also has a great all day $12.95 special for any 2 classic sushi rolls and 1 starter! 

For the appetizer we ended up getting the crab rangoon and it was quite flavorful and not too dry as many tend to be 10/10. For the main course, we ended up getting the  Rose Cave Deluxe Sushi Roll which consists of  Tuna, shrimp tempura, avocado, scallions, eel sauce, spicy mayo 9/10, the Florida Sushi Roll which consists of Tuna, salmon, avocado, cream cheese, and the Mexican which consists of Shrimp tempura, avocado 9/10. 

Kelp also offers Sushi burritos and bowls, which come made to order with your choice of 2 proteins, 4 vegetables, and 2 sauces including spicy mayo, jalapeno mayo, cilantro citrus aioli, teriyaki sauce, and eel sauce. Bowl options include salmon teriyaki, beef teriyaki, chicken teriyaki, tofu teriyaki, chicken donburi, beef donburi, salmon Poke, himachi Poke, Tuna Poke, sashimi, and nigiri. Kelp does not have a liquor license and only serves beer and sake, no mixed drinks. 

I look forward to coming back to try more appetizers, a poke bowl, more sushi rolls, or a burrito roll!

Very prominent sushi place for the purpose of small night snack. Unfortunately during pandemic, they still don't allow dine in. I would definitely like to do that. I like this sushi place because the restaurant is good for late night snack with sake or beer. 

The food is affordable and the takeout is busy. The walk in order take about 15 minutes to prepare. We wait at the car and they deliver to your car. I got the goyoza, spicy tuna, and unagi eel. The roll at medium size. The spicy tuna with good ahi. The flavors good. The goyoza also crispy. Great snack for the night. The unagi has enough eel sauce to sweet it up. 

Overall my experience for the take is great. I will like to visit them at night when they start the dine in again.

I felt like doing some food exploring today so I "dragged" a friend with me to Kelp for lunch. We had never been there before but had heard good things. And if you read my reviews you know that I love to try new places. 

We had no problems finding it. It is in a plaza on Bay to Bay. It is the same plaza that Feet First (running store), Pilot Bank, Massage Studio, Starbucks, Soleil Tanning, and Taco Fusion are all in. 

When we arrived we were able to park right up front. They have some spots reserved just for Kelp customers. We were also pretty happy to see the outdoor seating because it was a gorgeous day out. A couple actually had their puppy with them at their table outside :) Note that there is also indoor seating. It's a small place and I'm not sure how busy they get but between the indoor and outdoor seating, you should be good.

Their lunch options are great. For $12 you get 2 full rolls, a miso soup and a ginger salad. I went with that option. My friend got 2 rolls (see my pictures) and she really enjoyed them both. And their lunch, all the way until 4pm!

Service was very nice. Everyone was very friendly. They were attentive and the service was nice and fast.

Basically, I'll be back for more :)

We got takeout from here and placed an online order. It was easy to make the order, but no where to specify instructions or allergens. We had a little trouble finding the restaurant. its kind of nestled in the back of a small plaza. its a cute space with an outdoor area. We were able to pop in and pick up the food pretty much contactless. As for the food the beef Dan burri was great and would recommend it. The seaweed salad and ginger salad were a hard pass for me. The seaweed salad had a strange taste and the dressing for the ginger salad was kind of odd. It did not have a strong flavor, it didn't coat the lettuce at all. We ordered 2 sashimi platters, online it says 5 items come in it, however there was way more than 5 types of fish/seafood in ours. Some of the items were unidentifiable and the Krab (imitation crab) usually contains gluten so it would have been nice to be able to add a note to omit that item. Anyway, both my husband and I got sick after eating that food and we weren't sure if it was the sashimi platter or the seaweed salad. asomething just was "fishy" and we had what I would describe as food poisoning. We probably won't return because of this and the fact that there are so many sushi joints in Tampa, ones with really fresh fish. I am really only giving them 3 stars because the beef Dan burri with the fried egg was great.

This place is located in a busy shopping plaza with a Starbucks but the parking lot is pretty large. The restaurant itself is not too large so come early. They some happy hour food and drink specials. Overall the sushi here is average to slightly above average for its price. I think people come here for the convenience more than anything. Would not go out my way to come back here.

After being stuck in traffic for five hours, the last thing I wanted to do was drive to get dinner. Consequently I succumbed and did something out of character. I got on UberEats and started to search for places that could deliver to the hotel I was staying at.

Because of the fact that I was more exhausted than hungry, but I knew I had to eat, I ended up ordering what I consider light - SUSHI! To be specific, I ordered a Mexican roll and a ginger salad. You know, pretty standard fare for this type of place.

My food arrived pretty quickly. No complaints on that. Presentation was fine. I just wish they hadn't been so stingy with sauces and napkins. At any rate, had the ginger salad and found the sauce strong. Same issue with the wasabi. There's an expression that says "se le paso la mano," which figuratively means they went overboard (literally means "they passed the hand") and that's exactly how I felt about the flavor of the sauces there.

I'm not sure if maybe I ordered the wrong thing or what, but know I ate it, got ready for bed, and slept like a baby. Then, I completely forgot about this meal until now. It simply was unmemorable.

I've been once and was pretty disappointed with the sushi... It just wasn't that great, especially for the price.  The flavors were a little off... I'm not sure exactly how to describe it.  The place was completely empty. I only went because I had a coupon and prob won't be back.
Update - kelp has updated their menu a lot over the past year. I gave It another try and it is delicious! Love their sushi burrito, volcano roll and ramen options!

I finally got around to checking out this place again and boy am I glad I did! I was starving and exhausted after work and stopped in to have some sushi on my way home from work. I like how they open before five. I sat at the bar and was quickly and warmly greeted. I ordered a specialty sushi roll in the server informed me that a second one would only be three dollars. Both the rolls I had were absolutely delicious and I finished my entire plate. I'll be back.

Sushi was Not worth the price!! Few problems with this place during this visit:

1) overpriced everything
2) our rolls came out and looked like trash. I could have rolled the sushi better ..scratch that a 5 year old would have done better or cared more about what the sushi looked like
3) my spicy tuna cucumber roll had pieces of bacon in it, which was not listed on the menu ingredients. Horrible flavors together.. I love bacon but not with my spicy tuna and I can't imagine someone who can't eat meat would react.
4) my earth roll... Looks good on the menu and was the only roll that looked any thing like a specialty roll - tasted like trash. I love my rolls with volcano toppings and usually eat all the toppings... This time I left them on the plate. And not to mention $16 for that crap.

Not coming back.. If you want good sushi do yourself and wallet a favor and go to Soho or Zen sushi

Not bad sushi, especially since you can use ubereats for fast delivery in South Tampa. My order arrived in 20 minutes!

I tried the sushi burrito with salmon and hamachi. I didn't love the hamachi, should have stuck to salmon alone. The whole thing was difficult to eat without making a mess. I think I'd stick to a sushi bowl or poke bowl in the future. I also had a Mexican roll. It was well rolled and tasty.

I ordered takeout from their website and I'm so glad I did! I live about a mile from KELP and haven't tried it yet, but I'll definitely go back. Their website was easy to use and my food was ready when I got there, which is exactly when they said it would be ready. I took advantage of the 2 roll deal, which I strongly recommend if you plan on getting multiple fresh rolls and a starter. For $12.95 I chose the ginger salad, salmon avocado roll, and spicy tuna roll. I opted for brown rice on both rolls. The fish tasted fresh and all the veggies were perfect. I was feeling particularly fat today so I also ordered the veggie roll and chicken teriyaki bowl. Veggie roll was so good and the veggies were delightfully crispy. The teriyaki bowl was also very good and I loved all the veggies included in it. I ate so much and still have so much leftover!

Kelp Sushi Joint is a nice choice for casual sushi if you are in Palma Ceia. They have a small sushi counter as well as 2 or 4-top tables to choose from. They also have outside seating which is rather unique for a sushi restaurant. 

They have a great lunch special. $12 will get you 2 "classic rolls", miso soup and a ginger salad. There are about a dozen classic rolls to choose from. I went with spicy salmon and a Florida roll (tuna, salmon and avocado). The rolls were very tasty. The rice was cooked nicely, not too mushy which can really ruin your roll. I loved the spice in the salmon roll as I find many "spicy" rolls are actually lacking. This roll had a very pleasant kick! The miso was average but the ginger salad was above average. The dressing was very fresh. I actually took home leftovers from my lunch special! This is a great deal!

I also had the $4 sangria which was very good. It had fresh fruit and wasn't too sweet. 

The service was fast and friendly. My husband and I will definitely be back to satisfy our sushi cravings especially during the lunch hours.

I finally tried KELP sushi. This place has been on my hit list for quite a while now. I didn't feel like dining in, so I took advantage of their delivery service. It took about 49 minutes to arrive (I ordered 2 rolls on a Sunday evening). The delivery man was very nice, I believe his name was Patrick.  He thanked me for my service as well as for choosing Kelp sushi. I think highly of companies that acknowledge their costumers. *insert clap emoji here*. There was one slight mistake but after calling back to let them know the lemonade was not included, the manager told me they'd send me my drink and apologized. I'm obsessed with sushi and could easily eat it for breakfast, lunch, and dinner. There were ten pieces in each roll, each a decent size. I will say the spicy tuna roll had a unique, smoky flavor to it. If you like smoky flavor, try it. It wasn't my favorite spicy tuna roll, to be honest. But overall, my taste buds were satisfied. I look forward to trying other rolls in the future.  Enjoy! Xo

Kelp Sushi Joint was ok, but there are better sushi options in Tampa.

We were lured here because the restaurant offers BYOB (bring your own bottle) and they do not charge a corkage fee. Wine glasses and cork screws are provided by Kelp.

While I enjoyed the modern décor and appreciated the purse hooks underneath the tables for the ladies I just wasn't a fan of the menu. Most of the rolls were pretty simple (California, Spicy Tuna, Mexican). If I was a timid eater trying out sushi for the first time these rolls may have appealed to me, but in my opinion the rolls were boring. The rolls that were more intricate contained cooked fish, imitation "krab" or fried chicken. None of these ingredients appeal to me.

The sashimi and nigiri options are almost non-existent which raises a huge red flag. My husband could not believe there were no sashimi platters on the menu. When he asked the waitress if the chef could prepare one for us they agreed, but the platter he created only contained tuna, salmon, and rainbow trout. Not much of a variety!

While everything tasted fine, nothing "wowed" us. We will probably not return, but this is a good spot for people that like very simple or cooked sushi rolls.

So I feel slightly awkward saying that KELP has it going on - but it's true!

We opted for a Monday night sushi dinner because the usual COVID rotation needed a change up. My preferred food delivery service was clutch and made our selections a reality in about an hour. 

We noshed two specialty rolls and a smattering of 'classic' rolls. Everything was well portioned, well crafted and very high quality. The rice was perfectly cooked and each bite was downright umami!

Tempura shrimp? Crispy (not soggy). Tuna? Great texture. Avocado? Ripe and flavorful. The colors and textures were all very complimentary and we know we got a great value for the money.

KELP calls itself a sushi joint but that does not do it justice.

This small, tasteful dining spot has class and sass. The decor is subdued yet has a touch of swank and swagger to it.

Seating is limited but the outside area is really inviting when the weather cooperates.

But what really matters is that how the sushi rolls. Glad to say that the philosophy of make it fresh, find it locally, when possible, and let what's in season be part of the seasoning and flavor is part of what makes the already enjoyable sushi even more enjoyable.

There's even a premise and a promise of using sustainable seafood which is a stand to be celebrated. As Platinum members of the Florida Aquarium's Seafood Now program, KELP helps support responsibly harvested fish.

This sushi stand-out is a bit hard to find within a busy retail center that constantly has cars circling and searching for a place to park.

But find it, try it and you are sure to truly enjoy it.

To-Go order: quick and on time.

Crab Rangoon - $3 - solid price with a pretty solid backup. It's not all breading and the blend mix in doesn't taste like all cream cheese. So 4 crab Rangoon's for $3 that are pretty decent (especially in the little orange sauce they are always served with) - I'd call it a win.
I am trying to find the sushi roll that I ordered but I cannot for the life of me find the name. It was good and hit the spot for my sushi craving.
I'd give them another try.
solid service, plenty of parking, respectable seating area with leather couches and great doughnuts and coffee.

I can't wait until I finally become a senior, because then I can finally get 10% off the buffet at Szechaun Paramount. 

I like coming here for Chinese food, and I've been coming here, since I was a kid. It hasn't changed all that much, except that the buffet has increased in size significantly. It's huge, so there's lots of items to choose from. They have the usual Szechaun items, like ginger beef, spring rolls, deep fried shrimp, rice, noodles, beef & vegetables, and wonton soup. The food is pretty good. A lot of it is greasy, but not overly greasy. I would say the food is somewhat better here than the House of Quon. 

The restaurant is nice, but not overly fancy. You can come here dressed in jeans or whatever--it's very casual. I have ordered takeout from here too, and it's good. You get 10% off, if you pick it up and pay by cash or 5% off, if you pay by debit or credit (I always thought that was kind of unfair). Szechaun Paramount is just a great place to gorge on some decent Chinese food.

Delicious food. Great venue. Indoor/outdoor seating so you could choose if you wanted AC or lovely humid warmth. Accommodating to a vegetarian request. They made me their patty melt with local tomatoes.. it was awesome. They had some trivia going on which looked fun even though we didn't participate. Yelp says they are dog friendly also but we decided not to bring him.

I am overall a fan of Save a Lot grocery stores. It is not a store for all of your shopping. The produce & veggies are fresh & cheap. 
Canned products, pastas, cereal, juices, crackers....may not be name brand, but most are very good & fairly priced.
in the frozen food section, they may surprise you on some item & prices. Frozen fruit for example is great & so much cheaper than say Publix, by like 50%. So it may not be the name brand, read the ingredients & save yourself some money.
They do accept credit & debit cards. Remember to bring your own bags, not only for keeping it green, but they don't supply them, you have to buy them.
Give them a try, you won't be disappointed.
What's a girl to do? Fresh veggies & fruits, at affordable prices, I'm in.

We were looking to eat breakfast at an inexpensive place. We happened to walk by this Cosi and it worked out perfectly. We got to eat breakfast for all 3 of us for under $10 dollars. The food was delicious.
i don't have a whole lot of opinion on gay cosi. it's open late, which is nice. not cray about the coffee. not a lot of vegan options. but some comfy seats. it is what it is.

I'm sitting in your establishment right now because I'm in that awkward time prior to an engagement and I thought I could study here beforehand with your Internet.

What the hell. Why did you dim your lights. I already have glasses, you just want me to waste more money on eye complications don't you. Not only can I NOT find an outlet to plug my laptop in, but when I find it, it's right by the door so I am cold on top of having a cold. And this whole table service idea, really REALLY BAD idea.

I came for soup while I study. Your service was nice and your food was yummy. But why oh why did you just dim your lights and make me even more cranky :( You made me sad, Cosi, a very very sad Anjali :(

Came here to study. 

Internet: unstable
tables: unstable
service: inconsistent. the MANAGER forgot to make a drink order. If the MANAGER is blatantly forgetting to do things, i don't understand how the restaurant plans on functioning. 
tea: decent, but realized they are sitting in an semi-open canister on the counter the ENTIRE day.

My favorite stop on the way home for a super big ice coffee. Everything is fresh, the occasional brownie or blondie delish, and staff is always pleasant. Sign up for their frequent shopper card and get free stuff.

After the ballet went there for a quick bite, and ordered some pizza Margherita and a drink, and after seating down at a table and waiting for my order was told I had to take it out because they were closing

I hate the setup of this cosi... It's really confusing because you have to give your order at one end (not where the cash registers are) and then you have to walk around to the other side and repeat your order to whoever is at the cash register.. the setup is not systematic, it is jumbled and confusing and the employees don't really assist with directing traffic because they expect you to know the process (which i think is unreasonable considering no other cosi i've ever been to is set up in this manner)

In addition, I was 1 of 2 customers waiting on an order and i watched my hot beverage through to completion and it took FAR too long for me to be serviced. I'm usually relatively patient with this kind of stuff and I would have been in this situation had the employee making my drink 1. known what she was doing and 2. not had three different conversations with other employees in the meantime.

Disappointed and probably won't be returning to this location.

The food simply wasn't good. Ordered an chicken rice bowl and all I could think about was how I should have just gone to the chipotle across the street. My friend ordered a BBQ chicken pizza and it was decent in taste and could even feed two (small stomachs). 
There are way too many other solid food options in Philly to waste a meal here. If I come back, I'm gonna keep it simple and stick to coffee and a pastry.

This cosi is a good one! The lines can be out of control long around lunch time as everyone is grabbing lunch between classes, but the staff handles the rush well! The separate the ordering lines so that quicker orders are tackled pretty much immediately. If you just want soup head on up to the register! 

It can get pretty loud in the place during the day with students popping in and out so I wouldn't recommend for studying. Although it's a lot quieter in the evening when students have moved else where along campus and it's open decently late it you prefer a spot like that for studying. The upstairs seating is also always a good option as a lot of people forget about it. Otherwise this is a pretty standard cosi nothing to complain about. Oh and as with all my other reviews of cosi's throughout the land get the chicken TBM melt!

I generally hate Cosi - the bread is like hot cardboard - and the food is not my thing, but I stop in to this one every once in a while for iced coffee.  A good friend lives near this one so we'll meet here, grab some iced coffee and hang out with or without our kids in tow.

The restroom is abhorently filthy though.  Yick.

Just what, exactly, is going on here. It seems that I will never understand the Cosi clue! This location's low-level management is just awful and confused. I'm sure their intention is to IMPROVE, but obviously that ain't happening.

This location keep changing their in-store ordering setup. One day, you'll order here, go pay there, and come back here to pickup your food. Another day, you'll order and pay there, then go to the other side to pickup your order. Why you are trying to confuse us, Cosi?
 
Oh, you prefer to place your order online for pick up, make sure you got all your items, they have the tendency to miss either your bread or your coworker's bag of carrots, or perhaps they will forget the whole order. Re-think.

I believe that their management operation is just awful and confused. I try not to go, but it is around the corner from me, and it is one fast Ritalin food. Sometimes I cannot resist. 

I have another legit question, Cosi: Why most, if not all, of your employees are miserable and unhappy. 

One and half Yelps.

I've been here a few times for lunch, and every time I go, I've been impressed with the staff. They are the happiest bunch of employees I've ever seen at a Cosi, and they alone make it worth coming in for food. I got my salad in record time and chatted with my cashier about how hot it was. When I grabbed the salad, the man behind the counter gave me the biggest smile.

My only complaint is that the egg in my Cosi Club salad looked perfect, but something about it was off--almost sour. Otherwise, the salad was as good as any I've ever had from Cosi. Will definitely come back for lunch another day.

Cosi is the coolest place to hang out in Midtown Village. It's a trendy atmosphere, has gorgeous big windows, the staff is always so friendly, and it has a really nice refillable drink station. When you want to chill for a little while, and grab something to eat and drink while you read or mingle, this is the spot in Midtown.

This Schnucks gets no love for good reason.  It's horribly small where you can't even easily get butcher service.  Produce section is decent.  The deli is practically nonexistent.  
It really isn't worth coming here unless you just happen to be passing by and need something like a bag of doritos.

Brio's is Mom and I's go to lunch spot! It's right down the street from her work and is never disappointing. 

I have been here many times and have never went wrong with anything on their lunch menu. The bread is so good here (and I don't usually brag about free bread) and the crispy flat-bread chip things that come with the bread are also a yummy appetizer. I'm not usually a dessert person, but their creme brulee is irresistible! 

The prices are reasonable and the service is always top notch! They have a large bar area and outdoor seating. I always know I will have a great lunch at Brio's!

So I think Brio has the potential to be good, but i just happened to choose the wrong dish. I went not on my own accord but with my mentor who suggested we go there.  I read the description gargandelli carbonara pasta with wood fired chicken, bacon, and asparagus and I was like I know I'm going to LOVE this! The sauce had a weird taste so I couldn't really appreciate all the other delish items like the bacon and chicken. I would go back and try another dish but only if I was forced to, I'm not itching to go back anytime soon.

Today at Brio Tuscan Grille I felt lunch was just so-so.  We always come here before we go to the cinema at Plaza Frontenac and for some reason I just felt that Brio did not live up to my expectations.  

They have a large bar so of course we sat there.  There is  a selection on the menu that is 650 calories or less.  I did not choose from that.   I ordered the shrimp and crab cakes, and Majordomo order chicken under the brick.  We did not have to wait that long for our lunch to appear.  Both dishes were served with mixed vegetables and Major's came with mashed potatoes.  His chicken was tasty along with his sides.  My cakes were tasty also but I did not care for the vegetable medley.  There were also a few potato slices mixed in with the veggies.  Since everything was tasty, but nothing really blew me away like last time, I have to take away one star.

Would I come back here?  Yes, of course.  They have a very large menu.

This is the first time that I have been to Brio Tuscan Grille for dinner.  It was a beautiful night in October so we decided to eat on the patio.  We met some friends there, ordered drinks and looked over the menu.  No appetizers tonight because I wanted to have a full meal.

He started with a wedge salad.  It looked delicious and I was going to grab a bite but I decided it wasn't a good idea to put my hand where he could bite it.  Dinner consisted of the special ravioli for him (I think it was lobster) and the gorgonzola crusted beef medallions.  It came with roasted veggies, mashed potatoes and mushrooms in a marsala sauce.  We both agreed that our food was delicious.

Would I come back here?  Yes, it's a great place for dinner and lunch. I'll catch you on the flip side.

Back and better than ever. On my latest trip to St. Louis I came here not once, but twice. The first time was with a group for late-night wine and bites. The service was attentive but not overbearing, as we waited for other members of our party to arrive. The food came out quickly yet was not rushed or slapdash, even given the lateness of the hour. 

The second time was for an early happy hour after a movie and shopping at Plaza Frontenac. The drink selection (and prices) couldn't be beat and the appetizers were elevated small plates. The shrimp with eggplant was delicious and maybe even better than some main dish entrees that I've had. Definitely a must-go for anyone looking for a quality dining option in this area.

It's been quite a while since I was last at Brio, and not a lot has changed since the last time.

Brio's always had a nice location at the corner of the Plaza Frontenac parking lot overlooking Manchester Road, with a large outdoor patio for diners. The other week, the weather turned nice enough that we decided to try dining outside for a change and Brio sounded good.

What I always forget about Brio is that even at lunch time nothing is under $10 on the menu. At least they've started adding some healthier options to the menu in addition to the pastas, flatbreads, soups and entrees. And although the menu seems large, it's actually a bit sparse in options (and my mom asked for the gluten free menu and was given a list as small as the little special card - not very accommodating, in my opinion).

I ended up ordering a quinoa chicken salad, my mom had the strawberry fields salad with chicken and my dad got the lobster bisque and salad. Everything was fine, but I wasn't overly impressed, especially since everything was $12 or more. It just seems expensive for what it is.

Luckily, we went on a weekday, but on the weekend, trying to get in for lunch is nearly impossible without a reservation. Brio's is very popular even though it's just average as far as food goes. But I guess if you want to see and be seen in Frontenac, it's a safe bet.

Brio's in Frontenac is pretty good.  Their food's a little pricey, the inside's a bit pretentious (it is Frontenac / "Lah-due" after all), but the patio saves the day.

The restaurant evokes images of a palatial Tuscan villa (an oxymoron if ever there was one), but they've definitely toned down the Italian flavor for the American palate once you survey the menu.  When you enter they give you the option of dining in the wide, airy (unusually noisy) dining room that's partitioned off by chest high dividers creating various walkways, the bar area (it's a round island style bar), or if the weather's nice the patio.  Go for the patio, people, go for it!

The patio's much more laid back, quieter and infinitely more enjoyable than the main dining room, which gets a little more than chaotic when they get really busy.  Once seated a bread basket containing flatbreads and warm Sourdough bread will be delivered to the table before taking your order.  The menu is what you might expect for Americanized-Italian: bruschettas and flatbreads abound, classic chopped and Caesar salads are available (as well as some more exotic ones), and pastas, risottos, "chicken under a brick" and paninis are all readily available.  Heavy emphasis on the pasta combos.  And the portion sizes?  Ahem... generous, to say the least.

I usually opt to split a salad since half portions of anything are strictly verboten.  My first choice was a safe one: the Romano crusted chicken salad, then I graduated to the Tuscan harvest salad, the Tricolor and the strawberry balsamic chicken.  Of those salads, I generally favor the Tuscan one since it has all kinds of goodies packed into it: mushrooms, bacon, almonds, apples and cranberries in addition to the chicken.  The salads are good - but really, it takes a special restaurant to really screw up a salad, doesn't it?  And the prices for everything match the portions pretty well - on the larger side.

Brio's is certainly a good choice (especially if you've got people to impress or pickier eaters), but it's not at the top of my list of restaurants to frequent.

Ok. I found it shocking that this is a chain. Cause the food is truly special. Melt in your mouth goodness... the stuffed chicken breast, the wine, the steak quality, the creamy mash potatoes, the various dessert cups that give you a shot of heaven... and SO reasonably priced. ($2 a cup)  They have a zillion choices of creme brule', and rather large starter salads that are almost a meal in themselves.  We took our family here and were all around impressed. Only downfall was the slowness of service... we were definitely salivating before the food came, and ate WAY too much bread.

I had been wanting to try Brio, so I made reservations for Valentines Day.  I decided to do something different and eat at lunch time instead of the usual dinner.  We were seated right away at a little table for two.  We were told they had the tables set up like this for Valentine's Day.  My only problem with that is hubby was across from me instead of beside me.  No hand holding:(
Our server was a sweetie and took very good care of us.  The interior reminded me of the Cheesecake Factory.  Bread basket came quickly and loved the bread (I love bread) For our appetizer we had the steak bruschetta, it was good. I had chicken Marsala and was made with grilled chicken which is different for me and I loved it.  Hubby had the lasagna and said it was very good.  For dessert I had the Brios cheesecake and it was excellent! Sorry, I forgot to take a pic of dessert. It wasn't very romantic, due to the distance between us and people close by, but it was lunch so it was fine.  Over all, great lunch, great service.  We will definitely go back!
Happy Valentines Day!

I guess its all about definition. Just how you define the food you have on your menu, how you as the patron define your expectations. I've lived in Italy a fair amount, starting back in 1990 and at times for a few months at a time and usually in Florence so I've had a little experience with Tuscan food which by definition is simple, fresh and well made. Ok here's the deal, straight up before I get into particulars, this is a great place for people who have never been to Italy, have no idea what Tuscan food really is and are generally afraid to eat anywhere inside the 1-170 inner belt. Now for the particulars. I ordered a Beefsteak Florentine (I found it cute they used the Italian word for Beefsteak on the menu), I asked for it RARE, like I made a point of it (it was medium at best). What I got was delivered by the food runner as "here's your strip steak", I replied, no I ordered the Beefsteak Florentine and he disappeared only to return with the water who said "in the back they both come up as the same. My friends, a Strip Steak is NOT the same, Beefsteak Florentine is almost always a T bone, charred on the outside and very rare inside, often but not always served on a bed of arugula. It was also not rare by any way, but as my dinner  guests were into their meal, I did not send it back. Also the meat was served with mashed potatoes which I presume is for the West of I-170 clientele who prefer their food really worked over. My fellow companions ordered the lobster ravioli and shrimp which was very rich which is good but it was just too much. This place should just be more honest about their menu and say its Italian-American fusion for upscale people who like to shop at Sacks Fifth Ave and pay too much for everything(interestingly enough, this place is located in the parking lot of an upscale mall). The service was also not so great, we had to ask for more water for the table and the service in general could only be described as spotty. the bar service was also a bit disappointing, my wife Bellini was closer to an adult smoothie than a Bellini and the waiter seemed to not know what kind of gin the bar stocked.  All in all a disappointing meal that was over priced for what you got. On the plus side the Quattro Bruschetta was very good and I thought the only bright spot on the table.

I ate an early dinner at Brio on a Saturday evening.  I ordered the Pasta Alla Vodka (Ricotta-filled pasta, spicy tomato Parmesan cream sauce, crispy pancetta, basil.) My dinner date ordered the Tuscan Grilled Pork Chops with Mashed Potatoes on the side. The service was friendly and speedy. My water glass was kept filled and the bread here is always fresh and good. The pork chops were very well liked as was my pasta. The only thing I will say though is I felt the portion was extremely small for a $20 plate of pasta. They are always busy though. Clearly I'm in the minority. Be careful in that bar. A cougar might get you.

For a large chain, Brio serves up some great food. I've only been here once so far, but I enjoyed my meal. I went during Sunday brunch and found the large space fairly empty, which was good because I'd heard this place can have really long waits (maybe that's just for dinner?). The menu is quite extensive, and had a lot of options for vegetarians like myself. They had a brunch menu as well as a brunch special menu, so it was hard to choose what to order. I went with the tomato & mozzarella panini with homemade potato chips, and was not disappointed. My friend got a salad that she also enjoyed.

The issue I had with this place was the service. While it wasn't BAD, it was a little lackluster. When we ordered drinks, we ordered waters as well, but the waters didn't come. I flagged the waitress down during our meal and asked if we could have some water. She returned with one glass of water, so my friend had to ask for a glass too. It was just odd, because it appeared that all the other diners around us had received water when they were seated. Other than the water situation, service was ok. 

I noticed that Brio had a patio off to the side that has a bocce court! I would return just to go try that out. I also liked the airy atmosphere of the place, with super high ceilings. Will go back next time I am in town.

This restaurant is absolutely beautiful.  It is large inside, has a big bar and a beautiful patio.  Today was lunch before the movie.  Mike selected the Brio Sliced Steak Salad and I chose the Pasta Alla Vodka.  

Both our meals were outstanding.  His salad was large enough to fill you up and had a nice portion of steak on it.  It also had mushrooms, pecans and just enough creamy horseradish along with the balsamic glaze dressing to make it one of the best salads he has had recently.  Mine was pasta filled with ricotta, a tomato parmesan sauce (just a hint of spiciness) with pancetta.  It was like eating little clouds of cheese.  This was the best pasta dish I have had in a long time.  

We would definitely go back there and hope to try it for dinner one night.

We picked this place for an early dinner based on the number of 5-star reviews from friends.  Definitely a good choice!

Funny thing is that Aimee K wrote about how it is a heavy meal unless you have a salad and a flat bread.  What's funny about this is that I didn't read her review until after I had ordered and usually like a heavy meal...but had ordered a salad and a flatbread.  

The wedge salad was fantastic!  Beautifully crisp lettuce, generous amounts of Gorgonzola, perfectly ripe tomatoes and a creamy dressing that really pulled it all together.  The waiter and the kitchen both accommodated my request to go easy on the pepperoni for the pepperoni, sausage and ricotta flatbread.  I really enjoyed the spiciness of the sausage where pieces of fennel were evident (my favorite aspect of Chicago-style Italian sausage) and not quite enough ricotta.  Very crispy crust and an all-around great flatbread.

The wife had something loaded with horrible mushrooms that she thoroughly enjoyed and I didn't try.   

She opted for the bread pudding for dessert and I managed to pinch exactly two bites.  Really delicious and I enjoyed the addition of butterscotch to the dish.  It just seemed to add another layer of flavor.

We will have to go there again when I am up for a heavy meal.  I had my eye on the lobster and shrimp fettucini and the center-cut pork chops...
If you've never been for happy hour, you need to go.  You just might see me there.  Lol!

Celebrated my birthday with my family @ Brio this weekend. Service, I'd give 3/5 stars and food 3/5. 

Service: Service here is almost always perfect- quick, friendly, knowledgeable and more than willing to accommodate any needs. Last night they were a little off as our server was busy accommodating a large party of ~15. We had finished our appetizer and still had not ordered our entree. In fact, we waited a good 20 mins for him to return to take our order. I think we went through 2 or 3 bread baskets while we waited...

Food: Beef Carpaccio- Excellent! Out of all the appetizers, this is probably my favorite. Fresh beef and greens and I love the capers in this dish. It gives a nice tangy kick.

Lobster Bisque- Was a bit too rich (too much cream) for my liking. However, I did appreciate the amount of lobster in the bisque.

Tomato Bisque- One word. Delicious!

Roasted Lamb Chops- Beautiful presentation and more food than your stomach knows what to do with it. Although a little on the salty end, the lamb chops were grilled well. The wine veal sauce complimented the meat perfectly.

Sweet Potato & Chicken Risotto- Again, a little on the salty end, but the risotto was creamy on the tongue and chicken fell apart in your mouth. 

Father ordered a 5oz filet cooked medium well and when received, was clearly overcooked. He complained that the meat was too tough to enjoy but didn't want to complain to the server as the server seemed to be overwhelmed with the large party of ~15. 

I've been here enough times to know what to expect and what to order. I love the atmosphere of the restaurant and the decor, however the price point is a little high . A nice place for lunch and dinner. Highly recommend the beef carpaccio & seared shrimp risotto.

We stopped by for Happy Hour on a Monday night.  I was suprised that the bar wasn't packed like the other nearby restaurants that offer a happy hour.  Their bar is large with plenty of seating.  

Service was good.  The happy hour menu consisted of a handful of small plates as well as a listing of drinks.  We tried the burger, tots, shrimp, and spinach dip.  The tots were good.  Everything else was just ok.

I had a date and he suggested Brio. We wanted to sit outside for dinner and we both wanted wine. Goal achieved. It was alittle bit of a wait for a table, so we grabbed a nice glass of wine at the bar. Our bartender Bailey, was very knowledge and quick to serve us. I had the Moscato he had the Red Zinfandel, both excellent choices, because we had more than one glass each. 

Once we were seated on the patio, our server Seth was quick to greet us with water and menus. The menu was not overwhelming, I had the chicken with faro, and vegetables. He had the shrimp with faro and vegetables. They looked like the same dish when they arrived, and sadly Seth was not sure what faro was. For those of you that don't know, it is similar to rice. Dinner took a little longer than we thought it should, but we did have the wine and nice conversation. 

Next was desert, they had 5 options to pick from. We both selected the crème brulee, it was just the perfect ending to the meal.

This is a great restaurant with fresh ingredients and amazing food!
On Monday January  9 , 2017 Angie was an excellent server with a pleasant smile while being very friendly.

Angie was very accommodating by providing me with my infused  cumber water .
The staff highlight today was the exceptionally pleasant Host who seated us and my server Angie.

Lets get to the food. I had the salmon Fresca with a mimosa, both of which were good.

Wow we had an incredible great luncheon for  the first of the year 2017 with many more to come!
You own it to yourself to have lunch here it always yummy!

One of my favorite dish is Salmon Fresca!


Gloria~


My experience today was amazing! November 16,2016 time 2:58pm 
The General Manager Vin Lambrecht  was very accommodating with excellent service from him and the staff!

Thank you Vin  for being so amazing! 

Gloria~

I met a girlfriend for dinner. I arrived first, and was seated right away. Paul C. was our server.

I had a card for a free appetizer, but it had expired. I asked if they would still honor it. Paul said yes. Good show!

We got beef carpaccio. It was paper-thin sliced meat with capers and mustard aioli. Complemented by nicely dressed field greens. This is an appetizer to share. It was absolutely delicious. My dining partner had never had carpaccio, and she loved it.

We both opted for one of their specials: a 5-ounce fillet with a crab and lobster cake for $26. It came with garlic mashed potatoes, mixed vegetables (broccoli, carrot, red pepper strips and zucchini) and that wonderful parmesan-encrusted tomato that comes with many Brio dishes.

This was a plateful of food. And it was all fabulous. The steak was cooked perfectly (rare to medium-rare). The crab and lobster cake was rich, contained very little filler and sat in a tasty sauce of some type. The potatoes were well-peppered, so they didn't just look like a lump of white on the plate. The vegetables were well-seasoned. And I just love that tomato with its crispy outside and perfectly intact tomato.

The breadbasket at Brio is always inviting with the seeded flatbread triangles and sourdough bread, along with a plate of butter.

Paul was outstanding with his check-ins to ensure all was going well. Waters were refilled any time they got to half-full. And he brought over the dessert offerings. We had to decline.

I had hefty to-go vessels, including the remaining carpaccio, the bread and butter, and half of my meal.

This was stellar from beginning to end.

What can I say. I came in to town to entertain and visit with a colleague and friend, his wife and new baby. I called ahead to be sure it was kid friendly and reserved a table. This couple doesn't get out to higher end Italian restaurants since they are newly weds and poor ( weren't most of us!) . They had the table, a swing for the baby. perfect setting. Quiet atmosphere, great waiter, started with bruchetta selection- excellent, some Penfolds Shiraz, ( one of my fav), and between us had crab cakes, lamb chops to die for, and lasagna, and my guests even had the shooter deserts. Fantastic !!! Great choice as I was at the Hilton around the corner and my second time there in 3 years when visiting St Louis. Night life on Friday and Saturdays is upbeat classy, over 25, and the bar is well stocked and some place I like to hang when in. Come hungry, bread mixture is great start, good martini's and wine- what can I say. Love it.

For being near suburban St. Louis, the food isn't all that bad here. I like the steaks a lot in fact.
The wait is usually out the door on weekends, so call ahead (not sure if they take reservations or not).  
The bartender when I was there made a mean mojito...but we didn't stay too long at the bar. Not really my scene. 

Also, please, let's not kid ourselves that this is a "Tuscan Grille". Most things on the menu don't resemble anything I actually ate in Tuscany.

Sweet cucumber basil gimlet, I'm in love!  Best drink I've had in a long time.

Wedge salad was generous and well dressed, with lots of cheese and tomatoes.

For dinner I ordered the mushroom ravioli...homemade pasta with mushroom filling and more mushrooms in a creamy sauce.  I'm in mushroom heaven.  I love mushrooms, but I am the only one in the family who does so I don't cook with them at home.  As a result, I try to order them often in restaurants that seem to be able to do them justice.  Brio did not disappoint.

Dessert was a bread pudding with butterscotch sauce.  This was like no other bread pudding - it was thinner, no raisins (a good thing), and served with butterscotch rather than bourbon.  I rather enjoyed the departure from tradition.  It was thin enough that it didn't have that mushy pudding-like texture in the middle, and you could really taste the rum in the sauce.  

Service was the well-oiled machine that one would expect in a top-notch place such as this.  Overall experience made for a great date night!

This is a great restaurant with fresh food.
On November 7th, on my Birthday our waiter Jordan was not very friendly or attentive and had a nonchalant attitude.  We had asked for extra napkins and never got them. 

We have visited this same restaurant many times before and never had a bad waiter or any server like Jordan was today.   
The staff highlight today was the exceptionally pleasant Host who seated us. ( he was very nice)

Lets get to the food. I had the salmon Fresca with a mimosa, both of which were good.

This visit the food gets the Five Star while the service gets a Three.  

Gloria~


My experience today was amazing! November 16,2016 time 2:58pm 
The General Manager Vin Lambrecht  was very accommodating with excellent service from him and the staff!

Thank you Vin  for being so amazing! 

Gloria~
This place is always loud at dinner.  You can barely hear someone across from you.  Has a perpetually crowded bar.  Food is chain-like but not bad.

I've eaten here half a dozen times. Most of the time at the bar. Service always good. Food great although some items overpriced. The pesto pasta dish is one of my favorites . I can't believe it's a light (600 cal) menu item. It's more than enough for two meals .

We always come here whenever we plan to go to the movies at Plaza Frontenac.  They have a large bar to sit at and that's where we plopped our butts down for lunch.  This is the first time I noticed  that they have "lunch plates" on their menu.  Two courses with different options and different pricing.

We both decided to have the soup and the mezza pasta brio for $14.50 a piece.  He went with the lobster bisque and I tried one of the specials, minestrone soup.  His bisque was outstanding as usual.  I was a little underwhelmed by the minestrone soup.  It tasted more like a vegetable soup and there were no little noodles in it.  The mezza pasta brio was very good.  Pasta, chicken in a red pepper sauce.  It was just the right portion for lunch.  No time for a dessert, we have to get to the movies. 

Would I come back here?  Yes, I'll see you on the flip side.

This is a great restaurant with fresh food.
On November 7th, on my Birthday our waiter Jordan was not very friendly or attentive and had a nonchalant attitude.  We had asked for extra napkins and never got them. We ask for warm bread with butter, we received after our meal. He was engaged in conversation with the bartender. 

We have visited this same restaurant many times before and never had a bad waiter or any server like Jordan was today.   
The staff highlight today was the exceptionally pleasant Host who seated us. ( he was very nice)

Lets get to the food. I had the salmon Fresca with a mimosa, both of which were good.

This visit the food gets the Five Star while the service gets a Three.  

Gloria~

We had a Sunday lunch here and it was ok, nothing great.  Maybe I'm spoiled since I live in Chicagoland, where there are plenty of fabulous restaurants.

We were celebrating an upcoming wedding and they seated us at a round table with a nearby spot to place the gifts on.  That table was almost an afterthought, crammed in the corner, just like us.

The service was ok, but she could have really done more with recommendations and just doing things like taking about plates and glasses faster.  We had a drink spill while the bride to be was trying to open a gift.  There just wasn't enough room.

I had a hard time ordering because they use lots of sauces and I have a dairy allergy.  Yes, it's a pasta place, so you have sauce there, but many of the breakfast entrees are saucy as well.  I ordered a salad which was fine.  The other people in my party ordered breakfast and lunch items.  I didn't hear any raves about it.

Overall I was a bit disappointed here.  My sister picked it out, so it wasn't my choice, but given that it was in the Plaza Frontenac area, I just expected more.

I'm giving Brio 4 stars only because as a corporate-owned restaurant, they do have certain standards they have to meet 24/7.  I wouldn't go here if I wanted a cozy Friday night.  Granted, the food (Italian, big menu, not quite the scale of Cheesecake's but very adequate) is tastey and if you have any complaints a manager will be at your table in two seconds. Steaks, pork chops, pastas, pizzas... The bar seems to attract the 30 and 40-somethings.  I'd recommend reservations on the weekends.  Good for family events or if you're in the mood for a huge Italian feast, bellini and everything.

I have enjoyed Brio more than most chains that I visit. The environment is nice, nice enough for a first date without being too pretentious. I've only been there a handful of times, including for brunch and lunch, and always get good service. I like the patio area too. For being right on a major intersection, it isn't as loud or unpleasant as you'd think.

I always order a salad and the pasta del diavolo, which is a spicy penne type pasta with cheese on top. It's yummy!

I love this place, the food is good and the drinks are even better. I never make it beyond the bar area.  I always end up eating at the bar so I can not speak of the table service. 

I hate to make this call out, but anyone who goes here for Happy Hour or anytime for that matter knows it is a true "meat market" and it does not matter which team you play for. So this makes for a very fun and festive night.

April 4, Miss C. and I met for lunch. She ate from the fabulous and generous breadbasket. I looked at it.

Food selection was rather tough, as there were so many tantalizing dishes.

Sarah was our server, and she was quite friendly and at-the-ready with water refills.

Miss C. got penne a la vodka and added grilled chicken ($21.45).

I got a grilled steak salad (medium rare) ($15.95), which included mixed greens, tomatoes, Gorgonzola, crimini mushrooms and spicy pecans with balsamic dressing. There was also a creamy horseradish served on the side, which was a lovely addition.

We both liked our dishes heartily, and both took a lot home. My take-home lasted two more meals.

Went with the wife and dear friends to Brio.  The outside drink area was just jumping with energy and people having a happy happy hour or two. 


 We had a fine waiter Brian who was outstanding.  You come here and want to try different things and I thought what the  heck I will go to Brio's and have steak.  Somehow this made total sense to me at the time.  Don't know why I got it after looking at the the pasta dishes that were well priced.

For starters I had the minestrone soup.  It was vegetable soup no meat.  Boy it was nice.  Really enjoyed it.  I don't know if you know this or not but when you turn 60 there is a rule that you must order soup with your meal.  Just letting you all know.

The strip steak was served with gorgonzola cheese on top.  Brian the server asked me to cut the steak to make sure it was cooked to my liking.  I being an obtuse old man said nah it will be fine.  And it was.  The biggest surprise I had with my steak was the grilled vegetables.  Oh my! had the grill flavor and a touch of garlic.  

No room for desert but did get a nice show from Brian on all the options.  Did a nice job but too full to partake.

Dinner tonight. We meant to meet at the bar and have dinner there. But the bar was PACKED at 5:30 p.m. And the lights were so dim I could hardly scan the bar guests to see if my dining partner was there. Finally decided not, and went to sit at the bench in front for arrival. Felt like a refugee . . . not one of the hostess persons said anything to me.

When my dining partner arrived, we decided to take a table, since the restaurant was barely inhabited.

We shared calamari appetizer. It was fine, but there were some huge pieces of intact tentacles in it. Is that normal? Never seen that before. I actually had to spit one huge mass of chunky tentacles into my napkin. I was going to choke on the dang thing. Not a pretty way to take it to infinity and beyond!

We both had the biestecca insalata . . . a wedge ($6). It's always divine, and it's really a meal in itself. Dining partner got a flatbread ($13), of which ate one piece. I got chicken milanese ($21). I totally misread the description. The chicken was breaded (which I hate), and it was sitting on a bed of spaghetti (which I hate). I had one bite, and took the rest home. Somebody will eat it.

During dinner, a bug came crawling across the table on my side. I just watched incredulous of this happening. It took a turn on the white tablecloth towards my dining partner's salad. She swatted at it. It kept going. Disappeared somewhere.

It's amazing two women at a table with a bug didn't jump up screaming and make a scene. Brio should have been grateful to us for that. We informed our server Brad of the event. Some manager came over and apologized. Gave each of us a card for a free appetizer upon next visit . . . NEXT VISIT!!!!!

A great lunch at Brio Tuscan Grille before going to the movies.  Brio's is in Plaza Frontenac.  A nice size restaurant that we have eaten at several times but only for lunch.  We sat outside on a beautiful September afternoon.  My last review is dated from January but we have been here recently and I did not review it because of the service.  Sometimes a place can be a little bit off.  The most exciting thing for me - they have a new lunch menu.  Our service was good.  We really didn't have to wait to long for anything.

The sliced steak bruschetta called my name and he chose the pick two.  A wedge salad with half a sandwich.  My steak bruschetta had charred tomatoes, gorgonzola cheese and arugula on it.  It was very good and had a little of a sweet flavor to it.  His wedge salad was wonderful - I stole a few bites.  His half sandwich was a prosciutto and burrata sandwich on ciabatta bread.  I didn't get a bite but he said it was very good.

Would I come back here.  Oh yes, there are several other items on the menu we would like to try.

I have never heard of an Italian restaurant that doesn't have  plain fettuccine on the menu. From my remembrance of the menu, most of the items on the menu by default were swimming in pork or other meat. However, the waiter did say they could make plain 

Ok.... the good and bad, this is definitely a place you go for the ambience and not to be full. While the fettucine was some good stuff, I was still hungry and for over $15 it's a place I probably wouldn't go back to.

 I will say; the décor of the place is nice, the staff was pleasant and my family had a good time for my uncle's birthday.

A great place to lunch in St. Louis! 

Extensive menu allows for a variety of tastes. I love the crackers and butter they serve. I also love their bisque and career salad. It's perfect! 

They do fish well, and that can be hard to find in st l but perhaps the most amazing, outlandish thing they do is their carpaccio! I posted a photo because it is simply unreal. 

Everything's good and it's right by the best mall in StL so a great stop for a quick lunch on the patio or for a whole day of shopping!

I've eaten at Brio many times . . . mostly for lunch. Always had impeccable service: attentive, but not overbearing. Had beef carpaccio that was fabulous, salmon salad that was delicious (with leftovers), steak (don't know what it's called) with a wedge salad (iceberg, bacon, bleu cheese dressing) that was over-the-top tasting and after I ate the wedge, could just taste the steak (and it lasted for two other meals).

Which speaks to economy. I don't necessarily want mongo portions, but if that what is served, I accommodate. And usually I can make something last two more meals. Generally, that gets ridiculous economy for my pocketbook.

To address the noise issue numerous reviewers have mentioned. I don't know for noise. There have never been problems hearing fellow diners. And we've never been cascaded by other diners' conversations.

Tonight I went for dinner, Thursday. No reservation. Seated immediately. Rightly pleasant hostesses -- three at the podium. Ate with two others. We did not get appetizers. Two were drinking alcohol lightly. Service was -- again -- impeccable.

#1 got the penne mediterranean (and got a doggy bag for the leftovers). It looked delicious, and she said it was.

#2 got mushroom ravioli. It looked delicious, and she said it was.

I got the whole roasted chicken ($18). It came with roasted vegetables and crispy potatoes. I opted for a replacement for the starch and was readily accommodated with spinach ( there were many other non-starch options). This bird comes to your table whole with a knife stuck in the backbone, daring you to cut into it. I complied. It was succulent, delicious with crispy skin and juicy. The roasted vegetables were haricot verts, sweet potatoe planks and onions . . . beautiful and tasty. The spinach was baby spinach (I thought it would be like that frozen stuff.) with a hint of garlic and no soupy sauce.

The meal was incredible. And they packed it beautifully for me to take home, as it was served on a dang platter, and I couldn't have eaten all of it if I'd been an NFL linebacker.

Now, to the bread. The crispy (I guess it's called flatbread.) wafers with all the seeds are wonderful. The other bread served is toothsome and yeasty tasting. You ask for more of bread or butter . . . you get it.

Then dessert. The three of us shared a chocolate lava cake (not really sure what it was named) that was a single-serving round little chocolate-frosted cake topped with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and drizzled with chocolate sauce. The serving bowl edges were sprinkled with cocoa, and three beautiful raspberries were strategically positioned around the cake. I am totally not a dessert-eater. This cake was scrumptious. And sharing it with two others took off a little of the decadent splurge.

On a postnote, one of the specials that especially taunted me was an herb-encrusted salmon.

Yes, yes, and more yes. I love dinners at Brio... they are few and far between because a) I'm rarely in the area, and b) they are heavy, heavy meals (salads and flatbreads not included.) But if I'm going to go to an Italian restaurant, I'm going to get pasta. 

My favorite thing to order at Brio is the mushroom ravioli... I am not sure I can really describe just how good it is. The soft ravioli are filled with a blend of mushrooms and cheese, and the whole thing is covered with cream sauce and cheese, and baked until it's boiling hot and brought to your table. It's seriously heaven on a plate, and it's my favorite meal when I want something hearty and satisfying.

Brio is fun because you can have dinner AFTER you sit at the bar and enjoy a signature martini! The patio is really beautiful and it's fun to sit outside if the weather is cooperating. The staff is always on top of it and very friendly, and they just don't take any shortcuts at Brio. Yeah, it's a chain, but I never say no when someone wants to grab a meal here.

Yeah, I went back. We'll call this BAB (Brio After Bug). Ironically, we got the same table. I guess it's ours now!

I had my card for the free appetizer, so we selected beef carpaccio ($12.95, but FREE for us!) It was luciously tasting so thinly sliced meat with capers and a mustard aioli -- field greens in the middle (a beautiful presentation) on a HUGE platter!!

With that kind of an app, we both forewent salad and went directly to the entree . . . both selecting the chicken under the brick ($19.25), beautifully cooked chicken in a Marsala wine sauce with mashed potatoes and roasted vegetables. I opted to sub out of the mashed potatoes and got two portions of roasted vegetables. They were really roasted and that brought out such sweet vegetable flavor of the carrots, broccoli, red pepper -- and I can't remember the other vegetables.

Our server Derek was fabulous, and quickly got the flow of our dinner . . . slow, slow, slow, and it lasted 4 hours. I've never had a four-hour meal in a restaurant.

We had lovely to-go vessels.

OK, Brio, you've won me back, but no 5 stars . . . I still remember the bug!

I dined here over a year ago for a Sunday brunch/early lunch (seated in the dining room). The service was top-notch and the dishes were simple, yet tasty. It was with that experience in mind that I came here earlier this week for a light dinner and libation before attending an author reading at the St. Louis County Library across the street. I'm happy to report that Brio's standards had not slipped between my visits. The list of wines by the glass is accessible and by no means overwhelming. The house red Cab that I ordered was the perfect pour to complement my dinner selections--tomato florentine soup and extra-thin crust margherita pizza. Portions are reasonable and not gut-busting, with price points to match. 

Service in the main dining area was very prompt, without feeling rushed. We initially wanted to sit at the bar but were deterred by the SRO setup--our server later mentioned that Brio runs a martini special on Wednesday, which likely accounted for the press of people at the bar. Even with the new restaurants (BrickTops and St. Louis Bread Co) that have come up around Frontenac, I'm confident that Brio's consistently solid service and quality will ensure the continued viability of this spot.

Ladies room was horrendous; as if an employee has arrived & got ready for work in the restroom. The hanger still in the Accessible stall. Paper towels all over the place & stall out of tissue. I'm perplexed because it wasn't the end of a super busy night it was 3pm. 

Service was horrific. Cody was so engaged with another table he totally failed to connect with ours. We were 1 of his 2 tables and it took him 20 minutes and a reminder to bring my dining companion a straw. I ordered black bean soup quick arrived with sour cream (not indicated on menu). I advised Cody I did not want dairy and he stated the soup itself also has cream in it. OK scratch that...I asked about several other items to no avail. All the while he never made any suggestions.

My friend ordered soup, finished it and we sat a while before he even came back to check if I had decided, if I needed help, if he could speak with the chef to possibly accommodate my diet but noooooooooooo... None of that happened. I'd been to Brio many times over the years and bread was always served with vinegar & oil. For some reason none was brought out today, I payed particular attention because I was sitting blank faced as my friend consumed her soup. Something was missing!

Fast forward I expressed my concerns with Cody, requested bread & ordered the Insalata Della Casa salad sans cheese. The arugula, fresh greens & tomatoes seemed appealing. Cody stated bread is only brought after soup & salad. LIES! Thete is no better time to bring the bread sir. 

Salad arrived....dry, sad, dead. Lacking all life & greenery. It was a bag of iceberg junk salad mix with carrots & radiccio. 1 sprig of friseé & 2 buried arugula leaves. 

I couldn't take it anymore. I called Cody over, expressed my final words of disappointment & asked that he'd bring  the check. He apologized, returned with a salad to go & advised not to worry about the check. 

Other red flags included a cook wearing gloves wipe his forehead and drinking a beverage on the line. I observed a manager engaging with the staff so I opted not to alert him about what was obvious. Not even the hostess was welcoming; no hello, no smile, no thank you. This was a pathetic dining experience. 

I simply will not return to Brio. 

~Christy

After seeing a very good performance at the Rep, the D's and T's made it back to Brio for dinner with a bottle of a very good 2000 Toscano Alte d'Altesi.  It is worth noting that Brio does not charge corkage for the first bottle.  The glasses were acceptable.  Our server does need a little work on his cork removal skills.  This is not the first that we have had recently who broke the cork when the cork was in good condition.  They need to learn to be gentle with them until they start to move.

Ms T and Ms D had a Tomato Caprese salad that they both liked although the tomatoes were clearly showing that they were out of season and they were stingy with the balsamic.  The portion was very good and they were not stingy with the fresh mozzarella.  Mr D had the Tomato Bisque and I had the Lobster Bisque.  Both were very good.  The lobster version was well flavored and rich, with bits of lobster meat.  I felt it may have been a little over thickened with a roux or another starch, giving it a bit of a slimy texture, but it was not a serious issue.

Ms D ordered Veal Marsala and , Mr D had Veal Milanese.  Both were well presented and received solid reviews.  The marsala version was a classic style with mushrooms and Fettuccine Alfredo on the side. The Veal Milanese was topped with cherry tomatoes and white wine caper sauce and had roasted potatoes on the side. 

Ms T chose the Lobster and Shrimp Fettuccine and I was able to snag a spool of the pasta and can say that it was very nicely sauced.  The sauce was billed as "spicy lobster" and it was nice to feel a little heat from what was probably cayenne.  There were flakes of crushed red chile apparent in the dish.  The pasta was properly cooked, there was plenty of seafood and the right amount of sauce.  By that I mean it was not drowned.  Half of this came home with us.

I agonized over the beef, chicken and veal dishes and then veered off course and chose lasagna Bolognese.  I love lasagna and this is as good as I have had in a restaurant.  The flavors were elegant and well developed.  Everything was balanced.  In particular it was not covered with an inch of Bechamel, even better, there was none!  The texture was tender, there was plenty of very finely ground veal in the meat sauce plus sauce Alfredo and mozzarella.  I enjoyed a taste of fennel seed in the meat sauce.  The whole thing went very well with the wine.  It was a huge serving and I also brought more than half home.  

I was not sure what to expect from Brio, given that it is part of a giant chain, but we had a very good experience.  Many people complain about the prices, but I did not find it to be out of line.  Four dinners with soup or salad, wine corkage, coffee and ample servings for about $32 per person is not overpriced.  Also consider that Ms T and I made four nice meals from this.  The only negative aside from the missing corkage skills, was that the place is very noisy.  So while I prefer to go to the one-off places, I could certainly see us going back based on this experience.

First things first,  Brio is a beautiful restaurant with it's nice marble accents,  draped fabric,  and large floral arrangements. It is spacious, lavish, and has a nice patio.  Their entrees are decent but they have an awesome happy hour! Anytime i can get a good buzz and get full for under $20, it's a win! They have large, tasty appetizers and cocktails apart of the happy hour that start at $4. The burger is good, flatbreads, and shrimp are good.  Remember, it's only available in the bar area and patio. Some of the dishes are kind of salty but they still taste great.

We always eat lunch at Brio Tuscan Grille whenever we go to one of the artsy-fartsy movies at Plaza Frontenac.  Today it was really crowded but the service has always been spot on.  We were able to grab the last two seats at the bar (just tea please) and looked over the menu. They have many lunch specials such as pasta and salads, etc. 

He decided on the Brio sliced steak salad. I decided to go with the sliced steak bruschetta. His salad looked delicious and he said that it was. He scraped the plate clean. My bruschetta was also very good with pieces of steak and cheese and balsamic vinegar. It was very good and came out as six large pieces which would be easily shareable with two people. 

Would I come back here?  Yes, the next time I go to the movies I will. I'll see you in the funny pages.

NO CORKAGE FEE MOTHAFUCKAS!

Srsly. One bottle of wine per table, though. So when you're finished with your first bottle, relocate to a different table, bwhahaha! The look on our waiter's face was fukkin priceless when he uncorked my bottle of wine and was going to pour some for Sean and I said "no, he doesn't drink." LOL. "So this entire bottle is...for you?" Yep. I'm an alcoholic, woo.

I really enjoy their chicken milanese pomodoro but FUCK when did it get so expensive? I could have sworn this dish used to cost somewhere around the ballpark of $15, not $20...? Maybe I am thinking of the lunch menu. Also I could have sworn they had lobster ravioli here, but maybe not? I guess maybe I am getting them confused with Bravo...it is the same restaurant, right? Or at least same parent company... I still have no idea what the difference between the two is. ?? 

Anyway, Sean branched out when we last came here and ordered porkchops or something like that... he was "amazed" that the carrots here were "palatable" as he generally hates carrots. I think a miracle must have occurred that night. Had to do a double take at the night sky after we were leaving to see if there was a magical shooting miracle star in the sky or some crap. Once he decides he doesn't like a specific type of food, good luck getting him to eat it ever again. So yeah, thank you Brio, for keeping my picky eater open-minded and for not charging me extra money for my alcoholism problem. A++++ would return again (but with a coupon for the food.)

Brio is a popular restaurant near Plaza Frontenac that seems to be popular for happy hour. We came here on a Tuesday after shopping with our baby for dinner. The restaurant is really loud with a lot of people standing around the bar. Our waitress put in an order of butter noodles for the baby right when we sat down which was nice. The bread they have an an appetizer is delicious of course I could eat carbs all day. I got the shrimp and lobster pasta which was underwhelming and lacking flavor. For a chain restaurant I think it's a nice option when you're shopping if you're not expecting something spectacular.

I celebrated my birthday here...their accommodation for a party of 12 was top notch.  The order came out timely and everything was great.  Starter : Lobster and Crab Bisque...mmmmmm!  I will have this with each meal going forward.  The temperature of the soup was just right and the flavor outstanding.  My Meal: Crab and Shrimp Cakes with crispy potatoes and veggies.  I ordered the "2" vs "3" and the portion was just right because I had the soup and dessert.  If your really hungry, get the "3".  Everyone in my party loved their meal.  I tried a little bit of my friend's lasagna and OMG...I must have that the next time I visit.  I was a little jealous that I didn't order that.  Love Brio!

After a long, gray winter, I especially appreciated the large, well lit dining room. I had a lunch reservation for a group of six. We were seated as we arrived, rather than waiting for the full party to be present. Loved the fact that the gluten-free menu was laid on top of the regular menu, I didn't have to ask for it. Service by Ian P. was flawless. I enjoyed the Chicken Limone, great lemon and capers flavor. The potatoes were very good, and roasted vegetables just perfect. Everyone at the table enjoyed his or her plate. Excellent service, lunch menu, and dining space.

Went to this Brio for the first time last summer for the Yelp garden party. Didn't really get to try much more than a couple of flatbreads so I didn't have a good picture of what the place was like. I just know that they're owned by the same company that owns Bravo Cucina Italiana...so I expected good things from them. I am confused by the names...Bravo...Brio....the menus seem to vary slightly as do the prices. I've been to Bravo in Pittsburgh and Brio in Florida. So I wonder if the names just vary by region?  Anyway!

Sean and I decided to check it out last night after going to see a movie at Frontenac. When we got inside, there was a crowd of servers and hostesses all just mingling near the front podium thing. We were ignored for a few minutes while they casually chatted. Not really a great first impression. But I was hungry and didn't care. We were seated a little after that and we were handed menus.

Wow. Chicken milanese costs $19.95? Wtf. I thought it was more around $15 or so, at least from when I last ate at Bravo. But I am not entirely sure what the deal is with the different places so maybe Brio is more costly or maybe it's because it's at Frontenac. I dunno. I opted for the lobster and shrimp ravioli. It has some kind of crab thing on top with limoncello sauce. Never had that at Bravo so decided to try it. After all, for about the same price ($20.99) I might as well get something with more expensive ingredients, right? It was VERY VERY good....if a little rich. I ended up with severe heartburn later on but it was so worth it. The salad had crabmeat and a little tangy lemon flavor to it. Mmm. 

Sean opted for the last item on the flatbread menu...some type of sausage and pepperoni thing with ricotta on top. Needless to say he ordered it w/o sausage and scraped the ricotta off, but he seemed to enjoy it otherwise. Oh, and I had a glass of wine. They were sold out of the kind I wanted but I was able to get a recommendation from our server and he let me try a sample before getting a whole glass.  Food came out LIGHTNING FAST. Was really surprised! Pleasantly surprised, that is. ;)

I think I'd come back here but it's kind of spendy. Maybe to get the chicken milanese because I know it will be good, just not sure how ready I am to drop 20 clams on a chicken dish.

I had been wanting to try Brio, so I made reservations for Valentines Day.  I decided to do something different and eat at lunch time instead of the usual dinner.  We were seated right away at a little table for two.  We were told they had the tables set up like this for Valentine's Day.  My only problem with that is hubby was across from me instead of beside me.  No hand holding:(
Our server was a sweetie and took very good care of us.  The interior reminded me of the Cheesecake Factory.  Bread basket came quickly and loved the bread (I love bread) I had chicken Marsala and was made with grilled chicken which is different for me and I loved it.  Hubby had the lasagna and said it was very good.  It wasn't very romantic, due to the distance between us and people close by, but it was lunch so it was fine.  Over all, great lunch, great service.  We will definitely go back!
Happy Valentines Day!

Just finished Easter brunch at Brio and it was excellent!  The eggs were light and fluffy.  They give you so much bacon, I couldn't eat it all!  The breakfast potatoes were the best I've ever had!  We had reservations so we didn't have to wait and service was perfect!  We finished our meal with a splurge...it is Easter!  We shared the chocolate molten cake and OMG was it good!  Highly recommend that any time any day! Haha. Another great dining experience at Brio!  Happy Easter!

This place is a chain so I did not expect much but I was surprised how much I loved the food there!

Pros:
- Crabcakes are great (full of seafood)
- Their lobster ravioli is delicious
- If you make reservations, you get a table pretty darn fast

Cons:
- Service is a hit and miss with this place (1st time was a charm but the 2nd time I came here for dinner was not too good to say the least)
- Their martinis were way too watered down for my liking
- Did I mention you should make a reservation on a weekend night? Well, you should!

I rather go to Cunetto's on the Hill if I am ever in the mood for for some rich carbs but Brio met up to some of my standards!

I used to go here fairly often - especially when I went shopping at Plaza Frontenac.  The service the vast majority of the time was wonderful (every now and again there comes someone who must have been sucking on a lemon that day, ie. sour attitude) and the inside is very nicely arranged.  Light and airy and room enough.

The two things I want to rave about are their lamb chops!  YUM!!!  Everything that comes with the lamb complemented it instead of fought for top billing.  I believe at one time they had Gorgonzola crusted chops; that was insanely good!  The other thing we both loved was their cream of mushroom soup (and sadly it wasn't offered nearly enough to suit me).

All I can say for the soup was it was damn good!  And you have to do something right to make something as basic as cream of mushroom soup stand out in your mind.  When I come home, this will be one of my return visits.

I've been to Brio many times for cocktails, dinner parties and dates. They've never failed to deliver good food, service and great drinks. Brio is located in the Plaza Frontenac complex.
