Very spacious offering a ton of outdoor seating options, a full bar area with cocktail tables and of course their large open dining room. Service is pleasant. 

Brio is perfect for large parties, meetings and happy hour. They serve a delicious array of seafood, pastas, salads and wines. Dessert and cognac selections are just so-so. I highly recommend the Salmon, Tilapia and Shrimp & Crab Cakes dishes...all are real crowd pleasers.

Thank me later,
~Christy

What a beautiful spot, with such a fantastic happy hour! I was here not too long ago in order to enjoy the wide selection of drinks and food. I have to say: even on a Tuesday it was very packed (but also probably because of limited seating due to COVID and no happy hour outside). 

We opted to try a variety of drinks, including the traditional martini, the raspberry martini, a tasty drink made with ginger, and a Manhattan. We also were torn about which Abi or foods to get, but ultimately decided on splitting the burger and the flatbread. Both were absolutely delicious! I definitely want to come back to try the steak tartare and some of the other food options on the menu as well.

I would say to be sure to show up early if you plan to get a seat at the bar and enjoy the atmosphere. I look forward to when the weather gets warmer and we are able to go back and sit outside or enjoy more of a full dinner experience there as well!

Some of the best Lasagna Bolognese anywhere!

They have a large open dining area.  The place looks nice, but you'd feel comfortable coming here whether you're in jeans or dress pants.  There is ample outdoor dining complete with bocci ball.  Very good prices for the quality and quantity of food you receive.  I think my lunch-sized lasagna with chopped salad was only $12.95.

It's difficult for me to comment on much more than the lasagna bolognese.  It's so very good here, I have a hard time straying from ordering the same thing every time.  I will add, however, that they have tasty bellinis, which you can order by the pitcher.

Had a nice dinner for 10 on a Saturday evening. Service was super nice. They all were very friendly, brought lots of bread, plenty of drink refills, and quickly cleared the plates. The restaurant seemed pretty crowded too. I didn't notice if there were people waiting but all tables seemed full.  

Started with the mussels. They were especially delicious and I would recommend. Sometimes they can be gritty or have an odd (not so fresh) flavor. I highly recommend and will order again. They tasted fresh, clean, and very flavorful with the seasoning. 

The sweet potato and chicken risotto was very tasty. Creamy and perfect texture (not crunchy like some). The chicken was tender and the entire dish was very flavorful. The dish had asparagus which is a fav. I like sweet potatoes and this added a flavor of sweetness in an otherwise savory dish. I will say there were a few bites that were a bit saltier than others. But it was still an awesome entree.   Shout out to yelper Kay X as her photo inspired me to try this, I normally stick with pasta with the fear of undercooked risotto. 

Had the tiramisu for dessert and it was a nice ending to the meal. Strong coffee flavor, moist, not too sweet. It was a solid dessert.

It was a gorgeous day on April 17th around 3:00 pm. I was seated at a perimeter table nearest to Lindbergh (not a bar table closer to the doors) and was immediately approached for a drink order (iced tea). Arrived soon enough, as did my friend. For the next TWO HOURS, we:
1. were unenthusiastically approached by a new(?) server, told us she'd be right back.
2. were unenthusiastically approached by a third (server?) who also said they'd be right back. 
3. saw some kind of manager checking on the bar tables but he never even looked our way as we kept trying to get his attention to order off the menu. 
4. kept waiting for one of two servers working the bar tables to look over at us so we could get their attention. 
5. eventually asked a busser to get a server; nobody ever arrived. 
6. saw a server finally sauntering over to check on us and we told her we just wanted to pay for our drinks. 

Dear Brio, you'll see I rarely give super negative reviews but one of your managers and several servers need better eyes. Wow!

I've never done laundry here either but walking around the laundry side appears very clean. Staff is on-site from open till close. You'll find large TVs on walls, tables for laptops and coffee available. I will use for large blankets and quilts in the future.

I've been tanning here for years. The beds and rooms are clean with friendly staff. They offer specials each month on tanning lotions with free tanning weekends to all a couple times a year.
 
Want an instant bronzed tan without the standard orange day-glow you've had before or seen on others? NO MORE ORANGE! Check out the Versa Spa spray tanning booth here. It's terrific, fast, you choose the shade of tan you desire. I was terrified first time but NO orange after glow. In just a few hours your tan looks like you spent a few weeks on the beach. Versa Spa is perfect for brides and wedding parties, vacations or that special occasion. Try it once and you'll be a believer!

Great location with lots of parking. Love coming here with friends and even for a quick meeting. I'm not much of a beer person but I really like the fact that they offer a cider option and wine. Great decor and large seating area. Th summer here is great but it is often very chilly inside in the winter.

I was lucky enough to spend 2 weeks in Boise for "work." Spent my free time drinking my way around Boise's great craft beer scene. I visited about 10 breweries or brewpubs and Payette was far and away my fav. Tons of beers on tap. I would guess probably 30. Fun custom 4 beer flights, and cheap too! Like hard to believe cheap. Beautiful building and space. No food, but on both of my visits they had a food truck parked outside. Great vibe. Oh yeah, and most importantly, the beer is excellent!

I have been here a few times and I really like what is going on. Very clean atmosphere with vibrant people just partaking in a little beer drinking. The line to grab a beer got a bit long. However, those beer queens were slaying it and they were serving beer quickly. 

Laughs can be heard from every direction but especially from out at the beer garden where some fun peepers were playing yard games. I wanted to join.

From the bar area you can see all the brewing magic behind glass windows but fear not, enter the door on the right (you will see it) and view the magic a little closer from an aerial view. Scared? Just ask and they will tell you the same thing!!! 

Yayee what a fun addition to not only Boise but the greenbelt! It is a perfect stop if you are biking in that area! Plenty of bike parking!

Bringgg bringgg (that is a bike bell.) Cheers!

= Boise Beer Tour (self-guided) - Stop 2 =

I stopped here on my second day in Boise. In the late afternoon I decided to check out the pathway along the river, and at one point I noticed Payette was just around the corner. It seemed a prudent time to wet my whistle.

Unlike the local, casual vibe of Woodland Empire the previous night, Payette was loud, busy, polished; and it felt, dare I say...corporate.  The tenders were not unfriendly but a little harried and impatient, so I quickly ordered the first thing that looked good - a Blood Orange Rustler IPA; it turned out to be fairly boring; not nearly as good as it sounded (3*).

The place was big. And busy. (And did I mention loud?) There was a large front room and an outside, grassy area with a few lawn games set up; quite a few kids and families. I wandered around a bit but was never really able to find a good spot to hang out solo, not even at the bar.  I noted the crowd looked trendier than most Boise spots I'd been to and most folks were in larger groups; some appeared to be work-related.

I would have liked to hang and try more of their beers, but I couldn't get comfortable here, so I headed out as soon as I could. Maybe next time, if I'm with a group (or a family)

It's here!! July 1st. As of today, kids are allowed in breweries. Now before I get accused of being a bad parent, let me explain. Breweries are the cornerstone of my friendship with my husband. It's where we have conversations with old friends and make new ones. Where we relax and enjoy the simple things nature offers. Water. Barley. Hops. Grain. People. The best that there is. Our son is well-behaved. He makes conversation easily. Is interested in people and relates well to adults. It's nice to bring him along with us now. We can give him an example of moderation and enjoyment to be found when sharing food and drink. 

That all being said-- Payette is sure to be our favorite local brewery. They were well prepared for day one of the new law. In addition to the normally provided corn-hole, croquet, hammock, etc. they added crayons and, wait for it . . . .  Bubbles. (Not sure if those were for kids, but, pretty awesome). A large grassy area provides space for soccer passing and relaxing in lawn chairs (bring your own though). 

My son Ryan is anxiously awaiting the arrival of the taproom manager Zach, his buddy from long past Sockeye days. 

You do "family" your way, I'll do it mine. But I guarantee, I'll be swinging in a hammock, watching my boys play soccer, drinking a Rustler IPA from the best brewery location in town. 
Cheers! 

PS- the beer is fantastic!

I love how welcoming this place is! They allow dogs and children inside the business and in their "back yard". We went after work on a Thursday and they had a good size crowd inside. There was never more than 3 people in line to get a beer. The beer pourers were very friendly, didn't rush me at all and let me taste a couple prior to ordering. The building does echo a bit, so don't come here for a business meeting as it can get difficult to hear. I can't wait to see what they do with their backyard. Currently, there are two tables, a hammock, and a portable pool in the corner. If the owners read this, please consider bringing in some lawn games as well as board games! We will be back with our doggies!

Payette is near and dear to my heart. I can drink while my spawn runs around. :) The outdoor area is perfect for people who are always attached to creatures that need constant care (dogs, children, husbands). You can bring a blanket, or lawn chairs to sit in the yard. There are horse shoes and enough area for kids and dogs to run around. The beer is pretty good, not excellent, which is what earned 4 stars. But the atmosphere is 100% five star quality!

What a great find on vacation! We were looking for fun things to do to escape the heat, and as beer lovers I'm so glad we found Payette! It offers a beautiful, clean indoor space and a spacious outside area. Plus, the beers were great! We each did a flight and then a glass of our favorite! The bartender was awesome and we had a great time.

Don't go here if you want service. Strolled in on Monday the 4th. There were two gents working the taps we grabbed a beer menu at the counter, never greeted nor show any type of acknowledgment that we even were seen. The place wasn't that busy and once the tenders had.completed working their respective focus on two other customer (totally fine since they were being helped first) they quickly moved on to people who were standing/had shown up after us. It was so bad that a couple who came in five minutes after us and sat at a table and didnt receive service they inmediately moved to the counter and were helped before us. In fact we were NEVER helped nor shown that we were even there. We joked if they could see us and if we had become ghost but then realised that this in fact occured. There were four couple/customers who were helped after us and that was the kill move. We left after zero service and am drafting this review outside their establishment. Wouldn't waste my time..

The atmosphere was cool, the beer was good, the place was spacious...I don't see any problems with this place.

Getting there:
This place is down the street from downtown, near the river. However, you can't see the river from the brewery.

Experience:
This place was really cool. There was lots of room, everyone brought their dog, the staff was abiding by COVID guidelines. We did a flight of beer. They don't have a huge selection, but the beers I tried were pretty good.

Came here on a Saturday night with a large group of people for a friend's birthday. The organizers of the birthday party had been in contact with the brewery via email the week leading up to the birthday party to let them know that 20 or so beer enthusiasts would be rolling in that upcoming Saturday evening and would stay about an hour. They received confirmation that they would be ready for us.

Unfortunately, the person whom they exchanged emails with did not convey this to the gentleman tending the brewery tasting room that evening and he was less than thrilled to see our group enter. The first of the group to enter the brewery requested a flight and was told "5 ounce pours will take forever...I will *only* allow your group 5 flights." To which she replied, "Ok, well then I'd like the first of those." He then said, "I'll help you last," looked past her and shouted, "Anyone want a pint? I'll help you now."

Really odd, bordering on rude service. After his behavior was so unwelcoming, the organizer took it upon herself to show him the email exchange she'd had with the Payette Brewing representative. At that point, his attitude somewhat improved.

I am quite familiar with their beer and my typical go-to Payette beer is their Mutton Buster Brown. I was excited to see that the February "Ale of No Return" was a porter--Pistolero Porter. It isn't my favorite porter of all time, but I do prefer it to the Mutton Buster (mainly because I prefer porters/stouts to browns). I also like that 10oz pours are an option!

Overall, I'd order their porter again. But, likely, I'd find it elsewhere in town to avoid potential service issues.

More like a 3.5 rating. It's odd here to say the least. It's a beautiful, big, open space with plenty of room for a crowd. Yet, on my visit there were just a few stragglers, and this on a Thursday evening. I found out why quickly. None of their beer is amazing. It's just good. But, with a market that is growing exponentially you have to make great/excellent/special beer to stay relevant and alive. Payette has to up their game. The lone beer I tried that was above average was Fem(Ale), this was a great example of the strong ale style. But, nothing else enticed me to sip twice. The recoil and ooskie were both run of the mill IPA's. 
      I was hoping to find some of their hoop and stave series beers in bottles or their sours, but they didn't have any available when I came. These beers sound really good, and if I found myself in the area I would probably come back and see about tasting these.
     The big positives here are the staff and their food truck. The ladies (beautiful by the way) running the taps are super friendly and I observed more than once where they coached a novice beer drinker on choosing the right pint. They created an overall fun and inclusive vibe, and they had a good playlist going to boot. Out back they have a really good BBQ food cart, from what I gathered one of the guys running it is from my native Ozarks, so it figures that it's so good!!!
    I'd definitely give Payette another visit. And if you're into beer and in the area I'd suggest you try it out too. I think as a brewery that they have a lot of potential, and they have great people running the front of the house.

Wow just wow. I can't say enough about this brewery. The inside is expansive and kid and dog friendly. The beer garden is open. Tours are on Saturday but you can take your beer and sit on the catwalk and see where all the beer magic happens. I had iron brewer and the schwarzbier, both were epic. This is a spot where you definitely feel like home.

I wanted a coffee and starbucks had a line out the door! I ended up here instead. I'm a sucker for advertisements and went crazy when I saw 'Cafe Con Leche' now on the menu! boom problem solved I know what I want! And then we pull up and I'm hungry and want a sandwich and I see a picture of this chicken wrap and it looks so yummy in the picture! OH PICTURES...so we order that as well. The attendants at the speaker and the window were very polite and friendly. We pay the $8 for the coffee and wrap and start driving. 

I'm not a big person, my hands are as small as my niece actually and when I pulled out this tiny taco I was crushed! I would have been total excited had it come from a mexican restaurant filled with toppings (that's how small the wrapper was) and they usually give you 3! Anyways! It was so tiny! I was so upset and a regular size person would have taken 1 bite and it would have been gone.. luckily for me it took me 3... needless to say I was still hungry. 

Now on to my 'Cafe Con Leche'... I really should know better. I'm for Tampa for goodness sake! Never EVER order a Cafe Con Leche from any where else OTHER than a Spanish store or restaurant! ugh another lesson learned. First mistake was assuming they would put sugar (my bad on that end) and when I picked up my 'Medium' coffee it was filled up to the 'small line' meaning there was nothing in it! then I take a swig and it tastes just like any other normal coffee I'd make at home. Americano with milk!.... 

I'll forever be a fan of their donuts... end of story. =(

Came here for my free coffee on National Coffee Day.  I was pleasantly surprised how friendly the staff were.  Normally, I get the rudest people while at DD.  Their coffee was hot and tastes exactly like I remember.

The attitude of the employees deserves a 4/5 for getting drinks out in an efficient manner, especially serving coffee at 7am, but my iced coffee was no bueno! I used to work early hours, can't imagine reverting back to it; It definitely requires a "can do" attitude, so I appreciate it a lot. I decided last minute that I wanted a shot of hazelnut syrup and went on merry way to work only to realize too late when I took a sip that it was all sugar (ugh!!). I have a sweet tooth, but this was way overboard, like she at least added 3 pumps of hazelnut syrup. I should've had a sip before leaving...it was 7am and I had an unusually early meeting, so I needed to get going (my mistake for not checking!), but once you add too much sugar, it's not redeemable! I was super disappointed and to top it off, being a klutz, proceeded to spilled it all over my car, not Dunkin's fault...that was not a good day. I do love hazelnut, so for a good part of the day my car smelled good! ;)

I've been taking Platoon's free classes at the Comcast Center for the past four weeks and I absolutely love them. The trainers, Michelle and Malik, are awesome and inspirational. 

I'll admit, I begrudgingly went to the second class dreading the various cycles we had gone through the week before. I assumed that because the classes were free, they would be exactly the same. Wrong! Every single class has been different. Each has been painful in its own special way, but for me, not knowing what's next makes it easier to push through. This has kept me going back for more week after week. 

Although I already have a gym membership and pay for another boot camp in NJ, I am seriously considering looking into Platoon's programs.

Took advantage of the free doughnut coupon from Krispy Kreme ...so with all the signage and hype for the pumpkin flavored fall doughnuts.. I chose the Pumpkin Cheesecake... and it was very very good.... especially the FREE part

Krispy Kreme - I think you are going to get a pretty consistent experience across the chain. Heck, I did not even know about the "HOT" sign -- that is a cool concept! It was also great to see a full selection of Halloween items for the holiday. Not, obviously, frequenting this kind of store I do not know how common this is for the holidays. The only thing I didn't get was the sign reading $1.29 each -- add 20 cents for each in an assorted dozen. Okay, you need to reach into different spots to gather the donuts to fill a box but charging more for buying more of anything just does not make sense. I didn't buy a dozen but I had to read the sign several times to make sure my vision was shifting the words around.

Krispy Kreme Donuts sent me a coupon for a free donut and small drink for my birthday for being in their Eclub..so I took advantage of it. 
I went through their drive thru window and I ordered a lemon filled donut and small coca cola (not much of a coffee drinker) and gave her the coupon...she wished me a happy birthday and I took the food to work with me for a breakfast before I started my shift.

The donut was very fresh and it was so good. I highly recommend this for a quick pick me up or a small breakfast...I stop there once a month and get two dozen to take to my co-workers as a gift..They love this place too!!! and the drive thru is so convenient !!!

They make it right in front of you!  Where I'm from (Philadelphia) Krispy kremes are almost non existent so my parents were so excited to see an entire store devoted to these delicious donuts.  I think they were a bit too excited though because they started taking pictures and questioning the workers about what its like to work in a Krispy kreme.  C'mon guys! so embarrassing...

OMG YUM! I was so excited when I saw this on my walk back to my Air B&B from Vanderbilt University. I had to stop and buy some fresh Kripsy Kreme donuts because in NYC we only have 1 store!

The place was clean, the service was quick, and the donuts were amazing. I ordered 6 of the original donuts because they are the best! It was about $6 and change for the 6 donuts which I did not mind because we cannot get them at home!

I was shocked to discover that this location no longer caries my person favorite Krispy Kreme donut the "Glazed Chocolate Cake". Not that I need it, but it was a bit of a disappointment. 

The staff here is always friendly, and was happy to answer our questions about the Cheerwine Donut, so I won't remove a star for their discontinuing my favorite donut. 

Probably not as many varieties at Fox's Donut Den or Shipley's Do-Nuts but if you are looking for a Krispy Kreme fix, you'll do just fine here

The quality of the donuts are what you would expect. Very sugary taste but that is the brand. Donuts are served hot and baked just shortly before. The drive thru could use some love. The ordering board has an annoying welcome to Krispy Kreme how many dozen can I get for you today. This is a recorded message that is not only insincere but very rude to the staff to have machine answer when the motion detector shows you pulled up. Krispy Kreme- value your staff more then trying to sell more the one dozen at a time and the service will be better in the end....

Recieved a call from Big Boss, please bring donuts to meeting. I was already in a jam about making it to work, so called ahead. They were soo nice. I said I am in running behind, they said it will be ready in 15 minutes. In out and perfect order with 2 big Cartons of coffee, 3 dozen donuts and get this all the stuffs for the coffee all ready for me to run and pay and out the door. 
Really love this place. They also have a SMORES HOT CHOCOLATE!!! GO GET IT! 
THANK YOU KK!

Such a prime location! Right in Elliston Place. Man, EVERYTIME I drove down 21st, it just so happened that I would be in the vicinity of Krispy Kreme when the HOT sign was on. Sooo good and soooo worth every calorie! These literally melt in your mouth. I also liked their Very Berry Chiller.

Well krispy creme is great. But this location wasn't.

We thought ok let's be quick so we went to the drive thru. It took sooooo long. Their were only two cars ahead of us. Staff wasn't friendly either. Not rude. But just short. Not engaging. Seemed like they'd prefer if they weren't there and we weren't there.

Our donuts still tasted good. But they were cold. For the time we waited we expected them to be fresh!

A hot Krispy Kreme glazed donut is without a doubt heavenly.  To have one a block from my hotel is an absolute delight.  You walk in and that delicious smell washes over you beckoning you to buy more.  You watch as the donuts make their journey down the conveyor belt towards your mouth and the excitement builds.  As you can see I love them.  Can't get hit ones in New York unless you go uptown so this was a real test for me.  Service was very friendly and quick.  Loved my visits here and I'll be back again for sure.

Conveniently located on the corner on Elliston Place.  Have to be careful turning into the parking lot due to busy traffic. Don't let the hot sign cause you to have a wreck!!  You can see the conveyor belt with fresh, tasty donuts from the drive thru window. Stop by for a yummy treat if you're coming to St. Thomas Midtown (old Baptist Hospital), one of the many doctor's offices in the area, or just passing by.

Sweet cream vanilla is the way to go. Lots of great toppings. Friendly service. There are taster cups above the traditional ice cream case at the counter. Can't go wrong with blackberries and fresh mango toppings. This place always seems to do pretty well and I always enjoy my visits.. even when Raju beats me at their oversized checkers game. Comfy place. Surf Shack and a flatbread pizza type sports bar dinner place next door as well as Publix and Mickey D's in same complex on Linebaugh and Racetrack / Countryway.

I'm definitely a fan but I have to deduct a star since my last visit. 

The service is still great but I wish they would be more careful about making sure the toppings bar was fresher. Bottles of Hersey Syrup were empty when my brother reached for it. The cookie toppings were stale. There was a lack of care when it came to the presentation of the toppings. 

The fro-yo itself is still delicious and I love that they make it clear the nutritional value on each flavor. The toppings bar needs some attention nonetheless.

Lighting in the store needs some work because at night it's pretty dark and dim.
meh - nothing spectacular to report.  Everything we had was just okay.

First visit to froyo and became a fan. It was clean and though smaller than the yogurt mountain in carrollwood that I usually go to for my frozen yogurt fix, they had some pretty interesting flavors to choose from. The salted caramel was my favorite. They claim to be low cal, gluten free and kosher as well. Low cal is a bit deceiving if you add all the extras but who can resist some peanut butter cups with your froyo?  Many of the yogurts have Splenda added as sweetener so I tried to stay clear of those. 

They also offered a 10% discount with a receipt from the surf shack restaurant next door which was mighty nice.  A good way to cool your palate after some spicy food.
This place is AMAZING !! The yogurt selection is pretty small but the taste is wonderful. They also offer ice cream and smoothies !! The staff is very friendly and keep the place very clean.

Something told me to give this place another try since it's so close to home, and the fam absolutely loves ice cream and frozen yogurt.  I'm going to stick with my original 2 stars.  The place was pretty busy when we got there, and people were darting around like chickens with there heads cut off.  It was chaotic as hell.  One woman kept cutting in front of me while I was waiting in line at the soft serve machines...  I suppose her order was front-burner to mine.  I was willing to overlook this because it wasn't really a reflection of the business (other than the layout being ineffective for more than 3 or 4 parties at a time), but just as I was reaching for the lever to fill my cup, AN EMPLOYEE jumped in front of me and got some yogurt for a drive-up order.  My wife and I stood there in utter disbelief.  It was crazy.

As for the yogurt itself, it was good.  I got the creme brulee and slapped some hot fudge on top of it.  All 4 of us thought the selections were tasty, but couldn't get past the frustration of gathering of the food.

Tonight will definitely be the last visit.

I'm a big fan of Coldstone Creamery, but I'd have to give this place the nod as the best.  Don't let the froyo in the name fool you. Sure, they have all manner of frozen yogurt, but they have real ice cream too, and its the best in Tampa Bay. And if that doesn't satisfy your sweet tooth, they have the most amazing self service toppings bar where you pay by weight. This gives extra chocolate chips a whole new meaning!

The quality of the ingredients is outstanding, service is good and the place is clean and well organized. It is worth it to come here after a good meal even if you have to drive a bit. You won't be disappointed.  And if you are, an extra scoop of chocolate chips and marshmallows ought to fix you right up!

I was thrilled when a froyo place opened up in my neighborhood. It definitely did not disappoint.

I loved that the froyo is self-serve. They have several flavors and an endless toppings bar. They weigh your final product when you pay. I like their Classic Tart with fresh fruit toppings. 

The restaurant was spotless when I went and the employees were very friendly. They asked if this was my first time here and if I needed help with anything. 

They also serve sundaes, ice cream, boba teas, milk shakes and smoothies. They all looked delicious. I love that they have a drive though!

The Westchase plaza with a little bit of everything scores again on my first pop-in to Froyo Fresh.

First, very pleasant and professional employee working inside.

Always a sucker for anything Key Lime flavored, she allowed me to try some of their Key Lime ice cream and it passed the test.

I then split my cup between the peanut butter and oatmeal cookie frozen yogurt flavors and thought the taste was certainly authentic.

Overall, the selection of ice cream, froyo and toppings/tasty accessories was very good and they aren't very expensive at all.

There's a sticker on the front door that says "People love us on Yelp." Well, count me as one of those people.

Wonderful place, and I'm very glad that it's a bit of a drive from where I now live in Carrollwood since it would be awfully convenient to ride my bike over to this temple of FroYo from my former home in Westchase.

Tanya & Matt's Frozen Yogurt Home of Fresh Yummy Goodness is located in the Publix shopping center at the intersection of Linebaugh Avenue and Countryway, right in the heart of Westchase. It's tucked behind the McDonald's so you need to pull into the shopping center and look at the row of restaurants behind Mickey D's to find this place.

Tanya & Matt's is small inside, but they have plenty of room for about 20 people, plus outdoor seating along the sidewalk for more. There's also a drive-through window which was popular when I visited.

The quantity of selections was smaller than many other frozen dessert places (10 selections as I recall), but the quality of their product was outstanding. I was very pleased to see that everything was labeled as low cal FroYo, and noticed that they rotate their flavors according to the season. According to a sign in the store, "all our Frozen Yogurt is gluten-free, kosher, egg-free, fat/cholesterol-free, and has LIVE active yogurt cultures, 8-20 calories/oz."

I got a cup of the low cal Very Berry yogurt and then piled on fresh strawberries, fresh red and black raspberries, and freshly-grated coconut for a very tasty dessert. It's the usual game of fill the cup with yogurt, then pile on the toppings, and then weigh the entire mess to see what the cost will be.

Their toppings bar has all kinds of candies, nuts, fruit, and assorted sticky goodness so that you can customize your dessert to your liking.

The cost is 42 cents per ounce, which means that my cup of yogurt with all of the fruit toppings was under $5.

Great place, and worth a stop or two.

This Froyo- frozen yogurt - is intriguing. If you are for that, they have the many flavors of frozen yogurt. It includes many toppings such as fresh fruit and candy. They also has smoothies with fresh fruit. 

There is one item you may want to try if you have not. It is yogurt Thai tea popping. I have the Thai tea mixed with regular yogurt. Then bottom with the mango popping. It is like Thai tea smoothies with boba. It is interesting to try.

Not a huge self serve Fro Yo place and not as many selections as others, but the quality is great and their selection of low cal fro yo is high.  

I especially like the fact that they have FRESH raspberries as a topping.  I haven't found anyone who offers this option.

BTW, the offer homemade ice cream too (which I tried once and it was awesome)

OPEN EVERYDAY!! Idk y it said it was closed 

Friendly & helpful staff :) lots of flavors & options to choose from. There's Frappes, ice cream, froyo, bubble tea & bowls and smoothies! 
-  this place makes me happy !

They have a traveling froyo truck that will come to your neighborhood during COVID-19!

My neighbors are doing all the work for me and arranging for food trucks to come to our neighborhood. All I have to do it put it on my calendar and show up. These are the best type of neighbors. 

The froyo truck parked in my neighbor's driveway and was there between 4 p.m. an 7 p.m. on a Wednesday. We could come any time during those hours. Froyo for dinner? Yes, please!

The workers wore masks and there were cones on the ground to mark six feet apart. Still, with a window of three hours, we didn't have to wait in line. We saw neighbors coming and going, but we kept our distance. 

For $5 you get a cup of froyo and two toppings. For a dollar extra you could get homemade ice cream. Anything homemade captures my attention so I went for it. I got half peanut butter fudge and half salted caramel with butterfingers and reeses pieces for my toppings. Like I said, it was my dinner so I wanted all the calories! It did not disappoint.

The workers were so friendly and it was a nice treat during this time. If you have a group of friends looking for a business to support, call them up and have their truck come out!
Sweet cream vanilla. Lots of gr4st toppings. Friendly.service. Tasters above the traditional ice cream. Can't go wrong with blackberries and fresh mango toppings.

Tanya and Matt what's happening?  Your establishment is going down hill. What happened to the mature, responsible HS aged girls working there?  They were fast, efficient and kept the place clean. Lately it's been dirty, chaotic and lacking the basics like HOT fudge.  I know it sounds silly, but people like their hot fudge actually hot, not cold and a big glob like I found it today. 

3 stars because its close and I like to support local businesses, but clean it up, hire back the old staff and offer hot fudge please.

Amazing selection of froyo flavors and toppings at the cheapest froyo price I've seen in a long time ($.46 per oz)!

If I could insert the emoji with the hearts for eyes here, I would. I adore this place. Westchase, you just keep getting better and better in my eyes. Best part - they're locally owned and operated!

I won a bet with my husband while we were zip lining at Empower Adventures earlier in the day. If you've read my other reviews, you would know without a doubt that winning always equals frozen yogurt. As he started to drive us home I shouted "stop!" There was a frozen yogurt place less than three miles from us! Sure, it was in the opposite direction of home, but it would be quicker for me to get some creamy goodness. (My husband is a saint.)

As we drove to Froyo Fresh I quickly realized that we were heading towards Westchase. We have eaten in the plaza before, but never stopped at this shop. What a mistake. Parking is a breeze since it is in a giant shopping plaza. 

The shop is on the smaller side, but not uncomfortably so. I got a sample cup and turned to look at the flavors. Their flavor choices were spot on. It was as if they asked me what flavors I like and then poof, there they were. There were Snickers, Reese's Peanut Butter, Brownie Batter, and tons more. They even had my beloved tart. They also have a variety of toppings! No, they did not have my favorite - frosted animal crackers - but they had everything else, so I let it slide. There are a ton of crushed candy bars and nuts. I piled my yogurt high with sugary crumbles. 

As I stated at the beginning of this review, the froyo is only $.46 an oz! My snack came out to a little over $3. That's crazy! Most frozen yogurt places I frequent charge over $.50 an oz. That might seem like a small difference, but when you think about how much froyo I'll eat over my lifetime, it will definitely add up. 

They have ice cream too for those of you who don't want to partake in frozen yogurt (and know that if that is you, I respect you less. Kidding...kind of). They were offering a cookie sundae that almost tempted me. Basically, if you have a family that has different tastes, as long as it is ice cream/frozen yogurt based, you can satisfy them here!

Try this place, love this place, and thank me later.

15 microbrew taps, order food, pretty nice little bar but the Wi-Fi is so so slow slow slow. I love whole foods and have been to most of them in the western United States, it's a good bar but not a good value---come on, growlers $20 to $40????

March 31, 2014 Monday - drinks 5:15 PM
2 adults

Atmosphere - 5 stars
Food - N/A stars
Service - 5 stars 

Background - Out with a friend to have some beer and dinner after work.
 
Atmosphere - Reminds of a large German beer hall miniaturized and without Polka band.   Okay so really it is just the long community tables with benches that you can sit with complete strangers.  You can share fish stories with them, oh beer stories.   

Food
  Drinks - Started with Enjoy By IPA with the date of 04-20-2014 on tap.  This is a really hoppy beer which I love.  I noticed they had a Cast of Union Jack.  I was curious to try it but did not want a full beer and asked for a flight, which is about a fourth of a pint not really sure the exact size.  But large enough to give you a good taste.    

  Appetizer - none.

  My Main Course - Went and got a burrito from around the corner as the only veggie option was a veggie burger.  Never been a fan of those.

  Dessert - none.

Service - They had one bartender working the bar.  She was helpful and friendly.  She even gave us our two flights (one for each of us) of the Union Jack cast beer for free.  She showed us the cast and explained how it worked.  The tap for that is on far left while the regular taps are on the right.  Which was really helpful as this seems to be new trend.  

Future - Signs up saying grab a beer and walk around while shopping.  I think the next time the wife takes me there I will have one to talk around.

This was my first time at the Tap Room ... never quite noticed it before.  Anyway, it's a small area at the front of the store, small but adequate lunch menu.  I didn't want to have a beer or wine, so I went out into the store and picked up a lemonade and they just rang it up with my lunch order which I chose to sit at the bar to eat.  There are some counters and tables if you prefer.

Chose to have a Rueben ... OMG it was one of the best I ever had.  Came with way too many fries.  Almost finished the sandwich.  

I understand they have a Happy Hour .. great place to stop and have a snack before doing the rest of your shopping.

Would definitely go again.

I'm, stuck between three and four stars for a review of the Whole Foods Tap Room. I liked the beer and the chicken wings. But everything they do well is done better at the Legends bar a few doors to the north. I rate Legends four stars so I'm going to give the Whole Foods Tap Room three stars.
They had 14 beers on tap when I visited. Nine or 10 were ales. I don't like hoppy flavor so that's bad for me, but probably a plus for most beer drinkers. The wheat beer I got was good. If iit were a wine I'd say it had nice balance. The alcohol didn't show through.
I also got a chicken wing and a pretzel. The pretzle was a fail. Way too dry. It was supposed to have been freshly made but tasted more like it was freshly microwaved. I won't get one of those again.
The wings were pretty good and I recommend them to others. The meat was of good quality. But then again,. just a few doors down, Legends has some of the best chicken wings in the Truckee Meadows.
The Tap Room is clean and brightly lit. This will be a contrast to a lot of bars in the area.
Service was friendly.

A gem in hiding, if you ask me.  I have always loved whole foods and shop here regularly.  I had stopped into the taproom a couple of times for a beer with the hubby (while rewarding him for shopping with me), but it wasn't until recently that I learned the real secret of the Tap Room.  

Are you ready?  They have an amazing menu of bar food (including raw bar food) for extremely reasonable prices, and the best part is - it is all food from whole foods so you know it is high quality and as fresh as it gets!  We have had their fresh ground burgers, oysters, fresh cut fries, organic chicken wings, etc.  They even have happy hour deals with flights of wine and $5 (yes, $5!!) cheese plates which look incredible!  Don't miss a beat - and run, yes run, to the WF Tap Room!

Finally, someone decided that it would be a good idea to combine beer and grocery shopping!

I went to the new Tap Room last week and was extremely pleased. Great beers on tap, Steve Earle music playing, and a good vibe among the people there. I loved that they even had a "pub menu," and you were also able to bring in lunch from the store to eat in there.

My husband and I ended up doing a few beer flights, which was the perfect way to sample all of the beers we wanted to try. My husband fell in love with one and brought it home in a Growler, which I had never heard of before, but doesn't make as much noise as one may think.

I think the new Tap Room is a great addition to the Reno community. It's not as much of a happy hour vibe as some of the newer Midtown bars, but the staff is friendly, knowledgeable, and it's a great place to relax while you're writing down your grocery list. And after a few drinks, that list may have evolved into something like potato chips, hot dogs, guacamole, and chocolate bars. Thank goodness you're at Whole Foods, where you can get the best caliber of all 4 of those items.

Enjoy!

Not sure when or why the name changed here on Yelp, but this is the same great casual sit down spot inside Whole Foods. 

Oysters served vis the seafood department. Large rotating selection of craft beer. Small but mighty menu of delicious bar bites. All around great experience! 

The menu has changed here and there over the years, and with those changes came a little variability in the quality. The most recent visit has them back on top of it all, though I did notice a smaller portion on some dishes for the same prices as before. I'm happy to pay for the quality though.

I ordered the blue cheese burger and it was damn good. They don't serve them with fries anymore, but it's only $10 and a shareable order of fries is $3-$4. We also had some sweet chili wings and traditional hot. These are larger than before, sauces are average, but they're cooked pretty well. Ask for them extra crispy and it's a home run. 

Grab a pint or a flight and some bites, and hang for a bit! Do your grocery shopping later!

I have been to their Tap Room couple of times, for an event or for a quick meal between shopping. I liked the place. 

Most recent visit was on a Saturday afternoon (2/25/2017) right around late lunch hour, Tap Room was crowded with customers, as we had expected, but with dirty dishes and dirty floor in plain sight, we decided to not enter at this time. We will give it another try perhaps during week night.

Beer!!  Beer!!!  Let me tell you all about the Beer!!!

NOT.  Everyone knows I don't do beer...and everyone also knows they can read all the other reviews for the beer info.

So instead I will tell you that you need these fries in your life. NEED these fries and ketchup.  I don't know what ketchup they use.  Is it house made?  Is it just something they have in bottles in the store?  I honestly don't know but the combo they have here is without compare.

I enjoyed my Cheesesteak Sandwich and my wife enjoyed her burger...even if it was a little overcooked.  I think that may have been my fault.  I ordered some last minute oysters and that messed up the whole meal.  Next time I will just tell them to bring it out when it's ready.  I mean, no need to worry about courses when you are eating from a paper lined basket.  ;)

The Kumamoto Oysters were great, and for a dollar they are a great deal.  And we were lucky to have been there when they had the Bee Sting.  Gin, Rogue orange soda and honey.  Tasty.

Always a great selection and the batenders are friendly.  I love that you can get a shopping cup to walk around the store.  Also you can buy any alcohol in the store and they will open and pour it.  Easy to order food or get food from store and carry in.  We love that they have removed the wall and put a counter to sit and people watch.  On a side note the coffee bar that is just opposite of the tap room has an amazing mocha and cols brew and Vietnamese coffee on nitro.  Yes, nitro!  If you have half and half, it tastes just like Stumptown from Portland OR Blue Bottle from San Fransico, truly the best find in town!!!!

Who doesn't love drinking a beer while grocery shopping. This guy! That's because I'd rather just sit and drink beer and leave the shopping to someone else. So I suppose if I had to do the shopping though, the best way to do it would be with a beer in my hand, so then I might love drinking a beer while grocery shopping. 

Now that I'm confused on the matter, I'm not confused about my love for the Tap Room at Whole Foods. If the awesome selection of rotating beers and very fair prices are not enough to love, they have a pretty good bar food menu in there, and the "Beertender" with the sick mustache is the icing on the cake. He runs that place with an iron fist and a bad ass bowtie! His style is unmatched by anyone I know in Reno, and this dude knows his beer! While the other beertenders there know there stuff too, I'm sure he's had a hand in educating them about the finer points of everything he's put on tap. And if you're not sure, here's a PRO TIP: Ask for a sample and don't be shy about tasting more than one.

On my last visit I was looking for an IPA and none of the ones I recognized were that interesting. I tried Rogue 7Hop, but to me it tasted more like 1Hop, so I asked Mr. Mustache (I wish I knew his name!) what to do. He steered me toward the Hop Dragon that they were keeping at bay inside a cask. A cask is a device similar to a keg but typically not refrigerated and the beer is put in without any additional CO2 or Nitrogen for carbonation. In a cask, the carbonation comes from the secondary fermentation and conditioning that occurs within it, and the head of the beer is achieved by way of the nozzle the beer comes from. 

All of this was new to me, and it completely changed the flavor profile of what otherwise would have been a very hoppy beer. The hop notes came through tasting faintly like watermelon with a subtle hop character on the finish. 

In all my visits I've never been steered wrong at the tap room and I'll return again soon, hopefully on a day when I'm just invited to sit in there and leave the shopping to the experts.

The Tap Room at Whole Folds is a sure stop for lunch, beer, and good conversation any day of the week.  Emerse yourself in a drinking community rich with a diverse background of people and stories to take make even the most mundane work day seem like a blessing in disguise. 

 I come here multiple times a week to enjoy lunch and take in the atmosphere. If your hungry I recommend  trying the Louisiana Cordon Blue Chicken Sandwich. Its delicious in so many ways.  

For those beer coniesures that enjoy trying new things. On every visit the beer draft list will change. Nitro beers, stouts, pales, pilsners, sours. You name it its been on tap at least once. They've got pints or 20oz for whatever your fancy. 

They host Taproom Takeovers frequently to give beer patrons a chance to meet the people behind the beer.
 Even Wine Flights every Thursday.

Beer sampler was alright, there were only four spots available on the paddle.  It would have been nice to try six since they were only about 2 ounce glasses.  While they didn't have too many beers on tap to choose from, a lot of them were IPA's and a couple of them were local crafts - my favorite of the four was a well known Marlette Red from Virginia City, it' somewhat standard around town.  The two guys behind the bar were very friendly and eager to answer any questions I had about the beers.

Since it was happy hour we ordered the cherry chipotle wings and the sweet potato tots.  When the wings came out I was terribly disappointed because they were shriveled to the bone and loaded with sauce to hide the fact that there was absolutely no meat on them.  I'm not ashamed to return something when it's inedible, so I kindly told the guy my issue with them and he gladly took them back.  However, the sweet potato tots were FANTASTIC!  I enjoyed every last one, slightly greasy, but fried to perfection.  And for only $3 you can't go wrong!

I'm glad I had the chance to check another happy hour spot off my list.  I will definitely be back for a glass of wine during HH, since I noticed a great price on a certain type that was written on their chalk board.

What the heck??? I have been shopping here bi-weekly and I never knew this place existed?? I always thought it was more space for people to eat their purchased prepared food! It is for that but they also have a full bar and a menu in there. Friendly bartender yesterday greeted us and we enjoyed our pizza here while drinking some delicious beers.
There is also a Tap Room menu. So many great options! Great prices on everything. Wine, Beer and the food. We will be back!

It's so easy to fall into a routine of familiarity at the places you love, but when you dig a little deeper and venture away from that which is known, it can have great rewards.

Case in point, my recent visit to the Tap Room. Finishing out the Whole 30 with a serious hankering for se bar food, we figured that Whole Foods was a solid choice. On the diet we'd gotten accustomed to the prepared foods bar, which packed a ton of options, but we'd never thought about the Tap Room. Whole Foods knows what goes into their food, so we checked up on some recipes and basically uncovered a treasure trove of tasty goodness we could enjoy and learned about some other incredible deals in the process.

First up, wings. A solid entry in the category coated in a tangy sauce with just the right kick. If it's not enough for you, just grab one of the hot sauces and add to it. We loved em so much we've been back at least twice to get them! 

Second, burgers. We tried the bison burger with a romesco sauce and Brie cheese. Ordered medium rare and the kitchen nailed it! They even did it "protein style" on my request!

Last, a few amazing deals available pretty regularly in the Tap Room: fresh shucked oysters, wine flights, and $5 cheese plates! The oysters are "flown" over from the seafood dept on a bed of ice, and the tap room staff will get you set with horseradish, lemon, and hot sauce so you can slurp em down. They usually have two varieties, and j love to compare, and you can order them in sets of 3! The wine flights happen once a week (I think) and the wine buyer selects the theme and the pours, and examines the flight when you order. The $5 cheese plate is  a mind blowing value! I watched a big piece of herbed goat cheese, crackers, fig jam, and all sorts of other accoutrement land on a beautiful board before friends. I was shocked to learn it was only $5! 

The Tap Room seems to switch up the offerings and events all the time. It's certainly a place to keep your eyes on and visit when you're in doing your shopping!

Stopped in here after hearing they had opened recently.  It's in the space on the right as you come in the north entrance, that used to be where they had cooking demos and the like.  They've put in some long benches and tables, with bright, light colored woods.  The space is still relatively unfinished, with the walls being 'woven' plywood/OSB, and a big "Tap Room" sign.

The menu was pretty reasonable, and was definitely priced at a more accessible price point than I had expected from Whole Foods.  Wasn't super hungry, so the GF and I split an order of the Smoked Pork Sliders ($9).  Other menu choices included a $9 burger, $9 cheese board, $8 wings, etc.  They also mentioned we could go to the hot food/salad bar and bring that in to eat if we wanted.  The sliders came with sweet potato fries, and the three sandwiches were solid.  Looks like the food's the same as what they're selling in the prepared counters of the grocery.

Beer selection was solid, and I didn't notice the price for their tasting flight, or I would have ordered that.  The tasting flight is four 4oz pours for $7.  I had Upright Brewing's Six, a fantastic dark rye out of Oregon.  Selection is good, as many of their wines and beers are from Cepage Selections as their distributor - taps included a few Shelton Brother's imports, one of New Belgium's Lips of Faith, a Great Basin brew, etc.  Sounds like they'll be rotating taps frequently, as they're mainly serving pony kegs.

 I chatted a bit with the tapmaster, who mentioned they were trying to keep things friendly, mentioning Great Basin just down the street, and trying to coordinate a bit with Craft so they wouldn't have the same beers on tap.  Definitely different markets, but makes sense.

Overall, a bright, well-lit space, with decent beers and food.  While I'll most likely stick to Public House, Craft, and Lincoln Lounge for the majority of my 'real' drinking, this seems like the perfect spot for me to hide in while the GF goes shopping in Whole Foods, or if I'm looking for a beer and a quick bite at this end of town.

Finally! WE HAVE ARRIVED!

What? You've never been to the Tap Room? Well, you need to try this place. They have food and beer, and wine and even some spirits.

Verdict: It's not the original but it's not a bad alternative at the airport.

This place is located in the outskirts of the airport terminals, in what seems to have the local food offerings. You'll also find the Philadelphia Pretzel Factory right across the food court. The Tony Luke's here isn't cheap by any stretch but you'll pay the premium when in need of a Philly fix.

I loved going to the original Tony Luke's before they started popping up everywhere. They made a decent cheesesteak but you could get that in a lot of places in Philly. This place probably does a better job than most with their pork sandwiches.

Looking for that familiar flavor, I ordered the roast pork with broccoli rabe. There wasn't anything really on the lighter end but I did find and order the cooked spinach side dish. The sandwich was exactly what I expected and I enjoyed every bite. The spinach side was tiny and a bit salty but otherwise good.

Even though this terminal is at the far end, there's a shuttle that brings you right here from one of the more central locations. If you have the time and crave some more authentic local cuisine, this place might be worth the trip.

Granted I don't get to Philly much, but I definitely know a real cheese steak from an impostor. And this place knows what it's doing. Went with onion, provolone and mushrooms. The roll was soft, the meat was juicy, and the ingredients were all well proportioned. Next time in the Philly airport, I'll be grabbing this sandwich and a hot pretzel.
Thought it very good food.  Slow service, so prepare for that but food was very good .  Add onions and mushrooms to your Philly steak... Customer service is not their forte but food is !!

If you're stuck at the airport and need a Cheesesteak, this may be your place to get one. But it seems the pork is where it's at. So if you're reading this, take a risk and get the pork over the cheesesteak.

Was flying through Philly and needed to grab a quick bite.  Cheesesteak was on the brain.   Stopped by Tony Luke's and grabbed a junior cheesesteak.  It was decent, not as good as Pats or Gino's but it's all about location and your offerings.  

Might repeat in a pinch.

SFO to PHI... I'm tired. I'm half awake walking to my little terminal to head back to Norfolk. It's 5:40am and I'm zombie. Then all of a sudden I spot a Tony Luke's. I'm reminded of my trip to AC and the cheesesteak binge Creagan B and I had en route to giving the casinos $2,000. Why, yes, I'll grab a cheesesteak to eat when back in Hampton Roads!

It wasn't until noon when I had this deliciousness and despite killing time with a flight, nap, and running errands, I was so happy to devour this cheesesteak. And damn was this a good choice! It was tasty. The cheese whiz held its own. I was one happy traveler.

Sure, there are many other cheesesteak options that Philadelphia has to offer but given the circumstances, this was my best (and only) choice.

Top tip: the morning menu only shows breakfast items. Don't be shy, ask for a cheesesteak. They'll make it for you. Eat one at the airport and grab an extra for the air. Sooooo worth it.
Thought it very good food.  Slow service, so prepare for that but food was very good .  Add onions and mushrooms to your Philly steak... Customer service is not their forte but food is !!

I've tried to fall in love with Tony Luke's as it's the most notable cheesesteak in the airport, but always feels like something is missing. Tip here is to never order mild provolone because then the steak is very bland! I would say you'll find a better cheesesteak most anywhere in Philly but if you're in a pinch and you are near the terminal to go for it. Very ok food but nothing worth going out of the way for.

Good, reasonably priced food, although you should be prepared for a bit of a wait.  Everything is prepared fresh, so you might be waiting 15 minutes or more for a chicken parm sandwich, depending on how busy they are.  Just grab a seat nearby & wait for your number to be called & then enjoy (until you notice that the city of Philadelphia has put a surcharge on fountain drinks).

Roast pork wasn't bad, really it wasn't. The cheese and broccoli rabe were present, it was a bit salty. A little bigger for the price would have been nice. The fries were old and limp. If I had the hutzpah I'd if asked for some to be made but the service was not warm and welcoming.

My usual airport indulgence: Tony Luke's Terminal F at Philadelphia Airport. The staff here is actually very pleasant contrary to the general atmosphere of this airports staff. Are usually opt for the same sandwich beef, Liz and provolone or American. Left off them mushrooms this time round them up today and two sweet peppers. Fast, hot, served with a smile. TIP: if you're traveling with more than one person, have them cut the sandwiches two were four slices which is more than enough. Unless you are a professional eater, this sandwich can easily get the best of you.TIP 2: This is the best place to charge your phone at Philadelphia airport. One of the only places you can find a working outlet.

I didn't try the sandwiches right after I purchased them, so my review may not be the most accurate. Since I had a few hours layover before my next flight, I decided to pull a crazy stunt and take the bus to Terminal F and check out Tony Luke's. The least amount of time it'll take to go back and forth between Terminal F is probably an hour- the bus ride over takes 10-15 minutes each way, then you have to order and wait for your food, and catch the next bus that comes. Also, it'll take 10-15 minutes to get your sandwich at Tony Luke's, even though the line isn't that long. I decided to try:

-Junior Italian Roast Pork (w/Sharp Provolone, Broccoli Rabe, $7.59, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tony-lukes-philadelphia-6?select=GB5t3XxaxRhk0IGYfW12TQ#GB5t3XxaxRhk0IGYfW12TQ): Eh, just ok. The pork was really salty, and it got a little soggy from the broccoli rabe, so not even popping it in the toasted oven helped. If you order this, I don't think provolone is the way to go. I would give this another try but eat it right away.
-Traditional Cheesesteak (w/Mild Provolone, $8.49, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/tony-lukes-philadelphia-6?select=GB5t3XxaxRhk0IGYfW12TQ#5wQKfJkavtj6wcFMPFsyFA): I opted for provolone vs. whiz so it wouldn't get soggy, and I think I would've enjoyed this much more with the whiz. However, the bread was good, as was the steak, and I would order this again.

I didn't think that the cheesesteak or roast pork from Tony Luke's was amazing, and better than other cheesesteaks I've had in Philly. However, since I didn't eat the sandwiches right away, I'll have to hold off on my final opinion until then.

I was starving after what I thought was a long flight! We arrived at the Philly airport in the morning so I see a Tony Lukes . I'm thinking "Philly cheese steaks for breakfast ...don't mind if I do!" I told my husband he  had to order a philly cheesesteak too because we are in Philly!  I was definitely ordering one of those and then I see Salt & Vinegar fries!! What!! I had to read that again to make sure it wasn't a hallucination.  It was true and I was adding it to the order. While I was waiting for my order I was second guessing myself thinking the fries will probably overly salty where I can't eat any of it. I was thinking about canceling it but my order was ready. I tasted the sandwich with the perfectly salted fries and loved every bite of it!

When is airport food ever good? I felt like the philly cheesesteak could've been better, it was super oily and a bit dry and the bread.... too much of it. I was on a layover here in philly and I said when in philly always get a cheesesteak! yea, never again at the airport.

It's like Pat's and Geno's had a baby and named it Tony. It's chopped steak, which I prefer, on a substantial roll. God forbid the bread be 3 minutes past stale, because it would render this sandwich inedible.

I don't understand the local obsession with "crab fries" because if I'm getting something with "crab" in the name, I want actual crab meat. The dusting of crab boil spice/Old Bay was actually pretty good. The fries were very hot and crispy. The dusting of the Old Bay was generous.

As far as the location goes: it's in an airport. Don't expect much atmosphere. Except for the people watching while waiting for your number to be called out. 

Would I eat here again? In a wit onions and Whiz heartbeat.

Woah. Not good. If you are thinking, hey I'm in Philly airport so I should actively seek out a cheesesteak... think twice. What they serve here isn't a cheeses teak.  It's a mess, dry, and bland. I've had better cheesesteaks at mall food courts 

Save the moment and enjoy your first real cheesesteak in town at Johns Roast Pork. Or Pat's. 

I've not been to a real Tony Luke's so I can't say where they rate in the totem pole of cheesesteak-dom. And I've heard so many good things about Tony Luke's that i wet one judge then based upon this nasty mess. But if tony lukes is anywhere near as good as John's, Pat's, or Genos  I highly suggest they cut ties with this poopshow at the airport.  It's really killing their cred.

Out.

(4) ~ very good overall food & service. Notes: You have to ask for Fried Onions, as they aren't listed on the menu.  And if you ask to put on ketchup, be sure to get extra packets at the end as they don't put much on;)

MENU:
** Cheese Steak(w. Fried onions, Ketch-up, Whiz & Provolone) = (4] very good
** French Fries = (4) very good, best described as McDonald's Fries with the skin still on them;)

You know that saying "When in Rome, do what the Romans do"?  Well here's a different saying "When in Philly, DON'T come here".  Like you, I was fooled by the advertising that they won all these awards from Zagat and had these amazing reviews.  So why not?

Pros:
+ Philly Cheesesteak.  In Philly.  Only if you're desperate for a sandwich and can't leave because of a short layover.
+ Fries big and meaty.

Cons:
- Fries Bland.  they just threw the fries in a bag, shook it up, and gave it to me.  Even then, it was just...fries.  Very generic taste, even Burger King is better than this.
- Sandwich is big, but overall empty and unfulfilling (like a push-up bra).
- Even ketchup didn't help.  In fact, it made it bearable.  Thanks ketchup, you get 5/5 stars!
- Barely tasted the mushrooms in my sandwich. Onions were diced up.  Seriously? Thinly sliced mushrooms and diced onions?  It should be thick mushrooms and ring sliced onions.  
- Manager kind of a douche.  He was nice to the clients, but talked down to his employees right in front of customers.  Personally, I despise two-faced people like this.

Do yourself a favor and disregard those fake news reviews.  This place is garbage and you should STAY FAR AWAY.

Try the Chinese food.  The Romans probably did.

My family and I enjoyed their indulgent, tasty and affordable food recognized by the Food network twice. 

Pros: The Philly cheese and the Broccoli rabe were delicious.
The restaurant is clean and kid-friendly.

Cons: The Cheddar sauce was over-powering on the French fries.

An open letter to Tony Luke! 
Dear Sir,
I have touted your cheesesteak as the best in Philly for many years. I've been to many of the cheesesteak icons all over Philadelphia and after I tried them all I found meat cheese and bread your sandwich ruled! I would look forward to a hip through Philadelphia airport to Newark so I can grab a sandwich and also a fabulous Roast Pork Broccoli Rabe. Well sir sadly the sandwich I got today was a sad showing. Where's the beer is my battle cry! All the fuel is here but it's not making a big fire. Half of my sandwich was gone and I didn't even take a bite. Smaller bread less meat and my beloved Tony Luke's cheesesteak has been economically downsized.  
I'm going to need to eat something after nibbling on this tidbit!  I hope you come visit you airport location and make this right. Next time I get to Philly I'm going to the original location just to see if the real Tony Luke's still exists.  
Faith be willing,
Thanks for listening. 
FoodDude!

Look people, if youz think your gonna get the best cheese steak in Philly at Terminal F, then you deserve to be in Terminal F. 

Just appreciate that if youz was too stoopid to find a good cheesesteak among the million or so places OUTSIDE the airport, you can still pretend.

We came here on our philly layover. Im Not sure why people are crazy over "philly cheese steak" subs. They are boring and plain and nothing like the ones we have in New York. My boyfriend had one from here and never having a true Philly cheese steak sub. He was disappointed. It was basically all meat, dry meat. Minimal onions, no peppers and it came with a side of cheese whiz. Gross. There was of course no cheese on the sub. I tried a bite of it and was thankful that I didn't order from there. There was NO flavor. The ones in New York are sloppy and delicious with loads of cheese, onions, and peppers) next time we go to Philadelphia we will be sure to steer clear of the original sub. Maybe  ours was just bad but I doubt it. Glad we tried it though so now we know.
Not as good as I remember...or did my palate grow up?  The bread seemed chewy ...like it had been microwaved.  The meat had no flavor and seemed a teeny bit ...tough.

My first real "authentic" Philly. Yes it was in an airport and yes this is probably a watered down commercialized version but it was still absolutely delicious.
Best cheese steak I've had to date.
It really makes me want to have a reason to go to Philly and try all of the legendary cheese steak joints.
Around $10, for a foot-long sandwich.
The bread had a nice chewy texture which held up to the meat and onion and juices... I only got a little soggy toward the end and I had ran through the airport with it so I can't complain.
The steak was great quality, hot tender and delicious. The steak paired perfectly with the peppers and onions and cheese wiz. I am not a wiz fan per se but I had to go for the original. It's a bit salty but it really works with the sandwich. 
The service here was fine. No problems. I had an adequate amount of napkins provided.
If you're like me and you've never been to philly and you have a layover or connection at the airport it's an absolute must try.
Where does one begin with this epically bad and disappointing sub, well let's try the dry meat and tasteless bread. No jalapeños just blah blah

Just as I was starting to feel sorry for myself for having to travel for work the week of Thanksgiving, this little gem came beaming at me like a ray of sunshine with rainbows and kittens! I have been to Tony Luke's many times while in the Philly area and cannot get enough of their roast pork with provolone and broccoli rabe. The pork is so tender and juicy and the sharp provolone and broccoli rabe cut thru the richness of the pork. The fries were hot and crispy too. This location is just as good as the rest. Well done Tony!

Salty, ill prepared crap. I ordered the legendary pork sandwich end it was in fact legendary - legendary as in one of the worst salt sandwiches I have ever had. On top of that I ordered broccoli Rabe. It had so little broccoli Rabe that it was not even visible. I've seen more parsley on potato salad. The french fries were cold mushy it tasted like frozen turd.

It was so bad I made the trip back and returned the entire meal. That is when the manager kicked in as well as the grill team. They accepted responsibility and made me a new sandwich.

I have eaten enough meals to know when it is corporates fault and not those on the ground. The food was not fresh and the recipe is overly salty. 

Cold fries is on the staff. They are a rare treat and should be served hot an crisp. I eat oatmeal in the morning. 


The second sandwich was just as bad. It's the ingredients - terrible.
The fries were hot and crispy this time but again way to salty. 

Note to Tony Luke - you can add salt, you can't take it off. Also  the broccoli rabe was tasteless and mushy. You got an extra star for the staff and store manager. The food is crap.

The Cheese steak and fries are excellent, came here two times while connecting through philly, the staff however is the lack of 2 stars.

Look I'm from Texas I don't eat many Cheesesteaks, but when I ask what should I order, I don't expect *That you order something* is the right response. 

The food quality is excellent and the Maryland fries are delicious. If your having a quick layover in Philly, grub here, but don't expect any service or friendliness from the staff and please dont give me that "it's philly" bull$#4. We are humans are should be treated to a higher standard than the local level of intelligence. 

Also the tables that you sit at in the food court be sure to use your own hand sanitzer and wipe your own tables, the bus boys/girls just stand around on their cell phones while you look at a dirty table and then them and they just continue to text instead of offering to clean you table. Good luck.

Though, this may not be the best cheese-steak sandwich I've had in Philly, it is really not bad, especially for a chain.  I've found myself eating here, when in terminal F food court, instead of my usual SMASH Burger.  Everything is fresh, including the bread, and the toppings you can choose are also good.   I've had some really good cheese-steak sandwiches in Philly, and really the only thing missing here, is a little more meat and spices.  But, heck, for airport sandwich it's pretty darn good.

Out of all my cheesesteaks during my visit to Philadelphia, this last meal in the airport was the best.

Located in the middle of terminal F, Tony Luke's serves a huge cheesesteak full of meat, cheese, and onions (optional). It was also the least messy cheesesteak I had in Philly, which I definitely appreciated. Most other ones I'd tried were super sloppy and saucy, but the Tony Luke's one held together without running all over the place. The staff here were also friendly, and the made-to-order sandwich only took 5 minutes. I actually didn't eat it until an hour later on the plane, but it stayed warm and tasty despite the delay.

So if you're hungry and need a tasty and filling choice (and if you have enough time to hike over to terminal F), visit Tony Luke's for your airport grub.

I was hungry and I had an hour to kill at the Philadelphia airport so I figured when in Rome...or Philly I must get a taste.  I'm assuming this is somewhat of a chain to be in the airport but because it's a local chain I felt like I could trust it.  They had a brightly lit neon sign that said fresh bread and all sorts of awards hanging behind the counter.  This may be the closest thing to a Taste of Philly I'm going to get for awhile. 

I ordered the junior steak with American cheese.  The bread was chewy and soft and there was plenty of cheese.  They kind of skimped on the meat but what was on there had good flavor and hit the spot for what I was looking for. 

I'd definitely try this again.. maybe an actual one in the city.

This Tony Luke's location is in the food court of Terminal F after the security checkpoint at Philadelphia International Airport. It's a great place to grab a quick sandwich while you're at the airport. Last month I flew from my home airport in Norfolk, Virginia to Akron-Canton Airport to visit my parents in Ohio. I had a layover in Philly. I lived in Philadelphia from 1986 to 1994 during which time I developed a love for the traditional Philly cheesesteak. As soon as I noticed my flight had a layover in Philly I immediately knew I would have a cheesesteak at Tony Luke's.

After landing at the airport I easily located the food court. Tony Luke's has chicken and pork sandwiches in addition to its cheesesteaks. They also offer a breakfast menu but to me there is no choice, it's got to be a cheesesteak and fries. I stepped up to the counter and ordered my cheesesteak the traditional South Philly way with onions and Cheez Whiz, I had them add a little mayonnaise as well. I also ordered French fries and a soda. The order process was quick and easy, the employees were friendly and polite. The kitchen is open so you can watch your order being prepared, no surprises here. 

After a few minutes my order was ready so I had a seat at a table in the food court and dug right in. I first observed the sandwich was just a tad smaller than what I was expecting but it looked great and tasted even better. The first bite hit my taste buds and immediately set off the pleasure censors in my brain. As the grease ran down my arm I kept thinking that this exactly how a cheesesteak should taste. Everything was properly proportioned and seasoned to perfection. The bread was just right with a little crunch on the outside and a nice soft interior. Most Philly cheesesteak joints use an Amoroso roll but Tony Luke's sources their bread from Liscio's Bakery and bakes it fresh in the store every day. The results are very nice. The roll does not taste the same as Amoroso but is every bit as delicious. On to the natural cut fries. They were spot on, hot and crispy on the outside with a delicious soft center, seasoned just right. The portion size was generous and I ate every last one. Everything was so good that I had the exact same thing on my return trip a few days later. I enjoyed my second visit just as much as the first.

I really don't understand the low rating this restaurant has on Yelp because I found the food quality to be excellent. The cheesesteak was fabulous, the fries were delicious and the service was first rate. Every item is made to order so your food is always hot and fresh. The place was clean and presentable. I will concede the prices are a little steep ($16.92 including tax and Philadelphia soda surcharge for cheesesteak, fries and soda) but that's to be somewhat expected at an airport. Truth be told, I would give them five stars if the prices were a little lower.  I had two great dining experiences here a few days apart and will definitely make a point to do it again on future visits to Philadelphia International Airport.

Yo Adrian, Tony Lukes ranks #2 in the cheesesteak wars of Philly!  But damn that's almost as good as #1. That coveted 5 star goes to Pat's ( sorry it's my review) Let's face it anytime you have steak, melted cheese goo loaded onto a bun, how does this culinary delight go wrong?


Now I like my steak sandwich with fried onions and a molten hot layer of provolone melting throughout mine. Others want that golden pump shit called WIZ but not I. In the end buy it with anything you want on it cause it's all good. 

My suggestions is know what you want prior to ordering or face the wrath.  Having the Philly verbal wrath of God laid on you with furious vengeance for asking a dumb ass questions is just not worth it. 

Ok now back to review. Order some fries , coke and steaming hot cheesesteak. It's so damn good! Keep in mind Tony has many meat options so grab a few sandwiches to try. Who cares about weight watchers you only live once. Just grab a humongous stack of napkins for your flight, this way the goob a goo mess is easily cleaned up and not on you or your neighbors lap.  Forget about it and eat!

Amore Mio serves up the best pizza in Tampa!!!  

It's a traditional Italian style relatively thin crust pizza with the right amount of sauce and cheese.  

It's made in a wood burning oven so its evenly cooked and the crust is crispy but still soft enough to fold.

If you are from the northeast (particularly CT,  NY, & NJ) you'll love it!

Check it out!

I used to live right next to Desi Chaat House and pretty much went there just for the grab-and-go mango lassi. If you're in the area, Mood Cafe is definitely the better out of the two. Depending on how busy they are, they will walk you through what exactly each chaat is (and what chaat is if you've never had it), and will make recommendations for whether you are craving something spicy, savory, sweet, etc. I've stuck to the lamb and beef chaats, but all of them are pretty tasty. Customer service definitely prevails on this one.

Not your regular naan and curry. If you want to try something different, something a little lighter, definitely go to Mood Cafe.

Mood Cafe serves up a variety of chaats (snacks), which are essentially crispy flakes mixed with dates, different spices / sauces, meats (optional), beans, potatoes etc. I asked the owner for recommendations, and he recommended me the chicken salad chaat (medium spicy). You cannot go wrong with that! It's a burst of flavor in your mouth and feels healthy at the same time. I wanted to order mild (because though I like spice, I can't take the heat), but I am glad I went with his recommendation for the medium spice. It was perfect (not too spicy at all)

The lassi selection here is probably the most extensive I've seen. I ordered a mango and also tried some of my friend's honeydew. They were both delicious!
