Inside, it's quite charmingly appointed and hits the sweet spot between casual and formal, making it the perfect places for an intimate romantic dinner, or a casual get together with friends over a good bottle of wine.  All the tables are square, white cloth 2-tops, but they can be arranged to accommodate various size groups, including our spacious table for 8.  In contrast to many tiny BYOBs, FF is actually quite roomy--they could probably have squeezed a table or two more, and there is plenty of room to carry on a private conversation or fit your wine and glasses on the table (excellent Guy DeGrenne stems from France).  I think I had 6 glasses in front of me, without problem.

FF has an interesting, short, constantly changing menu (depending on what they have in; and not having either a fridge or freezer, this is an absolute necessity!) divided up into 3 courses of increasing size, each having 4-6 choices, plus a special or two.

We decided to make things difficult for the staff and came up with our own tasting menu, having bigger dishes plated into smaller individual portions to share, and changing up the order of things to better match the wines we had brought (I've uploaded photos for all the dishes):

Bread: Warm rolls, supposedly Parker House-style (although they look more like a muffin) with a crispy exterior and delicate interior, were spread with perfect, lightly salted homemade butter.  After Bibou, the best butter in Philly.

First course: Grilled Spanish mackerel, with shaved fennel, warm citrus vinagrette, pine nuts and grainy mustard.  WOW!  Let me repeat this: WOW!!!  The Beet steak gets all the love, but this was the DOTN (dish of the night).  Quite simple to read it, and seemed like a mish-mash of ingredients, but the sum of the parts was knock-your-socks-off.  Each bite was a different experience, citrus one moment, earthy nuts the next.  A lovely match with the SB.

~Preceded by a 1996 Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin Champagne Brut La Grande Dame and served with 2009 Merry Edwards Russian River Valley Sauvignon Blanc

Second course: Handmade pappardelle with Wyebrook Farm pork shoulder ragu, fennel seed and Parmigiano-Reggiano.  An nice dish, with a good porky flavor to the ragu.  I would order it again, but this was probably the least notable of our courses.  However, the 3 Corners was an unbelievably great bottle of Pinot, massive leather & smoke on the nose, midway between New World and Burgundy, with a long, long finish (WOTN).

~Served with 2005 J. Rochioli Pinot Noir Three Corners Vineyard & 2005 J. Rochioli Pinot Noir Little Hill

Third course: Josh's signature dish of bloody beet steak, with yogurt, shallots, pan drippings, aged balsamic and amaranth.  Yes, this is worthy of being a signature dish, with a rich, meaty texture and flavor that prompted us to move it back in the lineup and pair it with a couple of Chateauneuf-du-Papes and a cab (I think the latter was the best match).  But, sorry, I still think that mackerel was The Man!

~Served with 2004 Clos de Papes Chateauneuf-du-Pape & 2003 Domaine du Pegau Chateauneuf-du-Pape (didn't catch the bottling) & 2002 Dominus Napanook Red.  The Pegau was a very fine wine with lots of saddle leather and barnyardy hay on the nose.

Fourth course: Rare New York venison with farmer's cheese spaetzel.  This was apparently a entree special for which there were only two plates left, so we split a slice each.  Perfectly tender, perfectly rare, on crispy/chewy spaetzel.

~Served with more of the 3 reds above.

OK, running out of space, so click the link below for Part 2 of my review:

Lovely farm-to-table spot that does BYOB. 
Delicious menu - we struggled to do not order everything. Everything seem fresh and tasty in that way that actual food tastes unlike the Sysco sourced food we eat about everywhere else. 
Handsome and warm dining room. Equally warm (and, sure, handsome) staff. 
Wonderful dinner - if this was in my neighborhood it would be our go-to.  Also, don't go here during that week where you want to give up bread as their Parker House rolls are spectacular. 

Two minor things.  
The beet steak (which everyone recommended) was odd in that the skin of the beet was still on there and proved to make things a bit more messy. Meh. 
Things moved a bit slow. That's not an issue, really. You're here for a nice evening already. We sat without wine or bread for way too long and our first course took excessively long to arrive. Maybe it was because I was starving that I noticed that.  

All said, great dinner!

Part 2 of my review (see above for Part 1):

Fifth course: Natural strip steak, confit potatoes, spinach & brown butter puree, trumpet mushrooms and wild watercress.  Cooked medium rare, as tender as a filet and really made that Pegau sing.  [I also tried enjoyed some of the Virginia wild striped bass as well.]

~Served with the 3 reds mentioned below.

Dessert: Maple Napoleon, a simple, refined version with only a few crispy phyllo layers separated by delicate, lightly sweet cream.  A pleasant end to the meal.  I also tried a bit of the walnut molten chocolate cake...and I'm so over molten chocolate cake (Blackfish makes the best one)...and this was a nice change from the tried and true version.

~Served with 1975 Chateau Climens Sauternes

Service was fantastic: knowledgeable, unobtrusive, well paced and on top of the details (like reminding me to take the Sauternes off ice while we were eating our mains, so it wouldn't be too cold for dessert).  $92/person (counting a good-sized tip).

Even if based on only 1 visit, well deserving of 5 stars.

But how about changing the name to: THE BEET AND MACKEREL?

Sláinte!

When Judy Ni Tessier (one of the most engaging front of the housers in Philly) & Andy Tessier (Sous Chef) recently announced that they were leaving The Farm and Fisherman, which they have helped Josh & Colleen Lawler turn into one of Philly's finest restaurants, we knew we had to share some Champagne with them, and remember all the great meals we've had at F&F over the past several years.

Although F&F doesn't usually offer a tasting menu, they will do one if you ask, and Chef Andy really stepped up to the plate with one of the most memorable meals we've ever had at this wonderful restaurant.  See the photos I've posted...

9 courses (several of them off-menu), 8 bottles of wine, and 5 hours later, all I can say is that I can't wait to see what this charming and talented couple will do next...

Their last day is April 17th 2014, so you still have time to visit before they leave. Since Josh has been spending a lot of time at the new Cherry Hill restaurant, we'll have to see who he chooses to fill Andy's shoes. Judy and Andy have been with the Lawlers since the beginning, so they will be tough to replace...

For my more detailed review of F&F, click below.

The menu changes frequently so I'm not sure how helpful the specifics will be, but  Farm and the Fisherman felt like many other BYOBs in the city. I guess its a testament to the fantastic dining options in Philly, however, nothing felt new about the restaurant. As I glanced over the menu I was sad to note that there was nothing that really stood out to me. 
   That being said, minus our sad dessert, everything we tasted was made quite well. The bloody beet steak app (which seems to be a menu stalwart) was awesome. A strangely warm and incredibly delicious beet app which I can't recommend enough. Our crab app (not on menu) was meh and my main fish course (also been replaced) was perfectly cooked, but lacked seasoning. I love the fact that the menu didn't make me feel like I should run out and go on a liquid detox diet (everything was lightly prepared and flavorful), but a few things (i.e. the fish) could have really used some salt..
  As for the dessert. Lets hope the yogurt panna cotta (weird) was replaced. Even our waiter noted that we barely took a bite out of this strange concoction, and was kind enough to deduct it from the bill. At any rate, a tasty BYOB in the city, but not amazing by any means..

Fabulous BYO.
Get the bloody beet steak. It blew my mind!!! AMAZING!!! Thick slab of beet. I don't know how they cooked it, but it is awesome and so is the sauce.
I also tried the Duck ravioli which was very good, but unfortunately for me, the beet steak really overpowered it. It was a lovely dish, but unmemorable and didn't really wow me.
The red snapper with tarragon, fennel grapfruit and potato gratin was wonderful. Lightly seasoned and cooked to perfection. It was a great dish and the flavors worked well together.
The duck leg dish with risotto was also very good. Earthy tone to it. A little heavy, which is expected. Very delicious.
Every dish was very well done. I would return for the beet steak in a heartbeat and also for the red snapper.
Service was very friendly and attentative. Cannot beat a BYO. Small restaurant so you typically need a reservation.
A bit pricey, but this is definitely a place where you come for the food quality. Nothing was itty bitty so it was all worth it.

The first dinner out for our Philly family feastgiving. We called many weeks ahead, they were unable to accommodate a party of 12 so they said they would set up two tables of 6. (at least they were willing, unlike another orange colored squash restaurant) Kind of ridiculous since all the tables are two tops, just make some tetris like moves and make it happen. 

Like other reviewers we showed up a few minutes early for our reservation. One table was set the other we had to wait almost 30 minutes for. Thankfully there was another large party celebrating a birthday so as we moved from table to table to visit we weren't a disruption. 

The service of constantly rotating silverware and wine pouring was friendly and timely. A sense of humor shared for our carlo rossi growler. The little clover bread rolls were delicious and they brought more upon request. 

Items that were sampled, 

Scallops that had a wonderful crispy pan sear. The lardons were crisp. 

Beet salad seemed to have the beet skin intact, which was a puzzler but delicious. 

Kampachi, just lightly seared which had a smokey undertone and bright pomegranate. 

Stuffed rabbit saddle, very mild, tender and highlighted by a herb sauce and truffle.

Stripped bass was seared well, the vegetables were well seasoned and caramelized. 

Duck breast was served rare, some slices were a but chewy, the farro and veg a great consistency.

Boar shank was fall apart tender atop greens, hearty winterish meal.

Pappardelle with pork shoulder ragu was another winterish meal, with tender diced veg. 

Strip steak was cooked as ordered, blue corn polenta wasn't a favorite of anyone, but the brussels sprouts were well caramelized

We ended with a few chocolate napoleons, the filo dough was treated with caramel and sea salt, highlighted with fresh whipped cream. It was a nice rich yet light end bite. 

We all had a great time and would return. Overall comments concluded that the protein servings were inconsistent but the vegetable preparations were spot on.

I still remember the first time I came to the Farm and Fisherman, back at the beginning of the farm-to-table craze. The restaurant has grown in leaps in bounds since then, with great service, beautiful plating, and an exciting and cohesive menu that showcases the flora and fauna of the Northeast beautifully.

The space is intimate, simple but classy. Despite close quarters and a full restaurant, the sound level stayed surprisingly quiet. Our server was knowledgeable and friendly, and our dishes arrived promptly.

The food itself is beautiful - each dish looks like a piece of art. I ordered the smoked mushroom salad; the ingredients, from tart kumquat to smoky mushroom, created a vibrant palate of different flavors and textures. The hamachi crudo was amazing as well - the orange juice perfectly highlighted the natural sweetness of the fish, and the fish itself was velvety and incredibly fresh. I had the poached egg as my second course - the flavors were all wonderful, though I would have liked some more brioche to balance out the liquid from the egg and the saltiness of the pancetta. 

For mains, I had the lamb loin, which was just amazing. The lamb was incredibly tender and the preserved blueberries provided the perfect tangy accent. The chicken baked in hay was good, but unfortunately, we could not taste the sweet, grassy flavor supposedly imparted into the chicken by the hay; that delicate flavor may have been overpowered by the curry and all-spice that flavored the vegetables.

The desserts were both excellent - I loved the decadent, slightly salty taste of the chocolate napoleon, but the more mellow panna cotta was lovely as well.

The chef has a lot of creativity and really knows how to make local ingredients sing. We only booked a table because we heard that the Farm and Fisherman will soon be moving to the suburbs, and we regret that we did not try them out sooner. It is wonderful to find a restaurant where subsequent visits improve on prior ones in every way - I look forward to visiting them as they move onto their next chapter.

I've been searching for a new favorite BYOB restaurant ever since Matyson closed so we gave this guy a shot for date night last week. BYOB - no corkage fee, accepts credit card.

We had a really nice dinner. Service was professional, friendly and not overbearing. She came by to answer our questions, but gave us plenty of time between ourselves for our date. 

Although the website did warm they change their menu quite often -- I was still sad to find out the black truffle gnocchi of my dreams was not on the menu. Instead we started out with the mushroom risotto, cauliflower salad and we each had Hake and Arctic Char for our entrees. 

The fish were both cooked to perfection. My dish came over a bed of barley and red risotto. The entrees left nothing to be desired, so hats off to the chef. The risotto is to DIE for, get this. Get this. If you like mushrooms, get this. Am I being clear enough? My only wish was that it was in a deeper and bigger plate, because I licked that whole plate up. 

Dessert was good but nothing to write home about. Presentation was beautiful. 
Based on that experience, I would definitely consider Farm and Fisherman for a return visit, with a bottle or two in hand .

Service was absolutely amazing. I can't not speak highly enough about how wonderful the people are at this place. We came without a reservation and were informed that they could take us right then, but they had a table coming in an hour. PERFECT! :-) I took a seat while my husband went driving around. I ordered right away so I wouldn't take up a lot of their time. Unfortunately, my husband spend literally half an hour trying to find parking. I requested the food be packed to go because I was afraid I would run out of time they gave us. Then right when I asked them to pack it up, he found a spot. The server was so kind and made us a whole new dish. I can not thank them enough!!!! You can tell when someone is genuinely nice vs nice in front of your face and then when they get to the back, want to throw a tray at the wall. At the end of our meal, they apologized (I don't even know why!!!) They said sorry for making us feel rushed (which they didn't) and even gave us a complimentary dessert to go. This is what I call true service. 

Onto the food - This is a place that seems like they change their menu often (based on what is available and fresh), so I do not want to get into much detail on each dish we ordered, but I must say that everything we ate was DELICIOUS! The risotto was nice and light and so flavorful. All of their foods had a balance of sweet, salty, savory, etc. It was just perfect. The scallops were seared wonderfully and the beef was cooked to perfection. I can not tell you how much I loved it here. Oh, and the muffin bread....OMG! It's like crack. I loved it. Mmmm, so buttery and moist and flaky. I hope they serve this on an everyday basis!

Next time, i will make sure to make a reservation. :-) Thank you for such an amazing date night with my husband!

I still remember when I dined at Blue Hill in NYC with my family for my birthday. I had specifically requested that restaurant because it was at the forefront of the whole 'farm-to-table' concept, which was relatively new at the time. It was one of the best meals we had had in NYC, so simple and yet the flavors were remarkable. When I heard about The Farm and Fisherman opening up where Paul used to be, and more importantly that the chef was of Blue Hill fame, I really really REALLY wanted to try them out asap.

I mentioned it only once to my bf, and when my birthday approached he announced that dinner reservations were already taken care of and 'it was a surprise.' I love surprises, but I was a little wary - not that he chose a bad place, but I assumed it wasn't The Farm and Fisherman because my own little sleuthing had turned up zero available reservation times there - until 3 weeks later. Imagine my ecstatic surprise when we arrived there.

The interior has been transformed since Paul, and the warm, intimate vibe is perfect for the space. It's very small, which is one reason reservations are hard to get, and perhaps a bit close quarters but the food makes you forget about anything else. And since it's BYO, everyone arrives with their drinks and proceeds to enjoy them as much as they do the food.

It was a tough call, but we started off with their Kirby Cucumber Soup (Buttermilk, sour gherkins, chocolate mint), which was creamy and refreshing, and the Smoked Rainbow Trout (Bacon, pea puree, spicy cress, bachelor's buttons), a dish that we agreed was the best smoked trout we'd ever had (yep, better than Telepan). I'm not a big lamb eater, but my bf really wanted to try the entrée because it was seasonal and I have to say that the Braised Lamb Shoulder (New potatoes, Poblano pepper, merguez), had wonderful complementary tastes that built in flavor with each bite. I personally preferred two 'second courses' for my entrée and ordered the Stuffed Quail (Smoked zucchini, apricots, pistachios) and Poached Jennings Farm Egg (Peas, hazelnuts, patty pan squash, pancetta, morels). The quail was fantastic - it's only half of one, but the apricots it's stuffed add a nice sweet-tart flavor to the game hen. My bf initially questioned my choice with the egg, but one bite shut him up. It's the best dish we ordered, and such a wonderful surprise. The poached egg sits in a semi-stew of fresh peas (seriously, the freshest I've ever had EVER), patty pan squash chunks, morels, roasted hazelnuts and the lingering smokiness of pancetta. It's a party on the plate AND in your mouth - the combination of colors, flavors and textures created an absolutely unforgettable dish. I couldn't have asked for more - and almost couldn't finish it! We had a lot of food, so unfortunately dessert was out of the question, but I really didn't care. It was the best dinner I have had all year, and such a perfect way to celebrate my birthday.

Lovely meal at a quaint restaurant, but I can't give this restaurant a full 5 stars.

First off, the menu is a little limited, but that's because you're really leaving it up to the chef and whatever ingredients are freshest.  That's the concept, and the chef is very talented.

The space itself is a little small, so you can hear other people's conversations quite readily which became awkward for me near the beginning of our meal.

I harmlessly asked if I could do another vegetable instead of potatoes with my striped bass, this confused my waiter (the look on his face was priceless), but then he went back to the kitchen asked about it, and I could hear everything they were saying.  This literally took about 8-10 minutes, and I was like I don't care.  They said not a problem, but then when I received my dish it had the potatoes anyway.  If I were an internet dude I'd use the SMH acronym here.  I just did.

I don't want the newbie waiter's service to take away from the food, since that was outstanding.

Here's what we did:

Wine -- BYOB!

Bread (3/5) -- I'm not a big bread guy, but this was more like a muffin and lacked sophistication.

Leek Soup (4/5) -- Very good for a rainy evening.  A touch buttery, but not in a bad way.  There was a pea shoot garnish which I asked about to make conversation with the waiter; this turned into another "everyone-in-the-restaurant-hears" debate between the servers and the chef.  It was very good nonetheless

Kampachi (5/5) -- Easily the highlight for me.  It's seared (grilled?) on one side and raw on the other.  Sashimi-grade quality, and a good portion with just the right amount of sweet garnish with the dish

Striped Bass (4/5) -- These guys know how to cook a fish.  Tender on the inside, just a touch of crispness on the outside.  Served with purple cauliflower, regular cauliflower, and...potatoes!  Light on the sauce, so I did not feel like a blob after eating.  A goodish 7-ounce portion of fish, I'd guesstimate

I passed on dessert and did a coffee, which happened to be very good since they brewed it up fresh.

Crowd seemed local and very pleasant.  The restaurant veered from warm to a touch chilly, so I'm not sure if they were having some heating issues.

i'd definitely go again, but not banging down doors to get there.  Gut feeling is that this would be 5 stars with a more experienced waiter and during the warmer, summer months when the fruit of the earth is in full bloom.

Small, cozy, intimate, romantic setting. The atmosphere is so pleasant and everyone that worked there was so friendly and genuinely happy to help with anything. My bf and I each did 3 courses. While the portions initially look small, they are more than plenty. We forgot that we had each ordered three courses and they were timed perfectly in coming out. 

It's BYOB so that's awesome because you don't have to spend a fortune on drinks. For the main course I had bacon wrapped trout (umm WHAT?! how could I not order it?) - it was cooked PERFECTLY. 

For dessert we got the dark chocolate dessert which was amazing and gets an A+ for taste and presentation. We were both already so full, so splitting it was the perfect end to our evening.

Can't wait to go back here - definitely make a reservation in advance as they get busy busy!

I know they're closing the Philly location so this review is kind of pointless but we had a fantastic meal here last night and typing about it will help me relive the delectable flavors so here we go. 

I had an unused giftcard for this cute lil BYO from 2013 (unsure how I let that happen), so when I read online that they would be closing I went into a panic and immediately booked a reservation for 4 for Sunday night. I will say there was some confusion surrounding my party size and reservation time, but let's just chalk that up to a last-weekend-open snafu. No biggie.

First of all, you had me at BYO. The restaurant was empty upon arrival, and my boyfriend and his parents and I were seated nearest the kitchen. I liked the clean and simple look of the place. Our wine and water glasses were consistently full, and our waitress offered to answer any questions that we might have had about the menu (it's kind of an intimidating menu, to be honest). The menu is designed to be a flight of 3 courses, but we each went with 2 and had plenty of food to share amongst the four of us. The parker house rolls that were brought out at the beginning of the meal were delicious and fluffy. This is turning into a 50 pager (South Park, anyone?) so I'll try to keep it short from here on out. Just note though- this is no cheap date. 8 plates ran us about 200 dollars.

-Asparagus risotto: 5 stars
-Spring soup: 5 stars
-Bass: 5 stars
-Steak: 4.5 stars
-Pasta with ragu: 4.5 stars
- Mackarel: 4.5 stars 
-Chicken: 4 stars 

Not only were these plates delicious, fresh, and filling, but the presentation was downright artistic. Beautiful job.

We were too full for dessert but I have to say I was pleasantly surprised, since I expected this to be one of those "let's charge 30 dollars a plate for a portion appropriate for a 5 year old of some fancy food that no one knows how to pronounce" places.

This was long awaited for and a very special surprise. I've been having this new thing lately for trying out all of the upscale, foodie locales that are BYO in this city. What is better than amazing food paired with your very own choice of wine (that costs less than half the price of the restaurants bottles)? 

This is a very cozy little spot on Pine. Something about Pine St (OK, maybe a few things) makes me really happy, so finding this spot tucked away on a quite spot at 11th and Pine was special. Very minimal decor, but cozy enough to feel like you're dining at your family holiday dinner. I think it would be a great spot for a small group to celebrate a special event. 

I'm currently eating pescetarian with my man, and they did not at all disappoint if you are looking for seafood or vegetables. We shared 2 1st courses, 2 2nd courses, and 1 main course which ended up being perfect to share between two hungry people. 

Starters were seared tuna and quinoa salad and chilled sweet corn soup with crab cake. The corn soup was FANTASTIC and one of best of the evening. Really sweet and thick, without being too heavy. The bloody beet steak is absolutely to die for as recorded by roughly every previous reviewer. SPOILER ALERT: Maybe I'm not first on this, but if so I need to share that the waitresses outed this to me while I was here - http://www.starchefs.com/cook/recipe/josh-lawler/bloody-beet-steak-beet-pan-jus-yogurt-amaranth-balsamic

Anyway, I must continue. The baked egg/cheese/eggplant was not my favorite, but made up for by the sea bass over polenta. Fish-perfectly cooked, paired really nicely with the polenta. The chocolate mouse napoleon with fried phyllo dough was a little naughty. Perfect to close it all out. 

Our waitress was sweet and helpful-knowledgeable enough to switch up the order of the courses to pair better together. This detail, and the ever changing menu featuring seasonal deliciousness, would encourage me to come back. Next time with more wine.

I picked the Farm and Fisherman for a reunion with two friends from my analyst class that are in school with me, and boy I wish I had picked somewhere else. From perusing the menu online, it looked great! Food looked good, prices were decent. But what you can't tell is that the portions are TINY.

We walked in and felt out of place because the clientele skews much older. When the waitress came to take our order, we each ordered a dish. A look of disdain flashed across her face as she explained that the menu is set up such that we are supposed to order 1 from each of the three sections. Then she huffed away when we asked for more time. Sorry we don't fit your seemingly preferred profile (aka well-off older Caucasians).

We were a bit off put by her attitude. I'm happy to spend money when it's worth it. After all, business school is all about racking up that student debt on travel and alcohol and food. But not if it comes with a side of contempt.

No faults with the food. I just did not find the place welcoming.

Very nice meal. 

I believe the chef should taste some of the dishes post-prep for balance. We had two dishes with hardly any seasoning. 

The ingredients themselves stood firmly and were tasty because they were of impeccable quality. However, a bit of salt would be nice. 

A nice place for farm to table, inventive, clean flavors.

Let me start by saying that the service was excellent and the presentation of every dish was superb.   Now for the details.

Everything I ordered was 5 stars.  Now the menu changes daily, so what may have been an entree on a previous menu was an appetizer (and smaller portion) last night and so on.   Course 1,  I started with the 24 hour slow roasted summer squash, accompanied by a roasted tomato and an unique bbq type sauce.  This was a heavenly dish, flavors melding perfectly.  The grilled octopus for a second course was perfect, the texture, the grill flavor, as good as anywhere,  My main course was striped bass with a herb, cucumber vinaigrette.  The fish was very tasty, cooked perfectly, but the skin could have been a touch more crisp if that was the chef's intention.

I also tasted the other dishes ordered at my table and that's where this restaurant lost one star.  The beet appetizer was good, creative, but not fantastic.  There was an egg dish which looked amazing, but uneventful, so much so I forgot what it came with.  The cobia on the menu, after being explained to others at the table that it was a mild tasting fish, was very fishy tasting.  The two people who ordered that cobia left some on the dish.  I would have too, and it wasn't because there was too much on the plate.

Our dessert choice was a poor one compared to the rest of MY choices, the biscuit with berries and whipped cream.  Only a three star rating for that one.

As I said earlier, the service and food presentation was wonderful, and everything I ordered (I didn't pick the dessert) was fab.

Since the menu changes daily, and being a BYOB some would want to prepare in advance, so bring less than a full bodied red, or any nice white and you will be fine with any of your food selections.

A definite, serious, do-again is in order.  I love "fresh, creative and different", and this fits the bill.

I have had the displeasure of eating here twice and was disappointed both times.  The pompous asswipe attitude of the staff which I thought was just an abnormal thing is clearly the norm.  The food was border line Uneatable the last time I Ed there.

You don't have to mess with food that much. Just give me a frickin monk fish dude. Your poached egg gave me awful diarrhea.  Your rigatoni wasn't bad.  But I had to let my wife eat it.  So I had to order the crappy egg and it gave me diarrhea.  

Any way, they change the dishes daily which means the staff still sucks and they serve different dishes.  

I would go to a different BYOB in Philadelphia.

If you've never dined at The Farm and Fisherman, then please drop what you're doing and go immediately. If you are a regular, you may have one last time to lineup, and get a seat in their superb and lovely dining room. Sorry, had to do it, as The Farm and Fisherman will be closing its doors very soon. 

After a long, busy, and stressful night at work, I felt I didn't want to spend another tough occasion home alone (it was  Mother's Day.) I was tired and stressed; all what I needed was s a gift that doesn't need to be wrapped. I booked a lonely table just for one, and I survived my awesome brunch, thanks to Rachel, my awesome waitress. She made my visit very enjoyable. 

As soon as I saw the innovative brunch menu, I was torn between ordering two small plates and a dessert, or one main dish and a desert. Rachel gave me her opinion on different items on the menu, and I literally wanted to order everything. I decided not to contain myself and get one main dish: Chicken Roasted in Hay (brilliant & delicious,) and a dessert ( was something with strawberry & mascarpone whipped cream.) After enjoying few sips of my first coffee of the day, Rachel returned to my table with a small plate of Ricotta Crostini as a compliments of the chef. (Astonishing, I know!)

How many times have you gotten psyched about some delicious farm-to-table food, that you just couldn't forget the tasty difference?!
Farm and Fisherman, even when you close down, you'll always be one of my favorites.

Four and half Yelps.

The farm and fisherman and their bloody beets steak were on the top of my must-have list in Philadelphia.  It took some effort, but I was able to secure a table of 5 with my girlfriends on a Sunday night.  Please make a reservation if you decide to come because this restaurant is small.  It has about 10 tables, very minimalist with a feel of intimacy.  The only complaint I have is the lack of a hostess when my party entered.  Although they were around and about, no one took the initiative to approach us.  Our evening did get better from that point, so it's a non-issue.

We ordered two of the famous bloody beets steak to share.  This was only my second time trying beets but it made me an instant beets lover!  Now, if only I can have the recipe so I can make my beets like that every time.  That's what the dish does to people.  Even those who hate beets would change their mind.  Oh, it isn't so bad after all.  The yogurt and bulls blood (seriously?) were perfectly harmonious with the beets.  It was sweet and a bit tangy.  Just the right amount of sauce and god, the wonderfully well-cooked beets!  I can't imagine anyone would say this often.

The second course was the Stuffed Rhode Island Squid with chorizo, a special of the day my server mentioned.  It came with two, perfect to share, and the chorizo and Valencia rice were gooooood.  Chewy squid and soft interior.  It was a delicious combination.  The main course for myself was the stuffed trout.  I was worried that it would be an overkill on "stuffed" type of dishes but my server assured me that they are not the same.  I can't decide which I liked more, the stuffed squid or stuffed trout!  The stuffed trout had kale and bacon bits inside with crispy, chewy skin on the outside.  Not to mention, the farm and the fisherman makes the best sauce to compliment their dishes.

I was honestly very happy with my choice - in restaurant and the dishes.  It is currently the best overall meal I've had in Philly (and I've definitely been eating well..thank you Philadelphia and your never ending list of good eats!)

By the way,  I made the reservation on yelp!!  This is way cool :)

Our recent date night at The Farm and Fisherman was pretty flawless. From the food to the service to the restaurant itself, it was a great evening. 

Judy was our server and she was awesome. She knew the menu inside and out and had a real appreciation for food. Obviously, I like that in a server! We started out with delicious parker rolls - it was all I could do to not wolf the entire thing but I was trying to save my cals for the rest of the meal. 

Josh Lawler does some really incredible things with seasonal ingredients. This was showcased especially in the first course: grilled eggplant with burrata, and a slow roasted squash. Both plates were filled with vibrant colors from the ingredients and accompanying sauces. The flavors were wonderful, and every bite was different. 

Next I had scallops, which were served with pastrami and sweet corn. On point. Now that it's a couple weeks later, I don't remember what my dining partner had for his second course, but I do know he enjoyed whatever it was (helpful, I know). 

My main course was a grilled tri tip steak, which was very lean and very tender. It was served with lima beans, which I really liked as an alternate to the usual potato. My boyfriend enjoyed his bacon-wrapped quail. Who wouldn't love a teeny bird wrapped in bacon? 

For dessert we shared a lemon tart which was perfection. I'm literally shaking my head at the memory. Get the tart.

This was our second visit to this restaurant. The first was nearly a year ago, after they first opened. I have to admit, I enjoyed this second visit so much more, and I think it had a lot to do with the seasonal fruits and veggies of late summer. Regardless, I am really looking forward to my next meal at The Farm & Fisherman. This is the kind of place that just gets better and better.

I loved the idea of being totally naked & I def enjoyed the body scrub & massage. Because it was my 1st visit to this particular spa & the employees didn't speak any English, I was a little nervous as I didn't quite understand a couple of the instructions right away.

I went w/ my male friend thinking we'd get a couples massage but the only common area for couples was the lounge, which didn't really feel loungy. The lighting was high & I was expecting there to be water, tea &/or refreshments in the lounge but there was none. 

I'd def return. as they allow you to enjoy the amenities until closing which is @ 11pm. There's also a fitness center, but I didn't have time to see it. It's best to go alone or with a group of ppl of the same sex.

Okay, so I'm trying really hard to write this review in the cleanest way possible, but I really don't know where to begin.

I must say, its a little shocking when you think you are getting a deep tissue massage and body scrub in a private room, then walking into a literal bathhouse, where a bunch of women (old, young, fat and thin) are in "all their glory".  This is not a place for the shy gal, but I decided to not make a scene and go with the flow.

The body scrub was good, but I wasn't crazy about having a half-naked lady climb all over my back for the deep tissue massage, or the countless number of women walking by and checking each other out (I guess you can't help but look at one another).  I can't say anything else without being inappropriate, but they do have private rooms for a dry massage, but not for the body scrub/deep tissue massage package.  

I will come here again, but will not be entering the shower room/hot tub room/body scrub room (its all one big area). Next time, I will opt for a Swedish massage in a private room. The place is clean, their prices are good, and the people who work there are very nice.

I came here for some relaxing services with my friend after a long road trip.

I had the body scrub, which was pretty good - as long as you're okay with being naked and rubbed down in a locker room within full view of everyone.. the saunas, hot tubs, and showers were well maintained - although I felt as though I was being watched - and when your'e naked you don't always want that.

My friend had an hour massage, which she said was very good, but a little rough.  Her complaint was that the staff was cooking fish in the locker room and she smelled it throughout her entire massage.

Love going to this place!  If you're just getting the day pass, I feel like you get a lot of bang for your buck.  Additional services such as massage or body scrub are rather pricey, but they are worth it if you are trying to unwind or for your skin to feel creepily smooth!  The outside of the spa looks a tad sketchy, but the inside is below ground, and has a great retreat-like feel.  I enjoy the showers, the different temperature baths, the sauna, and the steam room.  I also had the pleasure of getting the full body scrub, and it was totally worth it!  Word to the uninitiated - everybody walks around naked since there are separate men's and women's areas, but it gets un-weird very quickly.

For some reason I had higher expectations of this place. I've been to Korean spas all throughout the country and none have been as bad as this one. First and worst of all, it's SMALL. It's not worth the $25 entry fee. My cousin and I went at 8 o'clock and had a scrub and massage scheduled. Upon arriving, we were two out of four women in the placeThe scrubs went well but the massage was lackluster. They used the lightest pressure on me! Once both services were finished, we decided to shower and enjoy the rest of our time enjoying the 
 salt rooms. For those of you unfamiliar with Korean spa rooms, they are supposed to be heated. However, both rooms to the crystal salt rooms were wide open..
We ventured inside to a cold and dark room. Not how it's supposed to be! Apparently, they were getting ready to close (early) and had turned everything off! Unacceptable. With 45 minutes before their scheduled closing time, this was a bit surprising, not to mention disappointing.
They also provide zero amenities for purchase. Most Korean spas have razors, slippers,towels, face masks, additional add-ons to make your stay pleasant. None of that was found here.. only hairdryers.
So basically, We paid $175 each to get a body scrub to take two showers and sit in a steam room. Not to worry though, at least I had a dry head when I ventured out in the cold. This place is a joke. Never again.

Just got back from Chung Dam and it was a good first experience!  I've been to bath houses in LA & SF (both Russian & Korean) but didn't know we had one in NE Philly.  

I went on a Thursday afternoon at 2PM and they didn't have the next body scrub appointment until 4PM.  I didn't think I'd want to soak in the baths or hang out in sauna/steam rooms for 2 hours by myself so I booked a massage for 2:30 which worked perfectly because you need to soak for 10 minutes before body scrub.  So I'd recommend booking an appointment ahead instead of showing up and thinking you can get an appointment in right away.  

It was $140 for a body scrub and shiatsu massage (hey - sometimes you just need to treat yourself!). I should've got the $100 scrub and massage package but she was making it seem like only the shiatsu massage was available - who knows.  The women at the front did speak English. Body masseuse was fully clothed and massage was in a private room(I read reviews where people didn't feel comfortable about being naked in front of other women or masseuse being half naked). Body scrub is behind a wall in bath area - there are 3 tables back there; no one was back there when I was scrubbed and I didn't feel all out in the open.

It seemed like a lot of the bad reviews on here were people getting chastised about tips.  
**All prices include gratuity as of now.**

Daypass admission is $25 and includes the 3 temperature pools (cool, warm, hot), sauna room, steam room, gym, and hot stone rooms (hot yellow clay and hot jade stone).  There's also a dead sea salt room in co-ed lounge where you wear your robe inside (in same sex areas its nude in sauna/steam room and tubs and you change into shirt/shorts for hot yellow clay and hot jade stone rooms). 

There were only 2 other girls in the tubs when I got there, which was nice.  Some more people seemed to trickle in but there were never more than 5 people in the tub/bathing area when I was there.  There were some loud talkers and a grandma did bring a child but maybe other days it may be more quiet. 

How it works:
- You pay at front desk. They give you locker key, robe, bath towel, hand towel (which I used when sitting in sauna).  
- Can put shoes outside of locker room but says it recommends you putting them in locker as they aren't responsible for stolen property.  I think you are supposed to take shoes off before entering locker room
- Change into robe (get naked) and put clothes in locker
- Walk into bath house
- Shower before entering tubs/sauna/steam rooms.  There's shampoo & conditioner (pink bulk but put into tresume and other brand bottles) but no soap? (3 tubs - cool, warm, hot)
- Soak for 10 min if getting body scrub
- Wait for them to call YOUR LOCKER NUMBER when it's time for your appointment (I had an appointment at 2:30 and kept looking around for whoever was supposed to come grab me so I continued to shower.  I walked out into locker room and I guess they wait out there?) I thought she was saying the time of my appointment and I just shook my head yes

Body Scrub (women is in bra & undies - see website for pic if feel uneasy)
- Face Up: She scrubs your body from neck to feet at least 5x
- Face Down: Scrubs neck to feet
- Side: this position was a bit awkward
- Other Side: ...
- Repeat process again, but this time it's faster and with soap
- Little massage at end - best part
- Washes hair
*Actually best part was them pouring buckets of hot water over body every time they finish a side

Hot Stone Rooms require provided undersized shirt and oversized shorts (I was looking for a medium but grabbed a large and seemed like I was wearing a little girls size Large*).  Hot Jade Stone Room is 98 degrees; you can be in there unlimited amount of time and stone contains Ca, Fe, and Mg which is good for people who have high blood pressure and diabetes. Hot Yellow Clay Room is 120 degrees (3-15 min limit) and is said to exert sebum and other impurities, increase blood circulation, kill common cold virus (though may not want to advertise that and have a bunch of sick people), good for arthritis and decrease stress level.  These rooms didn't seem that hot to me and seemed more like yoga rooms - a good place to meditate/rest.  

What to remember for next time:
- flip flops/shower shoes
- face mask would be nice
- if not getting body scrub, bringing own exfoliating mitt might be cool
- soap (you do get soaped at end of body scrub but when I first got it, I thought it was weird they tell you to shower before getting in hot tubs and theres no soap - but there is shampoo and conditioner).

Improvements:
- Hooks for robes/towels
- Soap in bathing area

Typical walgreens. Had to stop here on the way home from the shopping extravaganza with mom to pick up some pain reliever for the niece. Poor thing couldn't figure out the dosage on the kids ibuprophen all because "she wasn't 11" I did explain that being over 11 meant that was the "adult" dosage. *chuckles*

Clean and fair priced. I'd stop here again.

I've stopped by this location a few times because it's right near the highway. It's a chain, so the food won't be any different from any other Jimmy John's in America. The thing that's disappointing about this is how slow service is. 
When you think Jimmy John's, you think, "Freaky Fast, Freaky Good." My experience with this sight has been "Freaky Slow". On my last trip, I ordered two sandwiches, two bags of chips. I hung out in the drive-thru, watched the gentleman that took order restock chips and replenish cups... still no sandwiches. I saw him take an order over the phone, speak to a delivery person as they returned... still no sandwich. Then, after some more hanging out in the drive thru, I got my sandwiches. Sadly, in the time between me ordering my food and actually getting it, he'd forgotten my order. I had to remind him that I ordered chips. He hands me one bag. I reminded him there were two, he handed me another. My hope is that the experiences I've had are isolated instances. We shall see.

I came here to get a decent sized order for my whole family that were in town for a memorial service. It was last minute and we didn't think of ordering ahead of time. Everything was done perfectly and accurately. At the end I ended up adding a bunch of cookies and the girl had no problem with that. Very impressed with the confidence of this Jimmy John's establishment!

Sweet Alley was a pleasant surprise because I didn't expect a quality froyo place in Isla Vista. It's actually a well-run establishment. The only real complaint is that the flavors are lacking - but I usually only get tart anyway. 

The toppings are good, and there are plenty of options. Overall this is a good place to get froyo.

Sweet alley is so yummy! They don't have as many options as your typical froyo place, but the flavors they do have are never disappointing.

Some of my personal favorites are the honey Greek yogurt and the acai berry. The honey Greek is so smooth and creamy and not too sweet, and the acai is sweet with a little tartness that pairs well with the fruit toppings. I also tried the chocolate custard recently, yum!

They also have candy (Pop Rocks anyone?!) so if you just want a sweet treat you can get a piece of candy if you're not feelin froyo.

Rainbow's End brand self-serve froyo - nonfat & low fat options available. More sweet flavors than tart although many of them are melted out of the machine. Enjoyed the mint chocolate & cookies and cream, but definitely not the red velvet. Pass on the tart flavors (esp. the "creamy tart")... certainly wasn't memorable in a good way.

Many sweet toppings available, including most crumbled candy bars. Wish the fruit toppings were fresher (they looked rather dismal), the place was cleaner (there was a LOT of dried, melted froyo on the machines), and the froyo was altogether cheaper. This place definitely makes Yogurtland look pretty good.

Credit card accepted if over $3. Tasting cups available. No bathrooms. If you want self-serve bin candy, it's available for $6.99/ lb.

They have a WIDE variety of flavours and toppings! There are about 12 ice cream flavours, and 10 frozen yogurt flavours. For the yogurt, there's the regular froyo, and the guilt-free one (Wow Cow). For the toppings, there's cereal, candy, fruits, nuts, sprinkles, cookies, brownies, and my favourite: MOCHI pieces! Every froyo place I've been to lately seems to run out of mochi pieces, but this place has it!  So thumbs up to Sweet Alley!

When I went, I didn't think I got a lot, but I ended up spending over $3. I think it's a bit expensive for a the amount I got. But nonetheless, it was delicious!

Oh how I crave Sweet Alley.  Their strawberry bordeaux (or is it bordeaux strawberry) ice cream is OUT OF THIS WORLD.  I would kill like 5 scoops of this in one night.  It was pretty brutal.  I did my best to share with the boyfriend since he was an avid fan as well, but most of the time I failed miserably.  How can you blame me?  I'm sure you wouldn't be big on sharing the greatest ice cream gem in all of the universe if you had it sitting on your living room table, would you?  I didn't think so.  Anyways, I heard their strawberry bordeaux ice cream is really from McConnell's which would explain a lot (+10 points for quality).

Their frozen yogurt is also very yummy.  I'm a fan of the strawberry and plain.  I love loading mine with strawberries and/or blueberries.

Beware:  They are open late so if you have late night cravings, you cannot, must not say no.  Also, the self-serve part is kind of dangerous, as it can lead to overindulgence and intense food comas.

All yogurt is not created equal. For some reason, the yogurt is more bland? than the yogurt elsewhere. It's hard for me to describe what that means, but just try it and you'll understand. Personally, I would prefer going to IV Drip for their cookie-wiches, or visiting the other Sweet Alley location on MarketPlace - the location that also serves Ice Cream.

Have absolutely no idea why it took me 16 months to visit this place, but I was a fool. First, it's the only fro-yo place in IV so they get first place automatically. Second, their selection is really, really good and will remind you of Red Mango, Pinkberry, similar spots. Everyone is friendly, and they also sell a fuck ton of candy. WIN WIN WIN WIN WIN .....

Ultimately, Sweet Alley is a very forgettable establishment in Isla Vista. It's kind of cool that we have our own fro-yo and candy shop, but considering that I went like, once three years ago and just recently mustered up the courage to try it again, there isn't much to say about this place.

With their "re-opening" a year ago, management has introduced several Asian desserts to the menu, including the beloved egg waffle. Emily L., my significant other, and I each ordered one of their egg waffle sundaes, which comes with a large scoop of ice cream, fruit, and chocolate wafer roll. And so did the 20 people in front of and behind us.

The one aspect that was clear from the start was how understaffed this place is. There was one student at the front taking orders and making desserts, and on a Sunday night, with about 20 people out the door, that really piles up. After a 10-minute wait, another girl walked in (perhaps she was on her break with an hour left before closing?) and lazily began refilling the DIY fro-yo toppings bar. Hey, your co-worker is wildly swamped at the front and there's no one in line for chocolate chips. Start making egg waffles, or something!

That being said, the sweet blonde girl running the shop really did an excellent job of staying on task and keeping it cool. There were several things out of her control that this place really has to improve on if they care about making their customers happier. The staffing issue is one. Another was that the scooped ice cream was super icy. I'm talking "finding ice pockets in the cream" icy. Fro-yo might be a better bet, so stay away if you don't want to shock your molars every time you chomp down. Management should also consider paring down the menu (cold brew nitro coffee! Egg waffles! Sago soup! Acai bowls! Sour cherry gummy coke bottles!) to maintain quality control.

All that said, the egg waffle was just okay. Too dense for my liking. It wasn't strawberry season, so the fresh sliced ones on top of my sundae were kind of sour, but the presentation was pretty. What else can ya say for $5.95?

This place is an addiction.  Once you go, you can't stop... it's plaguing me and all my friends!  I don't know all of the fancy fro-yo terms... all I know is that this place is TASTY!  Fantastic selection of many different flavors that change every time I go, and a huge selection of toppings- candy, fresh fruit, carmel... you name it, they've got it.

Talk about a great business to open in IV.. goodbye Berrilicious.. hope your Korean BBQ place can keep you afloat, cause Sweet Alley has great selection for a great price.  All those frozen yogurt places that spawned out of Pink Berry are incredibly over-priced.  6 bucks for about 5 bites and a couple toppings? Not here!!  I have never spent more than 4.50 here and I get 2 or 3 times the amount you would get at other yogurt places... and this has way more selection!  Pricing is determined by weight, and it's definitely reasonable!

They also have Bin Candy... a dollar more expensive than good ol' Keg n' bottle, but at least it's fresh and hasn't been sitting around for god-knows-how-long like at keg n' bottle.

This place is great and you can tell by the huge line during peak hours!  I think there will be more like it popping up to replace the over-priced, low-selection yogurt shops.

I usually get their fro yo but I was craving something else...mmm McConnell's ice cream :)

I got two scoops of salted caramel chip and it reminded me of rich and creamy gelato. I also added to the ice cream mochi, blueberries, mangoes, dark chocolate chips and random toppings i thought wouldn't add much weight (like sprinkles lol).

For less than $5, it was a pretty nice treat. I felt really thirsty afterwards but it was worth it for the salty-sweet goodness :D

Well it's the only place in IV I know with fro-yo haha
It's okay it's not the best and it's a little overpriced, but it's close and pretty good
They have a lot of candy too!

Out of side, out of mind.  I had NO idea there was a restaurant inside the Sheraton.  When you enter the hotel through the main entrance, Alexander's will be straight back past the lobby lounge to the left.  The restaurant has a very intimate feel, partly because there are very few people there.  With so many other options in Clayton, I don't know that I would eat at Alexander's again...unless I was staying at the hotel alone or wanted a quite intimate space to get together with coworkers after work.

They have a soup and salad lunch buffet...with cookies, but after seeing sweet potato fries on the main menu I had to go with a sandwich.  I had the 4 Cheese Grill with Sweet Potato Fries, it was the closest thing they had to a panini or melt.  It was a lot of food too, I am just now finishing my lunch for dinner.  However, the sweet potato fries didn't make good leftovers, they lost that crispness.  They were good at lunchtime, no ketchup necessary.  The sandwich was tons of melted cheese...and I mean LOTS, a slice of tomato and strips of bacon.  Pretty tasty and filling.  If you like cheese, this "big kid" grilled cheese is great.

The service was wonderful, but I was with someone important to the hotel so they were sure to keep things extra tip top on the service...but I think they'd be attentive even if I wasn't, because like I mention, there weren't many full tables to attend to.

The Kenner location is just as good as the New Orleans location!! I'm glad that the parking is a bit bigger than the New Orleans location, but it is still a strange parking lot.

We went during the week, and it was surprisingly not that busy, yet my food ticket got lost.

My coworker and I split a salad and two sandwiches (nom nom nom) because that is how we roll at The Big Cheezy. I'm glad that we did split the two sandwiches because I was the second one to order, but my food never came out until I asked about it. They had to reprint my ticket so the kitchen could make my food. Even though everyone was already done with their meal, I gobbled up my food and left.

I really wish they would make Bacon Mac n Cheese fries a thing.

Daaaaaaaaaaang Big Cheezy, I am straight up embarrassed right now. After loving The Juice we tried at the FQF, and raving about the Broad St. spot to the guy I'm seeing, we stopped in tonight for some take out and it did not go well.

We came in a little before 7 and there was a good crowd. We made our way to the ordering area and we were told the wait would be 20 minutes for our food- cool. We took a seat and waited and waited and waited. People came, ordered, got their food and still we waited. We only ordered two sandwiches and fries, so what was the hold up? Finally, a guy working there noticed we had been waiting a while and asked what we had ordered. We told him and then we waited some more. FINALLY after more than an hour of waiting (no kidding), we were given our food with barely an apology. We pretty much concluded that they had lost our order somewhere along the line.

Once we got the food home and actually ate it, I was pretty unimpressed. My crawgator had obviously just been quickly thrown together and the fries weren't all that great either. The only reason it was any good is probably because I was starving. This is such a bummer because I love the Broad St. location and I really talked this place up. I won't be back.

There are some really good ideas here, and with some fine tuning in execution they could be done a little better. As for now, it's just a bit above average with a larger than average price tag. My fiancé and I came in for dinner, and shared the roast beef and cheese sandwich, Mac and Cheezy sandwich and I had tomato soup and he had sweet potato fries. The soup was so sweet is was almost inedible- I've never had a tomato basil soup that sweet before. The fries were decent but had no salt at all. The Mac and cheese sandwich was good, but seemed to need a different more hearty bread- the bread it was on just kind of disintegrated into the sandwich. The roast beef and cheese was good, but maybe needed a bit more cheese and less juice- and some seasoning. Overall not a bad meal, just needed a few tweaks!

I love cheese!!!! I prefer Gouda in everything when possible! Everything here was delicious but super rich! I was only able to eat of the big cheesy grilled cheese sandwich! I think all grill cheese sandwich should come with tomato soup or something to cut the fatty richness of the sandwich. Just a small cup.  

My hubby really enjoyed his cheezy melt! I should have gotten this too cause I love meat and cheese. Fries are generic.  Not homemade. They should cut their own fries cause it would be delicious than frozen fries.


Love the creamy Mac and cheese! It's just cream and not as stringy as I would like but overall tasty. It needs like a Panko crust on top for a great crunch!  Will be back soon!

The Big Cheezy is clearly a local favorite.  Known for their gourmet grilled cheese, it is easy to see how much they are loved by locals.

On the "$" price point, I would disagree.  Realistically, to get a gourmet grilled cheese, it's gonna run you $8 before you add on the $2 drink or $4 basic waffle fries.  I think it's more realistic to say it is a $15/person price point.

+ Plenty of seating.
+ Fun, irreverent bumper stickers and wall posters everywhere
+ Inventive food, including the-bomb-dotcom waffle fries
+ Close to a cafe (to the left of the resto), Cafe Du Monde (across the street), and gas station
+ As such, a good stop before/after the airport

First time at The Big Cheezy and it definitely lives up to the hype. First, Excellent customer service, Thomas who took my order greeted me immediately when i walked in with great enthusiasm and he's extremely knowledgeable about the menu. Now about the food: i ordered the Original Pairing which is a simple grilled cheese and tomato basil soup. The soup is only okay but the sandwich is awesome! Perfect portions, neither too small nor too large. Clean restaurant, cool music and free wifi! This place is winning on all levels.

Hmmm...just ok. Possibly my expectations were too high. I don't know but I must say I was a little disappointed. It wasn't horrible but it wasn't anything spectacular to make me want it again. I had the crawgator, which seemed to be lacking. I wanted more! More cheese! More sausage! More fries! In addition, It was too thin and the bread was really hard :( However, it wasn't nasty. It actually was ok. Unfortunately, it just wasn't enough.

Have a cheese craving? You can't really get any better than going down to the Big Cheezy! They have mastered the task of gooey melted cheese between 2 slices of bread grilled to perfection with the perfect crunch. 

I like the ones that have a little more substance that just cheese so if you're thinking its JUST grilled cheese, think again. They have the original classic grilled cheese, but they also have lots of other sandwiches for your more refined grown up taste buds. 

I tired the Flying Dutchman and the Brie-zy. The Flying Dutchman was turkey, gouda, bacon, and honey mustard. Excellent! The Brie-zy was Monterey jack and brie cheese, caramelized apples, pecans and a honey drizzle. It was very good, but glad I was splitting because I don't know if I could have finished a whole one. It was decadent! 

The tomato basil soup is the perfect side to go with your grilled cheese. Its really tasty and perfect for dipping or just eating it solo. They even sell a dipper size that is just enough for dipping. How thoughtful!

I will definitely be returning when I have a quench for cheese and need a quick fix at this casual eatery.

I am a member at the nearby Y, and when I noticed a sign saying that a portion of the sales on June 22 if the customer mentions the Y, so I decided to stop on by and have dinner as I have not been to this location.

Located just north on Williams, just past the I-10 interchange, on the East side, there is a small parking lot in front. On the counter, there is a sign saying there is a secret parking lot in the rear, which is odd they would announce it inside. If you are outside looking for a parking spot, you might not know to go in and ask if you can park in the rear, especially if you are by yourself (like I usually am).

Inside was clean enough, they were about half full, mainly one large group seated right in the middle. The party consisted of some adults with their kids, which was ok, but the adults were completely ignoring the children and the language was kind of inappropriate for a public place, in my opinion. That's not a knock against the restaurant, except as a statement of the kind of customers that come in. Especially since there were a few other smaller parties around, one with a small child, and they had their own kids.

Go to the counter, they have individual menus for you to hold, and one on the wall. I got the crawgator, cheesy fries and a drink knowing I would end up taking some of it home for later. The crawgator was good, but was spicy in some bites, and not in others, so the flavor was not equal throughout. The cheesy fries were good, but stuck to each other and the paper.

It was good enough, but I am not sure I will make a special trip out here again, unless it is in support of another cause. Even then, I am not sure, especially based on other reviews of this place.

After some shopping, we headed out to find something to eat. My nephew suggest the Big Cheezy. Driving into their small parking lot which were empty should be a sign for me to just find another eating options but my nephew really wanted to eat there. Walking in should also be a sign for me to leave. My nephew is autistic so once he decided on something, there's no changing his mind. The place looks really gloomy. It took them awhile before taking my orders because they were changing shift and busy counting the cash register. I got the Crawgator which are alligator and crawfish sausage with cheddar and pepper jack, carameltized onions and grilled green peppers on sourdough. The sausage was good but the sourdough bread taste stale. I did order a side waffle fries which was great, I mean no one can actually messed that up right?  My nephew decided on the Pizza Mac. Tomato basil sauce with mozzarella cheese and pepperoni and a side order of tomato basil soup. Nephew usually kills his food but he only ate the pepperoni and some of the pasta. I taste some of his soup. It was ok. Don't think I would come back or recommend this place.

Looking for comfort food? Im pretty sure a picture of their gourmet grilled cheeses with a side of either tomato soup or waffle fries is next to the definition in the dictionary. Mmm cheese. Makes me happy. 
Ive tried several and they are all good, some heavier than others. My top 2 are the alligator sausage and the orginal(4 cheeses on sourdough served double decker style) The bread is thick and  super buttery. This location also has creole creamery shakes if you want to live it up. 
They also offer salads for the timid. I wish they had a drive thru but then again I do want to live past 40. I like how they are called 'adult grilled cheese'.  Thanks to them, its now my favorite thing about being an adult.

Cheese! Cheese! Cheese! I went here last night and that sandwich is all I keep thinking about. The restaurant decor is nothing to get excited about, and it looks like they aren't very fast at cleaning, but the food makes up for that. I ordered the crazy old goat - goat cheese and monterey jack cheese, pepper, bacon, and green peppers. My boyfriend ordered the flying dutchman - gouda, turkey, bacon, and honey mustard. We both asked for our sandwiches to be on the Hawaiian sweet bread, and we both ordered a tomato basil dipper. We waited maybe a little over 10 minutes for the sandwiches to come out. During this time I started to regret not ordering fries. They looked really good, and I wasn't sure if the sandwiches would fill us up. They did! They were absolutely delicious and mine was so filling. The bacon on the sandwich was perfect and the pepper jelly added even more flavor to an already flavorful sandwich. We considered getting one of the creole creamery milkshakes, but we were both so full!

Walked up the counter...said "you got cheese"?
Order taker rolled her eyes and poured out, " puhleeze"

Now that we determined that fromage is the fare
I scanned the menu board while irony hung in the air

Got the cheese sammich with some cheese covered waffles
My dining partner the soup, sammich combo, said it wasn't awful

In fact he dipped his cheeser in the soup
Invited me to do the same with my cheddar from the hoop

Iced tea was weak, Gold Peak colored water
They need the right tea brand, cmon do what you oughter.

If you want your comfort food in the form of cheese
I suggest you stop in here and order what you please

The first two lines of my little dining ditty
Never even occurred, more like Walter Mitty

Service was fine, the food came out hot and gooey 
In this case it's good that your food is really chewy

Will return again one day and order more melted cheddar
For some grilled cheese goodness you cannot do better

My husband really wanted to try this place. 
I walked in, and the smells were enough to make me gag. Actually, I did. I'm not sure whether it was old grease or old cheese, but this wasn't it for me. 

Since I was getting a to-go order, I got my husband soup and sandwich. I couldn't do it. Now, he LOVED his sandwich which is why I'm giving it 3 stars. I may try it again later down the line because he is raving about this darn sandwich.

Very good concept. My family thoroughly enjoyed it, but it missed the mark for me. 

Kids all got, mac & Cheezy signature sandwich. It was literally cheesy sandwiches with Mac n cheese piled on top. The kids loved it and was in heaven. My husband got the crawgator signature sandwich and loved it also. I got "the juice", after viewing the screen with the pictures scrolling. 

However when I got the sandwich, the meat was pulverized, and looked like potted meat. Then my green peppers were missing also. I asked them to takes it back to add my peppers. By the time this evolution took place, I bit into my bread and it was too soggy for me to eat more than 1 bite. Not sure if I would go back here again.

Plus side is the grilled cheeses were tasty... downside is they are just a grilled cheese. I don't know what I expected? I guess I expected more for an $8 grilled cheese. $5 for a plain grilled cheese and no side or drink.... I just know my grilled cheeses at home are just as good. There was nothing on any of the sammies that I couldn't make on my own which is what I look for when going out to a place for lunch. 

No real special secret sauces or out of the ordinary ingredients to really warrant a second visit unless I happened to be hungry and in the area. Worth the try once, you may feel different than me. I just feel as if two grilled cheeses, two drinks and one side sweet potato fries a bit high priced for what we received... if they had combos that includes side and drink it would be better.

Went for the lunch buffet. It was good not great good and lots of it. It is good Indian food that will fill your belly and then you may be asleep after lunch. 
For a lunch place they can not be too hot so that is off the menu. 
The servers were very helpful and the parking is not easy at lunch. 
It is an office park area, so there will be people that need a buffet and this place fits the bill. 
Lots of food for a higher price tag but to be expected in Brentwood as Nashville grows.

Stopped here on my way back from Nottoway Plantation for a quick lunch on Sunday.  Very friendly and fast service.  Great diner food that hit the spot.  Portions weren't very generous but at the same time were exactly as expected.  Breakfast items were especially reasonably-priced.  Only complaint was that the cookies they sold at the counter ($2/bag) were stale/overly hard -- a bit disappointed given how other reviewers commented on the high quality dessert options.  No matter, I'll definitely be back to this location (or another Dot's) next time I have a craving for solid diner food.

Dots is great for breakfast or lunch if you are anywhere in the airport area. 

I make frequent stops when flying out of MSY and the service is always great.  I typically get breakfast and it's hot and quick.  It's hard for me to give 5 stars without it being a restaurant with filet mignon and swordfish on the menu so I'm going with 4 stars because this is a fast food diner but a good one at that.  

Enjoy!

Stopped into Dot for a breakfast on the way to dropping off a friend at the airport and it was a great decision. I ordered the standard Western Omelette and it was one of the best I have ever had with perfect grits on the side. I would get toast instead of the biscuit but overall it was a very quick enjoyable breakfast cooked perfectly. A great option for breakfast 24/7 at under $10 is a great deal.

If you are expecting class and fine dining, this is not the place for you. It's a diner. You sit in a booth, at the counter, or at a table and you can watch the cook slinging hash and artfully assemble meals. You can see people from every walk of life, come in and do what we do best in New Orleans, EAT. The waitstaff knows the menu and rarely make mistakes. They are not the most refined bunch, but they are good people with a smile and a friendly word for you. 

The coffee is always hot and fresh and the food is made to order. You will leave smelling like food and with a full belly.

My favorites are the club sandwich and the omelets and sliders.

Just landed? Hungry for simple fresh breakfast stuff in a friendly setting? Dots Diner checks all boxes.  This place is a gem.  Friendly people work here and they keep your coffee cup filled.  We had an assortment of breakfast combos to chose from, and everything was served up piping hot and with a quickness.  Eggs prepared perfectly, mine over medium, friends fried hard.  Wonderful thick grits and a short stack of flavorful pancakes.  This isn't the spot for micro greens or fanciness, but it is an absolute paradise for anyone seeking a hearty basic breakfast.  Great prices, great portions, I'm a fan!
Crawfish creole biscuits and beignet stix were a delicious start to my day in NOLA.  What a fantastic meal!  What hospitable people!  Reasonably close to the airport too!

Dots is for the most part what you expect to get out of a diner experience.  The food is classic American lunch and breakfast options with a few local options thrown in.  I have had breakfast and burgers here and all the times have been good with fast, attentive service.  This location can get a bit cramped and loud on a busy weekend so get there early but as in many diner type establishments they turn the tables pretty quick so you won't be waiting too long.

I stopped here on a whim, due to a coworker always speaking highly of their burgers. So i tried the bacon and Swiss burger with fries. I also purchased two monster homemade cookies for a dollar.  The burger was cooked to perfection and so fresh. I even got to watch them make it. The portions were huge! I was not disappointed, I'll definitely be back!

What an amazing meal! I'm so glad I stopped in here. The retro decor was nice to see, the tables were clean, the service was fast, and my waitress was AMAZING! 

The eggs weren't cooked with anything on them, yet were the best scrambled eggs I think I've ever had in my life! The grilled butter biscuit, was to die for, and my sausage was cooked to perfection!

You won't be disappointed if you stop in! I love that they're open 24/7!

Stopped in for a very quick, late lunch. Decided to have breakfast and got the standard eggs, bacon and wheat toast. So I don't have a lot to go on here but here's what I can say: It's a classic "diner" look and feel, service is fast and friendly, food come out quickly, was hot and well cooked (hard to go wrong with bacon and eggs - but I've seen it happen!) and the price was easy on the pocket. The ONLY thing I might change is that when I asked for some extra butter - it came out in the form of a squeeze bottle dispenser. Just my personal preference but I like my butter the old fashioned way! Minor observation for a good spot. Would definitely go back to sample other parts of the menu.

This place is my weekend breakfast secret weapon. 

Matt and I have a thing for breakfast diners, and although we had been to several in our area we didn't have a real favorite. All of that changed the day we decided to try Dots. 

The atmosphere here has that classic 1950's diner feel, which I love. This location is nice and cozy, offering a few booths, standard tables and some countertop seating. We prefer to sit at a booth, but if one isn't available we just set up shop at the counter with a few coffees until one opens up. 

The food is prepared in an open kitchen area behind the counter, so you get to see and smell all the amazing things they're cooking as you peruse the menu. The menu is large, and easily offers something for everyone- even that 'picky eater' in the family. 

I haven't tried too many items on the menu, because to be completely honest I have a favorite go-to item that I can't not get when I go to Dots and that item is the B9. It is easily the most delicious chicken fried steak I have ever eaten, covered in white country gravy and served up next to a side of eggs, hashbrowns and a biscuit. Matt usually gets the dinner version, which comes with mashed potatoes or french fries, a side salad, a vegetable and garlic bread. I love that you can substitute anything on your plate without it being a huge issue; sometimes Matt will get a biscuit instead of garlic bread or I will get fries instead of hashbrowns. Matt has also gotten the Philly cheese steak sandwich, and it is definitely one of the best in the Metairie area. 

Also, the biscuits here ARE LIFE. I have never ever ever Ever had a better biscuit in my life. TBH, I think you could justify going to Dots just for the biscuits alone. Get them.

Last, but certainly not least, is the service. From our first visit to our most recent visit the service here is always amazing. The ladies here are some of the friendliest servers and definitley make this place feel like coming home. If you visit often enough, they get to know you and you really do become part of the family. 

I can't speak about their other locations, but I can attest that Dots on Williams is THE breakfast spot to visit if you're in the Metairie/Kenner area!

My quest to eat at every Dot's location is now complete. If you're looking for a classic diner with good, reasonably priced, food find yourself any of Dot's five locations.

In case you were not aware, I am a ridiculous human being. A while back one of my co-workers suggested we get breakfast for lunch and that Dot's is where we should go. We went, and it was great. That is when we decided we should visit every location and see which is the best. 

This location is located right in the heart of Kenna Brah. I'm pretty sure Kenna people get mad when you call it that, but I am from the West Bank. We have to have someone to make fun of to distract from our own inadequacies. This location is super convenient if you decide you need breakfast before flying out, breakfast after flying in, or like me, world famous breakfast for lunch.

For me, this Dot's came in at #2. Service was super friendly and personal and we were made to feel like regulars even though it was our first visit.

The food was classic breakfast fare and the cook here knew what he/she was doing. It always perplexes me how Dot's can make their eggs taste so good and this location's were pretty much perfect.

Stopped in for breakfast prior to heading to the airport. We had coffee and split the Cajun omelet with hot sausage, onions, peppers and cheese. It comes with hash browns or grits and toast. The grill was down so we had to swap out our hash browns for grits. Hard having a diner with a non working grill! 
Still, we had a good breakfast and I'm sure better and cheaper than the airport.

Wanted a quick bite before heading out to the airport and my girlfriend insisted to eat here since it's close by the area. First impression I thought it was just another Waffle House type so I didn't really expect much from this place. Ordered their biscuits with two eggs with crawfish étouffée on top with hash browns and chicken fried steak with white gravy. Surprisingly everything was tasty. Food were delicious and service was great.

Think of this place as a locals Waffle House kicked up a notch. A few around town and we hit them for a late breakfast. 

Booths in front area a bit tight (yeah I know I need to lose weight) so we opted for a table in back. Stools at the counter open too. 

Fresh hot Community Coffee to start and opted for their version of corned beef hash with eggs. Wife had Crawfish Julie over eggs and biscuits. No complaints here. Hash was done very different with chunks of corn beef and hash browns. Rich meat flavor. Buttered toast too. I will opt for biscuits next time. Friendly folks and I bought a coffee mug for work.
