Will stop in again and try a burger with some onion rings too. Dot ain't your mama but she will treat you like its home!

Man this place serves delicious food! And the service is good.  And unlike many of the places we ate at in new Orleans, it has PARKING! I will definitely be visiting every time i come to new Orleans.  Yum!

I reviewed my previous review when I saw one of friends visited and was surprised at my score being only 3 star here. Not ready to go 5 star yet but after a few more visits after my first review I certainly can say with certainty we got us a winner here. Son loved the burgers, even for breakfast and I stick with eggs. 

We got in the habit of paying it forward here, especially around the holidays to continue a  Waffle House tradition. 

Will stop in again sometime when we hit the area.

Dots hits the spot. So stop at Dots. Pick it up and trot.

Let me first say that I'm a die hard Waffle House fan...but somebody else has won me over. This was my first time ever at a Dot's Diner and I'm so happy we stopped in. The service was so awesome...we truly felt right at home. 

I ordered a western omelet, no ham. It came out hot and fresh. My side was grits and although they needed a bit of salt, they were very good. We also tried out the French toast which tasted home cooked. I was very pleased with everything! I honestly can't wait to go back.

First time here and I decided to bring my father-in-law for breakfast.  This diner is practicing social distancing by blocking every other booth and table.  Masks are required prior to entry and staff are also donning their face coverings.  Well, some of them.  

In terms of the food and service.  Service was excellent and our food was prepared and delivered to us super fast.  As for the taste, well ya know, it's a diner and the food was uh, ya know, meh.  

I ordered the Biggest Omelet Yet, (the actual name), and it was delicious but the cheese could've been less and/or melted more.  All of the meat and veggies were diced nicely and portioned well so that was a plus.  

Paw paw wasn't a big fan of his breakfast but he ate just about everything.  I think he was disappointed that he didn't get lunch because he admired the way the spaghetti and meatballs looked on another patron's plate lol.  

I'll certainly go back and try something else because they are very friendly. I will say that it must be a very popular place because folks were piling up in there as we were making our way out.

Nothing makes me happier than being able to add an extra star on Chuck's Alibi. I like this place so much, that despite my moving about 30 minutes away I decided half way through my meal that I'll be making the trip back often! 

As I mentioned in my last review, all the negatives couldn't keep me away from the positively great crabs. So with a bit of mental preparation we stopped by Saturday night and were pleasantly surprised to find EVERY ONE of our previous issues had been addressed! We arrived toward the end of what I would call dinner hours (they serve late into the evening though) and the ambiance was  very pleasant. Frank Sinatra serenaded us at a ear friendly volume as we went to town on our Dungenous crabs. Late in our meal the clock did click passed 9 and the music got a tad louder and went to typical bar music, but still no where near the ear splitting level of before. In fact, I didn't see the guy that was running things on our last visit, and this time the manager in charge (an obvious seasoned veteran of the service industry, and an obvious positive influence on the business) made a point to go around to all the tables to check on things. The temperature problems seemed to be worked out too. 

If you haven't been, do yourself a favor and give them a try. Also, they have their own private parking lot with free valet, so don't stress about parking.

Went here on Sunday to attend an album release party so I was not dining in (and from the other reviews, I should count my blessings!) In the back of the restaurant through the doors is a really nice, intimate venue. It's ashame the bartenders suck... The bar was extremely crowded so I understood the long wait, however generally if there's and event , most places will staff more than one bartender. Its a novel idea, but it just might work! 

So after my friend and I got tired of waiting we went to the.main bar and the chick bartending had the nastiest attitude and horrible customer service. She proceeded to walk past us twice and serve other customers eventhough we told her we'd like to order, and the other patrons came up after us. So we went back to the slow bartender. And after he took 25 mins to get our order and spent another 20,mins reading the ingriedients on the menu to make our carribean punches we got our drinks in less than an hour. Based on that experience I would NEVER patronize the restaurant plus the parking situation is atrocious. Sux too cause the drink actually turned out good...

Chuck's is a mix between a local pub, an Atlanta club and diner. I am merely reviewing the night life here because I came here for drinks on a Fri night. 

The music was by far the BEST part of this friday night experience. It was all old school Mase, 112, SWV, perfect for a few drinks....and maybe a shot.  

I would definitely return, everyone seemed to be enjoying their meal, unfortunately I did not stay much past midnight as I had to work the next day.

This is a virtual 5 star review, but in reality I'm only giving it 3 until it works out the kinks. 

THE GOOD: The Dungeness Crabs! A full D. Crab close to 2lbs (last night) that left me STUFFED to this morning. My girlfriend and I have talked about it 3 times since getting up! At only $14.00 it was a steal! I'll also say everyone else's food looked damn good too.

Also the service. It did take a bit to get our waitress, but once the ball was rolling everything was great. They gave me a free beer to apologize for the long wait (in actuality it was probably to make up for them bringing me the wrong beer in the first place, whatev...) AND offered to get us new hot fires half way through our meal! Who does that? 

THE BAD: TURN THAT FUCKING MUSIC DOWN!!!!! This place is a pub (well more on that in a sec.) but they have a ton of food business and even a steak shop, that was hopping late into the night, attached. BUT THEY WERE BLARING THE MUSIC LIKE IT WAS SOME SOUTH ST. MEAT MARKET! I can't stress enough, it wasn't just loud, but insanely loud! Everyone was having to yell at each other and read lips, including servers to customers. We complained and for a hot minute the guy turned it down, but 20 minutes later his jam came on and up it went. Also, the A/C seemed to be an issue with definite pockets of oven like heat zones that are battled by near arctic blasts over other areas, namely our table. As best as I could tell the music and a/c are not evenly dispersed throughout the place so one area is hot and quiet and the other is cold and loud, no middle ground. This will not stop me from going back, the crabs where that good. 

THE UGLY: The bar is set up jenky. I don't mean the physical bar, that's fine with lots ( I mean LOTS) of flat screens everywhere. But the liquor they carry is odd. Some top shelf brands of one thing, then rock gut brands of another. They only offer Bud, Bud Lt. Miller Lite, and Yuengling on tap (and had tapped the wrong keg for the Yuengling and I got one of the two Lites to start) So go with bottled, it'll be colder too. 

In short, the problems are minor and will probably be smoothed out in time. The upside is huge, with great food and good people...There is a new star in this often neglected corner of the NE, and that's a huge plus!

When we walked in, my initial thought was - this was a winner.  Not only did they serve Dungeness crabs, but Johnny Cash was pumping through the place!  But then little problems began to surface:

- For starters, there were definite temperature issues.  It was hot outside and the air conditioning was having trouble keeping the place consistently cooled.  
- The waitress took a while to greet us though once she finally did, she was attentive and sweet.  
- The music was LOUD.  The mix was great but the bass was bumpin so hard I felt like I was eating in a nightclub.  Not appropriate for a restaurant/neighborhood bar.
- NO BOURBON!  Not a single bourbon behind the bar. 

But the food was awesome and as far as I'm concerned, that's what really matters.  The crabs were perfectly cooked and they served more than I could eat - for only $13.95!  And the side of fries was massive and perfectly cooked as well.  My only issue with the food was they did not provide a wet nap for clean up, just an itty bitty lemon wedge which was pretty much useless.

Since they have only been open for a week or two, I have high hope that things will improve and this will become a 5 star spot!

We stopped back this past weekend and it seems the previous issues were all magically addressed!  The music was much quieter and was more appropriate for dining, the temperature was consistently cool, and they served wet naps with the crabs!  

And the crabs, I don't know if I was extra hungry but they were extra good!!  This place is definitely a winner.

Seafood here is awesome. Drinks are super expensive for a bar though. I believe they charge you extra after a certain time or only doubles after 6pm which is ridiculous. Service needs a pick-me-up because it really shouldn't take me flagging down the waitress for napkins to get attention when she had two tables. I come here when I'm in the area. Not somewhere I'm going out of my way to get to.

I don't get it.  It's a big place in an incredible location but they definitely don't know what to do with it.  Plastic utensils? REALLY?!  So cheap. The food is okay but not worth the price.  Valet parking?  No, not even close.   The music is too loud too. Awful place.

I would said this restaurant is unique in many ways. The cuisine, the setting of the restaurant, the attention of owner make the place great to eat. There are gluten free item and grass feed beef as their advertisements of the material of the food. 

I like to mention a little about their sound system. It is front row seat to the concert. The restaurant invest a very good sound system that is pleasure to the ear. They also hide their speaker very well. Imagine they play the Star Wars music. May the force be with you. 

We have order the taste of the islands and the blacken mango salmon. The taste of the island include curry goat, Ox tail and jerk chicken. The goat is a bit heavy smell. The jerk chicken is great with the seasoning they have. The best is the Ox Tail. The Ox tail with Caribbean spice make this dish special.

The blacken salmon is prepare with Caribbean blacken spice. It is very nice. It serves over cook pineapple sauce. The fish is tasty. This dish accompanied with a side salad. The desert we have is the coconut cake. The coconut cake has layers of coconut cream. It is guilty pleasure. 

The greeting of the owner from the restaurant make this place special. The decorations is modern and it is gear up for upper class power lunch or dinner. Nice touch. Service is great and the cook is the owner wife. It is family run with attention to the details.

Great ambient here! I specially liked their surround  sound system. The music came out from different corners of the room. The crystal clear, high fidelity sound quality make me feel like the musicians were playing right there. The black and write color theme of the interior looked modern. The food and services were great ,too. We had salad (came with the entrée, I liked the fresh fruit on top), blacken salmon with mango, island delight (came with plantain, johnny cake - a fried dough, bean and rice, curry goat, ox tail and jerk chicken). The flavor was rich and the meat was tender. Beautifully decorated  rum cake and coconut cake were moist and fresh , tasted wonderful.

I have had this place bookmarked for quite some time now and could not wait to check it out! I am of Jamaican descent, so this food is what I grew up eating - yah mon! :-) 

I called in and ordered my oxtails and rice and peas dinner with a side of plantains. Yummm after reading some Yelp reviews, I decided it would be a good idea to also add the coconut cake to my order. Yes! 

The minute I walked in, I was greeted by a sweet lady hostess with a welcoming smile and then the owner Andre(?) came out with an equally warm smile to say hello and that my food would be ready shortly. How sweet! 

It was a comfy wait with wonderful slow reggae tunes playing and the dark ceilings and floors with the bright white booths and seating was so divine! It was inviting. 

I got my food and was sincerely thanked by Andre and was on my merry way. 

I got home and dug right in and the flavors of home hit my palate! The oxtail fell right off that bone and the rice was cooked to perfection. The plantains were also sweet and delicious. Even though my meal was for take out, the presentation of the food was top notch! 

The coconut cake was the perfect finish to my trip to Jamaica :-) it was moist and delicious and drizzled with caramel and accented with fresh blackberries & strawberry. 

I would highly recommend Yah Mon for takeout and can't wait to head back to dine in!

Yah Mon was absolutely delicious, they definitely deserve their rating! It's a bit hidden and in an awkward location, but so worth it. I had the oxtails and wasn't able to finish it was so filling. I was really upset that I forgot my leftovers in my hotel fridge. Both of my friends absolutely love their dishes as well. Good ambience, good service, good food, no complaints!

Delicious! Very tasty Caribbean food. The ox meat is ridiculously tender, juicy, and delicious. They close a little early, so don't plan to go if after 7 or else you'll feel rushed. The staff is really nice and courteous. Tables have white table clothes and it's beautifully decorated. Only beer and wine is sold. However they do have liquor flavored wine. Weird but delicious! They sell tequila, vodka, and rum flavored wine shots. Never had those before but they are great! It's in the back of the Walgreens on Platt. If their location was closer to SoHo, this place would be packed every night!

James Bond would feel at home at this secluded and beautifully decorated Jamaican and Caribbean restaurant tucked away behind Walgreens off Platt Street and Plant Street near downtown, Davis and Harbor Islands and SoTa. 

It's a black and white affair with scintilating desserts including bread pudding and rum cake. The banana fritters and Jamaican patties are worth the trip. There are also especialities including escovitch, callaloo, jerk chicken, and ackee saltfish. 

Relax and enjoy. Your new fav getaway is here in classy comfotable fun luxury with down home island cuisine. Jah Mon, jam on, and make it Yah Mon.

I've been torn on writing my Yah Mon review because Andre's love and passion for his restaurant was so wonderful, but it just missed the mark for me. We went on a Friday night with another couple. We were seated promptly. The decor is interesting, especially for a Caribbean restaurant. White (p)leather booths, white table cloths (with white paper on top), and other high-end touches. But the food itself is down home, Caribbean comfort food (which to me just doesn't go with the vibe). We ordered a few different dishes, which took a long while to come out (as other reviewers have mentioned). Our johnny cakes arrived with our dinners rather than before as an appetizer, as we had requested. The food was quite delicious, but also quite pricey. We paid $65 for 2 entrees and an order of johnny cakes (one was fish and one was the Caribbean sampler, so admittedly some of the pricier dishes) - no drinks. That price to me is quite crazy. I wish they were open for lunch on the weekends because I think that might be a better option for us. Either way, they are passionate about their heritage and food, and make some delicious dishes! But the prices were just too high.

I guess this must be what it's like to be treated like a celebrity! From the moment my friend and I walked in, we received friendly, individualized attention, despite the fact that we were sweaty and dressed somewhat sloppily from our day outdoors.  We were treated like VIPs as the red carpet was rolled out (figuratively!) and sat down at a beautiful, white table.  The place was sparkling clean, elegant, yet not stuffy.  This would be a great place for a romantic date! Don't let the unassuming exterior fool you, because it's actually quite elegant inside! Andre, the sharply dressed man that greeted us, is actually the owner, and he does a great job as a host, making each person that walks in feel special.  His entire demeanor is very calm and pleasant, and I was caught off-guard, because I have become a hardened Miamian that does not experience this often, unless there is an ulterior motive.

The music was fun, and energetic, and Andre had such a peaceful, happy energy about him that it permeated throughout his restaurant.  You couldn't help but feel happy while you were in the establishment.  The food options were plentiful and all sounded delicious, but my friend and I stuck with the safe choice of jerk chicken, which came with a salad and rice and peas.  We each decided to get a large, dinner portion, but had no idea it would be so much food! It was certainly enough to share, though to be fair, we had also had some delicious jerk chicken wings to start.  I had a watermelon soda, which satisfied my sweet tooth, and was very refreshing.  The chicken was very tender and tasty, and the wings especially were hot and spicy, just as we had asked.  It's great to find food that is well-seasoned, and that does not mean that it is dripping in salt.  On the contrary -- it means other flavors and spices dominate, with salt taking a backseat.  We were also told the ingredients were all locally sourced, and organic. 

We were checked on constantly, to make sure we were happy.  Not too long after, Janise, the owner's wife, came over to personally ask if everything was satisfactory.  She also happens to be the chef, we found out, and is from St. Thomas, which means you're getting the real deal here -- authentic Caribbean cooking! Janise was as lovely and friendly as her husband.  I guess that is probably why the food was so full of flavor and love, because they genuinely enjoy making people happy and have pride in their business.  We were too full to get dessert, and I am sure we missed out on something great, judging by the Yelp pictures.  I am glad my friend and I did not go to the place that the staff from the Henry B. Plant Museum had recommended and that we came here, instead, because that place was not very well-received.  Thanks to my Yelp app, I found Yah Mon, read some of the reviews, and we were sold.  The food, and the reviews, did not disappoint. If you're anywhere near this restaurant, you must make it a point to dine here.  Great food, catchy name, clean space, and great service.  This is the standard by which all restaurants should be judged!

Yah Mon is a very contemporary Jamaican restaurant with top notch service and good food. It's the service and atmosphere which prompted me to give 5 stars instead of 4. Very attentive and friendly service, aimed to please. 

But let's talk about the food. Two types of bread are served complimentary. Both excellent but I loved the one that was slightly sweetened with cream. The beef meat pie (empanada-ish) that we ordered as an appetizer was awesome. I would go back just to eat that. Very well seasoned and I loved the consistency of the beef filling. 

For entrees, I tried both the curry chicken that came with a couple fried plantains (maduros). The curry chicken came in a bowl like stew. Good but I guess I was expecting something different.  Also had the ribeye, which was fine but it didn't blow me away. So the entrees were a 4. The starters were a 5. The desserts I hear are awesome but I was so full and didn't get to try them. Next visit though for sure.  I'm on board with the 5 star rating.

You'll be saying, "Yah, Mon!" if anyone asks you  if they are Five-Star worthy!  I know I will. 

My expectations were unexpectedly surpassed as I walked up to the front door. Let me explain: as this is a Caribbean-themed restaurant, I was expecting the typical, super casual, laid-back, free-flowing, paper plates and plastic cutlery, Bob-Marley-just-left-the building decoŕ. No, my friends.  Black-n-white color themed interior, linen table cloths, tables set with flatware and dishware worthy of a 4-star restaurant. The staff was wearing classic black.The corner booth closest to the door was strewn with red-rose petals, a bouquet of red roses placed on one of the benches, a bottle of champagne in the table's center---a marriage proposal forthcoming for someone---made for a romantic presentation. I felt underdressed.

The hostess asked if we had a reservation, which we did not. Every booth was occupied as was each table. I noticed the bar has several spot open, so we were seated immediately.  The hostess appeared a little overwhelmed or nervous. She asked if we would like to order, but I replied by asking for a menu, as I am unsavy with Caribbean cuisine. The cook later confided that she was very new. 

I played it safe and ordered a chicken patty and rice and peas. I kicked up the rice and peas with pineapple pepper sauce, which gave it much-needed flavor. My companion, who feels vegetables are what Kryptonite is to Superman, gave me a side salad, which was fresh and delicious. Everything was delicious. 

Before departing, the owner stopped by to introduce himself and inquired how everything was. He took the time to chat and I inquired of the reserved booth. He shared an account of a previous proposal taking place and that, yes, it is reserved for another marriage proposal. (Whomever does the asking--it would be difficult to say "No", if ya ask me :-)

There have been several eateries at this location prior to Yah Mon. They have come and gone. But, I wish much success to Yah Mon and want to encourage whomever is reading this, "YOU GOTTA GO HERE!" 

Just be SURE if I show up when you're there--I get to sit at a booth. LoL! :-D

This place has been on my radar for quite some time and I finally got to try it.  Now, honestly, if you aren't the adventurous type you will probably get a little weirded out by the sight of Caribbean food because it's not visually appealing.  But the great thing is that it doesn't matter, because it tastes phenomenal.  I highly encourage you to try the ox tail.  Yes it's a little pricey ($15) and you shouldn't expect allot of meat (well..it is a tail of course) but it's super delicious.  They'll even let you taste test!

Wrote a review for this place a while ago but don't know what happened to it. This is my hubby's favorite place to dine for Caribbean food. He is completely hooked. The food is amazing and so are the couple that run the place. You will always find the wife in the kitchen and the husband on the floor working hard. They always remember diners and go out of their way to serve you. The place is kind of in a challenging location but it is worth the hassle.

The inside is dimly lit and romantic. You'll hear soft Caribbean music playing in the background; a nice compliment to the meal. 

I have tried most of the items on the menu except the dessert items. That's so weird for me right? Anyway, after my month long sugar cleanse I will make it my priority to sample some desserts on my next visit, I may even have dessert before dinner hehe.

We came here because of the amazing reviews on yelp. I don't know what happened the Saturday night we were there, but it was a completely different restaurant from what is described by these reviews.

Arrived at 7 pm with a reservation and there were only 4 other tables with diners. The owner was friendly and introduced himself. I was excited to be there as I love supporting family businesses. Unfortunately from here, everything went down hill.

My husband ordered meat patties, and I ordered sides because I don't eat much meat. 30 minutes in and we still hadn't received our beers or even a glass of water we had asked for. At 30 minutes we did see someone go into the meat patty case which is in the dining room, take the patties our and serve them to my husband. Again we sat for 30 minutes along with the patties that were in the case ten feet from us but they never made their way to us.

At the 60 minute mark, we receive our chips and guac appetizer.  The guac was ice cold, like it was just taken out of the fridge. 

Then 90 mins in, I kid you not, we receive the sides I ordered- veggies and mac and cheese. My husband had already finished eating his food almost an hour earlier.

We were actually the lucky ones, because the tables seated just after us still did not receive any food by the time we left at 9pm. The table next to us, four older folks, did not even receive water and I actually joked to them I would give them mine, which I would have if I hadn't drank out of the glass. They said they were leaving if they didn't get their food in the next 5 minutes, as we left.

At no point during our 2 hour ordeal did anyone come to us at any point, to check us on, ask if we needed another drink or a refill etc. I told my husband to ask for the check immediately because I knew it would and did take almost 30 minutes and three asks to get the check. The most bizarre thing is that there were only 7 tables total ever in the restaurant from 7-9pm. It was not busy at all and the service was so bad. I even asked my husband if he thought he were on a hidden camera show.

such a sweet place! you'd never guess such charm and tastiness are tucked away in this mini mall, but once you're in yah mon, you know you're in for a truly wonderful experience. 

upon entering, you're greeted by the lovely couple behind the establishment, and it's clear from the start that they care deeply about food and its presentation. this is not a place where you rush through your meal. items are brought out slowly, fresh from the kitchen, where they were lovingly coaxed from various ingredients into a beautifully presented supper.

my curried tofu with veggies was stellar, and the portion was enormous, serving me well as a second lunch the next day. super flavorful, and the veggies were perfectly done-just crisp enough but without a raw crunch. my dining compadres enjoyed their fish and steaks, and the bread pudding and coconut cake two of them took to go were reportedly stupendous.

i unequivocally recommend yah mon for anyone's dining needs!

Yah Mon...the restaurant is amazing! 

For the lovers of Caribbean cuisine, Yah Mon represents everything you wish could be found at most of other Jamaican restaurants...great food, nice decor, and chill atmosphere.  

In terms of the food, I usually opt for the jerk wings (best damn wings ever), stew chicken, or stew snapper.  The rice and beans are cooked perfectly.  The salad is super fresh and crisp.  Everything I've tasted at the restaurant has been OMG good (yes, really that good LOL)

The prices are commensurate with the portion and quality of the food so don't get sticker shock because they are different than what you'd pay at the little local Jamaican restaurant (IMO which should be expected at a beautifully decorated dine-in restaurant with amazing food)  

The restaurant is run by an awesome, hard working couple.  

Definitely check it out!  I highly recommend it for a date or even just for a nice dining experience.  

Please keep in mind they are only open for dinner and the hours are fairly limited.

We had a great experience at this restaurant. It's easy to miss because it is right next to a huge Walgreens by the way. The decor is classy and upscale. Each table is set up on the left for an intimate experience if that is what you are looking for. We came here for a date night and to try some gluten free jerk chicken and rice and peas which is my favorite. The staff here is very very friendly and attentive. Not a second passed that someone wasn't checking on us to make sure we had everything we. needed. The owner works out in the front and he is friendly and speaks to everyone- very nice and talkative. His wife is the chef and she came out to assure me what items were free of gluten. I can not wait to return here! Our bill was either about 75$ or 100$ before tip- that was with 3 cocktails. Very affordable. The gluten free jerk chicken, oxtails, curry goat, and rice and peas were perfect. They had the right amount of spice and saltiness. They reheated the same the next day. They give you a lot of rice so I actually reheated that a few times and every time it tasted the same. The gluten free jerk chicken wings were my favorite out of all of the meat we had because they were spicier in my opinion and I really like wings.

One word... phenomenal. 

Never have tried anything less than phenomenal! My fiancé is obsessed. This is the spot!!!

Contemporary Island Vibe- LOVE IT! 
This place is such a gem! It's about 3 min. from Tampa General Hospital, and located next to Walgreens. I ordered 2 Curry Patties and and a Rum cake that was so moist OMG Will definitely be back here!

Comfortable little restaurant in a convenient location. Easy parking and great service. 

The food though is out of control. Stop reading and get  over here to try it. 

Oxtail - A+
Sides - delicious
Prices - just right

Another mom and pop restaurant I had the pleasure of eating at during my trip, I'll definitely be back when I'm in Tampa.

I really wanted to like the food but I didnt. I ordered the red snapper with a side of cabbage. The cabbage tasted pickled which would have been nice if it were listed as such. I'm used to a more savory cabbage when eating Caribbean. The red snapper was pretty bland for me. 

The restaurant is beautifully decorated and the wait staff is outstanding so I'm hoping that it was just those dishes that I didn't like. I'm willing to try them again. That's just how good the waitstaff was. Here's hoping for a better outcome next time

Why 5 stars? Because the oxtail will forever live in my dreams.

   ---   ---   ---

I've known about Yah Mon for a while now because they routinely bring in some amazing reviews, but I wouldn't say that I typically think of Caribbean food when I'm looking for a place to grab dinner, so it wasn't until recently that I finally made it in. I'm so glad I did!

My wife is very pregnant - anything remotely spicy is basically like setting off a bomb inside her esophagus, so she decided to sit this one out. Enter: my friend Nick S, who is almost as beautiful, inside and out, but with a non-pregnant stomach like a steel trap and a can-do attitude. He was happy to sub in as my date for the evening.

And speaking of dating, this was quite the romantic venue. I was surprised to see the white tablecloth setting when we walked in. It's especially surprising, given that this restaurant is somewhat hidden in the back of a UPS Store, next to a Walgreens. But that's why Yelp is awesome - it spotlights, quite literally, a "hidden" gem like this one.

As for the food, we started off by sharing a beef patty and a chicken patty. The chicken patty had some kind of curry flavor to it, where the beef patty almost tasted like an empanada. I preferred the beef, but both were tasty!

For my entree, I ordered the oxtail and it was absolutely epic. The phrases "melts in your mouth" and "fall off the bone" are overused cliches, but combining those two together is the only way to accurately describe this dish. The meat would melt off the bone and dissolve in your mouth. After one bite, I knew that my review would be 5-stars, just based on the oxtail alone!

For those who have not had oxtail before, it was served in a bowl with some kind of dark broth. There were several bones, with small pieces of tender, delicious meat hanging off of them. I wasn't sure if I was supposed to eat this with a fork or with my hands, so I basically just kind of did both. It was a bit messy, but worth every second of digging through that delicious broth.

To drink, I ordered a virgin Island Paradise, which was like some kind of mango/strawberry daiquiri. If you like frozen drinks, you'll definitely want to order this one. 

The folks working here could not have been nicer, and of course, Nick S knew all of them because he's the Mayor of Platt Street. He's come a long way since his days in Hudson, but that's what happens when you marry royalty like Tina.

Bravo to Yah Mon - your amazing rating is well-deserved!

Island food with island hospitality. I had the sampler was was my than filling. I think the oxtails is my favorite. The curry goat was on point too. I think the jerk chicken was too spicy  but others may enjoy it.
I will be back for my samples.

First time in Tampa and this was my first spot. It's the most upscale and clean Jamaican restaurant I ever been to let's get that out the way. The sides were amazing the rice n beans and the Mac n cheese was on point. Service was on n off I asked twice for extra sauce on the side and never received it. Also this was the first jerk spot I been to which didn't have a jerk sauce either which was odd to me but either way the food was great. The sauce they use for the bbq sauce was amazing and I was disappointed I couldn't get extra lol but overall it's a bit pricey but the food is good it's definitely worth checking out if your in the area

My mind is totally blown that it took an invite from a friend to discover this hidden gem, even though I've seen reviews on this place.

JANISE'S JERK CHICKEN PASTA (5/5): I'm super impressed with the freshly made bowtie pasta; this dish was described as mild, but I can tell you from experience that they serve dishes on the spicier side, so you better make sure your water glass is full! The chicken was perfectly cooked with a ton of flavor - made me wish other restaurants would take notes! It came with a small side salad.

JANISE'S CABBAGE (4/5): Pickled & got a lot for $6 as a side. Also, their Cornbread was sweet & moist - a definite hit!

I sampled their Oxtail and Brown Stew Chicken - both are absolutely stellar, tender and Oxtail is also soaked in a brown stew with each sauce tasting unique & fragrant from Caribbean spices.

I got a glass of FREE DIVE (4/5) beer from Coppertail. It tasted better as I sipped on it w/my meal - not too hoppy.

You'll love the intimate setting and coziness of the restaurant with the lovely wife and husband duo that runs it. The wife is the only chef; the husband took our order as well as made sure everything was on point with our food - service could use a little more attention at the end when we just sat waiting for our bill.

The hardest part of writing this review is to figure out where to begin! The experience, food and service were all above and beyond!  I called in advance to make a reservation for a Friday evening since the other reviews shared that it gets busy and it is a small restaurant. Small because it's a hidden gem in Tampa! 

This family-owned and run establishment truly focuses on the full experience. The owner/host/waiter really goes above and beyond to make sure everything is just perfect - from the decor, the Caribbean music and the food. All the details make the experience one-of-a-kind.  

So, now on to the food. I'm from Puerto Rico but live in Miami and Jamaican cuisine is my absolute favorite! Want coconut water? Well, it's not just from a can or bottle, the entire coconut will be given to you with a straw. You can also refill it with your favorite drink afterwards - just a total win in my book. Don't miss out on the patties! I had the veggie patty and there was just so much flavor in every bite. Oh, and get the coco bread so you can soak up the sauce from the patties - trust me!  

I had the fried snapper with extra plantains because... well, everything is better with extra plantains. My date had the sample of all things chicken and he didn't even know where to begin. There was plenty for dinner and to take home. Just delicious and so hot when it got to our table (which is always important).  

This will certainly be my go-to place for any and all occasions. So glad they were able to stay open even with all the challenges COVID brought to the food industry. Don't miss out on this gem, your guests will thank you!

A very sweet find on the main drag, State Street.  Heartfelt, accessible, and reasonably priced (say $20-30 per person total) Argentinian cuisine in a sumptuous but casual white-tablecloth courtyard dining setting.  I can't exactly describe what I had but it involved pork, sundried tomatoes, goat cheese, creamy sauce, and it was fabulous.  Extra points for friendly but unpretentious staff and clean, luxurious bathrooms.  The owners also run a winery  back home and feature their wines here.  I would definitely return.
Another decent restaurant that closed. That's sad... Typical Argentine fare with fairly tasty weekend specials. Was hoping to pop in for another weekend getaway to SB to try some more specials =(
Our meal was excellent and the service was friendly, attentive, and informative.  And we did stare dreamily across the table from each other.

The only items I can really recommend from this place are the Empanadas (beef), the garlic parsley spread, and if you're thirsty, the Sangria is a quencher. 
The four of us ordered the Trio de Mariscos, Empanadas (beef, chicken 
& corn), a shrimp dish slathered in what tasted like Lucas pico de gallo chile powder and lemon salt. 
I had the pear salad -- what a let down. I have never had a pear salad that contained candied pear instead of FRESH pear. Yuk.
The salad wasn't bad but it also wasn't the refreshing light fruit dish I was hoping for. 
I also tried a Mojito -- my quest to find the right Mojito ended in Florence, Italy -- so this Mojito didn't have a chance. 

The garlic parsley spread is pretty potent. I had dragon breath for a good 3 hrs until I overpowered it with a few vanilla Stoli and cokes later. 

The beef empanadas were very delicious. Moist ground beef in a red sauce stuffed inside a soft / slightly crisp dough bread. 

We sat "outdoors" but it felt like we were indoors.
It was a romantic setting with dim lighting and lively atmosphere...a live Latin Jazz band performed this particular night. 

Overall...
The food was less than impressive and I don't think I experienced authentic Argentinian cuisine...however, the company I had made it worth my while.

Don't eat at many spots in SB regularly...except for this one.  Granted, the place has lost a little bit of its luster over the past 7 or 8 years, but its still okay.  

First draw, the outdoor seating and general ambiance of the place - you get that eating in a courtyard feeling, which is awesome.  I usually eat lunch here when I'm in the area, so I haven't eaten inside yet. 

Like I said, the place has degraded since I first came; not sure if it's because of a change in management or recipe or if my tastebuds just got more mature...well, not really that, just that the menu has changed.  They used to serve this really awesome salad that they sadly, no longer even remember was there.  But I'm usually satisfied with the empanadas and a salad.  They have soup and salad combos too, but I never order those.  

Service is generally good - the place is rarely too busy and overcrowded.  Price - normal, you can get a decent meal for under $20 for lunch.  

Parking - This is downtown SB, so you're probably already parked in a parking lot nearby.

My sisters and I love enjoying a pitcher of Sangria here... we were in the area on Monday for lunch and we didn't quite make it to Cafe Buenos Aires for our sangria but I'm glad that we stopped by Andersen's Bakery instead as this place is now closed.  The number is out of order and I just read in another post that they were closing.  The links on their website are down too so I guess they are gone.  So sad.  I'm glad my sisters don't know as they would be very bummed about this.

I can't believe this place is closed. I had a lovely dinner here with my cousins last year. The decor and ambiance is amazing. 

I loved all my dishes - the empanadas, ravioli, and the birthday cake. I'll miss this place :(

Great introduction to Argentinean food. We stumbled upon it several years ago after a trip to Buenos Aires and felt we were back there after the first bite. The steaks and empanadas are great. Wines by the glass selection great. Topped everything off with dulce de leche pancakes. Initial service when seated a bit haphazard last time around, but they scrambled to make up for it later on. Music on Wednesdays and Fridays great to keep the kids occupied while parents enjoy a quiet dinner.

BA is a city of foreign enchantment. 
Yeah, the women are gorgeous. Food is good, too.

This place brings a salsa mango tone to the SB area.

Bravo.

The only problem is that sometimes a couple with the rhythm and timing of a moose starts to dance.
No means no, ok?


FOOD

Salads: unique, inventive, sassy

The have a great palm hearts/avacado / gorganzola  salad

Meat: pops, filling, scintillating

Get the skirt steak for two. It's quite the entertaining spectacle. And it tastes very good, too!

Desert: fresh, stylish, fruit-tastic

A Mango sorbet mousse sort of thing. Great way to end a meal.

Flew in here last second needing lunch for 30 people... Kymberly helped us out and even though it was in the middle of lunch rush, she put together a catering order in no time at all. Best service ever. Thank you!!!!

I mostly utilize Panera Bread's lunch catering service for lunch & learn trainings at my job. The boxed sandwich lunches are convenient & really good.

This was my first time visiting a store front as I was on the hunt for some mid-day coffee. 
As I entered the store the scent of cinnamon filled the air. I was greeted by every staff person in site. I was amazed at the menu selection and healthy choice options with a calorie display chart. Well that went out the window when I became fixated on the pastry selection and my sweet tooth cravings began. 

I ordered a cafe mocha and pecan roll. The pecan roll was so big that I was only able to eat 1/3 of it & gave the rest to my 3 year old godson, who too enjoyed it. The pastry and cafe mocha were hot and fresh. The store, female restroom, and large dining area were clean. I particularly liked the recycle bin next to the trash can and the 97 health rating. I will visit again the next time I am on that side of town.

This Panera brings great value to travelers using Nashville Airport. It's a mere three minute drive to the terminal and the only non-fast food, or greasy chain in the area where folks can grab something quick to bring with them on the plane rather than paying for poor-quality and overpriced items available in the terminal. While it might seem far fetched to some to come here with good service and better value it's a 10-minute side trip that's attractive to others. 

As with all Panera's it's clean, prices are fair and there's free wifi, too. It's a great place to come kill a bit of time before a flight if you have it. Also, consider there's no risk of traffic between this location and the airport. No time on the interstate is required. Consider this next time you're coming to the airport and need a quick bite or a sandwich to bring along for the air time.

Seriously the first Panera I have gone to that seemed old and ill kept up abd just plain dirty.  Food was alright but the dirty floors and tables made it not an enjoyable experience.  I ate but would have thought about if if I saw the lack of cleanliness that was evident an hour before closing.

Nice, clean, and courteous.  Plus, I used the new mobile app for the first time with this store and it worked great.  It's down the road from Nashville International Airport, and around a lot of hotels.  Oh Yeah, the baked goods are dangerous.

The Donelson Panera Bread by Thomas Nelson Publishers is a good breakfast stop for me on the way to catch a morning flight at BNA. It is one of the newer Paneras in Nashville and has a better layout and bountiful plugs for smartphone charging before departure. The counter staff was even sharper at checkout than some other Paneras I have enjoyed and the line moved quickly. Before a power meeting I like the veggie Power  Breakfast Sandwich of spinach, avocado, tomato and egg white on a sprouted-grain bagel.

Ugh! I wish I could give them more stars because they are a great spot for working remotely. They have plenty of space and tables. I noticed they do have a sign on some tables that make them unavailable to use during COVID. 

When you walk in, you can go straight to the cashier or you can order on the tablets provided at the entrance. I ordered a cafe latte and a croissant. They give you the pastry and they have a microwave if you would like to warm it up. You pick up the food/drinks on the other side. My order was wrong and I only ordered a coffee. The lady before me also had to return her order as it was made wrong. The staff preparing the orders complained to the front staff that they were not taking the orders right because what the customer were telling them they ordered wasn't what it was coming out on the ticket. I went and got a refund for my drink and they gave me the right drink. They weren't busy inside but they had a big drive-thru crowd. 

Overall, definitely come with no expectations and you'll be fine. Sad to say but true :)
Easy parking, modern exterior with great patio sitting, friendly staff and decent iced coffee. Near the airport if you have time before a flight but want to be in the area. No issues.

I often go to Panera to pick up bagels for morning meals. The bagel packs are thirteen bagels and two tubs of cream cheese. These bagels always start the meetings on a great note.

Friendly service, good bagels (they can't compare to the bagels in New York and New Jersey, but what can?), and a full menu keep me coming back.

Mmmmm, kwesadila.....Went to Global Quesadilla for a quick n easy dinner on Sunday night.  Good stuff.  Not your stereotype cheesyn tortilla, but something totally different.

Started with chips and queso.  That's a lotta chips and queso for $4.79!  Chips are thin and crispy.  Very generous portion of hot cheese.  Not plain white queso, but some type of cheddar and other mix.  I really liked it.  A good semi-strong flavor, that wasn't just based on spice.

I got the Aztec quesadilla with aztec sauce on the side, wife and daughter split a florentine with added chicken (and red sauce came on the side).  They all come with a helping of shredded lettuce that you can put on yourself.

Since we were eating in (I like to get out of the house to eat), it was all fresh off the grill and very hot.  I have been here before, but forgot that these aren't just a bunch of cheese other toppings mixed in.  It's really a balance of all the items with the cheese.  So if you're wanting a big cheese explosion, it's not for you.  But if you want a variety of flavor in your Q, then this is for you.  My daughter said theirs was like a pizza, which she liked.  My Aztec is hard to describe, but I like it.  Mix of chicken, cheese, taco-sauce like spice, bacon (that I couldn't really taste - so that was a bit of a downer).  The menu describes it a sweet and spicy.  I think that's accurate.  Overall, Global Q is a good, different flavor experience.

Decor is pretty spartan.  That's not a knock, just how it is.  It's really just a delivery or quick-casual joint.  Workers were friendly, place was very clean.

Yelp scores another hit!  I had the BBQ chicken and my friend had the buffalo chicken.  We also had some queso to split, not knowing that the portions were so huge.  Shame on me for not reading the reviews more carefully before ordering!  Had I done that, we would have gotten one quesadilla and shared.  As it was, I had a tasty lunch for the next day.  Can't wait to be back again, loved the late dinner discount prices!!

One of my sons loves this place, so I get to sample the wares.

Overall, I would say the quesadillas are much more quesadilla and much less filling. I prefer more filling, yet it's all still tasty.

The size of these quesadillas is monumental! I'd say one could serve at least two people!

I've sampled:

The St. Louis ($7.49) -- Parmesan tomato sauce, pepperoni, Italian sausage, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a tomato-basil tortilla.

The Texas ($7.49) -- Home-made smoky sweet barbeque sauce, red onions, grilled chicken, thick-cut bacon, cheddar and monterey jack cheeses on a flour tortilla.

The Italian ($7.49) --  Parmesan tomato sauce, red onions, red and green peppers, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a tomato-basil tortilla.

The Parma ($7.49) -- Parmesan tomato sauce, grilled chicken, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a flour tortilla.

The Bleachers 'Chos ($6.99) are really the king! Yea, I know, it's just nachos. But the four-cheese queso is stupendously fabulous, and I could drink it by the gallon!

Also, as others have said: after 8 p.m., everything's $5.

Global Quesadilla. Bright red walls, sassy t-shirts, steady food. I like it here. I've come here with a big group before a few Arch Rival Roller Girls matches and they haven't disappointed yet. For less than ten bucks, you can get an obscenely large quesadilla or an obscenely large plate of nachos. They even throw in a handful of shredded lettuce just in case you need a vegetable side. Service has always been friendly and relatively competent. The concept may slightly outperform the execution, but hey -- other than tortilla and cheese, what more could you ask for?

This is my 100th review this calendar year...thus completing my attempt at the 2013 Yelp 100 challenge!

I am basing this review on what the wife ordered since she ordered better than I did at this place. I went for the Montreal steak but it was shallow and empty when compared to the Thai chicken with peanut sauce.

The Thai chicken has the right amount of crunch and spiciness to be really enjoyable. The idea of Thai flavors in a quesadilla seems odd and wrong at first but that opinion changes rapidly once you bite into the thing. Of note: the girl at the counter recommended sour cream with it and that worked too. What an odd combination of flavors and textures!

If you come here, come hungry. They put a lot of food in front of you!  I swear those tortillas must have been 14-16" in diameter.

Got more tastings tonight, as son-who-loves-quesadillas is home for spring break.

The St. Louis ($7.49) -- Parmesan tomato sauce, pepperoni, Italian sausage, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a tomato-basil tortilla. Quite fine and filling. Had a couple bites.

The American ($8.89) -- Tomato tortilla, covered with Parmesan tomato sauce, pepperoni, bacon, sausage, Cheddar jack and provel. There's something just too sweet about this quesadilla. None of the fillings qualify for sweetness, so it must be the tomato tortilla. I do not like this sweet taste.

And again, that four-cheese queso with fresh chips is irresistible and hauntingly addicting!

I did get a salad that I didn't get to eat tonight, since I was tasting the quesadillas, and I can't wait for this one -- dressing's on the side, so it will save until tomorrow lunch: New Orleans ($7.29) -- blackened grilled chicken, pico de gallo, bacon, blue cheese crumbles and blue cheese dressing.

Here we go for the kicker: The Global Quesadilla has declared quesadillas to be Irish -- so on March 17, EVERY quesadilla, salad and wrap is $5 ALL DAY LONG!!

Six tips:
1. The incredible queso is: cheddar, Monterey jack, Mozzarella and provel. The chips in generous supply have GOT to be home-made, because they're bumpy, all different shapes and soooo fresh-tasting . . . not like grocery-bought or mass-produced tortilla chips.

2. On the St. Louis quesadilla (parmesan tomato sauce, pepperoni, Italian sausage, provel and Mozzarella): sub a regular flour tortilla instead of the tomato-basil. It's a lot better. The tomato-basil has too much sweetness.

3. Get the paper menu if you're picking up or eating in, because it's chockful of coupons.

4. They've got lots of salads.

5. Right now, they've got a French Dip Quesadilla (roast beef, Mozzarella and provel with a side of hot au jus) for $6. Add peppers and onions for 99 cents.

6. For free chips and queso, text GLOBALQ to 686868

Just as I was exhausting all of my lunchtime options in Hazelwood, BAM! I get a new job in Ballwin! I promise that's not the reason I changed companies. :)

So with my first week on the job comes lots of training (Zzzzzz) and new food options (exciting!) In typical foodie fashion, I scouted out nearby options with the help of Yelp!

Enter The Global Quesadilla. Their online menu called to me with their wide variety of wraps, quesadillas, and more. Plus they offer delivery and online ordering! 

I needed to stretch my legs, so I put in my order online with plans to pick it up. Their online ordering module was easy peasy -- I chose what I wanted from the menu and the time that I wanted to pick it up. Super duper!

I went with the Buffalo Chicken Wrap (all of the wraps can be made into quesadillas, and vice versa). Buffalo wing sauce, grilled chicken, bacon, cheddar and monterey jack on a flour tortilla? Yes please! 

My order was ready when I walked in, which was nice. I'm not gonna lie -- I also got a strange sense of satisfaction when the 6 people waiting in line gave me the stink eye as I walked up, paid for my order and was on my merry way. Use da internetz, peeps! 

Anyway, the food was pretty good. It was tasty enough, but not anything mindblowing. It was also kind of on the expensive side (a wrap + a chocolate chip cookie = about 10 bucks!). 

However, given the close proximity of TGQ to my job, it's pretty much a given that I'll be back!

Such a wide variety of quesadillas that I would have never even thought of before. I have dined at Global Quesadilla a couple times, and each time have tried a different quesadilla and have yet to be disappointed. If you are in the area you should try their Sunday Happy Hour and enjoy a quesadilla for only $5, which is almost half off.

Napoleon would have loved a dang quesadilla from this place!  Fun Fun Fun and yummy food too!

Ordered the Thai Chicken on the recommendation of a staff member, and boy did she steer me in the right direction.  Well cooked chicken, spicy peanut sauce, and the right veggies in the right proportions.  

The husband had the Montreal Steak; it was good, but not as good as mine.  Lucky for him, I couldn't eat all of mine.  

Seemed really weird that they put many culture's flavors in tortillas but it really works.  I also need to mention the music; I'm not sure if it was a staffers iPod or a subscription service of some kind but it was really fun and unpredictable.  We lingered for a couple of songs just to see what would come on next.

So now the deal is after 8 p.m., everything is $6.

Recently I got the Greek Quesadilla -- Black olives, tomatoes, red onions, pepperoncinis, cucumbers and feta in a tomato tortilla, served with a side of cucumber feta sauce. This was good-tasting with a fine Greek focus.

Sunday, I did even better (after 8 p.m.) with a $6 Greek Salad -- Black olives, tomatoes, red onions, cucumbers and pepperoncinis, covered with feta, served with Greek dressing.

I had them add steak for $1.70, and the salad was divine. It lasted three meals. All the ingredients were generous, especially the feta. The greens were fresh and crisp -- not an iceberg to be found.

So, three meals for $7.70. I don't think I can do that at home and wash the dishes in hot water -- with soap!

And the queso is still grand!

I don't know whose idea it was to make quesadillas with ingredients and combinations that aren't typically found in quesadillas, but whoever that person is, he/she is a genius! The menu is kind of overwhelming simply because there are so many menu options that sound delicious! It was hard for me to decide which quesadilla I wanted, but I chose the Italian. It was really, really good. Think about a pizza but as a quesadilla. I know right, your mouth is watering right now. If you go to the restaurant, expect a wait of about 10 minutes to get your food. They also take pick-up orders over the phone and have delivery which is neat. The prices are about the $9-$10 per person, but the quesadillas are large and filling. I can't wait to stop by again to get a different quesadilla. Maybe the Greek, or the Buffalo Chicken, or the Memphis with pulled pork... who am I kidding? I don't know because they all sound so good!

This particular location of CVS is right on the corner of Napoleon and South Claiborne, near Ochsner Baptist Hospital.

Products: What you might typically find at any of these big box pharmacy chains---OTC medicines, Rx medicines, beauty products, supplements, photography accessories, snacks, etc. There are usually well-stocked, and their prices not unreasonable. 3 stars

Service: The management has definitely imparted the importance of the greeting when a customer enters the establishment. There's at least one cashier working at any time, but sometimes 2 during busier times, a security guard is almost always present, some pharmacy staff in the back, and they have "doc-in-a-box" service available for those requiring quick, non-emergency care. 3 stars

Facilities: A typical brick-and-mortar, flattop building you'd expect from this chain. There is ample private lot parking, and a drive through for the pharmacy. The major issue I've noted with the outside is the trashcan is not emptied often enough. Other than that, the exterior is quite nice. The inside is aisled, with the medical services in the rear. There is nothing really remarkable to say about the interior. It's usually tidy, though. 3 stars

Overall: This is a regular stop for me when I require a pharmacy. There is a Walgreen's across the street that's typically filled with all sorts of riffraff I try to avoid if I can. If you're in this area, go here instead. 3 stars

Here to use the MINUTE CLINIC... great idea, easy to access but PRICING IS HORRIBLE. HIGHWAY ROBERY. How can they get away with charging $35 to place a TB Skin test and then $30 to read it???? If $65 is the fee to place and read, why not just list $65? I Know why... Because no one would pay that... That's why!!!  

Hello CVS stop being dubious with your pricing.

#ThankYouThursday for CVS' minute clinic.  I came here for a flu shot and although their text message reminder was wrong, (time wise), their clinicians were great!  I've gotta say that this is one of the best CVS' I've visited in terms of friendliness. 

I will say, if you ever need a quick clinic visit, CVS is it.  It beats making a doctor's appointment waiting weeks to be seen.  

In addition to that, this store was clean, had employees willing to help and had products I've never seen at other stores.  Oh and they do sell a lot of "as seen on tv" stuff too.  

They are also applying CDC COVID-19 guidelines.  No walks-in, all appointments must be made online and the open seating area is almost obsolete.  I guess it's understandable since you're not waiting long to be seen.  Plus you can always walk around and buythings you didn't come for, like me lol. Pitiful, I know. 
Again, #thankyouthursday to CVS!

Re: COVID-19 Testing

I'll be upfront with y'all, the test itself hurts worse than getting lemon in your eyes, but I sure as hell would rather know my status than to be naive and not know. Potentially putting others at risk.

The test was super easy from beginning to end; however, the test results turnaround time is a little annoying.

I schedule my COVID-19 test the day before from their dedicated Minute Clinic link and was told it would be administered through the pharmacy drive-thru line. (little awkward you hold up the line, but tbh I didn't care because I wanted to know my status)

You never leave the car and I recommend filling out all of your information beforehand including insurance and all other documents you can online.

Upon arrival, make sure to inform them you are there for your COVID-19 test. They'll then instruct you to keep your mask on when they open up the "drawer" and hand your a brown paper bag. The bag has all of the materials needed including swabs, "what to expect" paperwork, etc.

They guide you through the process, including the swabbing/probing of your nostrils and it is uncomfortable. It only irritates while you're self administering. After that you're good to go.

You're provided a link which you need to claim your account within 24 hours of visiting to get your results. THEY DO NOT CALL YOU ABOUT YOUR RESULTS.

Instead you'll get an email alert to check your account once your test results are updated.

I was a bit annoyed that you're told you get the results between 2-4 business days. I took the test on July 1st and didn't get them until July 10th. 

Overall, I'm certain I'll still come back when I need to get a check-up a few weeks out so I can stay on top of my status.

////
This location is the closest to me from my place so I've found myself here time to time when in need of something quick or I'm feeling under the weather and need medicine + supplies.

I got the piadina first. It's a wrap of sorts. You pick the fillings . The concept is interesting but the sauce made the wrap so soggy I could not pick it up. I took it back and asked for the pasta bowl. The diavolo sauce was just ok and the pasta was just undercooked. Not quite al dente. 
The place was clean and modern but I was unimpressed by the food.

I wish I had looked at yelp before ordering from this place. 
Today was our second time ordering.
The first time it took an hour and 15 minutes for it to be delivered. We ordered a cheese burger, fried rice, wonton soup and 2 desserts. A cheesecake and a chocolate mouse cake. The fried rice was incredibly dry and the soup was so salty we didn't even eat any. The cheeseburger was okay. The dessert seemed like it had sat out for far too long.

Now today, I decided to order again because they recently dropped a flyer off at my door and I was craving soup. 
The trip tip was literally grey in color and my daughter couldn't even eat it. She had ordered it with a side of mashed potatoes and it came with a baked potato. 
The pu pu tray was actually a poo poo tray. Not one thing it came with was edible. Every single thing was burnt beyond what a decent restaurant would EVER send out. 
The chicken strips and French fries were the exact same. So burnt that when my friend tried to strip the breading off the chicken was so dry and over cooked that it wouldn't detach. 
I ordered the sizzling rice soup for myself and it wasn't bad, so we all shared that and the two cheese cakes we had also ordered and were actually okay. 
This time the order took an hour to be delivered. Which I understand the time, but not when this is the quality of food being delivered. 

I would seriously avoid ordering food from this place. Out of our $70 order maybe $55 was thrown in the trash. So disappointed.

I don't really think this place deserves a five star rating unless your basing it on speed of service, price, and portion amount.  As far as taste goes, yes the wonton soup was delicious and so was the sesame chicken.  The Chicken Lo Mein was nothing to run their screaming for it was a little bland and I absolutely dislike their fried rice.  Yes it has pork in it, i know you don't get that in too many places, but it had absolutely no flavor what so ever.

The egg roll was ginormous, i mean seriously massive.  it was just okay, i would not get again, but it was big enough to almost fill me up alone.

The portions were huge! I think it could feed four easy off one plate, so beware.

They have the standard pictures you see at any eat in and takeout chinese strip mall place.  Take that picture and double the size that is what you get for $6.99, amazing deal.

i do know they say they have 25 plates for lunch for 5.99 includes soup, egg roll and a soda, if you don't want a soda its only 4.99.  I'm assuming the portion size isn't much smaller than the dinner size according to the other reviews.

All in all i don't really think i will come back here, it isn't just my go to place.  I still have yet to find that place in the metroeast, the closest i have came for chinese is House of Hunan in ofallon and Sala Thai for thai food.

So many options I don't know what to choose!

I definitely thought my friends and I were the oldest people in the joint, you know following the school of 3 year old birthday parties ordering before us. The line went quickly and was worth it.

A small scoop will run you about $3 and they give you plenty! I ordered the  Black and Yellow Crunch which has chicory (that thing in Cafe du Monde coffee) which was awesome. It was really hard to not go with my gut and get a standard flavor, but I'm pleased I did.
The red velet was outstanding and I tasted the oatmeal chip cookie which was good for a bite, would probably be too much in a cone.

They have an array of Double Chocolate sweets all the way on the far left, but those are too chocolatey for me so I stayed away.

I wish this place had more outdoor seating.

Came in after attending the Zurich Classic golf tournament. It was a warm and a bit humid so what tastier then a ice cream cone? I lucked out and found a parking space on the street. The interior is quite cute and comfy.

The selection here is crazy huge but after sampling a couple of unusual flavors I went with the scoop of cookie monster ice cream on a cone. The ice cream hit the spot and I enjoyed it BC it wasn't overly sweet.

Creole Creamery was definitely worth checking out!

Great ice cream at decent prices. Can you ask for much more? Got to admit, we've been making our own ice cream and while it's good, we haven't figured out how they get theirs that creamy. Will keep trying but will also keep visiting ...to gather intelligence, of course.

Here's the absolute truth: I don't like ice cream very much. Gigs at two big ole ice cream chains really ruined my taste for the stuff, but I know a taste sensation when it smacks me in the taste buds. 

Here's the other truth: Everyone I've dated in the last 5 years is an absolute fiend for ice cream. I brought a date to Creole Creamery weeks after moving to New Orleans to try and cheer up my blue little love, and it worked. I was an instant hero. The case of just chocolate flavors (6 + chocolate in the hidden case) was a major selling point, especially because the chocolate flavors CHANGE. There is always something new and lovely to try in that case, which sold pretty much everyone ever. 

My present love is all about the ice cream to the point that it's a separate food group. A visit to Creole Creamery was a little overwhelming ("Suzanne, there are too many choices!") but won me a fair amount of acclaim because everything that we tasted was fab. The mini samplers are really great because it's easy to get lost in all that ice cream if you don't have One True Love for each visit. Not too many other ice cream places in this world will do a sampler with just a few bites for the picky, indecisive, and expansive among us. 

My favorites are usually Creole Cream Cheese (which is subtle so don't expect it to dazzle after eating three mini-scoops of super sugary peppermint or whatever), any sorbet that contains the word "pear" in the title, and the chocolate-orange flavor. (It seems to change names. That or I forget what it's called between each visit.) The pear thing seems odd, but this is true: the texture of the sorbet is the same as the texture of the flesh of a beautifully ripe pear. I am completely enchanted by that trick of sorbet making. 

Yes, it's cash only. Yes, it's a PITA sometimes. But there is a charm to something so quaint. (Plus, being cash-only keeps me from dropping by more often for that pear sorbet. This is probably a good move.) 

Accessibility notes: door opens out. No Braille menu or signage. High counter. Can get loud at peak hours. Both restrooms are accessible for mobility devices.

Yes yes yes. I'm currently taking a break from devouring the lavender honey ice cream, which is astounding. Creative options abound; it was very tough to choose between the many varied options ranging from cookie monster to passionfruit meringue.

I thought about writing something witty and entertaining but then I read what Scott S. wrote and his review was such a slam dunk, I figure why bother? 

My one word contribution: Amazeballs.

Humid weather calls for delicious ice cream creations! My boyfriend and I took a street car from our hotel and we stumbled upon this amazing ice cream shop. With amazing ice flavors such as lavender honey to peanut butter fudge pie....who can resist? 

Bring cash and 6 mini scoops for $6.

Who eats ice cream even when it's snowing out? This girl. 

Delicious ice cream that is worth any length of wait. They serve flavors you won't find anywhere else and will crave if Nola isn't your hometown. 

Don't be foolish, get the sampler and make sure you try the lavender honey, Mexican hot chocolate, and green fairy.

The ice cream scoopers/employees are more than happy to make recommendations which makes this place even more awesome. Definitely looking forward to coming back.

Delicious ice cream and sorbet!  Quick and friendly service with a smile. If you can't decide what to get, try thr 4 mini scoop sampler. The scoops aren't actually that mini, and it's totally worth it for $5 flat- tax is included. Just make sure you bring cash! I would recommend the mexican hot chocolate, lavender honey, pear-ginger sorbet, and the mango. So creamy and delicious!  Eat it quickly, because it does melt rather quickly. Lots of seating indoors as well as a bench outside. Easy access via the St. Charles streetcar. Definitely check this place out if you are visiting New Orleans!

I had a chance to enjoy me some Creole Creamery on a late Saturday afternoon. It wasn't overly packed, you should be able to find a table for 3 to 4 people to enjoy your deliciousness inside. Very nice family atmosphere to share some family time!

The staff is very friendly and helpful. They even let you try some flavors so you can make the best yummy choice. I went with a Rose Ice Cream that was yummy!!!! A little hint of wine and ice cream is what dreams are made of on a sugar cone, which was only 3 bucks. That's a big deal, these days you get ice cream in New Orleans you lucky some something less than $7.

Its surrounded by a coffee shop/cafe, restaurants etc. So you can do a few things in the area before enjoying your ice cream.

Make sure too bring case because it's cash only. Street parking area but you can find something within the 2 block radius.

oh you chocolate amaretto! so delicious! we walked here after lunch for a delicious ice cream treat. my mom actually ended up stealing the rest of my chocolate amaretto because it was that good. I love that they have little sample dishes you can get and will be back one day with my husband to get one :)

This place is a hybrid between Amy's and Lick in Austin. It has the creaminess of Amy's and the variety of Lick. There are a ton of ice cream flavors to choose from and a couple of sorbets as well. After trying almost all the flavors, my favorite two are mango unchained (cayenne pepper kick at the end!) and strawberry rose.

If you can't decide since all of their flavors are amazing, you can get a mini scoop sampler that comes in a banana split boat for $4. Definitely worth it but I'd probably share it with someone. The scoops are actually full-sized scoops.

Don't forget to bring cash!!!!

I saw the Creole Creamery on the Food Network's Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives and knew I had to try it whenever I visited New Orleans. It did not disappoint. It is as good as any ice cream I have tasted. It features some unique flavors. There are a couple of samplers, 4 mini scoops for $4.50 or 6 mini scoops for $6, so that you can try a few flavors. Despite the name, the mini scoops are regular size scoops. I tried the cookie monster, café au lait, lavender honey, and black and gold crunch. The café au lait and black and gold crunch are my favorites. The black and gold crunch honors the colors of the New Orleans Saints. It is comprised of French vanilla & chicory root w/ Oreos & chocolate chips. It is as delicious as it looks and sounds. Moreover, I saw the "Skyscraper" featured on the Food Network. In a tall glass, it contains cookies & cream, chocolate and vanilla layered with caramel, hot fudge and crushed oreos served with whipped cream, sprinkles, a cherry, and a wafer. It is very good and $7.50. I tried it on my second visit to the Creamery. Nevertheless, I recommend getting one of the mini scoop samplers and trying multiple unique flavors instead.

If you are visiting New Orleans and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile.

fast and friendly service.

for the indecisive (read: me), there's a nifty little mini four scoop sampler option for $4. win.

there's a old-fashioned feeling when you walk in, and it's quite spacious. at 10PM on a friday night, it was hoppin'. they have the regular flavors, but that's not why i ventured all the way there. it's all about the specialty flavors!

my mini four scoop sampler was:: steen's molasses oatmeal cookie, brown butter pecan, red velvet, and lavender honey. everything was so rich and creamy, and i wasn't disappointed. i was apprehensive about the lavender honey, but it ended up being my favorite. i'm not the biggest red velvet lover, either, but the ice cream made me a believer. the molasses oatmeal cookie really tasted like a cookie in ice cream form, and i'm a little sad to report that the brown butter pecan was just okay--not disappointing, but not unique, either.

i also had the pleasure of trying the skyscraper: cookies and cream, chocolate, and vanilla ice cream layered with caramel, hot fudge, and crushed oreo cookies. served with whipped cream and a cherry on top. its name comes from the fact that it's creole creamery's tallest creation..and, i'd argue, probably one of the most delicious.

Amazing fresh and creative flavors: ( the more interesting flavors include chartreuse or hazelnut biscotti ice creams and sorbets of cucumber or heirloom tomato)  

Other more traditional flavors are also available:  I loved my scoop of chocolate- not overly sweet with a great chocolate flavor and creamy consistency.

Reasonably priced.  Cash only.

Simply stated: the best ice cream in New Orleans. New Orleans is fortunate to have several places that offer lovely gelato or frozen yogurt. However, if you are looking for ice cream, look no further than Creole Creamery. Located in an former McKenzie's location, Creole Creamery has an old-timey ice cream shop feel. Creole Creamery has everything you would want- sundaes, ice cream sodas, milk shakes- but my favorite option is the 4 mini-scoop sampler. I love to get four chocolate flavors such as chocolate caramel chicory, chef's perfect chocolate, chocolate amaretto cheesecake, peanut butter pie, smoky salty chocolate almond... I could go on and on. If you're not in the mood for chocolate, Creole Creamery has a wide range of delectable, interesting flavors. Don't miss salted caramel if it's on the menu. If you're craving seriously scrumptious ice cream, head to Creole Creamery.

How do you just pick one of the inventive flavors that they have on the daily? Not possible for me so a 4 mini-scoop sampler is the way to go. On this visit, it was creole cream cheese (vanilla with chunks of cream cheese mixed in), golden fig, black and gold (vanilla and chicory ice cream with cookie bits), and white chocolate truffled popcorn. Yes, all of the flavors were good but I think my favorite will always be the creole cream cheese.

Staff is nice and efficient with getting you in and out. Lots of seating and a cool environment to hang out to enjoy your ice cream.

Pro tips: streetcar stop on the St. Charles line is Bordeaux. Cash only.

THEY ONLY TAKE CASH!!!  So we took our ice cream addict for a pre dinner treat and picked up a delightful tray of flavors and creams.  I had the raspberry sherbet (*** stars)  it was bland an unsweet but I guess that is my fault for coming to a creamery and ordering sherbet.

Our cream addict devoured five favors for 5 dollars with sprinkles.  She was in ice cream heaven as she drooled the flavors down her lips.  It was delightful watching how much she was enjoying the cold delight.

My other companion enjoyed the cone and unfortunately had to cover the tab because I wasn't carrying cash.  I guess its not that big of a problem being that its right next to a Chase Banking branch.   But its 2015, who doesn't take credit card these days?!?  Parking is also finicy as many of the the streets are under construction and I don't know how they feel about you parking in the strip mall across the street...

3 words for you, Creole Cream Cheese.
If you are a tourist in town, go get you some!
It is a sublime treat not to be beat.
Take the streetcar, and get off and walk the few blocks to this place.
You will be glad you did.
There is another Ice Cream Shop better than this,  but I am a definate fan of this establishments Creole Cream Cheese Ice Cream.

First of all, I'm lactose intolerant so when my friend drove me here on a stormy day before my flight back to Vegas, I was hesitant.  Is it going to be worth the pain and suffering?

First thing I saw was "NUTELLA" - you can't go wrong with that. They have a whole selection of different kinds of chocolate ice cream and that's the first thing you'll see when you come in. It was like they were holding my hand and asking me to stay so I did. The next panel was a variety of ice cream and sorbet flavors you won't see at grocery stores such as Green Fairy (absinthe with chocolate and candied orange), Calamansi, Lavender Honey, Champagne Violette, etc. I was so overwhelmed by the many options so I decided to try 1 safe flavor (Nutella Banana) and 1 weird flavor (Green Fairy) without knowing I could do a sampler. The waffle cone was delish and freshly made. Now, make sure you bring cash.

A few minutes later my stomach was cursing at me but I didn't care! I'll definitely come back to NOLA for some Creole Creamery. I'm having withdrawals right now and I only had it yesterday.

A kid, or an adult that is a kid at heart would love this whimsical dreamy dessert haven. These are the phrases that comes to mind when I envision Creole Creamery. The exterior and interior aesthetics scream antique candy/malt shop and it smells awesome once you step foot inside. When I walk inside, I immediately look at the giant chalkboard that list the current flavors. Note: Some flavors are subject to change. On my last visit I tried the Creole Strawberry Sundae-- Fresh strawberries served over a mound of our famous creole cream cheese ice cream topped with whipped cream, a cherry, and a wafer, which came in a huge sundae glass, topped with dips of creole cream cheese flavored ice cream, fresh strawberries and graham cracker.
