It looked too cute to bite into so I made sure to take a photo and upload it first. Then I took the first bite and seen rainbows. I am very dramatic but I like--well--love Creole Creamery and wish I lived down the street as a kid vs. Dairy Queen. I feel robbed. If you want, they offer samples to taste and try different unique flavors like Lavender Honey, which is also good. Next time, I am going to try either another sundae or Ice Cream Sampler--
--4 mini scoops or  6 mini scoops--so that I can try more awesome frozen goodness. 
Oh, and bring cash, this place is true to tradition, no fancy cards to swipe in this place.

Really good ice cream. The salted caramel was a bit too salty for my taste but the other flavors were amazing! Very creamy, sweet and delicious. The prices are very reasonable too. They have a whole wall of plaques of guests that have finished the giant Tchoupitoulas sundae.... I can't even imagine! The Jr. Sundae was quite big enough.

I was so excited to finally try this place! After passing it over and over again and never going in and even seeing it on tv, I knew that it was going to be good. I went in and I ordered a Black and Gold crunch in a waffle cone. It was sooo good. 

Although it's not gelato, the atmosphere of the place reminded me a lot of Brocato's with the atmosphere and decor. I guess it's the next best thing to Brocato, if you can't make it uptown. I think that this place is one of those NOLA "musts".

The best ice cream in New Orleans! There are always long waits when I come but I'd say it's worth it. There are so many unique flavors and it's the perfect amount of sweetness. I try to stop here every time I travel from Baton Rouge.

Creole Creamery is just all kinds of yummy delicious. Crazy flavors (just see Scott S.'s review for a take on that), good prices (cash only kiddies), and that old time ice cream parlor flair that just makes you feel like a kid. On a good day I'm out for the sampler which lets me get 6 mini scoops that allow me to "taste the rainbow". Then there are the days where I'm in for a solo flavor adventure, where I can concentrate on my love of the lavender honey or choc-work orange. Their ice cream cakes are also delicious. It can get crowded during the summer or on a weekend in the middle of the day. I stopped in this weekend on the way to the Prytania and it was pretty empty except I'm pretty sure there was a couple taking their engagement photo there. Now that is true dedication and love of a business!

Yum yum.  The ice cream was a bit on the expensive side but the flavors were absolutely delicious.  They have the best Salted Caramel (better than places in CA) and I loved the Creole Cream Cheese.

There's a big section of different variations of chocolate flavors as well so if you're a chocolate fan, this place is for you.

Love love love this place!!! Customer service is number 1! We were offered random flavors to try without even asking! Super duper fun!

When you walk in...it like a childhood dream! The smell of fresh baked waffle cones fills the air.  The unique chalk board menu immediately caught my eyes.  I wish I thought of this!   Love it. 

The flavors are abundant and chances daily! I was able to try Soo many flavors and my favorite so far is the coffee pecan pralines! It's rich and creamy, with a pecan praline crunch for added texture! I was not brave enough to try lavender honey. 

If you feel adventurous, take the Tchoupitoulas Challenge. 8 scoops and 8 toppings and be on their Hall of Fame Plaque if you choose to finish! 

This is a must try local joint!

*CASH ONLY*

Decor: 3/5
-cute wooden decor with table, booth or bar seating
-not quite the cleanest creamery though

Service: 3/5
-There is a sign that says "Don't be a sample hog". With over two dozen mouth watering, unique flavors it's a bit hard to limit samples to two.
-Noticed two workers touching ice cream sandwiches with their hands and then serving. 

Food: 5/5
-$2.75 for one scoop. We got two scoops
-I tried the Black & Gold based off a local's suggestion bc she claimed it contains coffee. I didn't taste any coffee. It tasted more like cookies and chocolate chip.
-The Peach & Ginger was more light, refreshing and less sweet. I love the texture and it had just the right amount of richness.
-Consider four mini scoops for less than $6 if you like tasting variety.

YUM! This would be definitely be one of my to-go dessert place if I lived here. There was a line when we came and I can see why people would wait in line for ice cream. The line goes back pretty fast though. The shop reminded me of those dixie cafes which gave off such a homely vibe. 

We had the strawberry soda with vanilla ice cream and root beer float with ice cream (forgot the one we tried). OMG. Both were so amazing and addicting. The strawberry soda definitely tasted like strawberry with a bubbly taste. Both ice cream flavours were creamy and soft!

Make sure you bring cash! Check out this place if you're in the area!

Man, this is my go to spot when I'm in NO. I make my best friend take me here at least one while I'm in town. The ice cream is so good and the flavors are heavenly. During Mardi Gras they have king cake flavor which is uh-ma-zing, and during football season the have black and gold which is just as good! Now, this place an get packed on the weekends and it's cash only! Also, don't be a sample hog, that's not cool.

Eat Ice Cream. Be Happy.

I ate ice cream and I became happy! I love this place! I always make it a point to stop by here on my every trip to NOLA. If you have a really bad case of sweet tooth as I do, this is the place for you! Curious? Adventurous? This is the place for you! Sad? In a celebratory mood? This is the place for you! 

I always get the sampler with 6 scoops since they have too many intriguing flavors that I can't wait to taste. By sampler, don't make the mistake of assuming they would be tiny scoops. They are not. It is an effort to finish it. But I promise that you would be wearing a ridiculous grin on your face by the time you leave. If you can't settle on which flavors to choose, they allow you to have a taste first -- just don't be a tasting hog, as their sign asks.

Creole Creamery's ice cream is creamier and denser compared to the other ice cream I have had before but they are not sickeningly sweet. Their traditional flavors (e.g. cookies and cream and mint chocolate chip) are excellent. But to me, what separates Creole Creamery from the other ice cream shops I've been to is their none-too-traditional flavors. My favorites would be the salted caramel, honey lavender, red velvet, Mexican hot chocolate, and strawberry jalapeño cheesecake. 

I dare you to go to Creole Creamery, try their fantastic ice cream and leave without being happy. If you win this dare, I feel very sad for you and please accept my sympathy.

Cash only.

Came here during a recent trip home from FL.  Parking is off street or you can take your chance in the private lot across the street.  The shop was busy with tourists and students but that is to be expected since it was featured on Diners, Drive Ins and Dives.  

There is no "line begins here" sign. You just push in wherever there is space, get someone's attention and place your order. I noticed they had unique flavors like Mexican hot chocolate and lavender honey. After requesting a few samples, I went with a scoop of salted caramel. Creamy and good.  The service wasn't exactly warm and friendly . More like blunt with no personality. The girl hurriedly took our orders and directed us to the cash register. Not exactly tip worthy.  

Overall, a cute little spot to stop in for a snack if you're in the area.


WARNING:
Make sure you bring cash as they do not accept debit and/or credit cards.

We stopped in here after lunch Saturday for a little dessert. The place was bustling, but we were able to get a table. I tend to prefer this location over the Lakeview location. From the old McKenzies neon side adorning the storefront outside to the old time ice cream parlor atmosphere inside - It all just culminates for a nicer experience.

They offer many unique flavors to choose from....Anywhere from Lavendar to Avocado! Be sure to sample the flavors before ordering. I was tempted to get the Mexican Hot Chocolate flavor, but after sampling it, found it had a little too much kick to it. I ended up with the Red Velvet Cake. My boyfriend loved the Cookie Monster flavor. I can't recall what our friends got, but everyone was pleased with their choices.

They make fresh waffle cones on site and it's 75 cents extra for those.. Not bad.

**CASH ONLY**
Make sure to have cash on hand when you go here as they do not accept anything else.
There are 2 banks across the street if need be.

I think I came here before my Yelp days and it was just as good as I remembered it. They have a lot of flavors and it's so hard to pick one. I tried a few and then settled on getting a cup with 2 flavors. Now the flavors are worlds apart and do not blend well, but they were so tasty I had to have both. I ate them separately, I had the red velvet and something with lavender (maybe lavender honey). The red velvet was rich and divine. The lavender was delicate and very smooth. I can't wait to go back!

My nieces & nephew loved it ! Lots of choices, good quality. The cash thing is inconvenient, but worth it to make them smile. I will come back to try that 5 scoop Sampler, I hate that I didnt see that when I was there. The staff was patient with our group of 6 kids so that was appreciated. They eagerly let the kids sample some options before making their final choices. Love the Retro vibe of the building and furnishings.

Not a lot of negative things to say about this or most dessert places, of course. The Creole Creamery did have its distinctive aspects, though, most notably an adventurous flavor menu that included a Mexican spicy chocolate flavor that had quite a serious kick to it, something I rather appreciate when I go in on a cold day for ice cream. Peppermint was less impressive.

There were some sorbets as well as ice cream. They are cash only, but the prices do come to nice round numbers.

Oh my god, Creole Creamery is amazing!  They have some of the most unique flavors of ice cream that I have ever seen.  Go to http://www.creolecreamery.com/flavors/ if you want to see a list of all the flavors they have ever had.  I tried the black and gold crunch on a cone and it was unbelievable.  It's a yellow and black cookie flavor with chicory and it rocked my world.  I definitely recommend you try this place.  Best ice cream I've had in a while.

I love ice cream parlors that venture and do unique flavors! My fave flavors were La Vie en Rose and Peaches and Cream. This is my must stop shop every time I go to NOLA for now on!

Try their scoop sampler!!

I have a huge sweet tooth and have been to ice creameries/dessert places all around. The ice cream flavors and quality here didn't jump out at me, but it's an overall solid ice cream joint.

Flavors:
-Tried a shitload of things because I'm a greedy fatass. Ones I liked the most were the creole cream cheese and salted caramel (though their salted caramel mix is predominantly more sweet with the sweet cream base).

However, $4 for 4 not-so-mini scoops in the sampler boat is an unbeatable value, like, probably even better value than mcdonalds.

Service:
-Really nice and somewhat timid teenagers working at the counter instead of some airheads with hearing problems and dance to beyonce after scooping

mmmm...a choc-work orange, so good.  Flavors to please everyone in the family from the gourmand to the 6 year old.  

This ice cream parlor does traditional bar service in the location of the original McKenzie's Bakery location (and they've left the old neon sign earning eternal love from many New Orleanians).

I came here with pals when I was visiting NOLA.  I got malted chocolate chip.  The flavor was good and the chips were crunchy and abundant.  The servings were huge and a pretty decent price.  I can imagine that I'd come here a lot in the summer if I lived in New Orleans.

Yelp's 5-star description says it all: "Woohoo! As good as it gets!" This place is soooooo good. I've been a couple times and have tried several of the flavors, all of which were fantasmical, but I always order the Lavender and Honey. I think it is my personal crack. There's just something about that flavor that makes me oooh and aaahh and feel good all over. It's so tender and gentle and loving. It's mild enough that I can eat the whole cup without getting overwhelmed; yet robust enough that every bite gives you a full flavor experience. Oh man, I just had some last night and I'm already jonesing for a fix! Even if you're not into conventionally whacky flavors, give this one a try. If you don't like it, you can come write a sad face comment on my review.

This is also in a really pretty neighborhood. There are a couple restaurants nearby, making it easy to grab dinner and a special dessert after. You cannot park in the parking lot across the street in front of the CVS portion, but if you go around the corner outside the bank they won't hassle you. The employees are super friendly (and endured my jokes about wanting to go live in the chocolate ice cream freezer, which I'm sure they have heard 10,000 times) and give you ample opportunity to sample. Just great New Orleans hospitality, atmosphere, and unique experience.

UPDATE: I finally had one of their chocolate flavors (I think double chocolate fudge or something equally crazy chocolate-y) and it was divine. My (girl)friend and I were both in those weird girly moods where boys and puppies and life in general makes you tearful and we both gravitated towards the chocolate. Needless to say, it hit the spot.

Since I was already spending half a day seeing the garden district via street car, I decided I better visit this popular spot for ice cream.  I ordered a 5 scoop sampler consisting of earl gray, banana foster, salted caramel, cafe au lait and chocolate amaretto cheesecake.  All of my choices were great, the best 2 for me were the chocolate and the cafe au lait flavors.  Not too bad of a price at $5.

Every ice cream shop in the country should follow Creole Creamery's example and offer a bowl of six mini-scoops for $5.50.  Especially places like Creole that boast way too many tantalizing innovative flavors.  Creole ranks with the greatest on this front, and if you cream yourself for creameries like Bi-Rite in San Francisco, Scoops in Los Angeles, Cones in New York, and Molly Moon's in Seattle, then you should put this place on your list.

The interior is very cute, with lots of photographs and phrases like "Eat Ice Cream" and "Be Happy" decorating the walls.  The service is friendly and generous with the samples.  I tried a ton of flavors before getting the mini sampler, perhaps defeating part of the purpose of that sampler, and most of them were pretty great.

All of the ice cream has a wonderful tuggy consistency and a creamy richness.  The base ice cream is sold as its own "naked" flavor, and it's really good, milky and not too sweet.  I like that they're proud of their base, and the quality of the product shines through in every flavor.

Like I said, I got six mini-scoops, which was a fair amount of ice cream but not too much, even coming off of two giant lunches.  For my six flavors, I chose creole cream cheese, red velvet, banana cane malt, coffee pecan brittle, peanut butter fudge, and Abita strawberry chocolate.   The creole cream cheese was my favorite, with a flavor like cream cheese but tangier, even a little bit sour.  The red velvet was so good and it actually tasted like the cake, rather than vanilla mixed with cake crumbs.  The banana cane malt tasted strongly of banana with an equally strong malty flavor, and the result was balanced and deep.  Coffee pecan brittle was as good as it sounds, nicely textured and very tasty.  Peanut butter fudge was a more adult flavor than you might imagine, very dense and dark with just a subtle layer of peanut butter.  The most out-there flavor was the Abita strawberry chocolate, and I would definitely recommend it.  Abita is the local Louisiana beer, and the flavor was prominent but mixed well with the strawberry and chocolate, both of which were also easily discernible.  My boyfriend got a scoop of the French vanilla, and this was a simpler flavor that was also quite good.  For some reason, it tasted vaguely of coconut.

I swallowed my six little scoops with ease then crawled in the back of our rental car and lay down like a beached whale.  I had two huge meals and a good dose of ice cream weighing me down, and it was only 5 o'clock.  I slept like a bloated Ignatius J. Reilly all the way to Baton Rouge.

yumm! great ice cream. probably best in the city. perfect for hot nights with a date (milkshake, two straws-- anyone?). if you're having a hard time finding a parking spot on the street, park in the CVS parking lot across the street

We were at Audobon Park and we saw the reviews for this place. I am so glad that we went! I had banana and coffee flavors but the real standout was my husband's oatmeal cookie!
I really liked this place and it was definitely worth the trip we took to get there,

This place is steller.  The ever changing ice cream selections are divine along with the wacky names.  I've never experienced a trip to the ice cream parlor they way I do when I visit Creole Creamery.  I get in there and it takes me a good minute to decide what I want (thanks to the complimentary tasters they provide).  

Only negative, I have to travel cross town to know what the daily selections are.  Wish they could update their website so I wouldn't have to travel to fnd out if Red Velvet is on the chalkboard today.

Also, if you're not dining in, then the parking lot across the street is accommodating to those quick stops to the parlor.

Mmmmmmmm.....local ice cream.

I love the Creole Cream Cheese. It's a lovely shop, with lovely workers. Anyone who enjoyed a Swenson's in their lifetime will have a great afternoon or evening here. Their shakes are great, too!

Most important thing : CASH ONLY

What's there not to love about a cute icecream joint that's churning out crafted speciality flavors?

My favorite so far has been pop champagne! It tasted like a strawberry something. I couldn't put my finger on it but I know that it was amazing!

I always choose the 6 mini scoops because I like variety. Their milkshakes are the perfect consistency too!

definitely a place you have to bring your out of town guest !

Thank you Yelp! This place is one awesome find!! Awesome creative tasty flavored ice cream! It's the Heladeria in Lares, Puerto Rico only this time it's in Louisiana. 

If you're like me, and can't decide on just one or two or three flavors and know that it'll be a long time before you ever get to visit a place like this: get the 6-MINI SCOOP SAMPLER for $5.50 it's an awesome value! All the flavors I had were delicious. Highly recommend all of them. 

MEXICAN HOT CHOCOLATE
LAVENDER HONEY
GREEN FAIRY (absinthe ice cream with dark chocolate chunks and candied orange peel)
DOBERGE CAKE
CAFE AU LAIT
PETIT FOURS (almond flavored)

This place totally made my day. Screw the snowballs and froyo in this city.  Come here.

I was too excited to get ice cream that on this first visit here, I didn't confirm what time they opened!   Derf!  I'll remember noon for next time!   

Initial smiles from the girl behind the counter who had such a bubbly personality, made me like this place already! 
Second thing, sooooo many flavors!!  I asked her some popular ones and her faves and she directed me to the chocolate freezer.   Yep!  They have one freezer dedicated to chocolate flavors!

After a few samples I settled on getting the mini scoop sampler.  4 mini scoops for $5.
Mexican Hot Chocolate
King Cake
Coffee Pecan Brittle
Salted Caramel

I didn't sample the King Cake prior to getting it but from what the girl described, and being a signature NOLA dessert, I got it.  I think I would enjoy a regular cake version of this more than this ice cream adaption, but it was interesting none the less, and had the flavors she described.

The other flavors I got were equally delicious, but the winner of this sampler is the Mexican Hot Chocolate.  Dark and creamy with a spicy note that lingers. Next time I'm here, I would definitely come back for another scoop of this and to try others on their list!  


(NOLA trip: 2/2015)

Always delicious!

This is probably the best ice cream in Nola. I love that it is in an old mcKenzie's, I just wish that they had more room to accommodate the tons of people that want ice cream.

I usually get a banana split, but last night I got the bananas foster in a waffle cone. Even their waffle cone is exceptional!

This place has too many good flavors to choose from.

After stressing out over what to get, and starting to draw the ire from the employee who had to keep giving me tiny little samples before I could decide, I finally got a cone with two flavors: Peanut Butter Fudge Pie and Cookie Monster.

This is some excellent ice cream - very creamy, yet dense and super sweet (in a good way) and flavorful.

If I didn't already eat 4 or 5 meals before coming here, I definitely would have attacked one of the many awesome looking sundaes.

There's a sign on the wall that "Eat Ice Cream, Be Happy" (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/creole-creamery-new-orleans?select=IQCKcqbE9ixXi3g5WuKVww). They are correct. You will definitely leave here happy.

Get out of here!!! This place is out of this world. The flavors are so creative and varied and they deliver. All unique and well balanced. I had the Mini Scoop tasting which was perfect. I had the Green Fairy, Magnolia, Creole Cream Cheese, La Vie En Rose, White Peach and Elderflower Sorbet, and Lome and Thai Basil. Wow. All of them rocked on their own way. I don't even think I have a favorite. I wish I could have tried all of their amazing flavors. This is a must stop next time I am in town. Oh but it is cash only!!

With such a variety of flavors, from the everyday "favorite choclate" to to off-the-wall "blueberry mojito", there is something for every taste here! Along with a few favorites that make their daily appearence, there are several new flavors every week. There's always something new and exotic to try.

Want more than just ice cream? They also make decadent sundaes (not that the ice cream really needs anything) and fabulous sodas! 

Feeling daring, try the "Tchopitoulas Challenge": 8 GIANT scoops or ice cream, toppings, whipped cream, and wafers- $25. If you finish it all by yourself, you get a placard with your name on it!

Family friendly and located in a lovely part of town, on Prytania St., right down the street from the Prytania theatre (such a good date night all set up for you!)

If they have it, try the Oatmeal Molasses Cookie flavor (YUM!) or, if it's Saints season, the Black and Gold Crunch is always a crowd pleaser!

WARNING: CASH ONLY!

kickass ice cream that all tastes home-made.  In a MMMMMMMGOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOD way.

no sissy flavors- everything is spiced full force.

the chocolate cherry cordial icecream burned and iced my throat and tummy all the way down.  I always tip the kids behind the counter 100 percent of my total, if only so they dont notice my flavor erection as i giggle out the door.

Skipped the Tchoupitoulas Challenge since I came from a Commander's Palace meal AND the sampler seems a better deal anyway. The 6-scoop sampler for $7 (cash only) was set up with the cafe au lait, lavender honey, molasses petit four, chocolate amaretto, chocolate five spice, and creole cream cheese (all the most popular flavors they cited sounded lame).

If you find yourself wanting ice cream, this is the place to go (skip Coldstone, where I swear their mint ice cream tastes like toothpaste..ick.)! They have some unique flavors (with clever names) to choose from, but their traditional flavors are equally well done.

My personal favorites are Cookie Monster (which I believe has Oreos and cookie dough) and Black and Gold Crunch (which may or may not be seasonal, not sure). 

Tip: If you can't possibly choose one flavor and instead want a selection, you can order a sampler which has four small scoops. It's not too much more expensive than a normal scoop! 
They also cater (we used them for several events when I went to Tulane) and have even been known to create a new flavor for an event.

Every guidebook mentioned Creole Creamery as a go to place to visit in New Orleans. Since my hubby and I ate at Milk Bar for lunch, we wanted to try this ice cream place for dessert. I like the ice cream parlor decor and the variety of ice cream or sorbets to choose from. The flavors were very unique. 

We had the Banana Cane Malt and Honey Lavender. Banana ice cream was sweet and had a strong banana flavor. Honey lavender had a strong lavender flavor. It was like eating a flower. The ice cream was good and creamy, but it didn't "pop" as I would have liked it. 

After eating at Chinatown Ice Cream Factory in NYC, I expected some more "wow" to the ice cream. 

Cash only.

This place is legit (hey hey), and with all their cooky flavors, I always opt for the sampler.  The scoops are smaller, but you get to try variety.  The samplers come is 4 or 6 mini scoops, and its a rare visit that I don't go that route.  

Of course, they also have sundaes, shakes, floates, sodas, splits.  The selection of flavors is the best in the city, and they always (at least every time I have visited) have at least six different types of chocolate available.  They had a Mexican chocolate once that was hot and sweet...let me tell you...I still think about it.  They rotate flavors, sometimes eliminating ones that aren't popular (I assume) so you never know what they will have...but no worries...they will have several flavors you will want and they always have the basics.  

Keep in mind:  cash only!

It's a must check out and once you do, it will be incorporated into your rotation.  Go get ice cream...you'll be glad you did.

This may sound ridiculous, but I have been in Creole Creamery five times and sampled their ice creams before taking the dive into actually buying a scoop. This weekend I went ahead and bought two! 

The first thing you notice when you walk in here is the cheery decor and the smell. The smell almost overwhelms you. It is sugary sweet and, honestly, I would come in here just to have a whiff. 

Then you catch a glimpse of the first ice cream area. An entire section devoted to chocolate creations. The Mexican Hot Chocolate is a favorite of mine because it combines sweet dark chocolate with spices like cayenne pepper. But, I ordered up a serving of Chockwork Orange- dark chocolate ice cream with specks of chocolate and an orange flavor. It reminded me of those orange chocolate balls that you smash on the table and they open up into orange segments. 
The boyfriend, of course, asks the staff if they have plain chocolate. They're confused for a second about why anyone would want plain chocolate when they've created all of these other amazing concoctions, but then serve him some with a smile. 
To compliment my chockwork orange I add on some pumpkin cheesecake. Creole Creamery does make a plain cheesecake flavor but it was the first day of October so I had to go with the pumpkin. It was creamy and just the right blend of the two flavors. 
Other flavors like the oatmeal cookie with molasses is heavenly. If you're looking for something original try the lavender honey- at first it's a little like soap- floral and not something your palate is used to- but it really is good. Try it! They will be happy to oblige with tastings (trust me). The only problem there is that they use tiny wooden spoons so you get the wood flavor that overpowers any ice cream. 

The prices, I must add, are just right. I actually was taken back when she rang up my order. Creole Creamery is much cheaper than my favorite ice cream in Boston. NOTE: cash only!!

I'm putting it in writing that one day I will do the Tchoupitoulas challenge- 15 scoops plus toppings that you have to finish all by yourself to get your name on a plaque on the wall. I will do it.

Yum yum yum!  What more needs to be said.  We walked from our bed & breakfast place and was ready for a treat!  

Only 2 people working on a warm Saturday though which made the wait long and slow service.  Cash only!  

A wide variety of flavors and they will give you samples (reasonable).  I settled for the white chocolate raspberry crisp and sister got almond chocolate cheesecake.  Creamy and refreshing.  

You can't go wrong here!

I was super excited to visit Creole Creamery during our weekend trip to NOLA this past February, due to the reviews and amazing-sounding flavors.

I feel so wrong for doing this - literally, I feel that maybe I am incorrect in my assessment of this place because it is so highly rated across the board - but I have to give this place 3 stars.

It just didn't quite live up to the hype. We order the 6 mini scoops for $6, so between that and the samples, we def gave it a fair shake.

(Ha, pun.)

We tried the following flavors: Cookie Monster, Creole Cream Cheese, Red Velvet, Absinthe, and Steen's Molasses Oatmeal Cookie. Very inventive flavors, for sure; I just wasn't all that impressed with the taste. Except for the oatmeal cookie, which had a really bold flavor, they were all a little muted for my liking. I wish the flavors had been more distinctive...less bland... more robust...however you want to say it, I just wish they'd been more memorable.

The cash only thing didn't bother me, but only because I live in Brooklyn where they think they're too cool for credit card machines. So I've learned to carry some cash everywhere. But I can see how it would be annoying for those who usually don't.

All in all, a fun experience, but I wouldn't come out of my way to go again.

In spite of the fact this place doesn't take credit cards Creole Creamery is a New Orleans staple when it comes it ice cream. New Orleans in spite of the heat is not a big ice cream town but yet Creole Creamery and their exotic flavors have been attracting fans for years. So many great flavors its probably the best deal to get little scoops of as many flavors as you can get just remember its cash only.

I am boring and just got a cup of mint chocolate chip. He got Mango Unchained because he is obsessed with Tarantino......I was very happy with my choice. Him not so much. You wouldn't be able to tell, since he ate a large cone in about 15 seconds....we will definitely be back, but I think we will both make different choices.

The staff was super fast, super friendly, and all around it was a great little Sunday night dessert date :)

I think this place has been reading its reviews and has gotten to be too big for itself. First of all I think the ice cream is overrated and overpriced, Jenis you are not Creole Creamery. Then today I say to myself let me get some ice cream since I am in the area and change up from my normal Yogurtland and when I walk in they insult their customers with a sign calling you a hog if you want to try the ice cream before buying it. Since they don't have plain vanilla, chocolate or strawberry trying the ice cream before you over pay for the experience of a full cup or cone should be an option. Problem is that the process is slowed because they never have enough people working behind the counter. This place already ticked me off by being CASH ONLY which I hate and again is a big sign saying come rob me but to be insulted when I hit the door is over the top. I will never step foot in this place again. Next time CC if you want to speed up the process of sales hire more people don't insult your customers. Across the street to Yogurtland I go, btw where I can get as many sample as I want for free.

It's funny that they have to put up a sign behind the counter telling people not to ask for multiple free samples. 

The ice cream tastes delicious and is a cut above the rest.  There must be something in the humidity and temperature of NOLA which allows for this kind of perfection to take place. An array of interesting flavours like lavender honey and butternut squash.
Waffle cones are freshly pressed.

This ia a great stop if you have a $3 street car day pass and are riding down St. Charles. Nice treat to accompany a walk through the Garden District.

A very large variety of ice cream, cones and a mixture of tasty treats. The guy behind the counter was very helpful and answered any question that I had for him.

You can't go wrong with any flavor combination. My only complaint is that it is cash only. Besides that its a great place to cool of and relax with made on the premise ice cream.

Also take a gander at the walls, there is a lot of local flavor here and I dont' just mean the ice cream. What is also neat is you can look through the window in the back and watch the ice cream chef in action. 

This place is a real treat in more ways than one!

I did not suffer the same complaints as other Yelpers reported.  I enjoyed some free samples of a couple ice creams I might not have otherwise ordered from a friendly helpful waitperson.  I like that you can put together a combo scoop and chose amaretto chocolate and ultimate chocolate.  This is really a really nice premium product.  I got mine in a cup.  I didn't really want to see the gallon jugs of Caro in the bakeshop window.  GMOs bum me out.  Could I at least pretend you don't use corn syrup.  Ice cream is indulgent but does it have to have this extra level of bad for you?  Why not use a glucose syrup like they do in Europe for example.  If I could find out which products they use this in, I might go back again to avoid the corn syrup.

I love this place!! I can't believe I have not came here sooner. I came here on a Wednesday and I was sad and Gloomy just driving round looking for a sugar sweets place. I initially went someone else but they actually was closing up. So I walked around and bumped into this place. I'm so Glad I did. I love this place! I walked in and immediately the place lifted my spirits. The waitress did such a nice job with offering me taste test of the various ice cream flavors.. I was like nah I'm okay. Then she suggested a piece of heaven to me. Just what I was looking for but didn't know i was looking for it. The hot brownie a la mode. O MFG!!! Thank YOU. AMAZING goodness that exploded in my life. She definitely did not disappoint with her suggestions and she just did such a great job being attentive. Then the Beach Boys were playing in the background and I felt so Happy!! I will be back to bring my lil son here ti enjoy this goodness!!
JUST A WARNING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! They do not take cards, CASH ONLY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I've been holding off writing a review for this place for over a year now, my sweet creamy love of my neighborhood. Any trip to my bank involves a trip across the street for ice cream, which is pretty much officially the only reason to bank with Chase by the way. I think their ATM machine is the official enabler for Creole Creamery.

Look, there are Cold Stones out there, and Pinkberries, and then of course your Ben & Jerry's and your Haagen-Dazs, and your classic 31 flavored Baskin-Robbins, but Creole Creamery is in a class of its own. Scratch that. It didn't even go to school with those others. While they were in class, Creole Creamery was in their homes playing hide the waffle cone with their moms.

31 flavors? Creole Creamery sees your 31 and raises you 3100 gajillion billion. Then it winks at you and leans back, not even caring if you think it's bluffing with a made-up number. It's Creole muthafuckin' Creamery and it'll take your cash money either way. If you want to keep your green, you're sitting at the wrong table in a casino you just aren't ready for.

Remember that episode of Seinfeld where they fell in love with the non-fat yogurt place? Well if you say you're sorry you can't, well you can just stuff your sorries in a sack, Mister! Creole Creamery dares you to compare it to anything non-fat, while flashing Newman for beads... Newman!!

Here, look at some of these flavors they've concocted thus far:

Avocado w/ Mint & Sour Cream
Banana & Brown Sugar Cheesecake
Blueberry Maple Pecan
Buttered Lemon & Pine Nut
Butterscotch - Pumpkin Bundt Cake
Candied Bacon & Cinnamon
Cayenne Lime Butter
Chocolate Pineapple Chip
Creole Cream Cheese w/ Wild Blueberry - Pecan Cornbread
Dark Chocolate w/ Coconut & Fresh Mint
Gorgonzola & Toasted Walnut
Honeydew w/ Ricotta & Pistachio
Honeyed Pear w/ Goat Cheese
Lavender-Pecan Chocolate
Orange Peel Ginger Cheesecake
Peach w/ Champagne & Mint
Smoked Gouda
Strawberry Jalapeno Cheesecake
Sweet Corn w/ Cracked Pepper & Raspberry Coulis
Sweet Potato Sassafras Praline
Vanilla-Bourbon w/ Brown Sugar
White Chocolate Bread Pudding

I know right? It's like you're pretty sure you just smoked something green and leafy just reading that list. And that's only a fraction of them. Don't deny yourself the experience of a visit to Creole Creamery. And definitely don't go with just Vanilla. That's like going to Paris and eating dinner at McDonalds. That's a pimp-slappable offense on all 7 continents by the way.

Basically, you can't go wrong with this place. Taste the rainbow and Skittles be damned. This is flavor country.

The
Palette
Of flavors
And late hours
Are excellent for surviving summer.
Wonderful ice cream place. Very unique flavors. Not too sweet. Highly recommend if you are in the area.

Such a great place to be a glutton. Sit at the fountain bar and enjoy the sites, sounds, and flavors of happiness. Every flavor was fantastic. Creamy creamy goodness. I got the sampler boat and was so blissed out I don't remember what flavors I had. My friend had the sundae with the Captain Crunch on it. Anything with Captain Crunch gets thumbs up from us.

We search far and wide for unique creameries. We found one here. 

Lavender honey. 
Sarsaparilla. 

Get them.

And get the 6 mini scoops for $6. You won't regret it.

The service is always fantastic here and the variety/options will also make you return over and over so that you can try everything. 
It was rather a chilly day- NOT a day I'd normally go for ice cream. But I was walking by and it's King Cake season so King Cake ice cream seemed inevitable.  But I also had the butterscotch. Both amazing!

The wife had seen this place on Food Network, and we decided it would be a good stop for the kiddos on the way out of NOLA. Suspicion confirmed. The flavor board is all sorts of zany, appealing to toddlers and adults alike.

I'm not a huge ice cream person (I basically stick to my go-to, Blue Bell's chocolate chip cookie dough), but I got completely suckered by the black and gold crunch. On a cake cone, natch. It's vanilla-chicory ice cream with chocolate chips and oreos. And it's amazing.

Home of the old McKenzies which they have still kept the neon glowing, What's there to say about Creole Creamery that Hasn't been said in the over 120+ reviews.  The place is local and uses fresh local ingredients and puts out a solid product and adventurous flavors that, if you dar to try, you will be pleasantly surprised.  An almost overwhelming amount of flavors to choose from and many of them are seasonal and use fresh, local seasonal ingredients and there is absolutely no reason to go to a baskin robbins marble slab or any other national chain when you have creole creamery.. and you should hang your head in shame for doing so!

They have a Tchoupitulas challenge which it just an overwhelming amount of ice cream and there are several people who have actually eaten it.. crazy!  The sundae is available at both locations but the official "challenge" can only be done at this one.

If you want ice cream go to Creole Creamery for a taste of New Orleans at its best.

Items Selected:
Samples:  Red Velvet, Lavender Honey, Gorgonzola and Candied Walnut, Petit Four, Nectar Sherbet, Salty Smoky Chocolate Almond, Creole Cream Cheese
Black and Gold Crunch (Chicory French Vanilla, Oreo Cookies, Chocolate Chips,) Pumpkin Praline, Café au Lait, Steen's Molasses Oatmeal Cookies

A longtime staple of New Orleans' Uptown district, the balmy weather making one wonder why more artisan Ice Cream shops have not popped up over the years, The Creole Creamery has occupied its space at 4924 Prytania Street since 2004 and although perhaps no longer *the* most adventurous concept in an ever-evolving market, the results speak to a place that has earned its accolades while continuing to innovate and mature.

Presenting diners with the mantra of "Eat Ice Cream.  Be Happy.," a phrase that even the most ardent dieter would have trouble disagreeing with, The Creole Creamery offers some three-dozen flavors including Sugar-free and Sorbet daily, the choice of toppings no less numerous with choices contributing to Sundaes, Shakes and other concoctions made to accommodate a broad range of tastes.

Limiting samples during peak times, a 5:55pm arrival finding the store sparsely populated and servers happy to chat, it was with seven small spoonfuls that The Creole Creamery showed off a wide range of bold flavors amidst a high milk-fat base with substantial creaminess, the signature Creole Cream Cheese a tangy taste unlike any experienced prior while the Nectar Sorbet was also something New Orleans Specific , a flavor something like Fruit Punch meets Frangipane that speaks of the city's long lost Soda Fountains and Sno-ball Shops. 

Happy to see the $5 "baby scoop sampler" as a menu option, each scoop of the quartet far larger than most of the balls sold in Italy for €3-4, Pumpkin Praline tasted something like a mixture of the two Holiday Pies with more restrained sweetness than either, the Molasses Oatmeal Cookie another unique taste with great complexity by way of taste as well as texture, the Café Au Lait and Black & Gold Crunch fairly similar in terms of the base with the former better for Coffee lovers while the latter should appeal to kids - and adults - of all ages.

I love when a place has non-dairy/vegan options. Their coconut sorbet was creamy as any dairy ice cream out there. Waffle cones were crispy and fresh as if they were just made. I like that. Hubby had two scoops of two different chocolate ice creams that he raved about for two days. The line is long, but worth every minute of your wait time. This is in a fairly pedestrian area - but watch for traffic as the cars move quickly. BTW - so does the line, so don't be deterred when you see how long it is!

This is my ultimate favorite go-to spot for ice cream! The only catch is Creole Creamery accepts CASH ONLY, but that could be easily fixed with nearby ATM machines. There are a variety of flavors to choose from, ranging from unique flavors, holiday specials, and the classic strawberry, vanilla, and chocolate ice cream. 

The texture and consistency is so heavenly and creamy, no other ice cream locations in NOLA can ever compare!! My favorite flavor is honey lavender and their peppermint flavored ice cream is also one of their very bests! They also have many unique selections of sundaes. My family's favorite is the brownie sundae! Overall, Creole creamery is definitely worth the buck due to their remarkable homemade flavors, generous scoops, and friendly service!! Please, if you are traveling around here, go grab a scoop, or two, or three! You will not regret it!

Creole creamery is the best ice cream in NOLA!  A very laid back spot in uptown that still has a very "locals" vibe, Creole dishes up scoops that push the flavor envelope.

Standards aside, they have seasonal highlights like their Black & Gold which they only make during the Saints season.  As soon as the Saints say their last "who dat?" and pack it in, so goes the flavor. Pumpkin praline was a definite "here today, gone tomorrow" (next month) flavor. 

What sets Creole Creamery apart is not just their base cream, which is reminiscent of "New England" style ice cream, but also their experimentation with flavors, which seem to work out amazingly.

An example of their adventurous side would be their green fairy which is an herb-saint (absinthe) ice cream. 

This is a cash only place that is worth the street car ride uptown.

Ice cream lovers should take the trip on the St Charles line and be surprised by the local gem.

I kept telling my mom and sister that Creole Creamery was just as good as Bi-Rite Creamery in San Francisco. The only differences are that there's no wait and it's half the price and double the portion size! 

I was going to order a single but when I saw the size of the cup, I asked if the single could include two different flavors. I wanted Christmas Morning and my sister wanted Black and Gold so we split a single for around $3. This was some of the best ice cream I've ever had. They should seriously think about expanding to San Francisco.

Creole Creamery is a very popular ice cream parlor. For years I have heard how wonderful it was, but had never sampled their product.

Now that I have, I can understand the hype. The amount and type of flavors can be a little overwhelming so make sure and try several. The workers are very helpful, but there are signs that ask you not to be a tasting hog. Apparently some people come in and sample everything, but purchase nothing. Don't be that guy.

After trying a couple, I settled on my choice. While I don't remember what it was called, I do remember that it was very good. I realize that isn't particularly helpful if you're trying to read this review and get what I got, but you'll figure it out.

If you're uptown and want ice cream, come here.

Yummmmmmmmmmm. Yum. 

Stopped in here for a birthday treat with the Hubs. The atmosphere is pretty cool, all old school, complete with the fountain shop style serving pieces. The young staff was friendly and content enough.

The list of flavors is overwhelming. Thankfully, the shop graciously offers complimentary tastings as well as sampler dishes in case you're like me and just can't get it together enough to choose just one flavor. 

Hubby and I split a four scoop sampler consisting of Peanut Butter Fudge, Mexican Chocolate, Lavender Honey, and the infamous Creole Cream Cheese. 

All four flavors were divine and tasted exactly how I imagined and desired them to taste, although the Lavender Honey was especially magical. Why? Because usually lavender foods try too damn hard and leave me thinking "yep, tastes like a plant, not sure what I was expecting." This ice cream, however, just sweetens your mouth with a little kiss of lavender, mellowed out by the smooth honey. I'm pretty sure my husband will keep this treat on standby for forgiveness bribery.

Huge fan!

So many flavors so little time! I stop in here now every time I go to the CVS across the street. No temptation from YogurtLand (sorry). 

Cash only.... I'm sure everyone knows

Lavender Honey = divine, light, subtle
Butterscotch = rich and creamy
Coffee Toffee something or other = coffee ice cream with some crunch, can't go wrong

All the people who work here are great at letting you try the flavors before deciding, very patient. I remember the days when I worked at an ice cream counter, and I wanted to throttle someone for holding up the line, guess it wasn't my line of work?

Who's with me to try the Tchoupitoulas?!?

I didn't find any of their flavors to be particularly strong, which I didn't like. All of the ice cream is good, but on the blander side. I liked lavender honey and salted caramel the most. We got a sampler and tried their waffle cone as well. 

Cash only! Staff gave us extra samples and were really nice, even with signs saying to get limited samples. Really thankful for that!

If you love ice cream you have to go to Creole Creamery! The flavors are on a big chalkboard and the staff is very friendly. They have sooo many unique homemade flavors. The Butterscotch is incredible. The Creole Cream Cheesecake and the Dulce de Leche are also scrumptious. Get the mini scoops so you can try six different flavors because it is so hard to pick just one. 

I will definitely keep coming back to this INCREDIBLE ice cream shop.

Salted caramel in a waffle cone. Yummy!! 

Tried a sample of the famous Cookie Monster but wasn't too impressed. Also tried a sample of the lavender honey and didn't like it loll. But those two flavors seem to be popular in the yelp review highlights so y'all should ask to sample it at least. The employees are really nice and patient. They let me try like 5 flavors haha

I LOVE the Creamery.  Came here this past weekend with my gf, roommate, his gf, and a another couple.  We were all served pretty quickly and as always, the ice cream was absolutely delicious!

The prices are fair, the staff is friendly, and I love the atmosphere.

My only issue is that it's cash-only.  But with a bank a half-block away and the prices so low, this usually isn't a problem.

Peanut butter fudge pie, salted caramel, black and gold crunch, Hubigs apple pie are just a few of the flavors they have.  Every time I go I see new flavors added to the menu. It is almost overwhelming because they all sound so curiously good, which is why I love getting the 4 or 6 mini scoops. It is a great way to get a good taste of several different flavors if you are indecisive like me. 

Along with all the flavors they also have shakes, creative sundaes, nectar sodas and coffee. If you are a peanut butter and chocolate fan you have met your match with the peanut butter fudge sundae. Your choice of ice cream topped with warm peanut putter and hot fudge that lasts to the last bite.  It really doesn't get any better than that!

I love ice cream! I love that they have so many flavors, and not just your run of the mill flavors either. I don't have a favorite because I love them all so much. 

I am disappointed that they don't experiment with other sweeteners though. As a diabetic, I'm always on the hunt for good ice cream that uses different sweeteners. I'm extra disappointed that their sugar free ice cream is not made by them. But I am happy to report that if you're lactose intolerant, they have quite a few great and unique tasting non-dairy treats for you.

Add me to the scores of believers... I mean fans. I live close to Creole Creamery and yet I only recently tried it. Probably for that very reason. I don't think I'll be the same again after this. Luckily I exhibit a fair degree of self control. The cruelest irony that ice cream season coincides with swimsuit season. WHATEV, right?

So, this is the best ice cream I have ever had. Want some cockamamie never-hear-of-before flavors (Green Fairy, anyone?) They've got that here. Die hard traditionalist? They've got you covered (anything from vanilla to butter pecan). Diabetic? There's both an ice cream and a special sundae for you. Can't have dairy? While I didn't see any soy or nut ice creams, they do have sorbet. On a diet? Well, then, I'm afraid you're SOL. There's a kiddie cup, but it's for the kids only. Their small cup *probably* won't kill you too much, though.

First visit had me sampling my friend's choice: red velvet cake. While not a fan of red velvet cake, I can't deny this ice cream brings it to a whole new level. Instead of being merely red velvet flavored ice cream, it's got bits of red velvet cake throughout. Scream-worthy, right?

Second visit, I came with a mission: to try four flavors via the 4 scoop sample (you get 4 small scoops for $4. A bargain, no?) My choices: sweet corn with raspberry and black peppercorn, Green Fairy, butterscotch butter pecan, and blueberry pie, my favorites being the latter two, however I wouldn't throw the other two out of bed... I mean the bowl. Green Fairy wins the creative award because I'd never think to have absinthe-flavored ice cream! It also has bittersweet chocolate and orange peels, which make for a really tasty, unique concoction. My only issue is that I'm not a fan of chocolate bits in ice cream, otherwise, I'd be all over this. Butterscotch butter pecan brings a bit of a more intense, grown up twist to an old timey classic (I had to wonder if there's booze in it). Blueberry pie... sigh. Just perfect. I need a moment alone with it. Perhaps even a year. The sweet corn is a bit too overpowered by the peppercorns and could stand to have more raspberry, in my opinion. That's the *only* criticism I'd have. With all those flavor choices, who cares? Oh and feel free to sample if you're on the fence (but obey the sign: don't be a sample hog).

The best thing about this ice cream is that it's not crazy sweet. I realize that sounds ridiculous, but it's true. Take the salted caramel, for example (I know you will). I tried my friend's and was quite taken with it. I love the idea of salted caramel but I've had that flavor before at other places and found it sickeningly sweet- not at all salty. Creole Creamery has somehow managed to achieve just the right balance of flavor.

And so, I bid Creole Creamery farewell... meaning in this review. Already planning what flavors I'm going to try next visit. Hey, it's ice cream season, don't you know?

After seeing this on the Food Network, I knew I had to try it.  I looked online at the flavors a couple times and would always pick out my perfect sundae!  I ordered four mini-scoop sampler which consisted of: Cookie Monster, Chocolate, Mascarpone and I Scream Fudge.  I topped that off with some chocolate jimmys, and it looked pretty darn good.  I was expecting it to be creamier than it was. I thought that the flavors weren't complex and didn't last too long on the palate. It was icey rather than creamy.  I had some other ice cream in the NOLA area that tasted the same, so either Creole Creamery supplied them, or that's just the Louisiana way of making ice cream.  Either way, I feel like it I go back I would end up putting a cup of chocolate sauce on my sundae to get some real flavor.  I did enjoy their innovative flavors, it's not every day you see Gorgonzola and Toasted Walnut ice cream.  

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AzseSGgDC6bVtMPEYo1CNQ?select=8e1M58W5T_E4-lAzCDbzVA

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AzseSGgDC6bVtMPEYo1CNQ?select=K0bIY9rIeQtMuK4EMtWD6g
rich creamy ice cream with weird flavors, love it

We took the longest walk in the absolute hottest weather to get here - and every step was worth it. 

We had the six-scoop sampler to share, and these were my favorite flavors: 
1. lavender honey - MY FAVE. light, delicious, sweet. 
2. white peach sorbet. 
3. salted caramel - definitely strongly salted. 
4. red velvet cake 
5. nectar sorbet - a little flavorless 
6. la rose en vie - got this for the novelty factor; didn't really like it.

So, on a hot, eighty six degree day like this in New Orleans, I couldn't go wrong with some good ole' fashioned ice cream from the Creole Creamery. On my drive there, I went through various neighborhoods, road constructions, and even smaller food stores nearby. On my arrival, the place was hidden amongst a long narrow street with cars parked left and right. If you're looking for some excellent parking, park at the CVS Pharmacy right next to the place, and you'll be able to enjoy a short walk there!

Anyways, let's move on to the actual review! Well, I wanted the best bang for my buck, so I went for the six scoop (mini-sampler) for only $7.00 FLAT! Cash only! Not really too big of a deal for me, and I even left a tip seeing as the woman at the counter provided me with excellent customer service in regards to explaining the various items on the menu to me and offering samplers along the way! 

After shuffling through all the flavors, I narrowed it down to these six:

Honey Lavender: 
Rating: 4.2/5
The honey lavender wasn't too bad, as with a majority of their ice cream, this one was really smooth. Best enjoyed eaten inside, because if you're going for a six scoop, the heat's going to melt your ice cream pretty quickly and soon enough you'll have ice cream soup! The flavor was definitely on point, it wasn't heavy, but rather faint. Additionally, it wasn't too sweet, but in between, you'd be able to taste the lavender more than anything else!

Creole Cream Cheese:
Rating: 4/5
Whenever you get the ice cream, there will be small pieces of cream cheese inside, not an overload of it! That's just the way I like it! The name for me was somewhat off putting in that I'm not a big fan of cream cheese, but at least the ice cream was delicious. The bits and pieces of cream cheese along the way definitely made the experience worthwhile, so why not give this one a try?!

Salted Caramel: 
Rating: 3.5/5
One thing that I NEED, and I mean, absolutely NEED in my salted caramel ice cream, is the flavor and color! The salted caramel at the Creole Creamery was whitish, not the usual lightish brown I'm used to in terms of most ice cream shops. The caramel taste was light, but I didn't receive any of the "salted" flavor in the ice cream which I've previously received at other ice cream locations on the West coast. Overall, it could use more color, texture, and flavor.

Banana's Foster:
Rating: 4.75/5
What I loved about this particular flavor is the bits and pieces of small caramel and banana present in each bite I took. A hearty banana's foster on a hot day like this one is all I'd ever need to cheer me up! Not much to say about this flavor besides the fact that it tasted EXACTLY like the actual dessert, which made me smile a bit on the inside. 

Cafe Au Lait:
Rating: 4.5/5
I'm a HUGE coffee enthusiast, so trying this flavor was mandatory! The ice cream was pretty amazing, it tasted just like a freshly brewed cup of Cafe Au Lait which actually made my tastebuds fall in love with this particular scoop of ice cream. The sweetness of the ice cream wasn't overpowering, but just right! 

Pistachio: 
Rating: 3.5/5
Pistachio? Sort of difficult to pull off, but they got it sort of right. The ice cream's sort of light green, but the taste is smooth and creamy, more light then anything. 

In conclusion, my only regret is that I was on a timed schedule and didn't have enough time to sit outside the entire time to enjoy the ice cream to the full extent! If you ever have extra time, this is the perfect place to take your close friends, family, girlfriend, etc. The customer service is extremely nice, and the employees are always attentive to your needs! Don't be afraid to stop by!

Debated between this and a snow cone place, and I'm so happy we picked this one bc they have a lavieen rosé flavor that was so heavenly. I loved the soft texture and the light crunch inside. It was melting a bit faster than I would have liked, but still enjoyed it thoroughly. 

The other flavors we tried were all really good. Service was fine and the interior is very bright and colorful, creating a happy feel right as you enter. There were some fun artwork on the walls that were hilariously cute. I'd def recommend if you are in the area!

Incredible ice cream!!! We tried multiple flavors among the four of us and the girl behind the counter was so sweet and patient. It was hard for us to pick 4 so we trusted the recommendations she made and enjoyed our ice creams very much!

The best ice cream, here in New Orleans! Thick texture, with lots of delicious and local flavors.

Cafe au lait was wonderful, and the red velvet used a really good cream cheese ice cream base.  Chef's Ultimate Chocolate was great reminded me of Haagen Dazs belgian chocolate chip from childhood days. 

Kids liked the colorful sorbets like Nectar (tasted like cherry), raspberry, satsuma. Interesting names for flavors too.

Abundant portions, reasonable prices, friendly service. Stopped here on the way to Hermes parade. Plenty to space to sit in this Uptown New Orleans favorite.

I've Yelped a lot of ice cream and gelato over the years. This place beats all the expensive places in SF Bay area for awesomeness across a wide range of flavors, and it's more beloved than my favorite gelato places in Italy.

Love the red neon McKenzie's sign out front on Prytania, pays homage to a local icon from the past.
Really good ice cream. I wouldn't necessarily call it creamy ice cream.

This place is the picture perfect small town ice cream shop. They had a ton of flavors - both old fashioned and new/ adventurous! I think it's really cute they kept all the digital photos of kids who have come in as well!
BEST ICE CREAM IN THE CITY: & about as corny, quirky & cozily Uptown as it gets.

Excellent creamery, much needed with the heat in NOLA.  
Just don't take the avocado-based ice cream, I didn't particularly find it appetizing, but the idea is certainly appealing...A good step towards a healthier eating habit.

It's been years since I've been here and I'm so glad I finally came back!  Creole creamery offers "real" ice cream, not the cheap kind you find in stores.  They offer an array of unique flavors all ranging from lavendar honey to mexican hot chocolate.  I have yet to try a bad flavor, but there's so many flavors, I didn't want to ask for a bunch of samples!  The lavendar honey is currently my favorite and the red velvet is just DIVINE!  My friend described the lavendar honey as tasting like "home" and I know what she means!  The moment you taste it, it's like you're sitting on the front porch of a country side home.  I loved te feeling!  Aside from the lavendar honey, I had this unbearable pull to try the pumpkin pistachio, but I didn't because I didn't want to bother the worker! Sighss...I now regret it because I had a feeling it would have been amazing!  The ice cream quality is really just above and beyond. So rich, creamy, and decadent! I wouldn't mind intaking a couple hundred of calories for this treat!

Creole creamery has a classic 1950's like feel to it that I adore!  It always reminds me of the ice cream shop that's in the movie Grease!  All in all, I can't wait to be back try a bunch more samples!

After a lackluster experience at the less-than-average Camellia grill, we needed a pick-me-up! The Creole Creamery was just the ticket! We've got a place in Kansas City called Syla's and Maddy's - I'm sure everyone's got their own one and the same: a college-town creamery, rich with hope and an aloof grassroots sensibility of purpose. Chalkboards abound, flavors are fun, and the prices are considerate. This place is precisely that. 

I think we walked out of there filled with homemade ice cream, sans $5 and change - a real deal. In places such as this, you cannot go wrong with any of their wonderful flavor profiles atop a waffle cone. Something new that I hadn't seen before was the venerable "TCHOUPITOULAS!" It's $30 worth of bad decisions, eight scoops and a whole mess of stuff. If you eat it all you get your name on a placard or something. While we were there, a boy was trying to impress a bunch of friend-zone girls to little avail - but he impressed me. Anyone with the sensibilities - or lack thereof - to take on I believe I heard 5 pounds of ice cream for a placard and some attention has wholeheartedly gotten mine undivided whilst I remain with a solitary cone and intrigue of what comes next. He gave up, looked sick, and lost the gaze of us all. Failure. 

Still, it's a nice little shop, good art, good feel, and better ice cream. If you're happening by, have a scoop of something worth the sin of indulgence.

They have some wacky flavors in this place and just their chocolate flavors take up an entire corner.  There is almost always a line to be served here and they offer free tastings of their many and varied flavors.  I'm all old fashioned and mainly just stick to my strawberry but I sometimes mix it up with one of their chocolate flavors or anything else that might catch my eye.  The only big negative about this place, other than the sometimes long lines, is that they only take cash.  They also have the infamous Tchoupitoulas Sundae challenge, that consists of 8 scoops of ice cream and then a huge onslaught of toppings, and completion of this challenge gets your name on the wall (I've never achieved this accolade but I could certainly eat the eight scoops but all those toppings just gross me out).

After an afternoon spent in the sculpture garden at City Park this ice cream hit the spot.  They have 5 or 6 cute little bistro tables inside so, there is plenty of room to indulge inside in the air conditioning.

I ordered the six scoop sampler for $6.00.  Anyone who knows me knows that I am not a huge ice cream fan but, these flavors were creative and delicious.  You like chocolate, banana split, coffee, marshmallow, etc????? well you will find it here.  If you can't decide grab the sampler that also comes in a 4 scoop size.

This place is my favorite. It's got an old feel soda shop when you walk inside. Cash only! We used to live uptown and would walk here weekly to get ice cream from here! Ice cream is homemade by the owner and the flavors extend from normal ice creams, sherbets, etc to out of this world delicious flavors!! My favorite go to is the Cookie Monster which is oreo and cookie dough ice cream combined. Love! On a waffle cone! They also do Birthday parties and ice cream challenges!! One day.....I will do a challenge! Life goal.

So many incredible flavors!! I love ice cream, and the choices here always make it so hard for me to decide. I typically get two flavors no matter what size I get. They let you try samples. There is always a line, but it moves fast. 

My favorites are the cookies and cream, black and gold, and christmas flavors. Can't go wrong here!

I am not an ice cream fan. I know, weird. I seriously get a craving like once a year, eat it, then I'm good. However when I do have a craving the only place in town I am willing to go is Creole Creamery. They have the most delicious and interesting flavors. One of my favorite flavors this summer was blackberry with cornbread in it. The flavors rotate with the seasons! The staff is very friendly and patient and will let you try lots of samples. There is usually abundant seating inside but with COVID it's take and go (and wear a mask!!).

Try the Skyscraper!

This is a very good place to stop by for some Southern style love and sweets. I had some of the best ice cream here. I would come back in a heart beat.

What did I have? I jad the "Skysxraper of Course!"

The Skyscraper..Creole Cream, Honey Lavender, Cookie Monster with Caramel and Hot Fudge. You get q fancy glass and extra long cold spoon for penetrating the bottom and scraping it alongside the layers of ice cream on its way up..a true spoonful makes this a fuve star treat!

They also have smaller treats that are perfect for those with less appetitie, dieting or for the little ones. Dieting sucks so try out the Red Velvet Cake Shake as the side kick for the little one.

One of the best ice cream treats I have had..the skyscraper is as good as it gets.

Delicious ice cream - totally worth the trek from French Quarter! I'm so glad Creole Creamery is off the beaten path from Magazine street. 

With so many unique flavors more than I can count on my fingers and toes (Salty Smokey Almond, Cookie Monster, and Creole Cream Cheese...), I'm glad that I got the Blueberry Pie in a leak free waffle cone.  I enjoyed it and truly reminded me of Blueberry Pie! My husband enjoyed the Cookie Monster with cookie dough, Oreos, and Chip AHoy!

Despite being a sample hog (I didn't the comical poster when I walked in!), the staff was friendly and patient. 

Best ice cream shop in New Orleans, I can see why it ranks in the top 50  shops in the nation. Skip the beignets and come straight here!

This place is bomb!! If you're craving some good and too sweet ice cream with awesome flavor selection, this is the place. 

On our first night in NOLA, we headed out here for some ice cream. With just the yelp reviews to guide us - this place didn't disappoint! We ordered 6 mini scoops for $7. We had Tiger Bait, Black & Gold, Creole Cream Cheese, Smoky Salted Chocolate, Chocolate Amaretto, Cafe Au Lait, Molasses Oatmeal Cookie. Everything was so delicious! But our favorite was Tiger Bait, Black & Gold and Creole Cream Cheese. It was sooooo good, we had to go back and take our family to share the love!

They are reasonably priced and would definitely recommend this place to anyone in town visiting. 

I didn't see a parking lot, so grab the first spot you see on the street. Just make sure not to block the atm driveway next door.

I fell for the hype. I'm a big fan of unusual ice cream flavors, and this place advertised tons of them, so on our trip to NOLa, after eating at Commanders, we made the short extra trolley trek out here to try this ice cream, which I thought would be just as impressive as all the various other amazing ice cream shops I've been to. It was... decent ice cream. Pretty good, even. I'd give it 4 stars instead of 3 because it's pretty cheap - but I could also tell the difference in quality between a place like this, and a place that can get away with charging 5 bucks for a cup instead of 3. And they didn't have that many exotic flavors when I was there, either. I don't even remember which flavors I ended up getting, and it's only been a couple weeks. Granted, it's been a *crazy* couple weeks, but still.

This is one of the best Ice cream shops I have ever been too! They have fresh ice cream actually made at the store. The chocolate milkshake is to absolutely die for. I use to live near this business and went here quite a few times during the summer. On occasion when I happen to be passing through uptown I still stop in once in a while. My only complaints were the cash and carry policy.  Also the the items on the menu were a little pricey. But overall it is still worth it to go in and check it out.

I was always willing to withdraw cash to get my Creole Creamery fix; however, they now accept cards and I can go swipe my card like Paris Hilton at Juicy Couture circa early 2000s.

They have some of the best flavors ever. I can't get enough of them. I only allow myself to go once in a blue moon, because my sweet tooth gets me in so much trouble.

The staff is so friendly and now during COVID-19 they only allow a handful of people in at a time and there is no indoor dining. I honestly always grabbed my ice cream to go and walked around the neighborhood, such a pretty area.

My go-to is a split small and tbh it's a good amount! If you love queso be a foodie like me and order a waffle cone on the side. Break it up into "chips" and you can thank me later.

Go get yourself some ice cream!

My constant craving of Ice-cream always leads me back to Creole Creamery. I tend to go to these independent shops as I feel they really do provide a unique experience along with great tasting treats. This place has many flavors with unique names and tastes. On different occasions I may just get a scoop or sometimes I indulge in a banana split. Huge scoops here so be sure to have a big appetite. My friend had the sampler of like 5 different chocolate scoops. Each one rich and very different. I had the Lavender Honey before and it was smooth and creamy. Such an exuberant flavor to choose! I can go on and on about their extensive list of flavors, but you could check out the website to see the list. Things from Witch's Brew, Wasabi, Mojito, to Doberge. I usually always take friends here who are visiting the city or who have just never been before! Don't forget to bring cash though!

**EAT ICE CREAM. BE HAPPY.**

I didn't come to New Orleans to lose weight,
so I ordered a sundae here.

ABOUT
======
Old-school ice cream parlor offers an ever-changing variety of flavors, 
including regional specialties and fountain classics.

Creole Creamery is on Prytania in the Uptown neighborhood of New Orleans, 
near the Prytania Theater.

AMBIANCE
=========
Cute, ultra- family-friendly vibes.
Felt like 1960's vintage ice cream parlor
with neon signs and black and white
checkered tiled floors.

ICE CREAM
=========
PEANUT BUTTER FUDGE SUNDAE - $6.25
Two scoops of I Scream Fudge! ice cream served in a peanut butter-coated glass with hot fudge, chopped peanuts, whipped cream, a cherry, and a wafer.
The ice cream isn't as creamy as I would like and a bit too sweet, but the flavors were nostalgically wonderful. 
Love the sticky fudge and the cherry.
RATING: 4/5 

SERVICE
========
Friendly, not over the top.
People left us alone and was
helpful with flavors.
RATING: 4/5

OVERALL
========
Good stop after the movies at the Prytania Theater.
Great for dates and family days.

RECOMMEND.

If you're back in your home state for the holiday break, why not go to a local ice cream spot that is homemade and pretty popular??!!  My girlfriend and I have been visiting here three times now every time we make it home (except for last year when I got sick with the cold) and left very satisfied.  This one was no exception.

My first flavor I chose was the lavender honey.  Second flavor was brown butter pecan.  Both were very impressive.  This latest visit brought on a tough choice.  Either it was creole cream cheese or Petit Four, which was wedding cake mixed in with cake batter ice cream.  After sampling both, I picked the Petit Four.  Wise choice indeed.  I picked two scoops in a waffle cone and man......talk about going to ice cream heaven.  Being a fan of cake batter ice cream, how can you go wrong???  The mix of wedding cake and ice cream worked out perfectly.  It was sweet, but not too sweet for my liking.  Definitely will go down as one of my favorites to pick from this place.

If you're ever visiting New Orleans or are a local who has yet to go to a homegrown spot that has a following, do come by.  You will not be disappointed.

My national ice cream tour continues ... 

YUM. Lots of original flavors, including one called a chockwork orange -- a rich chocolate with an unexpected, but nice, orange flair at the end. My waffle cone was fresh and tasty. Happiness. 

They only accept cash, but there is a Chase bank next door.

Omg! Omg! What can I say.... White Chocolate Truffled Popcorn Ice Cream!!!! What a delicious creation and who even thought of that.  The taste of white chocolate with huge chunks of popcorn infused in truffle... Mixed match in heaven. I can not imagine such a mix would taste so wonderful also with a crunchy waffle cone I'm in cloud nine. 

I also got to taste their other flavored such as breakfast at tiffanys, coffee and banana something... All of their ice cream tasted so creamy and homemade. Of course whichever flavored you want to try don't hesitate to ask for a sample. I love ice cream shops like this shop, coming up with unique ideas and most of all its homemade which makes the flavored very unique. 

I highly recommend anyone to try out this ice cream parlor because I believe it's top notch in Nola
Can have long lines but they keep it going pretty fast. Lots of flavors. The creole cream cheese was ok, not a strong flavor. The salted caramel was very good though. Parking was easy!

I love ice cream.  It may be my favorite food.  Whenever I can find a good local, homemade ice cream place, I am all over it.  I came here twice in 2 days...... it was that good!

First time here I ordered their 4 scoop sampler.  They give you 4 half sized scoops for $3.50.  I got blueberry pie, red velvet cake, cookie monster and jalapeno strawberry cheesecake.  All 4 were awesome.  My favorite by far was the jalapeno strawberry cheesecake.  This, along with Melted Chocolate from Molly Moons in Seattle, are my 2 favorite flavors I have encountered at a local ice cream place.  The flavors just worked.  You get the rich strawberry cheesecake and then all of a sudden you get a hint of jalapeno.  They take the seeds out so you don't get the heat, just the taste.  Damn it was good!

2nd day here I got 2 scoops in a waffle cone.  One scoop of the jalapeno strawberry cheesecake and then a scoop of the "Mango Unchained"  It was mango ice cream with cayenne pepper and Southern Comfort mixed in.  You could get a tiny bit of spice from the cayenne and then a smooth light mango taste as well as a hint of the SC.  These 2 flavors combined equaled a hell of an ice cream cone.  Another great thing they do here is they bend the bottom of their waffle cones.  Most places roll their cones and leave the sharp pointy tip.  That's cool and all,  but when its hot like it is in NO, your ice cream melts and then drips out the bottom.  These guys kind of rounded and tucked under the tip so its almost like a flat bottom.  No leakage and and its an easier way to eat it.  

This place is located in hipster heaven but whatever....when you make ice cream this good, Ill travel anywhere, anytime.  I will definitely be back in 2 weeks.

** CASH ONLY **

One of my friends recommended this place when I was travelling in NOLA and so glad he did! Dropped by on a Saturday night and there was a line out the door - always a good sign! 

They offer a lot of unique of flavors - some I've never even heard of before! I sampled a good amount of them, which were all good, and the employees were still nice and polite with me. I ended up getting the Petit Four and my god, probably the best ice cream I've ever had. Petit Four is like an almond flavor, with pieces of almond cake in it! Apparently this is a popular thing in the South? I've never heard of it in California!

I only got one scoop, which I still have dreams about, and wish I got more, but I was out of cash... cue sad music. One of the places you have to visit when you're in NOLA!

I was going to attempt the Tchoupitoulas Challenge...then I took an arrow to the knee.

I haven't tasted a flavor here that I wouldn't buy at least a scoop of. I'm not a fan of absurdly sweet things, so a five-star rating of an ice cream shop was not something I saw coming. But this place deserves it without a doubt. I would give it eight stars if I could.

The sorbets are fantastic, especially the 'weird' flavors! Strawberry and basil (which I find to be a natural(complimentary) flavor pairing, but no, is not a typical ice cream duo) is fit for the nine divines. The Mexican hot chocolate could warm any Nord. 

A word of warning: don't forget your septims! This place is cash only. Seriously, don't try to pay with a card. The cashiers have fought mudcrabs fiercer than you.

PS. The pints are surprisingly inexpensive for the quality of the ice cream/sorbet you're getting.

Various ice cream flavors available! I wanted to try all of it, but I didn't want to give the worker a hard time. I ended up getting a banana split (which was $8). It comes with 3 scoops of ice cream of your choice, a whole banana sliced in half, whipped cream topped off with fudge and a cherry. I like how you can also add toppings. I chose captain crunch. oreos, and graham crackers. It was all worth the calories!!

Why 5 stars? Because the salted caramel is world class.

   ---   ---   ---

I am still kicking myself for passing on the salted caramel. Even though I sampled it, I made a rushed decision and went with cookies and cream. Meanwhile my friend got ole reliable SC, and as I kept stealing spoonfuls from him, I cried a little. Why oh why did I make such a dumb decision?! It's not that mine was bad, it's just that salted caramel tasted like Jesus's tears. Insanely delicious.

Cash only! And worth every penny.

Creole Creamery offers a TON of creative flavors and combinations. When I used to eat dairy, my favorite was their Rose or Lavender Honey.
