Now that I no longer eat dairy, I go for their sorbet which is light, airy and not overly sweet. Tonight I opted for the nectar sorbet with a waffle cone. So good! The cone tastes fresh which I feel deserves a mention because I've had stale cones at other places before. My fiancé got the Pear & Ginger sorbet which was also very well done. They have many more flavors here compared to their Lakeview location. 

I love Creole Creamery!

In a town known more for snowballs than ice cream this place sets the mark for really terrific ice cream. Great range of flavors, helpful staff and its seems like enough seating, be warned it often gets busy here and the lines can be long.

Get in mah belly!!! 

Seriously, this place is bananas! The flavors they've here is unlike any other flavors I've seen like calamansi sorbet, lavender honey, and tomato sorbet just to name a few. I was  so stoked to see that they've calamansi (a small gumball sized citrus fruit found in the Philippines and taste like an orange, lemon and lime had a love child.) Now I can see why the couple we came with love this place! 

I couldn't decide on which flavors to get and knew that I couldn't eat every flavor. Well maybe if I was having a bad day I could. Instead,  I did the mini scoop of four flavors. Word to the wise....there is no such thing as mini ...just big and bigger. My three mini scoops turned out to be huugeee.  It was soo good. Will be coming back here when I am in NOLA!

This place is heaven.

Came to NOLA in August 2012 and Creole Creamery was one of our destination spots, even if it was a bit far from the French Quarter. We spent the day walking around the neighborhoods nearby and exploring the graveyard (which, incidentally, we came to because the graveyard where the Voodoo Queen is buried was closed to the public that day. Something about someone breaking the lock on the gate there). When done exploring, we were all drenched in sweat and craving both water and some ice cream. It was an added bonus when we were hit with the AC upon walking in. 

The shop itself is old fashioned. Warm atmosphere, welcoming employees, and that AC...can't complain when you come in during the summer! 

I love that they have samplers here. There were so many flavors that I couldn't decide on which to settle on. So I picked a bunch!

I don't remember all the flavors I got, but what stood out was the Blueberry Mojito flavor. Everyone I was with tried to steal this scoop from me, much to my chagrin. If I had known this was so amazing, I would have skipped the sampler and gotten a cone with this stuff. It's like crack. SO good! And I loved that it was specifically a summer flavor. The other flavors were equally delicious, but didn't hold a candle to the blueberry one. 

Water here is $1.50 and is ice cold when you get it. They have an ice cream challenge here that my friend and I were thinking about trying, but the risk of brain freeze made us chicken out. Maybe next time, if I ever come back to NOLA...

Been craving for their lavender flavor ice cream so we head over here after our brunch. I got the lavender and salted caramel ice cream, so delish. They only thing I have a complaint about was that our server didn't wear gloves when scooping our ice cream. When he was grabbing a spoon for my ice cream, the spoon slide from the ice cream and touch his hand that was holding my ice cream cup and he still handed to me without asking if I'm ok with it or he can replace it. At a time like this, we all should be taking precaution to stop the spread of Covid.

Ok, here's the deal, like many Asians, I am lactose intolerant. If I weren't so stubborn I would take some lactaid pill to help me digest lactose since I love everything dairy (cheese, yogurt, ice cream etc.). Hey, at least I drink almond milk and not real milk, that really causes me pain.

Anywho, with all that TMI, I must say that Creole Creamery is the best darned local ice cream in NOLA hands down! My go to flavor is a small cup of half lavender and half red velvet. But on this fine occasion they had King Cake flavor which I had many moons ago, read maybe last year around Mardi Gras time? Point being, I had to have it. Plus they're so friendly letting you try the flavors. But once I tried the king cake I was done, game over, it was a wrap!

One of the things I enjoy about this place is that they have a variety of seating with booths, tables, outdoor benches, a diverse group of folks from young kiddos to the elderly, etc.! Plus they have a whole front case filled with chocolate flavors, what's not to love? If you like spicy flavors and chocolate then I highly recommend the Mexican chocolate flavor-delish! Also, you can ask them what the new flavors/rotating ones are. Keep in mind though that the one in Lakeview doesn't have the same flavors as the one on Prytania in uptown so you may want to call ahead if you more craving something specific!

And don't forget it's cash only! It's also located near yummy eating places like Kyoto (great sushi), La Thai (elegant Thai joint, La Crepe Nanou (so damned romantic it makes my heart ache), St. James Cheese Company, and my favorite yogurt joint, Yogurtland!

Happy Ice Cream Devouring!

Amazing ice cream. The ice cream here is creamy, rich, yet not overly sweet like other places such as Sucre. My kid had the Creole clown sundae, and it was perfect for him. I ordered the mini sampler that comes with for scoops. I chose magnolia flower, honey lavender, rose, and fig with goat cheese. I wanted to try something different, and it was great. We also got the Creole cream cheese, and that was very good too, but it really didn't taste like cheese.

We absolutely enjoyed our visit to the Creole Creamery. First off --- yummmm! All flavors I sampled were rich, creamy and delicious. Secondly, who can beat outstanding service? We were immediately greeted upon entering and offered samples of flavors our eyes seemed to linger on. My daughter settled upon the "clown" version -- with lavender and a cookie flavor. Very cute way to decorate ice cream with cone, gummy bears and whipped cream. Our "scoop specialist" made it quickly and interacted so well with my daughter while she tried a few flavors. I decided to have the red velvet cake and creole cream cheese. Both very yummy, but I had food envy when I saw someone's brownie Sundae ( definitely my choice next time!) My hubby selected one of the yummy cream soda floats -- very good and generous portion. I was also blown away by the affordability of the menu. Overall, great visit and happy we tried it out. We will definitely return on our next visit to New Orleans! Way to go Creole Creamery.

I try to be healthy.

Honestly.

I eat whole grains (I even ate quinoa for breakfast today), I exercise a lot, I take my vitties every day, I take the stairs in the subway.

But I do all these because ice cream exists.

Ice cream.  The best combination of two simple words in the English language.

Ice cream is everywhere.  Great ice cream outside the Bay Area is seldom.

I read about Creole Creamery in my guidebook.  I heard about Creole Creamery from a fellow passenger en route to NOLA. I felt I HAD to try it. Then, I tasted perfection.

Lavender Honey. Bananas Foster Ice Cream. Pecan Brittle. Black and Gold. Red Velvet. Homemade waffle cones.  The list goes on, ad infinitum.

And no, I did not order the Tchoupitoulas Challenge with eight scoops, eight toppings, whipped cream, and a cherry, for $25.  I'd have to run a marathon to warrant that. Or at least a return visit to NOLA.

This is probably the Creole Creamery location that most people think of when you mention the local chain.   It's a cute little location (McKenzie's) on Prytania.  The parking is just street parking, but I've never had a hard time finding a mostly close spot.  They're not always the quickest when there's a line, but usually if that's the case, I'll head somewhere else to get my sweet snack.

They have a great selection of ice creams, and they rotate some of the flavors depending on the season.  The service is hit or miss, but the ice cream is delicious, so you put up with the lines or lack of seating.  Taking it to go is almost always the best option, and there are other places nearby if you want to take your snack and walk around.  

They also have espresso, so if you're an affogato fan, they've got you covered.

This New Orleans staple is located on Prytania Street. The streets is filled with local shops and the personality you would hope to find uptown. 
The ice-cream can actually be seen made in the enclosure they have in the back of the shop. 
This is definitely one of my favorite to go spots when I need something rich and creamy with a crunchy waffle cone! 
The red velvet and king cake flavor does not disappoint. 
You can try different flavors but don't take advantage of the situation as their little sign clearly states on the wall behind the counter! Lol The straight forwardness of N'awlins at its finest! 
Just a very cozy spot to bring the family and friends to enjoy dessert!

This place always has a line or people in the store. I went one time and decided on their White Chocolate Red Berry Crisp ice cream and I haven't had it since. I have been DYING for this flavor to come back.
But every now and then, I will come anyways because it is very good. The store is located uptown with street parking. Warning, the parking lot across the street has patrol watching you so don't get a ticket or boot. 
They only take cash so there are two Chase banks and a drug store across the street for you to get cash out if you don't have any. 

I decided to go with a scoop of the Pear & Balsamic Caramel which was a unique taste but I liked it alot. I tried the Earl Tea flavor was good too. 

They let you taste but don't get too feisty with the taste tests. One scoop is plenty for me!

The ice cream at Creole Creamery is really rich and creamy. For me, almost overwhelmingly so. I consider myself to be an ice cream lover, but I find it difficult to finish one scoop here (not a bad thing, since I probably shouldn't consume more than one big scoop anyway).

I've had the red velvet and the black and gold. Both were deeelicious. I appreciate the creativity in flavor choices and also the patience of the folks behind the counter as we customers try various flavors.

I think next time I'm going to try a sorbet.

A bunch of folks have said it already, but yeah, it's cash only.

This is hands down some of the best ice cream you will ever have. It is made fresh in shop and you can tell. The service is super friendly, however it is very efficient. The last time I was here there were only two young ladies working behind the counter. The line was so long it was practically out the door yet they kept it moving. The wait wasn't too long either, considering. This is our place to go when in need of ice cream in the New Orleans area!

Let's me start by saying, I love ice cream.   Love, love, love ice cream. 

So it's after 10pm and I'm in town just for a few hours. I had a great dinner now I need dessert. So YELP has a few suggestions but this one was nearby.

It's a local hangout which gets pretty crowded. It's late but this little place is packed. I'm talking at least 30 people hanging out.  

I tried a couple of samples before deciding on the Cream Cheese and Mexican hot chocolate ice cream in my sundae with butterfinger and was ready!!  The cashier warned me to the Mexican Hot had Cayenne pepper in it and I said "I hope so"!! 

Best sundae ever!! It was creamy, the scoops were big and I tried, really I did but I couldn't finish all of it. So I owe it to myself to go back again for more ice cream from this little gem.

I suppose I get to be the fly in the punch bowl on my review here, but I like to tell it how it is. Creole Creamery is mostly hype. Lemme explain.

Product: A limited selection of custom ice creams and toppings. I find their fare to be middling at best, and nothing to write home about. Oh, and last I checked, it was cash only in this establishment. Welcome back to the 19th Century!! (2 stars)

Service: Imagine, if you will, your typical arrogant hipster barista. Now, transplant said barista into an ice cream parlor. Yep, it's like that. (2 stars, generously)

Facilities: The best thing about this place to me, mostly out of nostalgia of it being a former McKenzies. Open McKenzies back up please, as this place really isn't that great. I hope you like neighborhood street parking, because that's your only option here if you're driving. I'm like 99% sure there's no bike racks, either, last I went. Of course, it is only about a block off the St. Charles street car line, if you can remember the cross street. 

Inside, it's clean and rather spartan in appearance. Nothing really special. (3 stars)

Bonus: Dunno if they do it any longer, but they used to have a "Tchoupitoulas Challenge", where you ate this ginormous bowl of ice cream and toppings. The winner board has been moved to the back of the building near the bathrooms. I defeated that beast, and it cost me $25. Oh, and they never put my name on the plaque. I'm a little grumpy over it still.

Overall: Cash-only and limited products with subpar service? I vigorously support local business, but go hit up 504 off Freret for your local ice cream fix. Their hours are lousy too. Ignore the hype. (2 stars)

I never knew that this is the way REAL ice cream tasted!
CASH ONLY ;)

Creole creamery rescued the day. After a couple of salty tacos I was looking for something sweet, and I'm so glad I stumbled upon the sampler. Your pick of 4 or 6 mini scoops of ice cream. A flight of ice cream? Yes, please! I asked for a couple of recommendations and ended up with King's cake, praline, molasses, and coconut. I couldn't pick my favorite. They were all my favorites. Great flavor combinations, fresh ingredients. Yum.

Not sure why it took me six months to get in here (maybe will-power?), but I'll be back, over and over, again. Without a doubt, one of the finest, most unique, ice cream parlors, anywhere!  

Flavors like: Almond Flan, Almond Toffee, Anise Cookie, Apple Berry, Apricot-Grand Marnier, Avocado & Cream, Balsamic Strawberry, Banana Cream Daiquiri, Blackberry Mojito, Blue Cheese Walnut, Blueberry w/ Mint & Orange, Buttered Lemon & Pine Nut, Candied Bacon & Cinnamon, Cantaloupe, Caramel Fudge Brownie, Cayenne Lime Butter, Coffee & Sambuca Cheesecake, Coconut Lemongrass, Coffee Pecan Brittle, Dark Chocolate Peppermint Toffee, Fig w/ Honey & Pecan, Ginger Peach, Gorgonzola & Toasted Walnut
Grand Marnier Cheesecake, Green Tea w/ Jasmine
Green Tea w/Honey, Honey Almond Eggnog, Juniper & Raspberry, Mexican Hot Chocolate, Mint Julep, Peach w/Champagne & Mint, Poblano Lime, Red Velvet, Roasted Red Pepper & Pineapple, Rosemary-Mint, Saffron Pistachio, Salted Caramel, Smoked Gouda, Strawberry Jalapeno Cheesecake, Sweet Corn w/ Cracked Pepper & Raspberry, Sweet Curry, Toffee Chip, Triple Shot Mochaccino, Wasabi - Pistachio & White Chocolate Caramel Toffee, just to name a few! 

Oh yeah, free samples, too... Just don't be a "sample hog". Seriously?

Nom nom. I'm not sure why New Orleans doesn't have more ice cream places given the year round temps. Maybe it's just not an ice cream type of town? But judging by the folks coming to Creole Creamery in the middle of a Wednesday it sure seems like there's a demand for it.

When we arrived it was just us so got to take our time and taste a bunch of ice cream. I'm not generally a sugary sweet ice cream kinda gal so the cereal and cookie ice cream wasn't doing it. Then I saw the Steens Molasses Oatmeal Cookie - tasting confirmed the deep molasses flavor and I knew my order. That and the Bittersweet Chocolate Torte - just like a flourless chocolate cake. And I normally don't like chocolate except straight up!

A word of caution: don't come here if you're a generally indecisive person.  After picking up a cookie next door at Manhattanjack, I concluded that to satisfy ALL of my sweet cravings, I'd cap things off with a scoop of ice cream from Creole Creamery.  Having read about it on various blogs and newsletters, I determined that no matter what avenue I decided to choose, I would come out a winner.  Sure enough, I walk in and already I start panicking with how many options there are.  Ultimately I went with what Yelp said and got a single scoop of the Lavender Honey, and it absolutely did not disappoint.  I would love to come back when they serve their special ice cream for Saints game day! Definitely a delicious treat and a fast way to beat that NOLA heat!

I love the unique flavors that this place comes up with! You can order baby scoops of 4 or 6 different flavors if you can't choose just one. Some of the flavors that I really love are the chocolate amaretto cheesecake, the cookie monster, and the dessert at Tiffany's (which I think is a vday special). This place has a really cool authentic ice cream parlor feel, and once you've been here once it's nearly impossible to not stop here after dining at one of the restaurants on Prytania. Make sure you have cash though! They don't accept debit/credit.

This place is ahhhhmaazing. My friend took us here while we were in town, and it was by far the best thing I'd eaten the whole time. I tried eveerything and ended up with the black currant ice cream, and the creole cream cheese. Thank god the staff was really patient in handing out samples and waiting for me to decide! So good and so unbelievably cheap! Would def come back!

No, just no. We tried 3 separate places and this side of Terminal has no decent foods.

We tried California rolls and salmon teriyaki. Came out of a pre-made package. California rolls were cold and slightly dry. Salmon teriyaki rice bowl was average - not freshly made and on the slightly cold side.

Better off eating a bag of chips or trial mix.
Nice service, they offer cleaner and fresher food. I wouldn't eat D graded sushi at the airport but the Tonkastu ramen wasn't bad at all.

was TOTALLY surprised by how good the bento box was. its like what youd find at a traditional sit down japanese place. 

the bento box isn't on the menu but you can ask for it. i saw it on their website. 

i swapped out the california roll for another roll.

you also get miso soup which has tons of tofu in it as well. 

so surprised by how complete and good this was.

chicken was tender and juicy too.

ORDER: at counter

its in that big food court in the middle of the airport, not the side by temrinal F

As far as airport restaurants go this has to be one of the best.  It is clean, pleasant, well designed, and a good varied menu of sushi, noodles and other Japanese inspired dishes.

We sat at the counter and I had a dry Udon with chicken.  It came in a nice bowl shaped dish and all of the ingredients tasted fresh and well prepared.

The sushi in the counter looked quite fresh and one wonders how long it can stay that way at an airport installation (?)

I also had a some hot green tea that came in a stylish cup.

The service was overly accommodating and the entire experience was quite good.

The tonkatsu ramen was disappointing.  The broth--which is most important part of a ramen experience-was kinda bland, just salty with a touch of pepper, but not complex and umami-ish the way good broth should be.  And it was not really what I expect as "tonkatsu" (pork cutlet); it was over-boiled pork belly (some pieces were tender, but many were hard and tasteless.  And the soft-boiled egg, although tasty, was too tiny to be worth the $2 up charge.  

I wish I had spent my $15 elsewhere.  Like buying lots of pastries at Au Bon Paine.

But the staff was appropriately attentive, though they didn't seem to understand what "warm water" is.
Picked up some sushi to go for an outbound flight and it was terrible!  The fish did not taste fresh.

It was pretty early in the morning but I had already been up for 4 hours so I wasn't in the mood for breakfast. I appreciated that Gachi had some lunch options on the menu that early because most places didn't. The chicken and rice bowl was pretty basic but hit the spot... white sticky rice and some grilled chicken with a little sauce. They were already prepared in a heated cabinet so there was no wait. I did get some gyoza as well which had to be cooked. It wasn't great but the chicken bowl was plenty on its own.
I got ramen from this store front in the airport and it was...ok. it took a long time to get the food and the food itself was just ok. Regardless, I was happy to be able to have ramen in the airport.

Chipotle is the Targét of the Mexican fast food game. 

What's not to love about Chipotle?  Burritos (or tacos/ bowls) made your way. Quick. Hot. Fresh. Generally great service at this Cherry Hill location.  They also have a really good soundtrack playing whenever I go in. 

My go to is the carnitas burrito but you can't really go wrong with anything.  Good rice, fresh salsa and guacamole.  

And yes, we are aware the guacamole is extra. 

As for the price, it's a bit more expensive than your normal fast food joint, but then again the quality and freshness is a step up.

in case you haven't noticed, i make it my personal business to visit every chipotle in my region of the grand ol USA. while in south jersey, i took a trip here with a chipotle virgin. i let her order first and as i gently poked fun at her for being mildly confused at the ordering process, we were overheard by the girl at the register. she decided to pay for one of the burritos we ordered in honor of her first time! how adorable.

Staff was friendly and there was almost no wait getting my food.  The food itself was really fresh and tasty even after getting it home and eating it.  The only downside to this chipotle is the entrance it is kind of hard to get in from the one side and easy to get in from the other so if it is on the opposite side of the road from you you have to be careful or you will probably miss the entrance.  Besides that they offered the same as other chipotle and we just as quick and as efficient as other chipotle .  Come here it is great and great tasting getting in may be hard but besides that you will enjoy.

The Vessel: Burrito Bowl (no rice) with double order of chicken/steak/carnitas with black beans, pinto, salsa, guacamole, lettuce, cheese and small dab of sour cream. Devour.

Service: No problems at this particular location.

Suggestion: Tabasco is okay in a pinch but I would appreciate if you would carry   Tapatío or Cholula sauce! (the wife refuses to carry it in her purse, the nerve of her). I would love to see a grilled vegetable option to add to my bowl (maybe some yellow/red peppers, squash, zucchini, etc.). I like lots of veggies with my meat.

Verdict: Great fast-food chain, simple menu, fairly healthy ingredients and easy-on-the-wallet. Parking lot sucks here during prime-time hours.
Great take out for fast, fresh, semi-healthy mexican food. Generous portions and great prices

The savory food is better than ever, but their online ordering is not as useful as it could be. I would like it if the food were ready for pickup and followed all the instructions. Otherwise, what is the point? Steak or chicken is a bit gristly at times, so I usually get the pork.

Chipotle works hard to get you a good business model, quality ingredients and the burrito portions have the same diameter as a Coke Can... I love me a good burrito as much as the next girl but when it is served to you with the enthusiasm of a wet plastic bag, it is kind of a downer. You get me? Good food, the service was dismal. 

One extra star for adding brown rice to the menu, nicely done!

DISCLAIMER: This is more of a letter than a review. 


Dear Ashley,

I speak for my entire family when I say, THANK YOU!

I get wild notions in my head sometimes and although for the most part I am a planner at my core, I am also helplessly impulsive. I want what I want when I want it and nothing can hold me back when I've made my mind up on something. 

I seriously had no intention of any vacations for the remainder of the year. I made an announcement to our family early in the year that family time will be limited to nearby weekend getaways. Tampa was not in the cards until one day I was watching a Hallmark movie with my wife and got the notion stuck in my head that I would like a family photo with my mother and sisters. After all, we hadn't had a professional picture done since we were kids. 

So I called them, and suddenly the entire family was excited with the prospect of a beach photo shoot, including my grumpy but lovable brother-in-law who only likes to visit two places: His sofa and the golf range. I decided a family vacation was in order sooner than later since mom is getting up in age and Thanksgiving week gave us the best opportunity. Enter Ashley Izquierdo Photography. 


[ THE EXPERIENCE ]

After trying to schedule a session with another photographer, but never receiving a call back, I discovered your page on yelp and liked what I saw. I was surprised that you didn't realize you had any reviews on yelp, but at the time all three reviews were 5 stars. 

Never having worked with a professional before, I was surprised by a few requirements, such as paying in full for my session up front and the minimum guarantee of 45 good photos, but you worked with me to ease my mind and I appreciated you efforts. So many bad stories of prepaying a business for services that are never rendered was a stressful thought for me. I also REALLY, REALLY appreciated how you were lightening fast in responding to my texts as we kept in touch for nearly a month prior to our session. Many times I could see you were typing just seconds after I sent a message. That comforted my anxiety about paying upfront without knowing you (more than you can imagine). 

Also I appreciate your being on time for our session and the extra effort you made in taking specific photos I requested. While you said our session would be available in your gallery in about 2 to 3 weeks, I was delighted they were ready in just a matter of days. I know I called worried because I had trouble opening the files on my moms archaic computer... but once I was back home in Atlanta, viewing them was a snap. 


[ FINAL THOUGHTS ] 

My entire family (including those whom saw the pictures but were not there for the session) LOVED your work! At first I thought $350 was pricey since I am good with a camera and could have done the session myself with a tripod, but it was money well spent and I'm so happy to have made your acquaintance. 

My only suggestion is don't take things to heart so easily. Some people (such as myself) calling to hire you don't know protocol or procedure when it comes to professional photography. Therefore, sometimes a question is just a question... not an attack that you must defend. I truly wish you much success in your future! You are very good at what you do and deserve all the business Yelp can send your way. While we were just a simple 1 hour photo session, your wedding & engagement pics in your online gallery are STUNNING, and your reviews on sites like The Knot & Wedding Wire speak volumes about your talent and professionalism. 

I hope you enjoyed working with us as much as we did with you! Happy to be your first Yelp sale! 


Thanks again,
Richard & Family


2019/8

Lauren does a very good job handling the inevitable "hiccups", and you can even make appointments online:)  We've been using Love 4 Paws for the past (3) years and plan to continue to use them for any future Pet Sitting needs:)  Thanks Lauren!

I'm not sure why this place has bad reviews. We've been here a couple times and its always good. Our server Michelle always is very attentive and is a wonderful server. I had no idea that they offered a free slice of pie on Wednesdays with any purchase. Not all pies are eligible but they do have a huge variety to choose from. I got the triple berry the crust was flakey fresh and delicious. My husband got the strawberry rhubarb and he said it was also very good. Our daughter got the coconut cream and said it was very tasty. The coconut cream is not eligible for the free slice of pie. Just a very good place to come for breakfast...it is served all day.

Great selection of breakfast food to choose from. I got the 1/2 lb country fried steak with gravy and it was really good and very filling. Wife got a build your own combo with healthy food for her and that was exactly what she wanted. We don't have these where we live or we would eat at these restaurants often

I went here today since it was right next door to auto zone and I was waiting for auto zone to recharge my battery which takes an hour.

Village Inn has wifi so it was very convenient to kill time here and have a nice lunch.  It really was a nice yummy lunch a lot better than I thought. My waitress was so very helpful as well.

I also came here a few weeks later, and guess what I learned. Wednesdays from 10am -close, you can purchase anything and get free pie. Oh yea that was wonderful. We loved it so much, and our soup was so good and the pie afterwards was even better.

The manager walked around and greeted everyone and he was soo funny!  Will be back, maybe even more on Wednesdays for that yummy bonus!

We wanted omelette so we decided to give this a try. I was impressed with hosts we where greeted with big friendly smile. We where seated right away , our server got all of our drink orders. My wife and I ordered the western omelette and shared buttermilk pancakes. The coffee was brewed perfectly and went quickly. The omelettes where so good and the pancakes where to die for good. 
We all enjoyed our food and will be back.

Rating: 2.8

Village Inn was the first place we ate in Tampa last weekend. V.I. is like an upgrade of IHOP and Denny's.  For a second I thought Denny's owned V.I. because you have the Denny's green and the menu looked like theirs as well.  

They had eggs Benedict but there is something scary ordering e.b. at a diner...so I opted for the chicken fried steak that came with pancakes, eggs, and potatoes and was pleased. 

So if you're craving diner food, come here.
Good fries... burger was nothing to write home about but I did steal my bf's fries .. yummy ...

I am torn. I really like the location and the atmosphere of this restaurant.  The drinks have always been yummy.  BUT.....the food leaves very little to be desired.

Every dish we have tried ranges from just ok to nearly inedible. Do Not Get the grilled Caesar salad!  I think the cook knows the food is just ok so he/she makes up for it by disguising it with a very heaved handed salt shaker.

We will keep coming here if only to stop in for a cocktail but it sure would be nice if they amped up the food quality!

I was a bit shocked at the tough reviews. I enjoyed the food here. 
First off I guess you need to be aware that you must order up front because there is no wait service. As long as you know that going in, you'll have proper expectations. 
We ordered hummus plate, Chinese chicken salad, and veggie burger with tater tots. 
All of it was fabulous. We had zero complaints on the food. 
The A/C seemed to not be working so well and it was really hot inside. But it was still a good experience aside from the sweating.

This restaurant is just awful and it has been since it opened. We hadn't been here in 1 1/2 years because the last time was so atrocious so shame on us for giving it another try. We literally drive past here several times a day since we live up by the Ritz and we didn't feel like driving very far, we just wanted to get out of the house for a bit but this is the LAST TIME we will ever step foot in this "restaurant". The owner should call Robert Irvine with Restaurant Impossible to learn how to run a restaurant and serve good food. Seriously.  

First of all, the set up is the most ridiculous I have ever experienced. You order up front when you walk in or you can take a menu and sit at a table of your choice but you still have to go up and order. They keep your credit card or driver's license up at the front until you pay. So you are giving up control of the safety of your card information or you are informing someone where you live and you are not at home - not a good system. Not sure how they remain compliant with their credit card merchant services, probably because they omit this tidbit of information when answering the mandatory questions.

Now once you place your order, you get a number and a server will bring you your drink and food. If you have servers running food and drinks, why not have them taking orders? None of this makes sense! I go out to eat and drink to be waited on. I don't want to go to the front and stand in line every single time I want another round. The owner clearly doesn't know what he/she is doing as more drinks would be sold for certain and more food as well if this was a typical restaurant with actual servers. I also think the employees would make more money receiving tips. 

The food. Sigh. The people working in the kitchen are not chefs. They are not cooks. They simply are heating up Sysco frozen food. Perhaps they toss on some fresh herbs to make it seem as though they actually cooked the food?  We ordered a flat bread and garlic parmesan fries. Both dishes arrived cold but because they don't have servers, only food runners, nobody comes around to check on you and the food.   Even if the flat bread had been hot, it was so lame that nothing could help it - no flavor, not really cooked, glops of cheese on it made it look unappetizing but there was a sprinkling of fresh basil. 

There are always people here but don't let that fool you -  that is only because there is such limited choices to eat in this area! If we ever get a decent restaurant(s), this place will fold quickly.

People look at me with bewilderment when I tell them that the best Chinese food in Santa Barbara is at Mama Lu on Milpas.  However, you have to be able to read Chinese and order from their "secret" menu.  Are they assholes for not translate the menu and keep their delicious authentic goods from the general population?  Not really.  I think "lost in translation" is the reason why a restaurant like Wok on the Wild Side has so many negative reviews and why many restaurant don't even bother with translation.   

I have never seen a restaurant generated so many opposite opinions.  I was intrigued by my fellow reviewers and I had to see it for myself.  Is this place really bad or simply misunderstood.  

The restaurant was clean and simply decorated.  The owner was from Dong Bei (North East China) and a first time restauranteur.  It seems like the combos were not well priced compare to the entrees and personally I would not recommend stir fry dishes that had being sitting out for more than 15 minutes.  I got the entree size xiang la pai gu and it came with a bowl of steamed rice.  I counted 11 meaty ribs pieces  with jalapeno, onions, and dry red chilies.  The sauce was very spicy and flavorful, but I agree with others that it was salty even considering that Sichuan cuisine tends to be heavily seasoned.  Most restaurants use cheaper long grain rice, but here they used starchier short grain rice that Chinese, Korean, and Japanese prefer because sticky short grain rice pick up sauce better than hard fluffy long grain rice.   

I spotted a pan of kou shui ji next to a line of ubiquitous looking stir fries.  I can't help it but get a small box to go.  Kou shui ji literally translates to salivating chicken, so good, you'll salivate thinking about it.  Its boiled whole chicken cut into more manageable chunks, with bones and skins, soaked in a sauce made of spices and red chili oil.  This was not on the menu and it was very good and authentic.  Now, I am definitely intrigued and already planing a future visit.  If they can tone down the sodium by a notch this place would be 4 stars.

The lack of service and funny tasting water don't help this place, but the soups I've had here are delicious. The prices are also very reasonable.

The mapo tofu was large, lacked meat,  and was so salty that it made my mouth tingle in discomfort. Also, some of the Americanized stir fry dishes contain too many onions.

I would eat here again just to have the chonqing beef noodle soup.

As much as I like the fact that a relatively authentic Chinese restaurant opened in Isla Vista, I have to say that the service is still inconsistent and terrible.  Its so bad that it reminds me of the type of service one would expect in China during the 80s, before the days of small business owners.  I ordered dry chili chicken (la zi ji) a la carte and the server took some from the steam table and tried to pass it off as freshly made.  I send it back, and one minutes later she said I can't have a fresh order if what I order happened to coincide with an entree that was already on the steam table.  I was not told about this little footnote when I ordered.  I complained to the server and the owner, but nothing was done to remedy the situation.  I know you are trying to minimize food and labor cost, but trying to serve cold dry leftover and charge full price for it is not the way to go.  I was dining  with Doug M's family because I wanted to show him some real Chinese food.  I felt bad about the chili chicken because it wasn't as good as the first time I had it, however, Doug really enjoyed the chicken, but just imagine how much more impressed he would have been had it been fresh from the wok.

I have since tried a couple of more dishes from this place and they were not as salt and msg laden as the first time.  They are making some good adjustments, however, I still can't give them a higher rating because this place doesn't run smoothly.  We are not talking about people waiting in a line here.  At around 70% capacity, the restaurant goes into panic mode and can't seem to keep up with the order.  The restaurant employs 3 people in the back and 2 people in the front, in addition, the owner serves as float, doing whatever that needs to be done.  As someone who have worked in the restaurants including the back of the kitchen, I can't say they are understaffed.  Six people serving an ordering at the counter type restaurant with 14 tables is very reasonable.  

I have no way of knowing what's going on in the kitchen, but the front is frustrating to watch.  I constantly see people coming out of kitchen stocking a couple of bowls.  Why don't you put all the bowls in a big dish bin and stock them all at the same time instead of making multiple trips into the kitchen?  They are also in desperate need of a couple of restaurant ticket holders.  They are less than $15 each and will hold the tickets in place so you don't have to fidget the tickets when a new one shows up.  What I see happening here is that one of the girl walks out of the kitchen with one plate of food and walks a few steps and remembers that she forgot the rice.  She then either walks back to the rice cooker to get more rice or she delivers the food and then go back to get a bowl of rice.  The kitchen is probably plagued with similar inefficiency because the table next to me didn't get their second dish until they were done with their first dish.  The second dish was scrambled egg with tomato, why did it take so long for such a simple dish?  Was the line not properly stocked or organized?  Some of the dishes share the same base sauce, maybe they can be mixed in a large batch ahead of time?  Perhaps they can put out a dish cart by the door and people can drop off the dirty dish on their way out?  What if you set the drink machine in the dining room so people can refill their own drinks?  The slow service is definitely due to inexperience and lack of proper restaurant tools.  They are not exactly hurting for business right now, but eventually people will get tired of the slow and disorganized service.

DON'T BELIEVE WHAT YOU READ!!!  

A week ago I felt sorry for this place.   So many one star reviews, one after the other after the other....    Looked to me that someone had it out for them.   All looked so fake, all by absolute Yelp newbies, profiles that had never written a Yelp review.   I flagged and I flagged and I flagged, but Yelp disagreed.    Decided the reviews are sincere and let them stand.   I didn't get it.  

A few days ago Wok got their first Five star review, then another, and another, and another.   I think a total of 8 or 9 in two days!!!   Again newbies, again first reviews.   You don't have to be a brain surgeon to recognize that someone was doing damage control.   I flagged and flagged and flagged, again Yelp for the most part disagreed and has decided that the reviews are sincere.    Maybe it is just a coincidence that most of them use the same "not like Panda Express" reference.    I mean some people get hit by lightning time and time again.    

So my curiosity got the better of me.    I went there for lunch yesterday.   I was expecting to see a sign twelve feet across that said "5 stars on Yelp gets you a free meal!!!!"   But it wasn't there. 

The place has no décor, no atmosphere, they have those super light aluminum chairs that cheap restaurants seem to love so much, my guess is that they are $12 apiece.    I was happy to see that I was the only non-Asian in the place, I took that as a good thing, might speak well of the food.  

When I ordered I asked the person at the counter what he would recommend.   His answer was "Get anything that you want."   Thanks dude, very helpful.

I ordered the Mongolian Beef, always a favorite.  I ordered the entree since it already comes with rice.   It was $9.72 before tip.    I was disappointed when I got my plate, a ton of rice and a teenie little bit of meat.   I eat at other Chinese places and for my $8 or $9 lunch I usually get a soup, I get an egg roll, a cup of tea and perhaps a little salad... oh and SO much more meat.   

I wasn't offered tea but was offered water, half a glass (pictured) I guess that is because of the drought.    

All in all I was completely underwhelmed.  The food was expensive and while quite tasty, it seemed like a very poor value.   But I did feel like I accomplished something.    Maybe the one star reviews were sincere.    And in my humble opinion the five star reviews have to be 100% fake!    Sorry Yelp, we will just have to agree to disagree.   

Oh and if you read my review and you agree with me, please flag any reviews you suspect as fake.  Hey, flag mine too if you want.

Decided to give this place another try after a year, and it turned out to be a lot better than expected! Got the beef noodle soup, which came with a pretty big portion of noodles! 

They also have black bean noodles (ja jang mian) here. Came with a large portion of noodles too. Overall it was pretty yummy, but a tiny bit too salty.

Takes about 15-20 min to wait for food, so it wouldn't be ideal to eat here if you just want a quick bite.

Please read my last review!!     I went on and on about all the previous five star and one star reviews and whether or not they were sincere.   I had a lot of messages and comments some supporting my views and others challenging them (to say it nicely)   

My friend Lily had a higher opinion of it than I did and we thought it would be fun to revisit the restaurant together.    Lily is my expert in Chinese cuisine and she ordered off of the Chinese menu.    Things I would never even know exist!!   

I have to say that I was quite impressed by the food!   The portions were generous for the money, very different than my first experience.   The taste was very, very good and while it isn't Lily's favorite Chinese restaurant in the area, I think she enjoyed it as well.    

That said, the restaurant has SO much farther that it needs to go.  It was complete amateur hour when we were there.   The ordering was awkward and slow, two of the four dishes that we ordered were wrong and had to be sent back.   It was a meal of explanations,  arguments and apologies.    

I want to say that it is OK that the place has no atmosphere whatsoever because it is in I.V.  But why shouldn't it be a more visually pleasant dining experience.   As I mentioned in my first review Wok had an almost entirely Chinese clientele which I think says volumes about the authenticity of the food.    

Ok there you have it, my previous one star review is now a two star.   Come on Wok, it won't take too much to get me up to three stars!   The food is already there!
Food is authentic and fairly good, service is slow and the people don't seem customer service oriented whatsoever, even by IV standards. Our glasses of water tasted like soap, disgusting.

OMG WOK ON THE WILD SIDE HAHAHAHAHAHA. Service is shit and the lady boss just glares at you. It's only filled with Chinese fobs because its the only place where you can Chinese food that isn't panda express. I lowkey like the chongqing hotpot tho and literally came here like multiple times a week my last quarter in sb. AHAHAHA. That and the sweet and sour ribs are the only good things on the menu. Other than that STAY AWAY. It's expensive and not worth the price or portion.

After trying this place, I'm surprised the rating is so low... 

Yes, the service isn't the most welcoming and the girl is usually awkward and quiet... But the food is very much authentic Chinese. A few yelpers complain about the "bare" interior but I find it very nice and clean. 

I came in 30 mins before they close and ordered the soypaste noodle bowl. It came out within 5-10 mins. It was a pretty big portion and wasn't too salty or greasy. The price is reasonable as well. 

Nothing to complain really so I'll be back the next time I crave some solid Chinese in IV.

Food, price, fast service = 4 stars

Two Words: Wok Away

I reaaaally did not want to go here, but my potential (training) client wanted to go. I ordered the kung pao chicken. It was really bland and cold in the middle. I guess they only microwaved it for 20 seconds.The sauce was more like a MSG soup. Service is non-existence.

I'd rather "Wok On the Other Side."

I think the rating would scare people off but I'm glad I came here. The food is not exactly the American-Chinese food you'd expect for Isla Vista. It's very asian here, that's probably part of the issue people have with the service. My expectations weren't high but honestly there isn't good service in Isla Vista anywhere.

Chongqing Beef Noodles were very good. I don't normally order off of pictures but I went with it this time. 

Not a bad place to eat. It's not the greatest though, but more deserving than its current rating.

I know these guys have a big following, and I am new to this chain and wanted to give it a go.  
I showed up at 11:45a . There are maybe 4 people in line at this time of day.   I ordered a small cheeseburger and small fries; I wanted to start with something easy.  

It took a nearly 15 minutes to get my food, but I had high expectations so I did not mind, plus they have those peanuts they offer to keep me busy.  
The fellow serving up the food did apologize for my wait, and it was nice that he noticed it took longer than a burger and fries should take.

Fries: A LOT oily I have to say.  Crisp is NOT a word that I would use to describe them.  Plentiful! They are generous with their fries portions! 

Burger: Wow. It was so average.  A little on the dry side, but it was a small burger.  I do not like chopped onions on my burgers.. I am old school and I like a slice of onion on a burger.. chopped is fine for dogs...but not for burgers. 


Sorry guys.

This was our 8th stop on Burgerpalooza (a quest for the best effing burger in B-town!).  

This is a hard place to review because, on the one hand, I love their burgers and on the other, I am annoyed at the lackadaisical (I KNEW when I was 14 and Sister Mary Margaret called my attitude "lackadaisical" that I would one day have an opportunity to use that word--this, my people...Is.  That.  Day.) service.  

Let's begin with the yum:  

The burgers are hand formed, never frozen ample patties of juicy deliciousness.  Their fries are made from local potatoes and are also never frozen, are hand cut, and are on the thicker side of things (yay!).  They have fry sauce (double yay!), which is great, given my affection for getting saucy with my fries.  So, from a strictly--get your burger/fry fix stand point--this place absolutely delivers.

The lackadaisical:

First off, when I went to get my soda (self serve), as I had just begun filling my cup, the diet soda (can't remember if it was coke or pepsi) began to sputter.  Dang.  But, no worries, I thought, as they had another machine that also featured the same sort of diet soda so I hopped over to that machine and pressed the button and out came a stream of clear soda water.  Annoying.  Then, after only half filling my fry sauce container--the fry sauce ran out.  And, this was on a very slow Sunday night (we practically had the place to ourselves).  We let them know, they told us they would take care of it, came and retrieved the canister but never returned it.  In fact, we went to a nearby bar (Bonefish) for after dinner cocktails and when we walked by an hour and a half later--they still hadn't refilled the fry sauce.  And, yes, we could have complained for a second time--but we were a large group and were too busy socializing to track down the sauce.  But, seriously folks...you load people up with fries like you do (they are VERY generous in their servings of fries), you need to deliver the sauce.  Period. 

Other notes:

If you don't ask for your cheeseburger to be a "little" one, you'll get two patties.  I get their "little" cheeseburger and it is absolutely ample.  

So...for the purpose of Burgerpalooza...where does this place rank as far as burger freshness, quality, and taste:  easily the second best burger in Boise (from the places we've hit thus far).  4+ stars.  

From a service stand point?  Barely 2.

Five guys is a great burger joint!  Fresh ingredients, including non-frozen beef and hand-cut french fries, Yum!  They have a sign identifying which farm the potatoes actually came from.  Plus, you get a TON of fries in your bag... probably enough to share with a friend... if you wanted to.......... or not!

We were in the Boise area for several days following a family member's wedding & staying at The Grove during our visit.
We were delighted to see a Five Guys just across the street, vowing we would be here a few times to sample their fare.
Meh. I like their burgers just fine.
My wife LOVES them...that being said I should mention we're from Southern California. I'll be honest with you, I'm still an IN-N-OUT fan through & through, the wife looks like she's jumping ship & heading to the dark side.
I'll give Five Guys this...its a bit bigger & juicier, but this does not mean its better tasting. 
A-OK for me.
Enjoy!
deez® out!

I never felt compelled to eat here before because I wasn't that impressed with the one on Milwaukee, but we often go downtown with our kids and it's family friendly.  The "little" cheeseburgers are not that little, and a large order of fries was more than enough for my family to share. My husband had a regular burger, and admitted a little cheeseburger would have been sufficient, and he likes a big burger, so that's saying something. 

While I could see a place like Smashburger giving Five Guys a run for their money, I'd forgo a burger altogether and eat Subway or something before In 'N Out.  It's not even good for a fast food burger. I don't get why I keep seeing it pop up as the baseline for a good burger.

Saturday - February 2, 2013 - 10:30 AM

Joe's Pizza offers breakfast, lunch, and dinner. I ordered an egg white omelet with mushrooms, peppers, and onions.  I asked for and received properly toasted wheat bread. I substituted the home fries for a fruit dish. I wasn't expecting anything spectacular. It's an omelet! The taste was adequate. I judge purely as presented. I never add salt, ketchup or any toppings. Occasionally, black pepper. The fruit dish consisted of bananas and strawberries. Refreshing! The server performed within her job description. The person appearing to be the supervisor was friendlier and accommodating. The owner was quite nice and cheerful. It ain't a 5 star caliber diner but, it's fine for me. I'll return.

nice clean family, locals, travelers friendly place.  Some kind of connection to The Dairy Cottage.  I'm not rushing back for the cheesesteak but if you have a group of people/family and everyone wants something different including a cheesesteak then this is your place.

Happened to be in this area, and saw this place. I know it's been around a while, but had never seen it before in my life. I was just in the mood for a couple of slices of pizza and coffee, so I figured what the hell! 

As I walked in I saw a sign for the Dairy Cottage. Seems this place might be related to that. I took it as a good sign as I enjoy the Dairy Cottage. 

Signs aren't always what they're cracked up to be. 

I'll say that I wanted to like this place. I like mom and pop places with diner counters.  Judging by other reviews here, I'll say that service is better. There were two young ladies working and they were nice. The gentleman at the cash register was nice too. 

I'll also say that I have a feeling that if I had ordered a sandwich, or breakfast, I might have liked it better judging by the reviews. 

But I tried the pizza, and it's quite easy to describe. I can describe it one of two ways. 

- It reminded me of the pizza they served me at lunch in elementary school. 
- Remember the line in Saturday Night Fever where Travolta's father said "Your mother's sauce don't drip. It don't taste, and it don't drip."  Yep, this sauce don't taste at all and there was barely enough to drip. The oregano sprinkled on the slices didn't improve matters.

Sorry. I'm sure this place has good enough sandwiches.  But if your name says pizza in it, you gotta take some pride in the pizza and do better than that.

My visit to Mimosa & A Masterpiece was the second wine & painting class I've done.  I loved the convenient Mass Ave. location- we were able to walk to dinner afterwards.  All staff members were personable and friendly.  However, our class seemed a bit unorganized.  It started a little late and, although scheduled to end at 9, went past 9:30. I'm certainly no artist, so I appreciate a little explanation or practice of technique before beginning to paint.  (I thought I remembered having this at the other class I'd taken.) Unfortunately, our artist didn't offer much.  Instead, we sort of watched her figure out what to do next and then all copied her actions.  This made it difficult to conceptualize my painting and see the "whole picture".  (I should say- our class painted Van Gogh's Cafe Terrace at Night which was very challenging!)  Overall, the wine & time with friends made the class really fun.  It was worth the Groupon price, but I don't think I'd pay full price to do it again. 

Oh- and drinks are $5 each.  Menu was limited to four or five selections, but pours were very generous!

I was glad to have an opportunity to finally check this place out when I scored a pretty good deal through Living Social. It was easy breezy to register for a class on-line. A class is typically $35. What makes this place stand out from similar companies is the uniqueness of the paintings they offer. Many are female centered, a few reworks, and lots of positive affirmations.

The class was held on a Saturday. Unfortunately, I was running super late. Not GOOD because Mass Ave was packed. I had to park several blocks way. Once I finally arrived, the class had already started. I was immediately greeted by a lady who I believe is the owner. I didn't catch her name, but she was so accommodating and super sweet helping me and my friend get caught up. I was so frantic, but she helped put me at ease. I enjoyed my experience. It was much more personable and quieter than Wine & Canvas. The mimosa I had, which was only $5, was delish! My only issue was the instructor. Nice girl, but not the best at explaining things which made it unnecessarily complicated.

All in all I had a great experience and would, without a doubt, return for a fun time and another one of those mimosas!

I could not believe HOW awesome this was! My husband and I went to Mimosa and a Masterpiece on Valentine's Day this year. My husband is NOT  an artsy kind of guy but he absolutely loved it and would totally go back! The location was easy to find and when we walked in, everything was clean, neat and in its place. The staff...OMG, the staff was absolutely amazing! They greeted us, took our coats, served us our drinks and had snacks! This was very well done! 

We had an awesome time and are thinking of doing a private class with close friends! Our paintings turned out wonderfully. Even tho we had to pay $5 for the drinks, it was totally worth it. We both had Mimosa's and Moscatos! They were nicely sized. Make sure if you go, get there early! Lastly, we loved that we were done on time. We just had a baby and didn't want to burden our sitters with being gone all day. This was the perfect timeframe and we have paintings to prove the time was not wasted! We absolutely will be going back.

Hosted a party for my friend's 40th birthday and truly had an amazing time! I loved so many things about this experience, starting with the ease of booking online. The website was very user friendly, and it was great that people could book a seat in our party without having to direct all the payments through one person. Next, there are paintings to suit any and everyone! Just pick your  fave and the the artist guides you all the way to the end. Both wine and mimosas are available to purchase, and although she doesn't serve food, you can have anything local delivered there if you want! We all enjoyed ourselves, and I would recommend this to anyone, especially as a group event!

Looking for something different for a date night or girls night out?  Check out Mimosa & A Masterpiece!!   Get online, go to the website, click on the calendar, pick a painting that strikes your fancy, sign up, and GO!  I believe they also offer private events for bigger groups.  SO FUN!   Located in the heart of the arts district off Mass Ave, enter through the door by the Stamp Shop on the corner to get here!


What makes it fun:
Twana -- AKA "the Hostess with the mostest" was awesome!  So friendly!   Our glasses were never empty nor did we have to ask for anything.  She was hilarious, personable, and anticipated our needs.  Sweet.  

Alan -- our instructor for the evening.  Provided great guidance while encouraging individual creativity.  He was very willing to hop in and help where needed and was funny to boot.  He even did a great job of diffusing the awkwardness of some "difficult" painters and made us laugh in the process.

$5 "liquid courage" -- Red and white wines, mimosas... very generous pours and quality product for just $5 a glass.


What sets them apart:
They let you customize your color palate so your painting can complement your decor -- which was really nice.  Other similar places already have your stuff set up and colors are predetermined when you arrive.  Not at Mimosa & a Masterpiece.  They will even give you a quick overview of which colors look good together to ensure you are on the right track.

You are encouraged to "make it your own" -- meaning they will provide a loose guide and framework, but not a step-by-step on how to make your painting look EXACTLY like theirs.  This is great for the creative or rebel painter...and it's all in fun anyway, right?  

So yes.  We will return to Mimosa & a Masterpiece again.  SO. MUCH. FUN.

BLACK WOMAN OWNED, I REPEAT, BLACK WOMAN OWNED on Mass Ave! For 7 years! I absolutely love that. Please support, no matter you race or gender, you will love the vibe here.

I looked around and have been to many paint and sip concept locations for my Ma's birthday and was sold on this location. It was so chill when we got to the place. Masterpiece offered two separate classes and even though I paid for a specific class, we were offered to paint whatever we wanted. Due to it being it being a holiday weekend, there was only one other group of people that signed up so we had the whole place to ourselves. We painted a lovely elephant, check out our pic! My Ma loved it! I got her tipsy with a mimosa so it was a win. The mimosa was so dang good for $5 each. 

The inside is set up with three rooms for multiple classes at a time which is dope. Each room different in size for the number of attendees. There is beautiful artwork on the walls from top to bottom which is a scene to see. There is music playing that sets a nice tone too. 

Our lead painter Haley was super dope. At this location, they are chill and let you create with their guidance. Haley showed us the way and helped us out when she needed to. She is so good at what she does and great trainer. 

I love this place and will only go here for a paint sip vibe in Indy.

Went here for lunch with a vender.  I got the grilled trout on the Z light menu.  I usually get the pesto trout, but it wasn't on the light.  Broccoli and corn grits.  It was so good.  I actually like the grilled trout better than the pesto.  Great service.  Will be back.

Meh.  I was expecting more.  I normally go based on reviews on Yelp/Trip Advisor and I really rarely listen to the propaganda pieces that cities put out in flyers etc, I like listening to the boots on the ground, reviews from real people.  So I went on the recommendation of people online, and my friend who loves it here, but I was sorely disappointed. 

My meal (pork with broccoli and potatoes) was good, the portion was small, the potatoes were delicious and the pork was sliced way too fine - for the price, I'd expect more.  

My brother asked for a burger, medium-well, it came out raw.  He thought it looked ok so didn't send it back and when he got in to it, it was raw. 

Hubby got the ribs and they weren't much to write home about.  He did love the grits though!

I don't think I'd go back, which is a shame, it was too much money for not a lot of food and not particularly great food at that, disappointing :(

This used to be my favorite "chain" restaurant in the city and I still love their corn grits, and would go back any day and just eat those.

Unfortunately, I am sorry to report that the last two times I ate here I got sick.  Yes, SICK.  Both times I ordered the trout Lafite (my favorite).  I thought the first time was a fluke and I was just coming down with something, but when I returned about 6 months later and ate the same thing, once again, I got sick.  It was terrible.

I have never had this issue at the Westbank or Elmwood locations, just this one.  It's sad, because I like supporting uptown businesses, but I will never go to this Zea's again.
The chicken and the ribs entrees were overly-salty. I like my foods full of flavor, but not salt. But still it was pretty good, and the parking lot was convenient. The sides were good though.

Yum! Always a good experience at this location. I think it's my favorite out of all the locations around here. 

I recently went with some friends here for weekday lunch. We had a nice table by the front window overlooking St. Charles. The service was friendly and knowledgeable. 

I had the Almond Chicken Salad. It was a huge plate of food! Seemed like enough for 2-3 meals. Two of my friends ordered the Fried Chicken with Red Beans, which was excellent. Our fourth friend got the Honey Island Chicken Sandwich. It looked huge! 

I haven't been disappointed yet with anything I've ordered from here. I look forward to going back soon.

Ordered the Rotisserie salad for the first time. It was very meaty. It comes with chicken & pork, romaine, radicchio, Jack cheese, bacon and your choice of dressing. I chose the pepper jelly vinaigrette which was so good. 

I have eaten a several different Zea's and I find their food to be consistently of good quality. I like their thai ribs, duck empanadas and corn grits as well. Prices are about $10 - 25 per entree.

I had the ribs and corn grits at a fundraiser Zea sponsored before and gained an extra ten pounds eating the ribs alone. The corn grits are good but not great. Today I tried them again and the ribs were great with delicious broccoli and sweet potatoes. I'm a big fan of duck and will try their version next time. Zea's is not just about chicken. Tip: much cheaper and bigger portions if you take out rather than eating in.

Food: After looking through the pretty extensive menu, I ended up ordering their special, the braised provimi veal with natural au jus. For the sides I got the roasted potatoes and the red beans & rice. I hate to admit it, but the veal was really good. My vegetarian and vegan friends always give me a hard time when they find out that I've eaten veal. Anyways I wasn't expecting to eat such good veal in New Orleans. I had to avoid the usual seafood that people eat in NOLA as I had a marathon to run in the morning. Along with the meal I had a Pontchartrain Porter. Nice beer.

Service: Service was excellent. My waiter was very friendly and helpful. He even recommended an excellent nearby bar that served the kind of beers that I liked.

Location: Very easy and convenient location to get to if you're staying in the Garden District. It's located on the north side of the famous St. Charles Avenue. This place had a nice ambiance. It almost felt formal enough that you could show up in your nice Sunday clothes without sticking out like a sore thumb.

We're in NOLA and we didn't get Southern Food? 

On our last night in New Orleans, we found this place for dinner. It was the night of the Super Bowl so we found a restaurant with only two other guests in the dining area and just a handful at the bar. In other words, we had a restaurant to ourselves. Having a restaurant to yourself doesn't guarantee great service, but we got it anyway. Good start so far. Zea Rotisserie and Grill is great option for those looking to take a break from Po' Boys, Jambalaya's, and fried food.  What you'll find is a restaurant chain that serves seafood, sandwiches, Asian based BBQ, grilled food, and of course, rotisserie.  I can almost compare Zea to a Cheesecake Factory, but with a better food presentation and a dining experience that mimics fine dining.   

-Garlic Hummus pita: This was our appetizer for the evening. I haven't had garlic based hummus before and pleased that I did. You still get the texture and taste of what you expect with hummus, but with an added buttery garlic taste to it. There's more hummus than there is pita and they are willing to hook up extra pita if needed.  (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Ov8JM-bcpHBtL30bGfPkKw&userid=y3FcL4bLy0eLlkb0SDPnBQ)

-1/2 Chicken & 1/2 BBQ Ribs Plate: This meal is big enough to serve 2, maybe even 3. The ribs are glazed with BBQ sauce and the meat is "fall off the bone" and "melt in your mouth".  As for their chicken, you get a seasoned and prepared rotisserie chicken.  Taste of their chicken rivals some of the top notch fine dining restaurants out there. Trust me.  (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=QN7x6WC505-ZoDT4ptVHig&userid=y3FcL4bLy0eLlkb0SDPnBQ)

Overall, I have to say that I'm a fan. If I'm ever back out here, I'm sure that my meals will be centered around the foods that I can't get in California or Las Vegas. But if I'm looking for something good, more traditional, and just want a change of pace from NOLA's Southern type dishes, Zea Rotisserie is on my list.



YELP PERSONAL CHALLENGE - (034/366)

I love Zea's. Friendly Staff and nice atmosphere.  Can't forget about the great food! I absolutely adore their Salmon!!! trust me I'm a Salmon Connoisseur.  Check it out and while you're at it have a mojito!

One of the best things about this place is Parking! It's on St. Charles and has a lot, which is greatness in my opinion!

I loved Zea.  This past weekend I traveled to New Orleans for an extended romantic weekend.  I was recommended to come to Zea from the owner of the B&B we stayed at.  Upon our arrival we were greeted with friendly staff.  I was highly impressed that the menu had a fantastic selection or food.  I was more impressed with the prices.  I had the half rack of wet Thai stylist ribs for only $14.  When the ribs came out I wa impressed with how big they were.  They looked like a full rack to me.  The meat was very tender and the food was filled with flavor.  

Now, I'm from  Texas & we are big on our BBQ.  I was impressed.  The food was great and extremely affordable.  My plate would have been double the price easily back at home.  I definitely got my moneys with & will stop by the next time I'm back in town.  The dirty rice was so de-lish that I wanted to place a big order to take home with me.  The closest we have to dirt rice is Pop Eyes.   I'm embarrassed to say that we ate every bite & did not have left overs to take home.  The staff was super friendly and the restaurant was clean & beautiful.  I loved how you could see the kitchen though the glass window.  Very classy appeal.   5 Stars to you Zea!

Totally did not know what to expect when I first got to New Orleans. Desperate to try to find a place to grub and ended up here. To my surprise everyone was so nice at the restaurant. They do say its that southern hospitality. 

Grilled trout with sweet potato and corn grits:
This fish was Delicious!! very flavorful and cooked to perfection. The meat wasn't too tough and soft enough to my likely. 
The sweet potato was also on point. Equal amount of sweet, salt and mash. 
Usually the grits I've had don't have much flavor but these corn grits where mmm mm  good!!

Sweet Tea: it was decent, just maybe a little too sweet.

I highly recommend this place to try and promise you don't be disappointed.

I went to Zea today to meet my dad and brother for lunch. I thoroughly enjoyed our meal.

We started with their Greek hummus and duck empanadas which may be my two favorite appetizers anywhere.

The hummus is loaded with olives, tomatoes, gets and something green. It is incredible.

The duck empanadas are fried and come with a very tasty sweet thick sauce.

For my entree I tried the grilled tuna. Wow, this pier of fish was perfectly seasoned and cooked. It was so flavorful that I didn't even use the basil butter that was on top of the fish. For sides I got zea's roasted potatoes and roasted corn. That corn is the best corn dish anywhere.

This location has a large off street lot behind the restaurant which makes it very convenient. We went at around 11:30 and the restaurant was crowded, but as we left at 12:30, numerous people were waiting for tables.

Our server, Shamika was great. She was dry attentive and friendly and helped make our meal more enjoyable.

Good food! And the lunch specials 7-days a week. They even have a daily special. Plenty of FREE parking too...something you don't find too often in a NOLA restaurant!

I had the fried chicken and red bean lunch special. GREAT STUFF! The fried chicken (2 pieces) came tasty and moist...and not dried. The sausage was good and the red beans and brown rice is good!

The service was good! Check it out!!!! BTW...I walked in with shorts...you might want to put on some jeans since everyone was pretty dressed up to a business casual style of dressing.

It is always a treat going to Zea. Ever since i was introduced to this place as a teen, i've loved the Thai ribs, my god you can never go wrong with them.

I recently adopted and am addicted to the garlic & herb chicken (with the double side of corn grits) can't complain about that.

In fact, they're in for a visit from me right now!

Been here a couple times with my girlfriend. Always get the garlic hummus, which is delicious, except we always need more pita. Her normal is the philly cheesesteak panini, but she got the grilled chicken sandwich to be easy on her stomach. It was pretty good. I got the arugula salad and sugar snap beans. Pretty good, but nothing special.
Didn't get them this time, but the Thai ribs are fantastic.

We'll be back, but only when we can't figure out what else we want.

I was a member of the New Orleans Energy Club that was briefly at this location prior to Katrina and I enjoyed that place.  I wasn't all that thrilled when Zea's took over this spot but Zea's has some pretty solid rotisserie meats and some interesting sides that are not very common at other restaurants in the area.  They are a bit pricey for what they offer.  Zea has very consistently good (but not great) meat and seafood.  I generally avoid chain places like the plague but this is a local operation and has quality far and above most other "chain" type operations.  I will go for the meat maybe about twice a year.

I was content to keep eating PoBoys from the gas station each of my four nights in town, but my friend wanted someplace with tables and chairs (Snooty, I know). 

I started with the Mac and Cheese appetizer. I honestly could've eaten that all night. It tasted like the lie that Kraft wanted you to believe their mac and cheese would be like (the commercial with the dinosaurs and noodles swimming in pools of cheese). 

My friend had the duck empanadas. If this is what Elmer Fudd had in mind when he was chasing Daffy all those years, then brother...I UNDERSTAND! 

With appetizers so good, I was let down by the garlic rotisserie half-chicken. The flavor was only skin-deep. It wasn't bad, but I made it my point to dip each bite in the red beans and rice or the sweet potatoes to give it some flavor. Those two sides were pretty good, by the way. Good, but not mind blowing. 

For dessert, I ordered the strawberry cheesecake. I hear music playing in my head when I think about it. HUGE is an understatement. They put a block of philly cream cheese on that one slice. And the strawberries...man, the strawberries. I'm so used to fake-me-out canned strawberry syrup that it took me a minute to process it. "Is this...is this real fruit? Is that pectin?"

I can't close out this encyclopedia-length review without acknowledging Adrianne, our server. She was great, she was friendly, and she even got me to step out of my comfort zone and try all of the stuff mentioned.

Great ambience.  Off street rear parking.  Complimentary valet parking.  Friendly staff.  GREAT FOOD!!!

Corn grits & thai ribs... yummy!!!!

Zea is a chain, but it is a local chain.

They started as a rotisserie and microbrewery and have expanded to several locations, including this one.

Their food is consistently good. Highlights include the duck empanadas, loaded hummus(not the official name), rotisserie meat of the day, ribs, ribeye and grilled fish.

I went to this location for fathers day and was given a free six pack of their beer. Their Pontchartrain Porter is wonderful. Dark with undertones of chocolate, it soothes your soul.

Anyway, you can't go wrong with Zea.

My SO surprised me last week and asked if I had time to go to lunch.  Of course I did!! So she picked me up and we drove up the Avenue just looking, and it dawned on me just to go to Zea!  They never steer us wrong.  So we did.

We split the hummus flight, which comes with a red pepper hummus, a Mediterranean hummus, and a pesto hummus.  Pesto is my favorite, and red pepper is her favorite, but we both love all three and left none to spare.  Especially since we got two batches of fresh warm pita.

Then we split the grilled trout, snap beans, and Thai snap beans.  Everything was cooked very well and seasoned to perfection.  

The food was a perfect complement to my company!

The only reason for a dropped star was the service.  Our waiter was nice, but it was very slow.  We were clearly ready to leave, but took quite a few minutes to get the bill and get it paid.
The veal was excellent melts in your mouth. Also enjoyed the grits and roasted potatoes. Excellent service love the lunch specials

I order takeout from here somewhat regularly, and they always get the order right.  In NOLA, this doesn't always happen.  So they are already on my good side for that.  I've also eaten in here a few times, and the service is always great.  

They have some yummy appetizers.  My two favorites are the duck empanadas and the asian almond shrimp.  During seafood season they have asian sesame oysters-AWESOME.  

I often order a half rack of thai ribs, which is more than enough for one person and comes with two sides.  For $14.  Like everyone has already said, the corn grits are like so effing good.  A while back, Zea posted a recipe for them online which contained something like 4 sticks of butter in one batch.  Why it's hard to live in Louisiana...

I've gotten the tuna steak, also delicious.  The only thing I've had here that I haven't enjoyed was the basil trout.  It was far too salty.  Another Yelper hit the nail on the head: Zea serves a wide range of food ranging from forgettable to quite good.  And everything is reasonably priced.

We came on a Sunday night and the place was packed.  The service was great though. We had many different people talking to us and serving us. We loved it!

We ordered the seared tuna salad, cream shrimp pasta penne and
corn and cheese grits.  The tuna salad was very good. The shrimp pasta was creamy and delicious.  The corn and cheese grits actually tasted really good.  I usually dont like grits so I was surprised I enjoyed this dish. It must have been all the butter in the food. Yum!

Portions are humongous. not the negative here...but there is an issue when your favorite item out of the dish is the steamed broccoli. The fish was overly salted, but the corn grits? DELICIOUS. service was superb considering we had a 30 person group. enjoyable, but average food.

I've always wanted to come here but not alone, I was finally brought here for a NOLA Eats event and I enjoyed my experience. I like ribs and I like thai food so I was naturally dawn to their Thai ribs. Not only were the ribs really tasty, but the meat was so tender that it literally fell off the bone. I enjoyed them so much that I bought back some with me for breakfast the next morning! They also tout their own beer. It not that bad but I don't think it matches well with the restaurant overall. 

The restaurant itself has your typical fancy chain restaurant decor. It sets the mood for a fancy date. It's probably not good to eat ribs when you do.

I am very impressed by the newly renovated Winn Dixie. I admittedly had never been to the previous iteration, nor Sweetbay, so I don't have much comparison. But I will say that I am impressed with this store and will continue to frequent it. The produce looks fantastic and is very nicely displayed on ice. The selection is pretty expansive, and they have a nice organic section. I would have preferred some additional organic produce, but I was pleased with what they have. I heard great things about their rotisserie chicken (supposedly better than their unnamed main competitor) and the pizza looks yummy. They deli counter is expansive (Dietz and Watson, not Boars Head) and they have house-prepared deli meat. They have a huge Kosher section, which is unheard of in Tampa, and lots of other ethnic food (excellent Asian selection for those of us who like to cook with those ingredients). We were greeted several times and asked if we needed help finding anything. One gentleman said to please let them know if there is anything we are ever looking for that we can't find in the store.
