The store is clean and bright. Can't give it 5 stars yet because I haven't tried enough to speak to actual quality, but I will definitely keep going back!

Winn Dixie will never be the old Sweetbay, but thankfully, the staff has remained the same. As a result of the company takeover, prices have dropped. This review is for the liquor store (I know, I know, what a surprise...haha). 

I visited the liquor store Sunday in order to stock up for Sunday Funday Margaritas that my bestie planned on making later that night. Thank God for my mid-afternoon nap because Sunday Funday began with six mimosas earlier that morning and I would have had no business whatsoever drinking margaritas. 

Bethany was the WD staff member working in the liquor store that day. She was very friendly and helpful with assisting me in finding everything I needed, especially since my best friend doesn't mess around with the cheap stuff. 

Like I stated earlier, prices have definitely dropped due to the WD conversion. I saved $8 with my WD card and I was proud!

Yes, this isn't your mass merchandiser liquor store down the street. Yes, they don't have an infinite number of choices for liquor and wine. But, they are conveniently located, the staff is friendly, and prices are low. 

No brainer here - I will definitely be back.

Wow what a change! The new Winn Dixie is amazing to walk into. So organized, clean and everything has been upped. As soon as you walk in you past their hot food section. Girls were cutting smoked juicy brisket. Yum! The produce looked so nice sitting on ice and meats section has dry aged steaks for purchasing. Winn Dixie did a great job making the grocery store more
Modern. Will be coming back. Seems to be giving publix a run for their business.

Very impressive  upgrade recently displayed in Grand (re)Opening.  This used to be a fairly standard large WD, but not getting much traffic in Hyde Park, that also had a spiffy Publix Greenwise and is near to Fresh Market and Trader Joe's on Dale Mabry.  The store now looks bright, open and modern.  New upgraded sections for kosher, cheese/deli and the take out prepared foods are a world apart from unusual WD fried 'n dried chicken.  Even their fried chicken cutlets offer several flavors, plus broiled salmon, roasted veggies and an adjacent salad bar.  The Grand Opening was lavish with live music, swarms of extra help, dozens of food samplings such as hummus, grape leaves, marinated mozzarella, salsa, salmon, Kahwah coffee etc.  We will be back even without the bells and whistles

This is not the Winn Dixie of my child hood. That is for sure! This South Tampa location looks clean and stylish and has many offerings that compete with local favorites like Publix. Their seafood options are well priced(sales on Salmon and mahi mahi for example were less than $9/lb), and they'll cook it for you as well for free. Their prepared foods were also well priced - bourbon salmon for around $4 a piece. They now have a prepared food storefront inside that has chopped barbecue and cooked food items. They also have a gelato station, a coffee shop, and mini donuts! They even dry age meats!

Staff were friendly and incredibly helpful.

I dislike the Winn Dixie chain as a whole. I think the products are overpriced and their food selection tends to focus on highly processed foods. That being said, this is probably one of the nicest Winn Dixies I've ever been to. It's always clean, it's a large store, it's right next to a basketball court and art studio, and it's down the street from my gym. The parking lot is also more shaded than most are due to the trees. So I guess if you're going to get ripped off at a Winn Dixie, get ripped off at this one.

Wowzers! Let me preface this review with mentioning it is not for all Winn Dixies it is SOLELY for the Hyde Park Winn Dixie. Boy, do they do things differently in Hyde Park. The Winn Dixie by my house on Gandy Blvd and Manhattan is a straight-up dump with very shady characters lurking about but this Winn Dixie in the rich folks neighborhood is a whole other story. 
First off, it looks prettier from the outside. The parking lot is large and clean. The carts have cup holders and purse hooks for your shopping pleasure. Upon walking in there was a live musician with tables set up and a wine tasting going on. I'm not kidding.
 Also, they had a lovely basket of free fruit for children to munch on while shopping. What? The manager was there and handed me a menu of all of the events for the month of June. Almost every day they have a cooking class, a wine tasting, bingo, coffee and donuts, activities for the kids, etc. This Winn Dixie has an actual event coordinator. Mind blown! The store itself is new, modern, and open. The produce department is lovely and has a nice prepared food area (like Whole Foods). The best part is they have regular Winn Dixie pricing. My complaint is why is this particular store so much nicer than any other?? This is the way grocery shopping should be done folks. Get it together with the other stores.

I stopped by to check out the grand re-opening and was very impressed with their new food stations and wide variety of gourmet items. I've never been a big fan of this chain but they really knocked my socks off. Everything from service to the ambiance was spot on and I can't wait to do more shopping there. I love how they promote local products.

I went in for a pack of gum and I went out with a whole new perspective on existence. 

Winn Dixie and I are BFFs, I am a proud loyalty member. I don't need the bells and whistles but this store has the bells and whistles. It is more Disney World, less grocery store. And even though I love my Winn Dixie as stripped and simple as it usually is this was a whole lot of fun. 

For anyone that would argue Publix is worth the price because ~experience~ I would point them in the direction of this magical store.

I absolutely love this dog park! Granted, I've only been to like 3 dog parks in my whole life... but this one is pretty great! The dogs and doggie owners that come here are courteous and respectful. It is a very clean area with shaded seating and water fountains for your pup. There are lots of toys left around to play fetch with your dog too! Great park, I am definitely going to be a consistent regular here every morning.

Great dog park but even better people. I've not meet too many poorly behaved dogs, or if there is an anxious one then the owners are usually attentive and accountable.

The pet owners here are amazing. I often see them sweeping the side walks and leveling any loose gravel. 

Generally no more than 10 dogs so it's usually a small to medium crowd.  They also provide tennis balls, poop scoopers and poop bags. Separate play areas for small vs large dogs.

Public pool, playground, baseball fields, skate park, covered picnic area and dog park all rolled into one!  The dog park is super cute and divided into small and big dog areas...complete with dog bone shaped benches, pooper scoopers and doggie drinking fountains.  I love that it is open until 1030pm!!!!  It is super well lit, so I like to go every night for the dogs...plus I can get a few miles in jogging or biking too.  We like to find baseballs that were hit out of the park...and it's fun to watch them play...Chachi, my youngest chihuahua wants a sk8 board and Spunky, the older chihuahua wants to try out for the team.  Great place to lizard hunt too!

In really like this park- it is a memorial to a K9 unit that got killed in the line of duty- take a second and read the placard outside on your way in.

The people who come here all seem to be really responsible dog owners- any signs of aggression are immediately taken care of and everyone is happy to pet and make friends with each other's dogs.

The grounds are really well kept- there is a little path that runs through the park for people to walk on and there is a good amount of landscaping with trees, rocks, little hills and tall grass for the dogs to play in. There was also an abundance of balls and Frisbees for use, which is nice. There are people and dog fountains as well as a large covered seating area. 

The park has separate areas for both small and large dogs. A few people brought their small dogs into the large dog space- but they first asked every single person if it was alright. I think there is a lot of good vibes in this park and I'm happy that it's located close to my home.

This dog park is nestled in the back of Purple Heart Park. You can park at Purple Heart and meander through or you can park right outside the dog park. 

The park has a large covered seating area as well as three benches without shade throughout. The park is dirt with some needleless desert plants around the edges. A paved sidewalk lines the perimeter for easy walking. There are the standard dog poo disposal cans with rakes/shovels available. I've always found this park to be clean, owners are pretty good about picking up after their dogs and the county staff empty the cans fairly regularly. 

Ivan's spot is divided into a large dog and small dog section. Some large/small dogs will still run along the fence in-between the two parks with each other and its adorable. 

Humans who frequent this spot seem to be friendly and overall keep a good eye on their pups, we've yet to encounter any horrible pups or humans.  My dog is much older and sometimes gets a little trampled at busy dog parks with aggressive dogs, but here she can meander along the edges easily without getting caught in the mix of larger, more energetic dogs.

Yogo Factory was located mere steps from the Courtyard that I was staying at, so I stopped in after a (crappy) dinner at Prime Burger. It's a big store and everything was really clean when I visited.

They've got a dozen or so froyo dispensers, but only 7-8 were "active". Still, that's plenty of choice. Unlike other froyo places, they do have a few flavors of regular ice cream (called "custard" here). The cups they offer are HUGE! Don't fill it all the way or your treat will be really expensive. 

Their toppings bar is, by far, the most comprehensive I've ever seen. They've got any and all candy, cereal and fruit options plus tons of sauce choices. Not just the standard hot fudge and caramel either - I saw fruit flavors, coffee syrup and my favorite, marshmallow. 

The froyo itself was pretty standard - not too grainy and pretty tasty. If you're staying at the Courtyard you might just want to eat ice cream for dinner because the nearby "food" choices are pretty bad.

The ice cream was OK. My visit here solidified that I'm not as big of a Coldstone fan as other ice cream places. For one, after they've mashed it altogether it loses the shape and texture of just regular old ice cream that I like. 

At this particular location, I stood waiting behind the glass awkwardly for a few minutes before even being helped. I was hoping someone might greet me and ask what I wanted. 

A-OK, but I'm not rushing back to this Coldstone or any of them, really.

mmmm... Cheesecake Fantasy. Birthday remix is good too. There is always a line here but with good reason, the Ice Cream is good! You could get one of their signature creations or mix things up and create one of your own. I can't eat more than a "Like It" (small) size cup. I've tried their waffle bowls before and although it tastes great, I just couldnt finish it. You also get very thirsty so you might as well buy some water or something while you're at it. 

The good thing about this location is that you're allowed to take the ice cream into the theater with you. Sit, watch a movie, and eat some ice cream. Can't get much better than that. It beats paying for pretzel bites or popcorn and a soda.

For the most part, Cold Stone is consistently the same across the board. It is my favorite place to indulge in some yummy ice cream!

Most of the times, customer service is friendly. This visit was no exception. The young lady allowed me to taste a few flavors -- which was nice!

My favorite ice cream from cold stone: cake batter cream w/ yellow cake chunks. I also had to be extra and added white sugar crystals (because they did not have anymore red and green crystals for Christmas).

The ice cream was delicious and made me very happy!! Love this franchise!
They really do well with their portion sizes. Not the most outgoing staff members but they got the job done.

Nashville is over-saturated. There are too many restaurants at too high of a price point offering mediocre food and service. I almost want to stop trying new establishments and let Darwinism settle the Nashville restaurant scene. I'll be over here eating at my old staples. 

I stopped in for lunch and it was empty. I ordered the cacio e pepe and it was inedible. It was so salty I couldn't finish it. I love pasta so much and I had high hopes, but it was truly awful and I should have sent it back. I was being too nice and it felt weird to do so when I was the only one there. I left so mad I spent $18 on the worst plate of food that I have eaten in 2018. By the end of 2018 many more restaurants are going to close and if Ellington weren't protected in a hotel they would be in trouble.

This makes me sad because it does have potential to be a great place. It's your quintessential two martini lunch stop. It's like you walked into Mad Men. The ceilings are low, the decor is masculine, and the music is jazzy/elevator. The only thing missing was smoke, which I am very glad we are almost living in a post-smoke world. The restaurant has a decent view too. 

I definitely won't be back. If they can't send out an edible plate when it's literally the only plate they've made in the past hour then there is a problem. How in the world can they handle a rush when you can't handle just me?

What a hidden gem  you step out of the elevator and into a different time. It is updated yet has enough of the charm from long ago. 

Reservations on Resy - Easy Peasy

All the wait staff -super friendly! 

I love the menu has a simplicity to it. 
My steak was cooked to perfection 

The biscuits were delicious (berry jam so I could not partake) 

Love the drink menu very unique flavors. 
The Pacific Prince was my choice they light the rosemary so it gives it a smoky vibe! 

Cannot wait to go back and check out the beautiful outdoor area. 

They offer love music and events!

The vibe of this place is far out! The ghosts of 1970 are alive here! The wood, the brass, the planters, the color scheme, the swank... the attention to period detail needs a shout out!! 
Mr Roeper night walk in any minute! (Three's Company reference, millennials) 
But the food is modern and fabulous! The watermelon and feta salad is one of my favorite dishes in The city.  The roasted cauliflower is downright meaty. The diver scallops are large and in charge.  The burger is a winner, and the fries  are delightfully lightly kissed with a touch of lemon zest.  The wine list is fairly priced (thank you) and the selections are fantastic. We had a rosè, a white and a red... all rave worthy. 
Dessert was a perfect ending... mud pie! My favorite was the fresh whipped cream. 
In nice weather, take a seat outside. Or enjoy live music inside. Can't go wrong either way. 
The manager, Scott, was kind enough to come to our table and check in. We were impressed with his enthusiasm. We shall return!

Ellington's Mid Way Bar & Grill is more than just a restaurant, it's a time capsule. Right when walking in, you will find yourself transported back to the 70's. Not in a flower power peace sign kind of way but much more of a Mad Men swanky lounge kind of way. 

Ellington's is located in the Fairlane Hotel in dowtown Nashville. The restaurant starts off right by offering free valet parking for restaurant patrons. The valet worker was very nice and excited to talk about the hotel and the restaurant. You know it's a good place when you see the worker's eyes light up when talking about it. I went here on a Friday night for dinner and it wasn't too busy seeing that they just opened. We were seated right away next to a window because I wanted to take in the ambiance of the interior. It was perfection. Clean lines, dark tones of green and blue, gold and wood, and fitting music to top it all off. Whoever thought of this concept had every detailed planned perfectly. I think it would be really fun to come back dressed in some of my 70's vintage best. Our server was really nice and helpful. She had great descriptions and opinions for the menu items. I started off the night with an Aviation. It was a beautiful gradient of white into blue and was equally delicious. I later ordered a New Heights IPA so they also have a nice beer selection. For an appetizer, we decided to try the Fetta. It was fetta, olive oil, thyme, and watermelon. At first I thought this sounded like a weird combo but man oh man was it surprisingly delicious. The salty and sweet really complimented each other well. Dinner also came with complimentary bread with jam and butter. I try not to fill up on bread but always fail to control myself. I ate most of the bread because it was so good. However, I still had room for my main course, the Roast Chicken. It was served with truffle jus, field peas, and potatoes. I always say that you if you can get me to eat my greens, you win. I ate it all. The flavor of the jus with the chicken and veggies was incredible. It was a big piece of chicken and plenty of veggies so I don't think you need a side dish with this meal. But maybe that's because I wanted to leave room for dessert. I had the Banana Pudding for dessert and it was the perfect way to end a perfect meal. After polishing off our meal, we took a little tour of the restaurant. Their is a full bar that is beautifully done and a balcony that wraps around about half of the building. The bathrooms are pretty cool so don't miss those! 

Ellington's is really an experience. They dared to do something a little different with the theme and really pulled it off. If you want to impress someone with a nice dinner, take them here. They also do brunch and lunch!

Maddening. This should be a 4.5/5 star review. Nashville is at a tipping point when it comes to bars/restaurants. I have heard time and again how difficult it is to find/keep good FOH/kitchen talent but doing so is essential to the business plan. I don't want this city to fizzle out when there's so much potential yet to be tapped. The fact of the matter, though, is when you're asking the buying public to dole out significant dollars, you have to be on top of your craft every time. You do.

My first experience at Ellington's came during their first week. I was (pleasantly) stunned by how well they tapped into the '70s cool of that era's James Bond, Hart to Hart, The Rockford Files, etc. Rather than depressing, the brass, browns, wood paneling, and large plants set a mood. This was punctuated by the music/muzak. My mood was further elevated by the menu. The choices of classic and signature drinks were well-curated (here, it makes sense to go with the classics). I was happy with my feta/watermelon appetizer and the shrimp & grits were delicious. Despite not having gluten-free desserts, I enjoyed the 1970s-era cups my post-meal coffee came in. I left happy. Very happy.

Then, I came back the following week and the wheels fell off. This time around, the place was busier but not so busy that you couldn't sit. We were warmly greeted by the hostess from the previous week. Rather than being seated by the window (by the patio), we were seated by the wood paneling/mirror banquette. Fine so far. I liked having the new perspective of the dining room. I spied my waitress from the previous week and it looked like we were in her section. Nice! Hopefully she remembered my generous tip. And then we sat. And sat. And sat. We stared awkwardly at each other. My guest started to get annoyed and I got embarrassed. No one interacted with us. We weren't given so much as a glass of water. We felt extremely unwelcome. Finally, our hostess came by with water and a smile... but that was it. The waitress from the previous week who was being so gracious and charming with other tables twisted her body so as not to have to acknowledge us. Again. We sat. And sat. And sat. By this time, I am past being embarrassed. I am angry. A floor manager finally comes by to take our drink order. She says that she put too many covers in our server's section and that was the reason for the protracted delay. A few things about that: 1.) A lot of covers =/= being unable to stop by the table and say, 'Hi, folks. I'll be right with you and I'll have a runner drop some water off to you. Thanks!' 2.) There were other servers/runners in our section joking with and serving customers (who arrived before and after we did). 3.) No mention of 'Let me get you started with some drinks/apps on the house. So sorry for this mix up.' None of these things happened. Rather, after a tepid excuse for being treated like filth and watching our server - the same server I over-tipped the previous week - treat other guests with professionalism, I decided to leave. I went to the host stand, informed them that they could cancel my order and that we were leaving. In the midst of this, who should arrive? Our server. For the first time. Nope. Please continue to ignore us. You were doing that so well. The floor manager took my name and number and offered to have a manager call me. I left Ellington's and retired to the Fairlane lobby. I noticed two people from the restaurant had followed me down there but neither engaged. I used my Yelp app to find another eatery, left and have no plans on returning.

It's a shame.

No. No. No. 

I'm pretty sad to leave this review but it should be known. 

First, we walk in the place is basically empty. And I'm already worried because it's in a hotel but I'm giving it a shot. 

Sat in the "bar" area in where the booths are. So the bar tenders had to come and serve us which wasn't bad but they had to leave the bar to come around and it was just wonky. 

The first guy bar tender was just so lax and loose he seemed like he just was there to be average. I'll explain. 

Ordered the Caesar salad and it was fine, nothing exciting. He split up the plates for me and my date and I didn't ask for that. Then says "well you have two forks to eat both." Uuummmmmm I can't. 

I ordered chicken and said I DO NOT want mashed potatoes and to sub them with the Brussels sprouts and jam. He repeated and said you know what hey when we get the chicken we get the Brussels sprouts I'm literally said that is exactly what I want with no mashed potatoes. My chicken was fine nothing go home about and I didn't get sick which was a plus. 

The shrimp and grits were also ordered thinking how can you screw up shrimp and grits. Well apparently you can. These grits were terrible and tasted like spiced dirt water. The shrimp was rubbery and tasteless. Whatever seasoning used was awful. They did take it off the bill and said they would also get dessert on them. 

Ordered the key lime pie because they were out of cheesecake. It was fine, but then I get the bill they freaking charged me for the dessert they said they were going to comp. I was about to lose it and just remained calm and paid it. 

The best thing about this place is on Sunday's it's half priced bottles of wine. 

Two stars for the effort and zero stars for the adding insult to injury of offering to comp dessert then charge. 

The most disappointing thing about this entire experience was, it was the last night in Nashville and we just had a rough experience. I won't be back and I hope they correct the menu and do more testing in the kitchen.

A few friends and I went to Ellington's before a show at TPAC this week, and there were definitely some things I liked about it! But there also things I didn't.

The good? Their happy hour has GREAT prices. A lot of happy hours in Nashville kind of suck? This one doesn't. Seriously discounted prices. All cocktails on their menu were half off. One house red (a red blend) and one house white (a pinot grigio) were half off. And all their beers were half off. HALF OFF. They had $2 oysters, and ALL THEIR STARTERS WERE $5. These are some real discounts. 

More good? The service was good. The wine and the cocktail I had were good. The restaurant is beautiful. Very Donald Draper walking in for a few martinis over his lunch hour. And it's really close to TPAC. There aren't that many dinner options walking distance to TPAC, so another option is good. I'm not huge at sweating through a nice meal, so you won't catch me on a patio until late September but for those of you who like to sweat and or don't sweat - they have a beautiful patio as well. 

The not so good? We decided to try ALL the starters (there are 7 of them) since they were all $5 (there were four of us). While some were better than others, only one really knocked my socks off. Here's what we had: warm olives with orange zest, roasted garlic and brioche (good, but it turned out that two of our party don't eat olives, and the other two of us coudln't eat the 100 olives that were in that bowl! way too many); piquillo peppers with queso fresco and chimichurri (okay); roasted cauliflower with togarashi spice, split pea puree, and ponzu (this wasn't a hit at our table); picked deviled eggs (this was the one - the one that impressed a lot - despite the fact that I'm not a deviled egg eater generally!); cheese curds with green goddess (okay - sort of bland cheese that could have been string cheese rather than a real cheese curd and I wouldn't be surprised); pork loin with white bbq sauce (I think that was the least favorite at our table - the pork seemed really dry and tough and bland); and a cold shrimp dish (I can't describe this one, because it wasn't on the menu, but it was one of the better starters in my opinion; the 7th starter on the menu was a feta with olive oil, thyme, and watermelon, but that's not what we got; all of our group ate shrimp, but I think they probably should have let us know that one of the dishes was different than on the menu). Overall, the food was okay at best. I was certainly happy with the cost ($35 for all 7), but the food definitely wasn't good enough that I'd be excited to eat there for dinner (when entrees range from $20-42). Some of the dishes we had seemed a little too much like bar food for the location and the prices (if weren't happy hour) - cheese curds? In a place as decked out as this? 

The Fairlane Hotel is beautiful (this restaurant is on the 4th floor), but parking in this part of town is practically nonexistent, so you're going to have to valet out front or park in a nearby garage (I was parking for a show at TPAC anyway, so this wasn't such a big deal for me). 

(Note: we had a reservation for 4 at 5:30 on a Tuesday evening before Ilana Glazer's double header show at TPAC. We didn't need a reservation. The restaurant was still pretty empty when we left at 6:40.)

The restaurant is beautiful. And the happy hour is great. I just didn't think any of the food was great unfortunately.

Nashville has grown so much and i never thought i would be going to so many hotel restaurants. But i had to try this one since I'm all about trying the new and upcoming spots. Right in the mids of downtown nashville and they offer complimentary valet which is nice. As you enter the hotel everyone is so nice and helpful. The doorman walked us right to the elevator and led us to the restaurant on the 4th floor. Once we entered the restaurant we was greeted by the hostess and asked to be seated out in the patio. It was a beautiful night to sit outside and enjoy the view and our food and drinks. Our hostess she basically turned into our waitress and she was very attentive. She gave us some recommendations as well. I wasn't too hungry at the moment and i just went with a sig cocktail and a dozen raw oysters to share. It was fresh and also tried the ribeye and mash potatoes. The food was good but nothing that just stand out.

Popped in to get gas in the work vehicle today and that was the most confusing fleet card experience I have ever had in my life.  I'm still confused as to why it was so confusing.

Anyhoo, this location has a car wash, fuel, as well as a fairly big snack/drink section for a Hughes.

I'm sure I'll be seeing you again Hughes :-)

This has become my go to place to fill propane cylinders and to wash my car.  My favourite propane place and wand wash car wash closed down over the last few years so now I go here.  A bit farther than my old favourites and a little bit more pricey as well, but not outrageous.

Gas Station: No comment.  I haven't filled-up here for gas.

Propane: I bring in my empty tanks and get them filled here.  Nothing special, fancy or better than any other propane filling place.

Car Wash: I prefer to wand wash my car.  My old favourite was the Fas Gas in Old Strathcona but it closed down and is under renovations.  The Hughes Car  Wash has about 10 bays and the few times that I have gone there I didn't have to wait long for a bay.  They use tokens which you can buy inside the gas station.  They have a change machine so you can feed in paper bills or coins to get your tokens (1 token = $1).  I believe each token gives you about 1 minute.  This is a bit less than Fas Gas so it usually costs me about $1-2 extra to wash my truck (big whoop!).

Pros: Good location that is quick to get to.  The place is clean.  The staff has always been friendly. They have gas and propane and a car wash -- one stop action packed vehicular and bbq pleasure.

Cons: I wish the car wash gave you a tad bit more time for your loonie.

I didn't really think much of this place. It was pricey, but that's to be expected of markets in the city. 

What surprised me was the lack of higher end products. It seemed to be filled with a lot of regular items, which is fine for a grocery I guess. But with higher prices, I'd expect a wider array of higher quality goods to match the price. All in all, I wasn't very impressed with the selection of products.

Rittenhouse market has some great produce and products.  if you're in a bind and need something quickly and your in the area it's a great place to shop.  I would never use it to get all my groceries because everything is extremely overpriced. Extremely friendly stare out always helpful.

I, too, am absolutely shocked that a grocery store in Rittenhouse is overpriced. Shocked!

The convenience is really worth it sometimes, especially when I'm coming home from work and want to pick up a bunch of veggies and don't have the cash in my pocket to go to Sue's. And really, nothing that I buy there is so marked up that I feel like I have to borrow against my 401k just to eat. If I need to be frugal, I know where to go.

Plus, the people who work there are friendly. And they deliver, which is a neat option.

Step right up, folks! What mysteries, what wonders lie within this glass-fronted grocerarium? You've gawked the bearded lady, you yawned as the sword-swallower downed a flaming bayonet, but ladies and gentleman, let me assure you - you have never seen anything like this. Here in our fair city, mere blocks from our humble abodes, there dwells a spectacle of most mind-shattering magnitude: it's the WORLD'S MOST EXPENSIVE GROCERY STORE!

You heard it here first, folks. You want carrots, lasagna noodles, a block of feta? You'll find all these things and more, at prices so high you'll feel dizzy just reading them. Marvel at the $6 crackers (gasp!), gaze at  singularly unappealing prepared foods (no!), and don't even ask what they charge for Method dish soap! I'll bet you thought Whole Foods was rather pricey - my dear friends, take it from me: you've never seen anything like this.

It's still pricey, but yes you are paying for the convenience. Try your hardest not to shop here, but if you must it can be a pleasant experience. I once was dead set on having rhubarb preserves and lemon sorbet. I only like hagen daz lemon sorbet. I've tried every lemon sorbet, Hagen daz is seriously the best. I mean other than capogiro. Well they didn't have any in the case. The super sweet manager, went in the back and dug up a ton of them for me! He didn't have to do that for me. I might have received this sort of service at Whole Foods, but definitely not at super fresh! Super fresh where I have had to explain cream of mushroom soup to the manager. No joke. I have a witness!

This place should be listed in the dictionary under "expensive". That being said, I still find myself here every couple of weeks due to the convenient location on my walk home from work. Overall, they have a little bit of everything. They also have a selection of  Di Bruno Bros meats and cheese which adds a gourmet touch.

I find the prices to be shocking and the store itself overwhelming - the space is tight and packed. However, I give Rittenhouse Market three stars due to their attentive staff.  The managers here are excellent and always assist me with whatever I may need, seeing that one of my downfalls is a lack of patience and a hatred towards browsing aisles for hours.

The prices are sky high, staff are scarily unfriendly, produce is disgusting (rotten garlic) and overpriced, but the last straw for me was my latest interaction with a cashier.

I presented a manufacturer's coupon I printed at home to the cashier and she responded with, "That's no good here."  I checked to see if it was expired (it wasn't) and asked why.  She told me it wasn't "legit" and after I asked why again she said it was because it was printed.  During this lovely exchange she made zero eye contact and sighed repeatedly.

The only thing they have going for them is their location.
Expensive due to location. But great selection for the small space. Perfect for picking up a few things including produce. Staff is insanely friendly an helpful!

Not a lot of selection to be honest, but it's nice to have a corner market in the neighborhood for basic items. Stopped by here to get a few snacks and toothpaste. They have a deli in the back of the store and a soup bar. It would be a nice if they'd run a meal deal like the ones in England or Ireland. Mark & Spencers, Sainsbury, Tesco, Lidl, Dunnes....They all offer some sort of meal deal which includes drink, sandwich, and chips! This store is very basic. I didn't see anything good on sale either.

Wow - such awful reviews for this place.  Sure it's sky-high prices - but you are paying for the convenience factor.  Decent produce, frozen foods, dairy, meat and prepared foods.

I go here for emergency purchases, certainly not to do my everyday shopping.

GLad they exist.  Grocery stores are few & far between in Center City.

Its far from my first choice to shop for groceries. But Rittenhouse Market can be a good mish mash of conventional, organic, and local items; albeit oftentimes on a more expensive pricetag than most other grocers as others have alluded to. But I suppose that's the price to pay in supporting the little guys these days, and the amicable customer service and reliability of being able to locate some harder to find items can make it worthwhile.

The produce section is always fresh and well maintained. and the butcher and prepared foods sections are spot on for a tinier store.

Walking into the Rittenhouse Market reminded me a Tesco's Express or Sainsbury's Local in the UK. It is what it is: a small, no frills grocery store that's conveniently located in the heart of a city so you can get what you need (or what you forgot elsewhere) quickly. It's not especially clean, it's not especially spacious, it's not especially cheap... but it's always there.

We were staying nearby on Manning Street and realized that we were desperate for diet cola (side note: I did *not* know about Philly's soda tax... way to shame me, City of Brotherly Love. Je ne regret rien!). We walked down here thinking we'd pop in and out, but ended up exploring the store more than we anticipated because of the impressive amount of variety. Seltzer water flavors we had never seen, new-to-us chip options, and vegetarian staples I swear by at home that had selections I didn't even knew existed.

Okay, Rittenhouse Market, way to have everything I need (or forgot elsewhere) and THEN some!

GREAT SCOT ITS RIP OFF MARKET

walk an extra block to maxx's or food and friends on 20th and spruce. hop on the bus to trader joe's but only only shop in here if you want to drain your bank account or mortgage your condo for a lousy package of moldy strawberries!

Stopped in here before attending Festival of Speed at Vinoy Park last weekend. We were in need of some coffee and a bathroom and Annex delivered on both fronts. We ordered the chocolate smoothie (I believe it was called the chocolate monkey) made with almond milk, banana, and some peanut butter. My boyfriend ordered a to-go cup of tea. I was a little shocked that the small smoothie cost about $6 but the small tea was $3 and most of the breakfast sandwiches on the menu were around $6-7 and granola/yogurt for a little bit more. They also had several different options for lunch. You are definitely paying for the location here. They have several tables outside to sit and enjoy a coffee and people watch. The view here honestly cannot be beat, you can see the ocean and the park and plenty of pretty people and cars walking to the other restaurants, shops, and galleries in the area. Annex also has a small shop where they sell cute gifts and other touristy odds and ends. They have a decent selection of wines to purchase for carry out. Service was a little slow but it was a busy Sunday morning in St Pete and the view was worth the wait.

After walking and walking and trying to find a good place to have breakfast we finally end up here. And I'm so glad we did. The food was amazing, the coffee was spectacular, and the service was good.

They have seating areas outside and inside at this ample coffee shop where they also have a store and they sell nice souvenirs.

Their prices are great.

We got a ham and cheese croissant and let me tell you it is one of the best I have had, crispy, fresh ham and cheese, and served warm with a wonderful price. 
Their coffee was served extremely hot and I was extremely happy too because that's the way I like it. They didn't put sugar which is wonderful because then we chose the sugar amount we wanted. 
The taste was very good and we had a mocha and a café con Leche.

This little place is fantastic!

I always get the same thing (creature of habit) a large decaf caramel almond milk latte (that they always get right!) And a croissant with egg and cheese. Their croissants are always light yet crunchy. 

Perfect

Every time! 

And it's only $11.50

Oh and super nice people that work there.

Pro tip...check out their wine selection

Four star first impression of Annex. Thought this unsuspecting cafe hidden among fancy restaurants and bars was the perfect spot to break for lunch. My group was walking along the waterfront park, and weren't dressed appropriately for fine dining. Annex provided shade, air conditioning, and a casual dining experience with gluten free options. The first thing we noticed was the art covered walls and unique collection of retail items. For lunch I ordered myself an egg, cheese and avocado sammich on gluten free bread. It was absolutely delectable in all its simplistic glory. Exactly what I was hoping for. Added bonus for serving breakfast items after noon. Everyone enjoyed their light lunches and milkshakes. We left Annex feeling refreshed and rejuvenated.

Had a very nice experience here.  Very friendly and efficient employee took my order, and the restaurant seemed clean.  Food order came out quick.  I did have to go back up for breadsticks as they forgot to give them with our meal, but otherwise it was tasty and I would come back.

We r in the land of Fazoli's. It's dinner time and got off the road for some good fast food Italian. When my baked Spag with meat sauce came it was pretty sad looking! I have never had it this small of an amount and hardly any sauce on top!! Noodles were exposed and dry looking. I spread them a bit for the pix. The taste was good but I have to say this is the WORST looking dish I have ever had at Fazoli's. 
   Bf had the chicken carbonara and it was good. He ordered a side salad and drink for add on. Thank god for the breadsticks.  I use my app for $ back too. I now have $5 on for next time! I needed one dollar to score my points which I did this visit.

I got so excited when I saw a commercial for Fazoli's. I've been searching far and wide for this place. I went like four years ago while I was in Anderson, SC and fell in love with their breadsticks and pizza. Back then they served only whole pizza's and no slices. In recent years they started selling slices and I don't think the pizza taste as good. The breadsticks are still good for what there worth, but Fazoli's is not at the top of my list for best food in the world. It is good when you need some where quick to go.

The dim sum here is rather delicious. And while I've only ever ordered dim sum here, I do totally recommend it for that. So many wonderful dishes! It's hard not to over order when out for dim sum in general, but this place is good. The menu is varied but really quite good.

I have nothing bad to say at all, I was very impressed.  

My mom and I went for Dim Sum on Sunday at about 11 am, and although it was almost full, there was no wait at all and the carts starting come by immediately.  There was a good pace to the carts as well, we never had to wait very long for our next option.  The staff were extremely friendly!  Everytime I said "thank you", they would respond with "thank you as well".  Which delighted me to no end for some reason.

The food was delicious!  I would gladly go every day.

Saturday night at 6:30 and the restaurant was getting full.  Within an hour, people had to wait until a table was available.  The  restaurant presents itself as a modern and appealing place for a Chinese restaurant, unlike some dark and dingy places.  But appearance doesn't mean the food will be great.  I noticed the customers varied and the dishes ordered varied from the more traditional Chinese dishes to chicken balls and dim sum.  

We ordered set dishes and added a few more.  We had soup, lettuce wrap duck, crab/lobster dish, fried chicken, peaches and shrimp, veggies, sweet sour pork, fish, and noodles.  The size of the dishes was adequate and enough for the table of 11 with some leftovers.  The food was flavourful and not greasy.  

Service throughout the night was good with refills on our drinks and rice.  The bill was a little high compared to other places at around $250 but still decent for the amount of food.

Would recommend reservations if you come with a large group or on the weekend evenings.

Visited Tasty Noodle recently for a wedding reception. It was definitely above my expectations! The reception took up at least half of the resto, but because of the layout and the service, it felt like we had the place to ourselves. We had ten dishes which were timed well; none of the tables suffered for lack of service or food. The clearing of dishes was timely and the service staff were generally on top of things. Food was good, more traditional Chinese (thank god), I really liked the jellyfish salad, the cured duck with gai lan, the pan fried noodles with enoki mushrooms, and the crab & egg soup. Had a great time, everything was clean and organized, and the reception went off well. I'd definitely come back! Hopefully there's not just a caucasian menu and a secret (chinese) menu. I did get asked like 7 times if I'd like silverware, so maybe... The Chinese menu is good anyhow!

I'm very sad to downgrade my review of Tasty Noodle.  And so drastically.  But I won't be going back for Dim Sum.

I'll leave it as 2 stars because the food is still decent.  But the overall experience is just not right.

There was no lineup and a few tables were empty on Sunday at 12:30.  That should have been my first clue that something was wrong.  When we sat down, we were given a big "menu" with a bunch of pictures on it, and a sheet of paper that we were apparently supposed to indicate our order on.  We weren't told anything.  These items were just placed in front of us.  We had to flag somebody down to explain it.

So... there's no more carts.  With the exception of the dessert cart.  You have to order your dishes.  I don't like this for a few reasons.  #1 - I prefer to leave dim sum up to fate.  What I eat, depends entirely on what carts come around that day.  #2 - All of your food comes out at once now, and you need to find room for it on your small table.  #3 - the menu does not list any prices.  With the old method, I could keep track of what I was spending, but this way I cannot.

It's really not an enjoyable experience for me and not worth the drive from St. Albert anymore.  I'll stick with Jumbo on the West End now.

Recently ordered dim sum take out and wow. The portions are large and plump! I was surprised how big the food was as we've ordered from here before and I don't remember the things being that big. 

We ordered the dumplings and some other things. Check out the picture, they are plump juicy, and so flavourful! I was very happy with this order. They still offer a discount for pick up so make sure to support this great dim sum place and order your pick up yourself.

Great spot for convenient pick up! They offer 20% off your order if you go pick it up for takeout! We love coming here for dim sum and usually that's what we order. The shomai and the deep fried shrimp wonton dumpling with mayo are my favourite!! If you're in the mood for low cost but decent dim sum, try this place out! We usually call to order ahead and then pick up.

I ate my first 5 Guys burger in Columbia SC several years ago during a visit to Daughter #1 who was in college at USC. Five guys is the rage, Dad. We have to go. So go we did. It was the rage for a reason. I really loved the burgers, the peanuts, and the vibe which was pretty cool for a fast food place. I googled 5 guys when I returned home and loved the story of a Dad and his 4 sons opening up a burger place. And the rest is history. 

So I was super excited when I read that 5 Guys was coming to NOLA. An educated guess is they were in tune with the recent NOLA burger craze and decided to cash in. So D #1, who has since returned to her beloved New Orleans, and I headed to the concreteness that is Clearview Pkwy for a nostalgia burger. 

They did a good job of getting the restaurant to have the same feel as the ones in SC. It was packed at lunchtime on a Tuesday, but the bustle didn't bother me for some reason. I consider the burgers to be the best of the fast food class, pretty close in flavor and texture to Camellia Grill. The fries can stand up to some of the best in NOLA no doubt. One disappointment was the amount of fries per order. In SC I remember ordering a medium fry and getting enough for a family of 4. These orders are tiny and rather pricey. Overall cost is more than your typical fast food jernt but well worth the extra 3 bucks or so for a lunch for two.

Honestly....I don't see how its any better than a Wendy's burger. HOWEVER, the fries alone get all three stars. I love fresh cut fries and you can order them extra crispy and they will fry them twice to make sure you have a heart attack. You would think the cajun seasoning would be a big win for me, but I like them with just the sea salt they use. Sometimes simple is better.

I heard quiet a few things about this place from people all around. I noticed that they opened one up by where I live. So I decided to check out,"Five Guys Burgers and Fries". Yes I know there is a typo, and no I am NOT the one who posted the business listing.
{edit}- looks like they fixed the typo, I guess no yummy french feies for me ;)

When I got there they had a long line out the door. The thought that kept racing through my head was that the food better be worth the wait. as I inched my way to the counter which took about 25 minutes.I finally got to the cashier. She was very friendly and explanatory about the menu. She gave me suggestions to order. So I picked what I wanted and placed my order.

I ordered the Bacon cheese burger with cajun fries. They give you multiple options of what you want on your burger. The toppings I chose were grilled onions,grilled mushrooms, lettuce, tomato and mayo. The burger was fantastic! I also tried the cajun fries they were good also! Still the thoughts of that meal dance through my head. They sell hot dogs at five guys, so I might keep that as an option.Also for vegetarians out there they do sell grilled cheese sandwiches and a veggie burger. 

One thing that I will note is that the fries are cooked in peanut oil. Also they have free peanuts available for customers. If you have any allergies to peanuts than this place is probably NOT for you. I just thought I would throw in that disclaimer. Another heads up is how busy this place gets. You may have to take your meal to go given the fact that indoor and outdoor seating may be occupied. The prices are pretty reasonable here because you can get a filling meal for under $10. 

It still boggles my mind that this place is fast food, because it is almost as good as most gourmet burger spots. I will admit that for a chain fast food restaurant this place is top shelf. This place is definitely worth checking out.

In short good food,good prices, and good service. Who could ask for anything more?

100% FRESH BEEF... Fresh Cut Fries cooked in 100% peanut oil... YummmmmY

Well i finally made it. And apparently at a good time, I WAS NOT greeted with the "line out the door" phenomenon; thank you Jesus!!! 

Upon entering, its quite busy. People preparing food. People eating. People talking. People taking orders. In short, the use of your inside voice is not necessary. 

There were only 2 people ahead of me, how sweet is that???? No struggle there. But here's the reason for 3 stars instead of 4... 

The cashier who was "supposed" to be taking my order found it moooooooore interesting to talk to her fellow cashier & that cashier's patron than to take my order. So, I PATIENTLY waited for her (Maya according to the register receipt) to acknowledge me, greet me & ask me to step forward before I did so (I initially thought she was helping her fellow coworker with an problem, but as I ear hustled, I learned she was engaging in a nonchalant conversation with the 2 other ladies)... So, 2.5 minutes passed & she FINALLY acknowledged me & took my order (which, of course, not surprisingly she got WRONG). 

The food was good. Temperature was great. No biting & shuffling of food in your mouth because it was too hot. I got a little cheeseburger, thanks to my neglectful cashier, "all the way" less pickles. Grilled onions & mushrooms made me Happppppppppppppy!!!!

The burger prices seem comparable to Wendys, the fries are a little pricey, but I skipped out on that portion of the experience.  

Free roasted peanuts for your dining pleasure, but don't throw those shells on the floor, as the sign directs; this AIN'T O'Henrys (well that part isn't in the sign... I threw that in for free  ) 

I enjoyed my dining experience, but I failed to see what all the hype was about.  But hey, "I came, I saw, I conquered..."  

Parking is shared with other retail establishments in the strip mall area, but there's really NOT a shortage of parking spots. 

The outside dining is a plus.

It's a Five Guys. Although the novelty has worn off, since they are now popping up everywhere, this is still a good burger. 

Fast food price, since it's a fast food restaurant, but I would pick Five Guys over Wendys, McD's, etc any day.

This was my first time at a Five Guys. I was told when I was in DC a couple years later that I *need* to eat at a Five Guys but I didn't have a chance to, so I was pretty excited that they were now in Louisiana.

K and I were deciding whether to check out the Five Guys or to go to Chipotle, and we went with Five Guys. The service I received when ordering our food was great. When I stood there looking at the menu like I didn't know what was going on, the cashier asked me if it was my first time and told me she could help and went over the menu with me. 

We each ordered a little bacon cheese burger and we also got the cajun fries. It took a while for the food to come out, so if I were in a hurry I'd definitely hit up another fast food place. K did not like the fries at all and I wasn't a huge fan but I still ate them because... well, because they're french fries. Our little burgers were indeed not little.

The one thing I did really appreciate about Five Guys is that they don't skimp on their toppings. Bacon and cheese are the only things you have to pay more for and I was very happy with the amount of bacon (compared to "fancy" burger places that charge 1.50 extra for bacon and give you like two strips).

Unfortunately the cashier did not hear my say I wanted jalapenos on my burger so I was a little disappointed about that, but the burger was pretty good (I got mine all the way minus mushrooms).

I would probably try it again after a while but we will probably skip the fries. Maybe eat some free peanuts instead.

It's...ok. Over-priced for the quality of food. The burgers are ok but in all honesty, we had a better burger at Dairy Queen. Seriously, I'm not joking...DQ had basic burgers but with a smoky flavor and good sauce amounts.

The young lady at the counter could NOT have been more helpful. The food was just ok. The fries were a bit soggy and since we ordered the "Cajun" fries, they came coated with a dull flavored powder. 

If I happened to be in the area and was really craving a burger, would I come back? Naah. 

But we're glad we tried it. 
That's about it.
Heart surgeons must love this place, much like the ones that own Corky's.  A group of Jewish cardiologists.  "Heaven in a brown paper bag!"-  I think not....

Five Guys is supposed to be the best burger  a bun has ever seen. In my opinion it falls way short of that distinguished honor. I got a "little cheeseburger" little because it had one patty instead of two. I had it dressed mayo, mustard, lettuce, tomato, pickle. Nothing fancy, but I could not even taste the burger! I feel like I just ate a lettuce, tomato, & pickle sandwich. I'm disappointed in that because I love a good burger, and I feel I just wasted my money.

I was very underwhelmed by Five Guys, especially as I had heard it was the east coast's answer to In n Out. Let me tell you, this burger pales in comparison, plus it's more expensive.

I got a regular burger (which the server did warn me was a double patty, which I am glad it was because I was hungry) "all the way." Things I liked: mushrooms, grilled onions. It's cool and a bit nicer to get these on your burger, makes it feel less fast food-y. The patty itself was pretty good. The cheese was unremarkable. Thing I didn't like: the bun. It had a not-quite-right texture and taste to it, almost too dense and sweet. I paid more than I would like for the burger, only for it to be drowned out by this weird bun. 

I got the Cajun style fries which were good; I think I like things REALLY seasoned though so that may be why. 

I am impressed that you can get a hot dog or veggie burger here, though frankly, with these prices, I'm not sure I'd ever go back. It's just barely better than Wendy's at twice the price. It's not as good as I.N.O. (as previously mentioned) and not nearly as good. Anybody want to sign my petition to get the real best fresh fast food burger out here?

I have been to Five Guys in the past. On my most recent visit, I had the small bacon cheeseburger with mayo and pickles, a small Cajun fries (they still fill a small brown paper bag, as you can see from my picture), and a soft drink. The total was just over $10.

There is plenty of parking. The interior is clean enough, but being primarily white, it is difficult to clean. You walk in, go to the part of the counter that says "order here", they give you a receipt once you have paid that has your number on it. You try to pick the cleanest table possible, which is tricky. Then fill your beverage cup and wait for your number to be called. During non-peak times, it could be 5-10 minutes.

The food is good enough. All in all, I do like this chain. This location could use some cleaning attention. In my opinion, the prices are a bit on the high side. Yes, you get a lot of fries, but I could share a small order with someone else. Which is nice, but most of the time, I am dining alone, so there is a waste of food. Being part of Elmwood Shopping Center, there is plenty of parking.

I feel very meh about this place. I never crave a burger from Five Guys. But if I'm in the area, and want a burger, I'll go here. I like that they have peanuts to munch on while you wait for your burger. But be warned, if you order anything but a burger and fries, it'll take some extra time for you to get your food. 

Pro-tip: When ordering a burger, keep in mind, a regular is a double patty, while a small is one patty.

Five Guys..
Man, I love your burgers, and crave your fries..
My only complaint for you is that you charge like you are fine dining.
For the cost of burgers, fries and a drink, I can get an oyster platter down the road and that is not an exaggeration.
I just cannot see paying your price point for a burger and fries thatyes, are better than the fast food around you are not good enough when I think of the dining choices for the same price point.
Rethink your prices..
Then, I'll be back.

Stopped by for lunch and was impressed with cleanliness, customer service, and cuisine! 

I indulged in a Burger with EVERYTHING on it and some hot and delish Cajun fries. One order is enough to share for 2. 

I enjoyed all of the drink options. They have those cool, new age, digital pick your flavor coke machines. 

The main cook on the grill was entertaining and kept the moral going amongst the kitchen. It was really a treat to watch him cook and prepare the made to order burgers. You could tell he was a "Vet" in the game! 

Restrooms were clean and well kept!

May be overrated? Both of my kids are allergic to peanuts and the fries are Cooked in 100% peanut oil. In addition, they really should stop making the veggie sandwich, it's gross without any flavor. Pretty pointless to have on the menu. Instead they should actually make a veggie burger with some seasoning. So I don't recommend this spot for people with peanut allergies or vegetarians.

This place is seriously overpriced. Don't get me wrong, they have a decent tasting burger. I just don't feel my double bacon cheeseburger should have carried a price tag of almost $9...and that's without fries or a drink. I ordered the Cajun fries and was underwhelmed. They were Cajun, but they could have used some salt as well. Also, they should rethink putting the piping hot fries straight in the cups after pulling them from the grease. By the time I got midways to my cup, the fries were sweaty/soggy and undesirable. I do appreciate the fact that food is cooked to order and you get it hot. Maybe I'll give them another chance, but will be sure to pour the fries out of the cup as soon as I get them.

Well unfortunately only 3 of the guys will get a star of the 5 of them or maybe they can get split custody.  Maybe 2 guys will get the stars every other weekend.  Hopefully they have good lawyers and there isn't a huge custody battle.

Anywho, Five Guys is a basic burger and fries joint.  The burgers are cooked to order on a hot griddle, the patties are on the thinner side which I like and there are a bunch of toppings and sauces.  The fries are fresh cut and also cooked to order.  They come in regular or Cajun style which I think means Tony's instead of regular salt.  The fries weren't as crisp as I'd like but not bad.  The only part of the burger I wasn't pleased with was the bun.  It comes on a sesame seed bun which I hate.  They are always dry and not nearly as smashable as I'd like.

The workers here were super friendly.  It's like they stole Chick-Fil-A's handbook because I swear 2 of them said "My pleasure" after I thanked them.  Sorry if I got you in trouble with any of Chic-Fil-A's trademarks.  You may want to keep one of those star custody lawyers from earlier on retainer.  

Anyway, It's a solid burger if you need you fix while shopping in Elmwood.

So I should say this right off the bat....I don't eat ground meat. Right, that means no burgers for this girl. Guess yall are wondering how I can review this place. My hubby loves this places so every now and then I'll go. There's hotdogs and veggie sandwiches. So first I tried the hotdog. Eh...it's a hotdog. Certainly not worth the money the charge for it. Also, the wrap it in foil which made the bun soggy from the steam from the hot meat. Then I tried the veggie sandwich. It was a ton canned mushrooms, a couple slices of tomatoes, lettuce, onions and bell pepper. The bun was nothing but mush so I really needed a fork to eat the veggies. The veggies were extremely bland. A nice veggie burger not lose veggie sandwich would go a long way here.

The fries are okay. I would prefer a crispier french fry myself. They offer regular or seasoned. We ask for light season, if not they put so much it burns your mouth and doesn't even taste that great. 

The atmosphere is great. The staff are always friendly. Service is quick. You get free peanuts in the shell. Also, it makes my hubby happy to eat here which makes me like it a little more.

Typical franchise for this chain.  Clean (except maybe peanut shells on the floor) and bright.  I like the burgers, nothing special, but decent.  Usually I get the double dressed (lots of options here).  The fries are problematic.  Often they are too greasy for my taste.  I prefer them with the sea salt rather than the seasoning.  For your drink, they have one of those mix your own soda machines

Dirty tables
High prices
And the food really isn't that good.

But the thing that is really disgusting about 5 Guys are those scrofulous touch screen coke machines. I mean they can't be sanitary. I've never seen anyone clean the panels when I eat there. Also they are hard for some slower folk to use - too many choices.

Out of the spite of "bud!s broiler", my son and I went to five guys on MY suggestion.  I opened the foil and thought there was a baseball spit cup poured atop the burger.  But a picture is worth a thousand words, so let's go to the slide show...

(see attached photo)
The employees handed me a sundae bowl filled to the brim  with melting ice cream and sauces. While I understand ice cream melts, it's still irresponsible to hand a customer something this messy. It's impossible to eat this standing or take it to go without it overflowing into your hands.

Service was nice. Aside from poor preparation, the sundae didn't taste bad.

WOW. Had lunch in Greenwood and we were looking for desert. Yelp led us to Handel's and I am so glad it did. 

I had a chocolate sundae with coconut cream pie ice cream, chocolate sauce, chopped nuts, whipped cream and a cherry on top. My friend had the turtle sundae and my wife had a cup of the coffee chocolate chip ice cream. 

It was ALL amazing. Some of the best ice cream I have ever had. The coconut cream pie ice cream had large pieces of pie crust in it. Delicious. The chopped nuts were not just peanuts. It was a mix and it was fresh and delicious. 

Two thumbs WAY up. Incredible.

This location is located off of 135. Newly built and a great place to enjoy lots of varieties of ice cream. The pistachio ice cream I ordered was great. It was loaded with pistachios. 

They actually have Handel's locations in ten states! It actually began by a lady named Alice Handel who in 1945 started serving her ice cream out of her husbands gas station in Youngstown, Ohio. In two publications Handel's has been crowned the  "best ice cream in the world!!" They were #1 in National Geographic's 10 Best of Everything list! What an honor! 

The ice cream is made on site daily and they use fresh ingredients. The banana cream pie, cherry vanilla and the buckeye ice cream flavors sound like good choices on the next trip! They also have root beer floats and they sell ice cream pies that look so pretty and delicious! Mint chocolate chip, Reese's, and Oreo's are a few of the options. This is a great place to go enjoy a nice treat on a hot day!

Tea Cottage is the main competition for Tea Bar for bubbletea in Chinatown. It never really struck me as having a great atmosphere to stay and lounge around in, for some reason. I think it's because it's small and looks really basic; tables and chairs, a few Asian posters on the walls, that's it. And they usually serve their drinks in the disposable to-go cups, so might as well take it to go and stroll around the area. I find Tea Cottage to be fresh sometimes, but not all the time. They use a lot of flavoured powder, but I prefer the real thing, like fresh fruit. All in all, Tea Cottage is okay and I'd go there if my friends suggested it, but my top choice for bubbletea is always Dream Tea on the south side of town.

Bubble tea is as delicious as it is addictive, and there is no better place to sample its sweet taste than at The Tea Cottage.  The no-frills, non-descript interior of wooden chairs and tables are accented by the crates of fresh fruits and boxes of syrup bottles that line the walls.  Behind the counter there are usually two server working furiously to keep up with the demand and lineups.

But what exactly is "bubble tea" you ask?  Don't let the name fool you.  Many of the drinks don't even have tea in them.  The "bubble" part refers to the spaces in the wide straw between the soft balls of tapioca that one slurps up in the process of drinking.  The tapioca is referred to by the Asian name "Sago" and are chewy, golden-brown balls made from the starch of sweet potatoes.  They also look like bubbles, which is an alternate explanation for the drink's name. For people who dislike the texture, the drinks can be made without sago but it's worth trying - the sago is essentially flavourless and a lot of fun to chew!

The drinks themselves have a syrup or fresh fruit base, mixed with milk, juice, or tea.  They are 32 ounces and shaken in a plastic cup, over which a colourful thin plastic cover is attached.  When the drink is ready, the customer stabs the very wide straw through the cover, and enjoys pure taste pleasure.

Syrup-based drinks are very sweet and available in a variety of fruit flavours.  There are also coffee varieties, from plain coffee to mocha, to coffee with almond.  By far the most popular drinks are the ones with fresh fruit.  Mixed with ice, fruit, syrup, and the milk, juice, or tea base, the creation is essentially a smoothie with a sweet kick.   Some of the varieties include strawberry, cantaloupe, and avocado.  Yes, avocado is a fruit, and it makes a very tasty smoothie - a nutty flavour with just a hint of sweetness.

Since bubble tea originated in Taiwan, there are also a lot of uniquely Asian flavours to try, such as the gritty and vanilla-like taro root and lychee.  You can find all of this and more at the Tea Cottage, as well as a variety of hot coffee and tea drinks.  So get adventurous, and you might just find yourself going back for more.
Nice middle eastern market on Busch Blvd. excellent customer service and has everything you're looking for to fill up your middle eastern kitchen! God bless!

You can come to sultan to get any of your middle eastern products which is wonderful. They have a variety of items there, customer service is outstanding. I went probably 2-3 times and it was really nice to see how great the staff were. I highly recommend it and will definitely return soon to get more items

First off, it's a very nice market but not really as large as it seems in the photos on Yelp here: from these photos I rather expected a massive supermarket but it's rather small. Still, they carry a great array of Middle Eastern goods and the staff are very friendly and helpful. They have the Greenland Foods line of spices where in my experience is about the best you'll find in the United States prepackaged. They also have a good selection of teas, olives, olive oils, and dairy products plus some vegetables. The kindness of the staff however is what really makes this market stand out among the many in this part of town.
Very Informative, took us to haunted places (that we were planning to see anyways) and gave us funfilled stories behind each place. Kept us listening all night!

Amidst the slew of tours in this great 'haunting' city, we settled on the help of the great reviews of prior Yelpers. 

Our guide was super enthusiastic, which I believe is required for any good tour guides, and was super knowledgeable about the tour in general. It wasn't a super long tour, but there were many great stories and a break in the middle where a bar was nearby for refreshments. 

Definitely enjoyable! And do go and get one of their spots for readings. It was incredible to say the least!

Don't forget to tip the guide!
